column2: Today is the groundhog's day, and a more unlikely candidate for a weather prophet's mantle would be hard to find. The groundhog, or woodchuck, would be hard to find for any purpose today, in fact, since the typical woodchuck hibernates in November and stays in a comatose sleep till March at the earliest. The animal actually knows less about winter than a deer mouse or a cottontail rabbit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Speaking as one who once floundered about in the Congressional spend-and-tax maze, former Treasury Secretary Joseph W. Barr has offered Congress a blueprint for tightening its "control over the purse strings."

BATH, Me., Feb. 1 -- The guided missile destroyer Rommel, the third of three built for the West German Navy at the Bath Ironworks under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, slid into the Kennebec River here today.
Denny McLain will be at the keyboard and in the winner's circle tonight when New York's baseball writers hold their 46th annual dinner and show at the Americana.

ALEXANDRIA, Va. -- A handsome, red-brick structure that served as the boyhood home of Robert E. Lee, and which is believed to be the last house in which George Washington dined as a guest, is becoming a leading tourist attraction here.
VIENNA, Jan. 31 -- After 20 years of existence, Comecon, the Soviet-bloc Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, finds itself at a crossroads and bogged down in controversies and disagreements.

A worker whose union went on strike Friday was arrested early yesterday at Aqueduct Race Track by the police and Federal tax agents who said he was trying to blast a storage building with two "dynamite" sticks containing talcum powder.

SINCE 1809, rights of the citizens of Sweden have been protected by an ombudsman, a concept now gaining more and more acceptance in this country. That protection is now being extended to visitors to Goteborg, Sweden, where a tourist ombudsman has been appointed.

STATESBORO, Ga., Jan. 26 -- The soft late afternoon sunlight filtered down through tall, long-leaf pines, frogs peeped gently in a nearby swamp, we had a good bag of quail and all seemed well with the world.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Royals, trailing by 18 points in the second quarter, roared back in the second half tonight and defeated the Seattle Supersonics, 111-96, in a National Basketball Association game. The victory ended a five-game losing streak at home.
Homes that have hot water or steam heat can now be equipped with the same type of permanent installed automatic humidifying device that those with hot air heating systems often have.

Fifty years ago, a chance survivor of the Zapatista Guerilla wrote on a wall in Cuernavaca, the ruined capital of the Mexican state of Morelos, the phrase that was to hearten ruined Madrid 20 years later: "It is better to die on your feet than to live on your knees."
OPORTO, Portugal, Feb. l -- In the country's first mass Opposition rally in more than a decade, Portuguese democrats demanded last night that the regime permit genuine steps toward liberalization.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- P. K. Wrigley, the owner of the Chicago Cubs, said today that the rush to select a new baseball commissioner did not seem logical and he would not attend the major league owners' meeting in Miami Tuesday.

SANDERSVILLE, Ga., Feb. 1 (AP) -- A Superior Court judge has denied a writ of habeas corpus that would have freed from juvenile authorities a 14-year-old Negro girl whose arrest touched off widespread racial unrest in Worth County.
More than semantics was involved in the disturbing difference of emphasis between President Nixon and Defense Secretary Laird in their press conference discussions of the arms race last week.
A group of politicians and housing officials walked up a newly poured front walk on Locust Street one recent Sunday afternoon and went through the front door of a demonstration house.

When Alastair Horne reviewed William Manchester's "The Arms of Krupp" (Nov. 24), it is indeed regrettable that he did not have available the source material upon which Manchester based his book. As a result, he has written what appears to me to be an unjustified and unwarranted criticism of the book and of its author's motives.
WASHINGTON -- "I suppose," President Nixon mused last week, "that the nation wonders what a President does in his first week and where is all the action that we've talked about?"

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 1 -Calling for "mutual trust and cooperation" President Mohammed Ayub Khan told the nation tonight that he was ready to discuss changes in the Constitution with responsible leaders of the opposition that has been pressing for a restoration of full democracy.
A 53-year-old rule based on the idea that dancing and sports are not too good for young ladies may be repealed soon so that public high schools girls here can compete in inter-school sports contests.
By airmail from Johannesburg, South Africa, the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has received a $50 contribution, as the 57th annual appeal continues to collect money for the city's unfortunates.
The National Sporting Goods Association's 40th convention and sporting goods trade show, will run from today through Thursday at the Houston Astrohall.

THE action of radio station WBAI-FM in putting its microphone at the disposal of persons making extreme anti-Semitic remarks underscores the point that freedom of speech carries an accompanying responsibility for common sense and restraint. It is not too much to ask of a station that it be mature enough to report news and controversy with vigor and still avoid needless acerbation of racial tensions; it can be done, and WBAI should grow up.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- Samuel Eliot Morison talks about the finer details of American history as casually as most people rattle on about what's happening in contemporary Washington, and he was at it again yesterday at a cocktail party in his honor.
The Inter-American Press Association has protested to the Brazilian military regime over new arrests of newspaper executives and the continued suppression of freedom of information.

WASHINGTON -- The recurring search for a new China policy in this country, said a retired diplomat, resembles nothing so much as the sleuth who labors to find the key to a closed door, then discovers that the door has no keyhole.
While I agree that the United Nations should investigate reported mistreatment of Jews in Arab countries, I think The Times Jan. 29 editorial condemnation of Iraq was overly bitter.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. l -- The number of traffic tickets being issued on Long Island parkways is twice that of a year ago and the number of accidents has fallen, but the policemen who started giving the extra tickets as part of a campaign to obtain a raise still have not received any pay increase.

The five short stories that comprise Roland Starke's "Something Soft" are the work of a talent that is none the less convincing for being somewhat conventional. The observation is crisp, the dialogue accurate, the writing controlled and the stories neatly shaped.

Much modern theology is haunted by fears of irrelevance. What if it just doesn't say anything that could possibly make any difference? In some quarters, such fear turns into virtual panic, which explains why so many books are written to prove that theology is the hidden content of everything from soup to "Peanuts."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Government employes' retirement system is badly out of balance because Congress has neglected to appropriate the employer's full share.
MADRID -- the past decade, the entrenched and arbitrary dictatorship of General Franco had begun to show some signs of liberalization.

THE other night at the Boston Garden, a frozen rubber puck ricocheted so violently off the rink's sideboards that a typical, improvised play developed before most spectators realized what was happening. The Montreal Canadien's three man offensive line glided at about 25 miles an hour toward the Boston Bruin's end of the rink.
WASHINGTON -- In a campaign statement on September 10, candidate Richard M. Nixon declared that the "time is long past for the wringing of hands" about the tragedy of starvation facing Biafra.
The attack on the Beirut airport has occasionally been cited as an application (somewhat exaggerated) of the Biblical rule of "an eye for an eye."

In the dissolute, ungirdled, tradition-busting twenties, there came a time (as lawyers like to say) when, in the city room of The New York Times, a manuscript was passed from hand to hand. It was read, an alumnus recalls, "with raised eyebrows." This was the city room, note, not the offices of the editorial page, or even the Book Review.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- Edward J. Logue, chief executive officer of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, asserted this week that unless "drastically new approaches are taken, we are going to be talking about the urban problem four years from now."

THE Stamp and Coin Division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York expects to triple its donation to the 1969 drive through its unrestricted public auction to be held on Feb. 19. This prediction is based on the enthusiastic response of coin dealers and collectors of this city, considered the "Coin Capital of the World," since plans for the sale were announced several weeks ago.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 1 -- The Palestinian National Council, conceived as a parliament of the Palestinian people, met in Cairo tonight with 23 of its 105 members absent, according to reports received here.
A newly married Chicago woman went to Dr. Henry L. Nadler with a haunting question:

An unemployed auto mechanic was arrested by Nasssu County police yesterday in Manhattan on charges of strangling a 14-year-old boy, probably in Manhattan, and dumping the body from a car on the shoulder of the Long Island Expressway last summer.
A guard at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was thrown to the floor and cut on the hand yesterday by a vandal he found scrawling an obscenity on a wall.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 1 -- Independence Square is empty now but its approaches are still flecked with crumpled cigarette packs and flattened bits of rubbish. It is the litter left by a big, lively crowd similar to what remains after a band concert in Central Park.

LEO DUROCHER has always bristled at even the slightest failure but the Dandy Little Manager has been inordinately pleased by the total collapse of one of his projects. For three years the virtually peerless leader of the Chicago Cubs has made an effort to replace Ernie Banks as his first baseman on the presumption that Ernie is in the twilight of his career.

When it sprang to life a few weeks ago after disclosures of theft and managerial chaos in the city's Human Resources Administration, the Congressional task force seemed to have one primary aim. It was going to investigate the superagency's handling of antipoverty funds with the intent of revealing, to the last scandalous penny if possible, just how much was stolen.

Regarding the letters (Jan. 5, 12) about Sue Kaufman's "Memoirs of a Vassar Girl," Dec. 22: Vassar '67 was different from '47 -- although I thought it was understandable that the college's stunted sexual and intellectual development had been edited to assure peaceful Christmas weekend reading.
Walter Simon's family never used to need a calendar to know when it was September. When Walter packed his bags and left for the New York Knickerbocker training camp, that was September.

The medical care and feeding of the American tourist in preparation for his trip abroad and in tile odd corners of the world is a highly debatable subject. Every well-traveled tourist has his own ideas for a traveling medicine kit, and few doctors agree on just what preventive inoculations and immunizations to give in advance.

Tom Cornell's account of his experiences in the Danbury Correctional Institution as the price he paid for burning his draft card is quite moving ("From Protest to Resistance to Jail -- A Draft Resister's Story," Jan. 19).

As World War II ended, Averell Harriman, the American Ambassador to the Soviet Union, recommended that Foreign Service Officers with special knowledge of the Soviet Union be assigned to strategic places around the world in order to keep a suspicious eye on Russian behavior.

THE experimental rules concerning pinch-hitters, announced by the Baseball Rules Committee Friday for use by four minor leagues during the 1969 season, opened up a treasure trove of speculation for every level of fan.
Decisions, decisions, decisions. As the nine-day National Boat Show entered its final weekend at the Coliseum yesterday, the decision-makers were running aground again on familiar complaints:
A national advisory committee of authorities on aviation and aerospace announced Wednesday the first an annual series of seminars designed to acquaint teen-agers with all phases of the air industry.
TWO of the most popular courses by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden are scheduled for this month. Flower Painting taught by Miss Eva Meladay, an eight-session course, will be offered in three sections.

Spurred by a second-half scoring burst by Jim McMillian, Columbia posted its 15th victory in 16 starts last night, downing Yale, 69-48, at University Gymnasium. It was the 22d consecutive victory for the Lions on their home court and raised their Ivy League won-lost record to 6-0.

HONG KONG -- Communist China publicity machine focused anew on Mao Tse-tung last week by reporting in fulsome terms an appearance he made in Peking before 40,000 activists of his great proletarian "Cultural Revolution."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) A leader of a newly formed "Black Workers Alliance" said today the group would try to win Negroes away from labor unions that were not living up to their promise of racial equality.
The Greeks, who have always had a word for it, have added a new one to the shipping vocabulary -- the mini bulk carrier.
A barren West Side playground crowded between the brick walls of two high buildings has been redesigned as a place to channel, rather than challenge, the aggressiveness of neighborhood youngsters.

WITH land values (and tax assessments) soaring how many property owners can afford to keep their acres off the market? They may believe deeply in conservation goals and yet wonder how much longer they can hold out against development. Individuals are not alone in facing this dilemma.

THE notion is getting abroad that stringent fiscal and monetary policies are finally beginning to bite into economic activity and to nip off inflationary excesses, even though there is still scant evidence to prove that this is actually happening.

Activity continued to be good at the retail level last week on sales of pants for women, and the volume was reflected in orders to resident buying offices here. Following are reports on individual departments.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1 -- Meeting in a secret session here today, the University of California Regents named Dr. Philip R. Lee, an ardent advocate of Medicare, as chancellor of the university's medical center in San Francisco.
Norman Redlich, professor of law at New York University and director of its Project on Urban Affairs and Poverty Law, was appointed to the city Board of Education yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Mike Mansfield, Democratic Leader of the Senate, urged the Nixon Administration today to send representatives to meet with Fidel Castro's Cuban regime to seek ways of stopping plane hijackings.

The numerous battlefield parks and historic sites under the care of the Department of the Interior are visible reminders of dramatic moments in our nation's past. John Clagett has visited several of the best known of these and retold, in chronological order, the events they commemorate.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 1.-Defense Minister Allen Fairhall said yesterday that in the future Australia would not place large armaments orders with any country unless that country agreed to spend an equal amount of foreign exchange on Australian-made arms.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- An executive order this week by Acting Gov. Francis W. Sargent cutting back Medicaid payments by $35-million was seen as a first bold step in untangling the skein of welfare in Massachusetts.
The owner of the House of Venus beauty parlor, in Brooklyn, and one of her hairdressers routed two robbers by throwing lye in their faces, blinding one of the men, the police reported yesterday.

When economists talk about how inflation erodes the value of the dollar, it may be difficult for the average person to grasp the meaning. But when a man has to pay perhaps $10 more for the same type of suit he bought last year or a woman finds her boy's shirts costing about 50 cents more than she paid 12 months earlier, inflation becomes a real rather than an abstract problem to them.
Thirsty horseplayers at this year's Kentucky Derby won't have to drink their mint juleps out of paper cups. But they will get no history with their ounce and a half of bourbon.

Several hundred West Villagers crowded into a theater workshop the other night to view an architectural plan that could turn part of their neighborhood into a testing ground for a new theory of urban housing.

The precision of Nicholas Mosley's highly figurative writing has the odd effect of creating, not an explicitness of statement, but an augmented elusiveness. Small gestures, looks, ways of talking and moving or maintaining silence are particularized, while the larger actions that enclose them move in widening circles from opacity to enigma.
City Controller Mario A. Procaccino criticized the Lindsay administration's fiscal policies last night and blamed the Mayod "for the fact that our credit rating is down."

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- A committee of liberals, including some prominent Democrats, has endorsed two independent liberals to seek to defeat the regular Democratic organization candidates in special aldermanic elections here March 11.

WASHINGTON -- It is no doubt true that Robert Finch, the new H.E.W. Secretary, needs time to make his own review of the cases of five Southern school districts which were scheduled this week to suffer the loss of Federal financial aid for moving too slowly to abolish school segregation.

This weekend house in Vermont, designed by architect Eliot Noyes, is a double-function retreat. Spacious enough to accommodate 100 people for cocktails, it is laid out in such a way that the family feels comfortable on a quiet weekend alone. The interior has a disciplined unity that grows out of a consistent use of natural materials, built-ins and compatible furniture classics.

Tom Cornell really slayed me with his mixed-up combination of Christian-Communist ethics. He finds bitter fault with the guards at Danbury Federal Prison because they looked upon him and other inmates as "bums," rather than seeking the Christ in them. In justification, he mentioned that when working in a Bowery mission he always attempted to see the Christ in the bums who came in for help.
BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- East Germany has begun sketching the outline of a policy in its relations with Western Europe for the nineteen-seventies, according to well-placed informants in East Berlin.
SINCE I last saw "Cabaret" it has not only changed most of its cast, it has even changed its theater, having transferred a month or so ago to the Broadway.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- Automobile sales in the Greater Boston Area held up well in the first full month of winter. The first early autumn enthusiasm for the 1969 models has faded in a seasonal dip, But compared with volume for January, 1967, dealers report sales up 3 to 6 per cent, varying with the make and locality.
The Navy Board of Inquiry in the Pueblo spy ship case raises some interesting questions about how we investigate official blunders in the United States.

SUVA, Viti Levu, Fiji -- The Fiji Islands, once considered a place to be avoided by Pacific travelers because of the fierce reputation of the bushy-haired natives, are now one of the fastest-growing resort areas in the South Seas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -B'nai B'rith today condemned President de Gaulle's embargo of military supplies for Israel but decided against authorizing a boycott of French goods and services among its 500,000 members.
JERUSALEM -- Many Israelis did not have to wait last week for newspaper accounts to learn of the public executions in Baghdad. They heard it live.

MIAMI, Feb. 1 -- Everything came to a head in the two divisions of the Palm Beach Handicap at Hialeah today as Needles Stitch defeated Out The Window in the first half of the stakes and Doon closed with a rush to catch Monitor in the final strides of the second division.

ST. ANTON, Austria, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Karl Schranz and Gertrud Gabl gave the Austrian skiing team a sweep today by winning the men's downhill and the women's special slalom at the Arlberg-Kandahar Alpine meet.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 -- A 12th juror was seated this afternoon to try Clay L. Shaw on a charge of conspiring to assassinate President Kennedy in 1963. But testimony will not begin before sometime next week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- On Jan. 21, the day after President Nixon's inauguration, 700 young men and women volunteered for two years' service abroad in the Peace Corps.

UNITED NATIONS -- The search for a Middle East settlement was renewed here last week in circumstances slightly more encouraging than those prevailing in the past year. Ambassador Gunnar V. Jarring, Secretary General Thant's intermediary in the crisis, began consultations with the permanent representatives of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France in an effort to get their support on proproposals for dealing with the crisis on the basis of the U.N. resolution.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A staff study prepared for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee concludes that the Pueblo affair has once again reyealed serious weaknesses in the whole command and control system for American intelligence gathering operations.

The latest word on Lower Manhattan expressway is that it is going to be poisonous. Well, that is no surprise to a lot of us who have considered the whole idea of a Lower Manhattan expressway poisonous for some time.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Feb. 1 -Rajat Neogy, the young editor of Transition magazine, and Abubakar Mayanja, a spirited and controversial member of Uganda's Parliament, were acquitted today of the sedition charges that the Government had brought against them.

WASHINGTON -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie, who lost the election but obviously won friends in the process, receives 20 to 30 speaking invitations a day. During the months of February and March, as a result of careful but intensive scheduling, he will make 22 appearances around the country.

When the Spaniards got to Mexico they found the Aztecs believed they were living in "the fifth Sun." The Aztecs believed, too, that the sun and moon they were enjoying were created by the heroic sacrifices of two brave men who were transformed into the heavenly bodies by leaping into a great fire.

MANY black artists wish to strengthen black cultural institutions without regard to white opinion and white standards. Why should anyone view this development with alarm? Working within black rural and urban communities will give our writers, directors, producers and actors opportunities to explore the entire range of black experience in depth.

Beneath the West Side Highway, where a ramp leads down from the elevated roadway to Canal Street, there is a warehouse in which the Sanitation Department stores the property of people who have been evicted.

Harassment of union teachers has stopped in Ocean Hill (if not elsewhere), and the police details are down to one or two men per school. Indeed, the worries of the parents about personnel are now concentrated less on union teachers than on the corps of enthusiastic and loyal beginning teachers, some of whom have proved utterly incapable of controlling their classes, even with the help of paraprofessional aides.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 1 -Laotian officials and foreign diplomats here are mildly encouraged by a decision of Moscow's Ambassador to Vientiane to visit the region of Laos controlled by the Communist-led Pathet Lao guerrillas.
WASHINGTON -- "I think over the years, we have not done the things which would have made military service more attractive, simply because we always did have the draft to rely on."
Special programs to speed trials will begin tomorrow in two parts of the City Criminal Court in Brooklyn and the Bronx to relieve critical over-crowding in the city's detention centers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- New safety rules designed to cut the accident rate of the nation's 12,000 "air-taxis" were proposed this week by the Federal Aviation Administration.

BUENOS AIRES -- At souvenir stores in various Latin American capitals, tourists were buying banners last week describing Fidel Castro as a "Hero of the Americas" and phonograph records with such titles as "the Battle Songs of Che [Guevara]."

A gust from a gathering storm sends Peter's very special handwritten invitation to his birthday party sailing down the street with yellow-slickered Peter in pursuit.

The steam locomotive today is strictly for the nostalgia trade. And the clean-exhaust, steam-powered automobile is still only a gleam in the designer's eye.

MEADVILLE, Pa., Feb. 1 -- Twentieth-century engineering skills are slowly winning over a 10-square-mile marshy area in Western Pennsylvania that has defied highway builders since the first wagon road snaked northward from Pittsburgh to Erie.
Councilman Edward L. Sadowsky charged yesterday that the city's Community Planning Boards were "toothless" and urged that their powers be increased.
A $2.5 million plant for Automatic Data Processing, Inc., which specializes in computerized payrolls, has been completed in Clifton, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The American Institute of Architects has announced that William Wilson Wurster of San Francisco, dean emeritus of the College of Architecture of the University of California, has won the institute's gold medal for 1969, its highest honor.

ESCANABA, Mich., Feb. 1 (AP) -- A circuit court jury ordered the General Motors Corporation today to pay a Grosse Pointe Woods, Mich., man $420,000 for injuries received when a 1965 Corvair broke away from a tow truck and crashed into his car.

The decision to turn Mineral King Valley over to private developers exposes the essential fraudulence of the Forest Service's much-vaunted "multiple use policy." Created to protect the nation's forests from exploitation, the Forest Service has gradually evolved into the ally and protector of the private lumber companies. As a public relations maneuver, it has promoted the idea that it is developing the forests for recreation as well as profit, that is, for multiple use.

Daniel M. Madden's story of Jan. 12, "Adieu to France," was very pleasant reading, but somehow gives the impression that Villefranche is a recent discovery by the Sixth Fleet (to whom all best wishes).

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Feb. 1 -- A seventh college to be built on the experimental campus of the University of California at Santa Cruz will be devoted to the problem of "cities and minorities with special attention to Afro-Americans and Mexican Americans."
TRENTON, Feb. 1 -- "It's a pretty sad thing," State Senator John L. White said, "that these state colleges have to borrow from their bookstore accounts just to meet their payrolls."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Reports circulated here today that Vince Lombardi would become general manager and coach of the Washington Redskins' National Football League team.

BERNARD MALAMUD is getting to be a big name in the movies. The film version of his Pulitzer-prize winning "The Fixer" is current at the Sutton and a movie based on his short story "The Angel Levine" will soon go before the cameras in Harlem with Harry Belafonte in the leading role.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- President Nixon is expected to announce early next week some of the key diplomatic appointments that he and Secretary of State William P. Rogers have agreed on, officials said today.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Parchment, Peter Fuller's newest 3-year-old prospect, and Mr. Coincidence won divisions of the $15,000 added Francis Scott Key Stakes at Bowie Race Course today.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 1 -- A conference called by the Bertrand Russell Peace Foundation on the Soviet-led invasion and occupation of Czechoslovakia opened here today with a strong attack by Earl Russell on the "insatiable demands" of the Soviet Union.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A shipbuilding executive says he foresees a resurgence in the fortunes of the ailing American maritime industry under President Nixon's policies.

Andy Heilman of Fargo, N. D., was substituted yesterday for ailing Doyle Baird of Akron, Ohio, as Emile Griffith's opponent in a 10-round middleweight bout tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- By the margin of 12 inches, Roger Dion, a former American Olympic training team member from Lebanon, N. H., today topped 17-year-old Matt Bimonti of Lake Placid for the Mount Beacon Ski Club's President's Trophy.
Cocoa prices as measured by futures contracts have swung high and Wide since last summer. The strength reflects an underlying story of discouraged growers and ever-rising consumption.

MONTREAL, Feb. l -- The Montreal Canadiens poured it on the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game tonight. The upstart Broadway sextet had humbled them the last time they met and the Frenchmen fairly flew at their foes, routing them by the score of 6 to 2.

BOSTON, Feb. l -- Willie Davenport may not be ready for professional football, but amateur track is getting an eyeful of Davenport's speed, jumping ability and confidence. Tonight, for the eighth consecutive time on the current indoor season, Davenport won his specialty, the hurdles.

RICHMOND, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Thomas Koch, the Brazilian lefthander, beat top-seeded Arthur Ashe, 6-4, 6-4, today and advanced with Clark Graebner, seeded No. 2, to the final of the Fidelity Bankers invitation tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- News Item: Secretary of Defense Laird says that spending more money on the Sentinel antiballistic-missile system will strengthen this country's bargaining position in possible arms control negotiations with the Soviet Union.

Negotiations on a new contract continued yesterday between the city and welfare and social serivce unions. The unions will hald o point meeting on the situation tomorrow night. The old contract expired on Dec. 31.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 2 (AP) -- An Iraqi carrying two explosive devices has been arrested at Beirut International Airport, security sources said today. They said that he had documents suggesting that he was en route to Syria.

At the beginning of last week 3,000 coal miners formed the West Virginia Black Lung Association to dramatize the health hazards below the perilous earth. Two days later twelve men were trapped in a coal mine fire. Luckily, all were rescued.

Arthur D. Morse, author of "While Six Million Died" and former executive producer of "C.B.S. Reports," was formally named yesterday as executive director of the International Broadcast Institute. He will move to Rome, where the I.B.I. is opening headquuarters later this month.

TEL AVIV -- A tip from an American food dealer that his gefilte fish was too dark helped an Israeli manufacturer develop a product acceptable to the American market. WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (Reuters) -- A Federal judge ruled today that the Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan would not have to wait in a predominantly Negro jail until 'he was taken to Federal prison to begin serving a one-year sentence or contempt of Congress.

DUBLIN, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Judge Kevin O'Keefe refused today to hand over to the British authorities the Irishman who helped George Blake, a Communist spy, escape from a London prison in October, 1966. The judge held that the crime committed by Sean Bourke was a political offense.

Y., Feb. 3 -- Western diplomatic sources emphasized today that until the differences over the interpretation of the 1967 Security Council resolution governing Middle East peace-making were reconciled, it would be impossible to present the Arabs and Israelis with a common view by the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France.
Philip Kalodner, a Philadelphia lawyer who is a stockholder of the Curtis Publishing Company, filed a suit yesterday in Common Pleas Court in Philadelphia seeking the company's liquidation.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has undertaken an inquiry into the holding of unregistered stocks by mutual funds to determine whether new safeguards should be established for fund investors.

The election of Thomas R. Vaughan as chairman and chief executive officers of the Freeport Sulphur Company was announced yesterday. He succeeds Langbourne M. Williams who retired but will continue as chairman of the executive committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Nixon Administration is deferring its decision about starting missile disarmament talks with the Soviet Union until the results are in on two forthcoming tests of the domestic and international political climate.
The controversial plan to build a $140-million bridge across Long Island Sound between Rye and Oyster Bay was ruled unconstitutional yesterday.

In an effort to speed settlement of the 45-day-old longshoremen's strike, Labor Secretary George P. Shultz appointed David L. Cole yesterday to take over-all control of Federal mediation efforts in the dispute.
A Manhattan man was arrested yesterday on charges of bilking the state of $50,000 in unemployment insurance claims by using 17 fictitious names over the last five years.
NOT long ago, Vincent Thomas Lombardi said, "I don't know how long I can stay away after being in coaching for 30 years. We'll see."

The United Federation of Teachers was fined $220,000 yesterday and its president, Albert Shanker, was sentenced to 15 days in jail after being found guilty of criminal contempt of court in the defiance of court orders to end three citywide school strikes last fall.

The so-called limited Sentinel anti-ballistic-missile deployment was authorized by the last Congress (against the advice of most of the Government's scientific advisers) as insurance against an irrational Chinese attack or accidental launching of a limited number of nuclear armed missiles from some other source.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 3 -- Two Arab boys were killed today and 10 were injured when a grenade was thrown into a crowd in Gaza's Falastin Square.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 3 -- The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has raised its sights on a projected ore-handling facility at its Sparrows Point plant and has authorized a $50-million waterfront complex for one of the largest private facilities in the country.

CORONADO, Calif., Feb. 3 -- A Seventh Fleet destroyer was alerted to steam into Wonsan Harbor in North Korea to tow away the Pueblo after the intelligence ship was seized by North Korean gunboats in January, 1968, a former senior naval operations officer in the Pacific Fleet said today.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 3 -- Prime Minister Terence O'Neill tonight called a general election for Northern Ireland to put his leadership -- under attack from within his own ruling Unionist party -- to the test of the ballot box.

The Santa Fe International Corporation has reached an agreement in principle to acquire Global Bulk Transport, Inc., and the States Marine Lines in exchange for Santa Fe stock with a current market value of about $101-million.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 4 (Reuters) -- A Thai gunboat and a Cambodian gunboat opened fire on each other today in a brief engagement over fishing rights in the Gulf of Siam.

Documents recently made public show that the Vatican attack on a controversial cultural center in Cuernavaca, Mexico, was preceded by two unsuccessful attempts by high Catholic officials to force the transfer of its founder, Msgr. Ivan Illich, to a post in New York City.
Railroad and steel stocks forged ahead yesterday as popular market averages showed a mixed pattern in the absence of any dramatic news developments.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A handful of junior Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee teamed with Republicans today to force a change in the committee's rules.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 4 -- Baseball's clubowners, in response to yeseterday's affirmation by the players that they would boycott spring training unless their claim to a share of national television income was acknowledged, unanimously agreed today to stand firm.
The city has developed plans to build a short take-off and landing airport within three years along the Hudson River between 26th and 33d Streets.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- Robert H. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that he opposed "freedom of choice" plans that perpetuated school segregation.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Oil from a huge slick fed by a ruptured undersea well reached some Santa Barbara beaches tonight even as offshore drilling was resumed by oil companies under stricter Federal regulations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Governor Rockefeller has agreed in principle to make a series of short fact-finding trips to Latin America for President Nixon.

President Nixon's forthcoming trip to Europe is primarily a symbolic and exploratory mission, no more than that. His limited purpose is merely to reopen diplomatic channels that have been clogged by Vietnam and other misfortunes, rather than to place any grand new strategy before the allies.
PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 4 -- "Persecution by the prosecution," a defense lawyer thundered.

James Oliver Buswell 4th is a name with a ring to it, and if it sounds more like that of the man who pays a symphony orchestra's deficits than of the man who plays the violin with it, then an adjustment must be made in the preconception.
Roy L. Ash said he had come to town -- amid a flurry of rumors about Litton Industries -- to announce two executive promotions and to answer any questions the press might have.

TRENTON, Feb. 4 -- The state today began one investigation into alleged election frauds and another into questionable grand jury practices in Atlantic City, where registered voters are racially catalogued.

LAKEWOOD, Feb. 4 -- A group of prominent Orthodox rabbis appeared in general agreement here today that the white non-Jewish community had played a strong role in fomenting hostility between the Jewish and Negro communities.
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, the nation's largest brokerage concern, disclosed yesterday that it had a decline in profit last year for the first time since 1962, despite rising income.

The Fordham basketball players stopped their happy chattering for a moment last night when a visitor walked into their dressing room. The visitor was Bobby Knight, the energetic young coach of Army, the team that had just been beaten, 52-42, by the Rams.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 3 -- A civil war that started as a short, sharp "police action" and has since dragged through 19 more and more painful months is draining Nigeria of her self-confidence.
DETROIT, Feb. 4 -- The Ford Motor Companys' car sales in January trailed last year by 6 per cent but were high enough to put the industry total well above last year's sales.
NORMAN F. DACEY, a bane of the courts and of the legal profession who took both to task in the best-selling book "How to Avoid Probate," is now leveling his guns at the mutual-fund industry.
BALBOA, C.Z., Feb.4 -- A helpless liner was towed into port here today with her captain an apparent suicide and her 983 passengers counting themselves lucky to have escaped disaster.
An attempt to improve American prisons by subjecting them to professional accreditation will be made by the American Correctional Association with the aid of a Ford Foundation grant.
DETROIT, Feb. 4 -- The General Motors Corporation promoted three executives today, including those in command of its two top car divisions.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 -- The United States Air Force disclosed plans today to give 60 jet fighter-bombers to the South Vietnamese Air Force.

SOME of the smaller ethnic groups in New York City have their own bridge clubs, which combine intellectual effort with social activity. One of the most flourishing of these is the Chinese Bridge Club, which meets in the China Institute, 125 East 65th Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- State corrections officials will begin a series of conferences next week to help plan improvements in the nation's penal system, the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration announced today.

The state's school watchdog committee announced yesterday that it had scheduled a hearing into charges against Leslie R. Campbell, a teacher at Junior High School 271 in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration district in Brooklyn.

TRENTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Transportation Commissioner David J. Goldberg today ordered the maximum weight and speed limits on the Route 87 Brigantine Bridge, over the Absecon Channel between Atlantic City and Brigantine, reduced for safety.

EVENINGS FOR NEW MUSIC, last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, mixed young American composers with two-thirds of the Viennese trinity. Alban Berg's Four Pieces for clarinet and piano (1924) and Anton Webern's Six Songs (1917-21) were the contributions from Vienna.
State mediators will try tomorrow to end the 15-day-old strike by 300 employes of the Union News Company that has closed many newsstands in railroad stations and in several large hotels.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 4--The Torino Talladega, the newest of Ford Motor Company's high performance road cars, was approved for competition today by the Automobile Competition Committee of the United States, beginning with the Daytona 500 at Daytona Beach, Fla., Feb. 23.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- Senate foes of the Sentinel antiballistic missile system urged the Nixon Administration today to postpone its construction pending a thorough review of cost, safety and diplomatic factors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Susquehanna Corporation was accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission staff today of making false and misleading statements in connection with its tender offer for stock of the Pan American Sulphur Company.
The American Stock Exchange took forceful action against speculation yesterday by temporarily banning its members and member organizations from trading in 103 stock issues for their own accounts.
The National Theater of the Deaf will start its first Broadway engagement Feb. 24 at the Longacre Theater.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Senator Hugh Scott, the assistant Republican leader in the Senate, predicted today that the income tax surcharge would be continued by Congress for the fiscal year beginning in July and then would be reduced from 10 to 5 per cent for the following year.

The announced closing of four more Brooklyn piers at Bush Terminal was deplored yesterday by Frederick W. Richmond, chairman of the Brooklyn Citizens Parks Council and a member of the City Commission on Human. Rights.

The New York Knickerbockers may soon begin to bore their currently enraptured fans. Their same old formula has produced six victories in a row, 23 in their last 27 games and 17 straight at Madison Square Garden, the latest a 122-97 rout of the Atlanta Hawks last night before a Garden crowd of 18,437.

KADENA, Okinawa, Feb. 4 -- Despite the forebodings of American, Japanese and Okinawan authorities, a massive demonstration in driving rain in front of the huge American airfield here today ended without a threatened invasion of the base by extremist students.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Nixon's Task Force on Education has recommended that the Government spend $1-billion a year more to aid schools in big-city slums, Alan Pifer, head of the group, said tonight. WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee staff has obtained information suggesting that the Army, under the guise of a bird study by the Smithsonian Institution, is looking for a remote Pacific site to conduct experiments in chemical-biological warfare.
ROME, Wednesday, Feb. 5 -- Millions of Italian workers began a work stoppage of 2 to 24 hours today in a general strike for higher pension.
Hijackings of trucks in the New York area have increased to an average of 10 a week at a cost of more than $300,000 a day, New York truckers said yesterday.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 4 (UPI) -- The half-billion-dollar XB-70, the largest aircraft ever to fly at three times the speed of sound, became just another museum piece today, never having realized the future envisioned for it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association asserted today that Federal guidelines prohibiting placement of help-wanted advertisements under separate male and female headings did not have the force of law.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday although they closed above the day's lows. Sentiment was influenced by fears of further credit restrictions and prospects of a slowdown in industrial investment.

Buster Mathis injured his right foot in his winning effort against George Chuvalo in Madison Square Garden Monday night and may not be able to keep his appointment for a scheduled heavyweight bout with Jerry Quarry.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 4 -- Foreign Minister Abba Eban said tonight that the most recent proposals on the Middle East by President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic were "a plan for liquidating Israel in two stages."

The American Can Company lifted earnings in 1968 to a record for the fourth straight year, reflecting a 7.3 per cent increase in sales. Earnings in the final quarter, however, declined, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay's Commissioner-designate of Consumer Affairs visited City Hall yesterday and was paid all the honors appropriate to a Miss America.

The Federal Reserve System has been putting informal pressure on the nation's major banks to head off another increase in the prime rate, the minimum interest rate on bank loans to business, a leading banker said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A new, dual-purpose weapons system now being developed by the Air Force may revolutionize strategic bombing and bring big new bombers back into the good graces of top defense officials, Pentagon sources said.

PRAGUE, Feb. 4 -- The Czechslovak Communist leadership announced today determination to re-exert party control over defiant youth movements and trade unions leading a campaign to prevent concessions to the Soviet occupation authorities.

The collision course of life and its untidy ways with art and its immemorial traditions has produced a turbulence in the performing disciplines in all fields. In dance, the merger has produced choreographers like Meredith Monk, who appeared with her company at the Billy Rose Theater last night.

Seven contractors, their companies and two other corporations pleaded guilty yesterday to rigging bids on millions of dollars' worth of contracts to do trenching and paving work for the Consolidated Edison Company in Westchester County.

RICHMOND, Calif., Feb. 4 -The 300,000-member California Teachers Association has blacklisted the Richmond Unified School District for what they called failure to provide adequate financing for its schools.

New York waterfront employers have decided to throw out a contract they negotiated with the International Longshoremen's Association three weeks ago unless the 22,000 dockers in the port get back to work soon.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- A preview of the bitter controversy expected on the issue of school decentralization when it comes before the Legislature took place in the Senate today.

Dick Fosbury, the Olympic high jump champion, and Ron Freeman, a member of the United States's gold medal 1,600-meter relay team, have withdrawn from Friday's track and field meet in Madison Square Garden. Illness was the cause in each case.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 -- Sirhan Bishara Sirhan, erect and neat in a gray suit and blue :buttondown shirt, took the wtthess stand today for the first time in his trial for the murder of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.
" I may never get to see him," Miss Joan Kahn, mystery editor of Harper Row, said yesterday about one of her writers whom she admires. "He sounds like a very nice man."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 -- Vietcong terrorism increased nearly 30 per cent in South Vietnam last month, allied officials reported this evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Congress handed itself a 41 per cent pay rise today -- along with significant increases for the Cabinet and Federal judges -- despite cries of critics that there should be moderation in wage-price gains.

Dr. Thomas A. Bartlett, 38-year-old president of the American University in Cairo, has been appointed president of Colgate University and will return to the United States to assume his new post after American University's commencement in Cairo June 8.

The appointment of Dr. James E. Allen Jr. as United States Commissioner of Education gives assurance that the Federal voice in matters of school and race will remain liberal and independent. There had been mounting fear that pressures from conservative educators might result in the selection of an establishment figure, intent on reducing the Federal role and pacifying the Southern state education departments.
Ten men were indicted for murder yesterday as a result of robbery attempts during which two Bronx jewelry store owners were shot and killed late last year.

Speculative favorites on the American Stock Exchange took a beating yesterday in the wake of the exchange's latest effort to quell excessive speculation. The Amex dis closed late Tuesday that it was temporarily barring its members and member organizations from trading in 103 stock issues for their own accounts.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- The jury in the murder trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan was sworn in today, and the defense and the prosecution immediately began questioning prospective alternate jurors.
" The time is out of joint," Hamlet complains bitterly, implying that jointness is something to be desired.

A plan for a one-day "research stoppage" March 4 to protest Government "misuse" of science and technology has spread from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to two other universities, and the movement appears to be still growing.

The interest rate that commercial banks charge each other on overnight loans of surplus reserves at the Federal Reserve climbed yesterday to a record 7 3/4 per cent -- 2 1/4 percentage points above the discount rate.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 5 -- The military Government and the International Petroleum Company moved a step closer to final confrontation today as the regime's deadline for payment of a $14.4-million bill ran out.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Congressional Joint Economic Committee asked the Federal Reserve Board today to hold up its proposed changes in the "discount mechanism" until there was a chance for "further study" by the banking committees of the House and Senate.
BONN, Feb. 5 -- The West German Bundestag elected Kai-Uwe von Hassel president of the lower house of Parliament today despite opposition.

WILL Albert Corley be able to penetrate the fashion jungle of Seventh Avenue? If he does, it will be a miracle. If he fails, it won't be from a lack of distinguished advisers who don't happen to see eye to eye.
Harold Mabern, a jazz pianist with a full-bodied lyrical style, filled the auditorium for the Countee Cullen Branch of the New York Public Library, 104 West 136th Street, with musical joy last night.
BELLEAIR, Fla., Feb. 5 -- Professional and amateur tennis officials moved toward an agreement today that would preserve, at least temporarily, the lucrative open tennis program in the United States.
MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- The latest Soviet attempt to capitalize on the racial issue in the United States is a stage version of a highly successful 1967 film, "In the Heat of the Night."
One man was stabbed to death with his own knife and three other persons, including a policeman, were injured early yesterday during an argument aboard a Staten Island ferryboat.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- In a move he characterized as "historic," President Nixon announced today that all postmaster and rural letter-carrier appointments would be re moved from the political patronage system. The effect of the announcement is to deprive Congressmen of much -- but perhaps not all -- of their power to appoint postmasters and rural carriers and transfer that authority to the Postmaster General.
Your call for a "general inquiry" into hunger and malnutrition in the United States (editorial Jan. 29) is very important but far less urgent than the need for immediate action.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 5 (UPI) -- A radio relay satellite owned by 64 nations soared into space tonight to cut communications costs by doubling orbital telephone links to the lands of the Pacific.

LISBON, Feb. 5 -- Former Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar of Portugal went home from the hospital today, five months after he underwent surgery for a massive brain hemorrhage which, it was widely believed, would be fatal.

Eight demonstrators overturned furniture, scattered books and ripped out telephones yesterday in the office of a Queens College dean who has been named interim director of the college's program to assist students from poverty areas.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- Still in a slump, Lieut. Arthur Ashe, the United States open tennis champion, was eliminated tonight by Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, a virtual unknown in America, in the opening round of the $30,000 Philadelphia international indoor open tournament before a crowd of 6,261.

The Xerox Corporation has leased about 30,000 square feet of space in the 39-story Tishman Building, 666 Fifth Avenue, between 52d and 53d Streets, and will consolidate various sales and showroom facilities there.

DURING the recent Coral Gables, Fla., annual title tournament, a Swiss System, five players tied for first with 4-1. Among these was Anthony Santasiere, a former New Yorker and many-time champion of the Marshall Chess Club.

Tougher legislation that not only would limit rent increases on uncontrolled apartments to 5 per cent a year but also would roll back "exhorbitant" increases to 1967 levels was filed with the City Council yesterday by Council President Francis X. Smith.
PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 5 -- After deliberating four hours without reaching a verdict, the jury in New Jersey's longest murder trial was sent to bed tonight.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Feb. 5 -- The Green Bay Packers released Vince Lombardi from his contract tonight allowing him to take control of the Washington Redskins of the National Football League.

Walter Winchell, the 72-year-old syndicated columnist who has not written a column since Jan. 11, is taking a vacation "to get his bearings" following the suicide of his only son, a spokesman for the McNaught Syndicate said yesterday that Mr. Winchell was said to be resting somewhere in the West.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits has overhauled his staff for his third term in the Senate.

STANDARD bidding methods are often at some disadvantage in the slam bidding area. On the diagramed deal, for example, an excellent grand slam in hearts or clubs escaped almost all the pairs in a mixed pair game at the Cavendish Club, 23 Central Park South, last week.

MADRID, Feb. 5 -- Foreign Minister Michel Debre of France arrived here tonight to begin a visit that has been politically clouded before its start by the state of emergency imposed in Spain 10 days ago.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb. 5 -- Robert T. Lorimer, general manager of the Auckland Harbor Board, pointed to a large drawing of a $7-million project for waterfront development that will make this city a major port for containerized ships within two years.

New York University's popular "20th-Century Dance" series, now a squatting-room-only event, continued last night at the School of Education auditorium, 35 West Fourth Street, with a program by the Lucas Hoving Dance Company.

Riding the new Metroliner to New York from Washington is both a promising and a sobering experience. It is at once a graphic demonstration that modern America need not be overwhelmed by its problems and a useful reminder that those problems are sizable indeed.
The former Brooklyn Navy Yard, which New York has long wanted, will become the city's property in a yard ceremony at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon.

CORONADO, Calif., Feb. 5 -- Solemnly and unhesitatingly, three key officers of the Pueblo supported today the decision of Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher to surrender the intelligence ship to North Korean warships without a fight.

The Theater Company of Boston is coming to New York to perform James Leo Herlihy's "Stop, You're Killing Me!" in an engagement at Stage 73, 321 East 73d Street, beginning March 12. The company, which is directed by David Wheeler and is generally known as TCB, will be presented here by Dick Duane.

To Ella Winter, returning to the United States for an extended visit after 18 years in Britain, the chief impression is one of "people talking, thinking and acting about what they believe concerns them."
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation got very artsy yesterday, but for a reason.
NORTH BERGEN, N. J., Feb. 5 -- North Bergen Public School teachers voted 240 to 20 today to end the strike they had begun Monday and to return to their classes tomorrow morning.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation cooperated here and in Pittsburgh yesterday to show just how well the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's latest model Picturephone really works.
Mayor Lindsay put on a bright yellow helmet and drove a bulldozer about 30 feet yesterday in ground-breaking ceremonies for the new food center in Hunts Point Market in the Bronx.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5 -- The jury to try Clay L. Shaw on a charge of conspiring to assassinate President Kennedy was completed today.

Leading singers of the Metropolitan Opera will take part in a gala performance at the opera house Feb. 15 to raise money for the company's benevolent and retirement funds. This evening is being arranged by the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

HAVANA, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -- A Colombian Airlines DC-4 landed at the eastern Cuban city of Santiago this evening after it had been hijacked, a spokesman for the Swiss Embassy, which handles Colombian affairs here, said.
TOKYO, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -- The Japanese Government announced today that from March 1 it would allow direct foreign capital investment in a wide range of industries.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Col. Frank Borman, commander of Apollo 8, called on the United States and the Soviet Union today to agree to pursue separate objectives in space with a full and free exchange of information.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 5 -- Songs critical of Britain and the United States were banned on Zanzibar today by Tanzania's First Vice President, Abeid Amani Karume, who said that anyone singing them would get six "hot strokes."

WE have known for decades that Negroes were natural actors; we are now busy discovering that they are also natural playwrights. Black writers are nothing new, but the existence of a developing black theater has provided them with totally new possibilities.
WHEN a bouvier des Flandres named Naris du Posty Arlequin came from Belgium a little over a year ago he didn't understand a word of English. He had always been addressed in French.
Volume remained heavy yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, while prices drifted downward.

The first of Penn Central's silvery six-car Metroliners, which has been running at 80 to 90 per cent of capacity between New York and Washington since Jan. 16, will be joined by a second on Monday, to provide morning and late-afternoon high-speed service in each direction.

The oil pollution disaster in the Santa Barbara Channel (one of the most scenic areas in America) raises the question of who is going to bear the cost of damages to beaches, wildlife, boats, etc. Although the possibility of a leak was raised at last year's hearings on Federal oil leases, the oil companies minimized the likelihood of such an accident, making it appear extremely remote.

The South became a factor in the defense of the America's Cup for the first time yesterday when Charles E. Morgan Jr. of St. Petersburg, Fla., emerged as the backer of a new 12-Meter yacht. She will be a candidate to become the defender against a yacht from Australia, Britain or France, whichever becomes the challenger, next year.

Air traffic congestion and delays at the three principal airports here cut sharply the rate of growth of passenger traffic in the last half of 1968, Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, announced yesterday.

Mrs. Santa Rein, whose mentally handicapped 7-year-old son, Gregg, has had to miss sreveal days in school because of a strike by drivers for the City-Wide Transportation Company, was bitter yesterday.
A historic Lower East Side church that has been burglarized repeatedly in the past year was broken into again early yesterday morning.
American industry as a whole in 1968 overcame the twin handicaps of inflationary pressures and the 10 per cent tax surcharge by establishing a new record in corporate profits last year.

ROME, Feb. 5 -- Italian labor unions, acting in rare harmony, staged a one-day general strike today for better pensions. Many major industries were shut down. Major ports lay idle. Not a single major newspaper or live television program appeared.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Nixon Administration will follow the lead of its predecessor and seek tighter fiscal control and improved programing for New York's antipoverty agency, city officials were told today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 5 (UPI) The American Basketball Association will experiment with a number of new playing rules, including use of the zone defense, in the last two months of the 1968-69 season, George L. Mikan, the A.B.A. commissioner, announced today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5 -- In a 24-hour period of light combat activity, 36 enemy soldiers were killed in two engagements, Allied military communiques said. There were no United States casualties.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 -- The court-martial of two young soldiers charged with mutiny was suddenly recessed today to permit time for a sanity inquiry.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Nixon asked the Senate today to proceed promptly with approval of the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Hyman Bookbinder, an influential member of the Johnson Administration, said tonight there had been "further deterioration" of white and Negro relations since the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders warned against a polarized society almost a year ago.

A real-estate entrepreneur and owner of eight Miami Beach hotels, his two sons and a lawyer were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to violate the Commodity Exchange Act by excessive trading in Maine potato futures.

The Star of India, the De Long star ruby and the Midnight Star, the jewels that were stolen from the American Museum of Natural History four years ago, went on exhibition again yesterday as the museum reopened the Morgan Memorial Hall of Minerals and Gems.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A Department of State official testified today that the United States planned a new diplomatic move on Monday in efforts to stem the flow of hijacked airliners to Cuba.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan today proclaimed "a state of extreme emergency" on the University of California campus at Berkeley and the surrounding area.
A dapper, dark-complexioned youth of 19 who assertedly said he was R. Hartford Duke and related to Huntington Hartford and Doris Duke, was arrested yesterday on charges of grand larceny and forgery.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Dr. James E. Allen Jr., President's Nixon's choice as the next United States Commissioner of Education, said today that he hoped to design a program of "massive" Federal aid to urban education.

President Nixon's call for Senate ratification of the treaty to check the spread of nuclear weapons is important both in itself and as a step toward his goal of "negotiation rather than confrontation."

The trouble with most available books about Tibet is that they have been written by foreigners. BUFFALO, Feb. 5 -- A Federal judge approved today the United States Justice Department's request to intervene in a suit by the Catholic Diocese of Buffalo accusing the City of Lackawanna of racial discrimination.

Buster Mathis, the heavyweight from Grand Rapids, Mich., and Jerry Quarry of Los Angeles, signed yesterday to meet in a 12-round elimination bout on Monday, March 24, at Madison Square Garden. The winner is expected to be matched with Joe Frazier, the recognized world champion in five states, at the Garden in May or June.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 5 -- Goronwy Roberts, the British Minister of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs, indicated today there was a large degree of acceptance in the Arab world for a proposed Big Four solution of the Middle East problem.

CARL MARASCO is a 32-year-old insurance adjuster with a family of five children and a hobby -- pro football's draft. Marasco keeps track of 1,000 college players who are candidates each year for drafting by the 26 pro teams. His expenses amount to $25 annually. The pro teams spend a lot more than that.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Nixon ordered today an immediate increase of $10-million in the expenditures ceiling placed last year on the National Science foundation.

WASHINGTON, Feb 5 (UPI) -- A group of young lobbyists was told today that they would have to "overcome the stereotype image of militant demonstrators and beatniks" before they could persuade Congress to lower the voting age.

How successful Dr. Allen will be in translating his beliefs into action in Washington depends largely on the Administration's willingness to give him the tools and authority to do the job. During the campaign President Nixon expressed views of considerable ambiguity on the Federal role in financing education and enforcing the desegregation guidelines. These views have left a residue of much disquiet in educational circles.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Federal Communications Commission moved today to bar cigarette advertising from television and radio.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 5 (UPI) -- Gene Littler, Marty Fleckman, Lee Trevino and Tom Shaw shot five-under-par 67's to share the first-round lead today in the $100,000 Bob Hope Desert Classic golf tournament.

In your Jan. 24 editorial on the Hatfield bill you have perhaps inadvertently misinterpreted the proposed legislation. The bill does not "abolish military conscription altogether," as you assert, but provides only for the end of inductions into the armed forces.
DETROIT, Feb. 5 -- The American Motors Corporation, the smallest of the Big Four auto makers, made several disclosures concerning its operations at the company's annual meeting here today:

THE drama entitled "Teacher, Teacher," reiterated last night a point that hardly can be stressed too often. The problems of the retarded child lies less in his own handicaps than in the attitudes of the normal adults around him. By way of giving added emphasis to that eminently sensible contention, the taped production of the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" used a retarded child, Billy Schulman of Woodbury, L.I., to play the key role of Freddie.

MIAMI, Feb. 5 -- Eddie Neloy drew a blank in both divisions of the Bahamas Stakes at Hialeah today, but he had considerable consolation in the performances of Beau Brummel and King of the Castle, the stable's best bets for the Kentucky Derby.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 5 -- More than 1,000 Jehovah's Witnesses are reported to be homeless and hundreds of others to have fled into the Congo or into the bush following a purge of the religious sect last month in Zambia's remote, northerly Luapula Province.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its subsidiaries earned $2,112,000,000 in 1968. This was more than any company had ever earned in any single year except for the $2,126,000,000 reported in 1965 by the General Motors Corporation.

Three members of a group of West Side clergymen who have organized a cooperative council to tackle neighborhood problems declared yesterday that rising racial and religious tensions called for a similar city-wide effort with help from Mayor Lindsay.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The United States proposed to France, Britain and the Soviet Union today that preliminary talks be held at the United Nations promptly to investigate the possibility of a Middle East settlement.
GIMBELS decided to look in its own backyard for a theme for its annual mid-winter "exposition," as the store calls it, and came up with New York.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 5 -- The single wing will undoubtedly endure at Princeton University and so will the throb in Jake McCandless's voice when he talks about his alma mater. But other aspects of life are changing and the 39-year-old coach seems willing to acknowledge it.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The State Education Commissioner said today that he had no power to block tomorrow's voter referendum in Great Neck, L. I., on a schoot board proposal for an unusual experiment in busing disadvantaged Negro and Puerto Rican children from Queens to the affluent suburban community.

BONN, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -- Economics Minister Karl Schiller of West Germany told a news conference today that the Government's plans for a giant combine of West Germany's eight domestic oil companies would not entail a complete merger of the companies immediately.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 5 -- The Iraqi Government today released Paul T. Bail, a United States citizen who had been under arrest in Baghdad for more than a month.
A prominent film director and producer said yesterday that he had "borrowed new techniques" from film made recently by college and university students.
Quiet trading marked most commodity futures yesterday. Only one significant price change was worth noting -- a decline by the daily limit for silver futures.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 5 -- On the last afternoon of her campaign, Mrs. Hamida Habibullah did some hut-to-hut canvassing in her constituency near Luck-now.
The police began a crackdown on drunks, homosexuals, loiterers and other undesirables in the Times Square area last night, although the cold weather apparently kept many of them away.
A city policeman was arrested and suspended yesterday following a joint investigation of an auto theft ring by the Queens District Attorney, the Nassau County police and the city police.
The Anaconda Company reported yesterday a drop in earnings for 1968 but an increase for fourth-quarter profits.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Requests of Government agencies were cut by $28-billion in the process of making up President Johnson's budget, it was disclosed today.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 5 -- Prime Minister Terence O'Neill said today that unless he obtained a clear mandate in the Feb. 24 general election he would resign.

VIENNA, Feb. 5 -- Intense diplomatic activity in Eastern Europe this week appeared to be related to efforts to smooth the after effects of the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia last August and to face the mounting problems before the Communist regimes.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- The United States is expected to renew tomorrow its proposal of discussions aimed at reducing the level of violence in Vietnam at the third plenary meeting of the broadened peace talks here tomorrow.
The Board of Trustees of Harlem Preparatory School elected a new chairman yesterday along with a student and five parents who will be board members.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Prominent politicians, former Assemblymen and a few relatives of legislators have found jobs on the payroll of the 1969 Legislature.

The new French Consul General in New York, Jean Beliard, has enough "constituents" -- about 35,000 -- to make him feel like the mayor of a small town.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Republican Congressional leaders said today that President Nixon would propose "in the very near future" a tax reform program and a new Presidential electoral system that retains the Electoral College.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 5 -- In the short history of the Pittsburgh Penguins, this date is a memorable one: It marked the first time the home team had defeated the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 5 -- Israeli officials are expressing a quiet confidence that President Nixon's policy on the Mideast will not undermine Israel's basic position.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 5 -- American Jews are threatened by growing Negro anti-Semitism but this will not prevent Jews from supporting the American Negro's struggle for his rights and equality, a sociologist said tonight.

The Nixon Administration and the Congress were urged yesterday to steer United States foreign economic policy back on a liberal course by lifting curbs on investment abroad and opposing import quotas.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The Republican majority in the Legislature successfully waged its first major battle with the Democratic minority today when it pushed through Governor Rockefeller's record deficiency budget of $222-million for the 1968-69 fiscal year.
IN this youth-oriented era, it's no surprise that the sophisticated Sugarbush (Vt.) ski area is about to play host to its second annual mini-Olympics.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Senate Commerce Committee has resolved to keep a close watch on the Nixon Administration's enforcement of consumer protection laws in this year's session of Congress.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- The Adlai Stevenson Institute of International Affairs observed its second anniversary today with a report of robust growth and activity.
A recently formed New York investment banking company announced yesterday that it was considering a tender offer for control of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Major Leagues' Umpires Association has signed a 1969 salary contract, but still unsettled is the dispute over the discharge of two American League umpires, Al Salerno and Bill Valentine.

PRAGUE, Feb. 5 -- Alexander Dubcek promised today to take "resolute steps" against both neo-Stalinist extremists and those who accuse him of capitulating to Soviet occupation authorities.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 5 -- The assassination of Dr. Eduardo Chivambo Mondlane in Dar es Salaam Monday is threatening to split the Mozambique Liberation Front, until now one of the most effective and hardest fighting liberation movements in Africa.

Nor has Hanoi responded to suggestions that it make the first bid. The two sides thus far have merely engaged in desultory sparring about whether military or political issues should be discussed first -- and in what forum.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- A policeman making a routine check at a department store loading platform today found more than $30,000 worth of Russian religious objects that had been stolen last night from the Washington National Cathedral.

BONN, Feb. 5 -- Leaders of West Germany's National Union of Students, which for 20 years has represented the nation's college and university students, today presented plans designed to break up the organization into units that would be more autonomous locally and led by campus radicals.

The Women of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest will hold a luncheon, fashion show and bridge party in the auditorium of the church at 2 East 90th Street on Tuesday. Proceeds will go to the Rector's Discretionary Fund.

THE Museum of Modern Art, which five years ago completed a $25-million enlargement program on its present site, may move to another location. Desperately in need of space, it is also considering the alternative of erecting a high-rise structure to replace the adjacent Theater Guild Building at 23 West 53d Street, which it has owned since 1956.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Staff members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who have been studying the Pueblo seizure for the last year, drew a contrast today between testimony yesterday by Lieut. Edward R. Murphy, the ship's navigator, and a statement a year ago by Secretary of State Dean Rusk.

Mendel Rivers, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, has temporarily blocked further construction of missile defense bases and has called on the Administration to clarify its overall position on the controversial Sentinel antiballistic missile system.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The "only way" to halt disruption of inner city schools is for a majority of the students in the schools to organize and not "let the radicals destroy their schools," according to Mr. Shanker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Leaders of a group that has supported defiance and evasion of the draft as a form of protest against the war in Vietnam said they were given a "very respectful hearing" at the White House today when they pleaded for amnesty for draft resisters.
