At Carnegie Hall last night, Gary Graffman and the Cleveland Orchestra led by George Szell made the old warhorse sound as though it were fashioned of pure gold.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 2 -- A campaign by the United States to ease its balance-of-payments problems has brought American assistance in Bolivia to a virtual standstill.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5 -- The Vietcong have begun directing propaganda written in English to Eastern Europe and throughout the Far East by teletypesetter, American officials said today.

The Mendelssohn Violin Concerto is a standard test for up-and-coming young violinists, and last night at Philharmonic Hall, the famous work didn't faze 20-year-old Pinchas Zukerman one bit. With the help of the New York Philharmonic and its conductor, Leonard Bernstein, the Israeli-born Mr. Zukerman, co-winner of the 1967 Leventritt International Award, tossed off the concert as if it were a nursery rhyme.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Miami Floridians increased their record to the .500 mark tonight for the first time since Dec. 2 with a 111-99 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets.
CAN a Johnny-come-lately on the business scene move in on the Establishment and knock off one of the biggest prizes in sight?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A Democrat out of office is a terrible thing to see. As fish are born to breathe in water, Democrats are born to hold office. Take away their in-baskets, their Federal-issue water carafes and their limousines and tell them it's time to go back to Pocatello, and you have an exceedingly pathetic batch of Democrats on your hands.
The longest waterfront strike in the turbulent history of North Atlantic ports moved through its 47th day yesterday as Congressional leaders warned that it had better end soon "or else."

The Atlantic and Gulf dock strike, begun after expiration of a national emergency injunction signed by President Johnson, is ending its seventh week. Under the Taft-Hartley Act, President Nixon has an obligation to give Congress his recommendations on what must be done to end this crippling tie-up.

HUE, South Vietnam -- The countryside around this old imperial city has a soft, luminous beauty reminiscent of a scene from an ancient Chinese scroll. But for many years it could not be visited safely.

MARCO ISLAND, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Even though a man might, come to this Florida Gulf Coast resort with only fishing in mind -- and the light tackle angling is superb -- it is difficult to avoid what might best be described as Marco Island fever.

The impact of tight money hit home at the man on the street once again yesterday. The New York State Banking Board increased to 7 1/2 per cent the maximum interest rate allowable on home mortgage loans, up a quarter of a point from the ceiling that had prevailed since last summer.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 6 (UPI) -- Rod Funseth, who spent five years in Palm Springs learning his trade, showed he was a good student today by shooting a six-under-par 66 and taking the second-round lead in the rain-delayed $100,000 Bob Hope Desert Classic golf tournament. His total for 36 holes was 135.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 (UPI) -- The six alternate jurors for the murder trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan were still not selected today as the defense and prosecution exercised peremptory challenges.
President Nixon's decision to visit West European capitals later this month, only five weeks after taking office, represents an important diplomatic initiative with broad implications.
A FLORIDA educator has combined his talent as an artist with his knowledge of the laws on gift-boat tax deductions to launch an unusual fund-raising drive.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 6 -- Israeli soldiers battled demonstrators in the west-bank town of Nablus today as protests continued to erupt in the occupied areas.

WILLIAMSTON, N. C., Feb. 6 -- It was here in Martin County a few years ago that one of the largest crosses ever burned by the Ku Klux Klan, a 90-foot masterpiece of plywood and scrap lumber, etched its flaming message of white supremacy into the evening sky.

Five major drug manufacturers offered $120-million yesterday to settle damage claims by states, cities and others growing out of alleged illegal price-fixing and overcharges on tetracycline and other broad-spectrum antibiotics -- so-called wonder drugs.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange plans to begin consideration of disciplinary action against member firms that have not adhered to exchange rules designed to ease the long-standing paperwork problem.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that it was censuring Lehman Brothers, one of the nation's oldest and most prestigious investment banking firms, as well as all 39 of the firm's general partners, for having failed to keep its books and records in order.
New labor agreements announced yesterday will give the city's 28,000 clerical employes and 19,000 hospital aides and technicians salary increases of $1,100 to $1,500 over a 30-month contract.

GRENADA, Miss., Feb. 6 -- A 27-year-old woman lawyer was jailed for three hours here today after being held in contempt of court by Circuit Judge Marshall Perry when she attempted to file a bill of exceptions to a case involving a Negro civil rights worker.

Judge Nicholas Tsoucalas dismissed charges in Criminal Court yesterday against two members of the Black Panther party who had been accused of conspiracy to murder two policemen in an exchange of gunfire in upper Manhattan last month.

WBAI-FM, which has been criticized for having permitted anti-Semitic sentiments to be aired on its programs, called on its critics yesterday to join the station in constructive efforts to solve problems of community unrest and racism.

Track and field returns to town tonight with the Madison Square Garden invitation meet. And Hardee McAlhaney returns to town convinced he can beat Lee Evans in the 500-yard run, one of the meet's few strong races.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6 (AP) -- A widowed grandmother was found bludgeoned to death in this university community today, less than one month after a similar and still unsolved killing about one mile away.
On the London Stock market, prices were mixed in quiet trading.

An old-line steamship enterprise will pass into the hands of a relative newcomer in the field under an agreement announced yesterday by W. R. Grace Co. and corporate interests of the Spyros Skouras family.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Summer programs for poor youths fell far below target last year, according to Government investigators, who gave New York City and Washington some of the worst marks in their report.
PARIS, Feb. 6 -- The chief North Vietnamese delegate at the peace talks, Xuan Thuy, paid a rare compliment to the United States during the round-table session today.
DETROIT, Feb. 6 (UPI) -- Gordie Howe scored his 714th, 715th and 716th regular season goals as the Detroit Red Wings swamped the Chicago Black Hawks, 6-1, tonight.
GREAT NECK, L.I., Feb. 6 -- A proposal to bus disadvantaged children from Queens into the Great Neck School District was facing defeat at the polls tonight on the basis of partial returns.

BELLEAIR, Fla., Feb. 6 -- Dramatic changes in the organization, operation and purpose of the United States Lawn Tennis Association were recommended today by a special committee on long-range financial planning.
QUEBEC, Feb. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Finance Minister Paul Dozois announced today that the Quebec government had "found a solution to save Man and His World this year."

In the world of avant-garde dance no one commands more intense loyalty from her performers than does Yvonne Rainer. One of her cast interrupted a California tour to appear at the Billy Rose theater last night, and another broke a self-enforced retirement to be part of Miss Rainer's new work "Rose Fractions."
Net earnings of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company last year dipped to $150,045,000, or $3.71 a share, on record sales.

World unrest apparently knows no bounds. Even the Four Seasons is becoming a hot bed of revolutionaries -- sort of an East Side Sierra Maestra. On Monday it spawned American Airlines' Second American Revolution.
MARATHON, Fla., Jan. 30 -- Small-craft warnings were flying, but our skipper, John Caperonis of Saratoga Springs, N. Y., said it would be a good day to try for Spanish mackerel in Florida Bay.

"Bezhin Meadow," a 30-minute reconstruction of an uncompleted film that Sergei M. Eisenstein worked on from 1935 to 1937, and a complete version of "Ten Days That Shook the World," the silent feature made by the noted Russian director and first shown here in 1928, are being presented, through Sunday, at the Bleecker Street Cinema, 144 Bleecker Street.

President Nixon has clearly made a very careful and intelligent judgment about what a new chief magistrate must do in the opening days of an American administration. He has found the delicate line between personal control and domination, between being too obscure or too prominent, between evading the paramount issues or defining his position on them too boldly or precisely.
The president of Queens College said yesterday that he was recommending the appointment of a Negro faculty member as interim director of a campus program to assist students from poverty areas.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 (UPI) -- A violent new storm battered Southern California with high winds and heavy rains today, forcing some residents of foothill areas to flee their homes for the second time in two weeks.

TELEVISION'S promised trend to more variety shows evidenced itself last night in "What's It All About, World?," a contribution of Sol Ilson and Ernest Chambers, who were the original producers of the Smothers Brothers show.
CHE GUEVARA died for the Incas; he dreamed of transforming the Andes into "the Sierra Maestra of Latin America." How he so misread that "revolutionary situation" is a mystery yet.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 6 -- District Attorney Jim Garrison said today that he would present documental and eye-witness evidence that President Kennedy's assassination was plotted in New Orleans in the summer of 1963 by Clay L. Shaw and others, including Lee Harvey Oswald and David W. Ferrie.

Rhode Island, a team with a losing record, resorted to a slowdown and other futile tactics last night in its basketball game with fifth-ranked St. John's. The strategy quickly backfired as the Redmen overpowered the Rams, 73-46, at St. John's Alumni Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Nixon will make a nine-day tour of Western Europe, starting Feb. 23, aimed at "strengthening and revitalizing" the North Atlantic community, he said at his news conference today.

MIAMI, Feb. 6 (UPI) -- C. V. Whitney's Watch Fob, making her first start in almost a year and rated a 31-1 shot startled most of the crowd at Hialeah Park today by winning a $7,000 featured allowance race by two lengths.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- House Republicans reacted angrily today to President Nixon's failure to consult them before announcing plans to remove postal appointments from Congressional patronage.

BONN, Feb. 6 -- Shortly before the Christian Democratic Union voted earlier this week on a new president for the lower house of the West German Parliament, the party's chief spokesman was asked about the criteria used in selecting a candidate.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The Public Service Commission today ordered the Penn Central to improve its railroad passenger service in New York State or face court actions and fines.
The Lick Observatory atop Mount Hamilton near San Jose in California has photographed the winking of a pulsar across the vast reaches of space between the earth and the Crab Nebula.

BERLIN, Feb. 6 -- East Germany warned West Germany today that it would "be forced to take measures" against Bonn's plans to hold the election of the new federal President in West Berlin, a city isolated 110 miles inside East Germany.
MOSCOW, Feb. 6 (Reuters) -- A Soviet newspaper, in a review of a new book on Zionism, asserted today that it contained too little information about Zionist intrigues against the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) -- The chairman of the Senate Labor Committee pointedly told nominees for high Labor Department posts today to go slow with plans to reorganize the country's manpower programs or abolish the Job Corps.

The dismissal of Martin S. Ackerman as president and chief executive officer of the Curtis Publishing Company has been called for by the trustees of the Cyrus H. K. Curtis estate, in an effort to "revitalize the company as a going enterprise and to bring about a profitable redeployment of assets."
The credit markets appeared to gain a substantial degree of stability yesterday.
A 19-year-old armed youth was shot and killed inside a bakery truck in Brooklyn yesterday when he allegedly tried to shoot a detective who had interrupted his attempt to hold up the truck's driver.
A-OK was the word for "GO 6," Murray Louis's dance work that was given its New York premiere last night at the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse by the Murray Louis Dance Company.

The same complacency that led to the oil-produced ecologic and economic disaster off Santa Barbara seems to be asserting itself all over again, even while slime befouls the beaches and marine life pays the price of man's rapacity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Nixon demonstrated today that the Navy had not been entirely successful in its efforts to persuade the American public that the court of inquiry into the capture of the Pueblo did not involve the guilt or innocence of the people involved.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Nixon said tonight that he would give "immediate Consideration" to using Federal troops to combat the 400-square-mile oil slick that is menacing southern California harbors and beaches.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 6 -- Oil engineers were poised late today to make a "massive effort" to plug the offshore runaway oil well.

John W. Macy Jr., the new president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, declared yesterday that the primary purpose of public television should be "broadly educational" and that local noncommercial stations should be strengthened and not dominated by a national network.

St. Mark's in the Bowery Church was burglarized for the second time in two days yesterday morning, bringing a warning from its rector that he would be forced to close the historic house of worship unless the wave of thefts and vandalism that was plaguing it came to an end.
PARIS -- Moscow devised its present Middle East policy in 1955 after the Geneva summit conference made plain that no nation was prepared to risk nuclear war, almost regardless of provocation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- President Nixon, who says he favors putting more Federal funds into education, will get a chance to do so if a higher education bill introduced today is passed.

BONN, Feb. 6 -- Semyon K. Tsarapkin, the Soviet Ambassador to West Germany delivered an urgent note from Moscow to Foreign Minister Willy Brandt today concerning the international treaty to bar the spread of nuclear weapons.

In the Middle Ages, when Jews were forced to listen to Christian sermons, some of the more imaginative listeners stuffed cotton in their ears to produce the desired silence. One wonders if the practice has not survived in our own time when one hears so many charges of silence in the churches from Jewish -- but also Christian -- observers of the Jewish-Christian scene.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 6 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan has formally invited opposition leaders to meet with him in Rawalpindi Feb. 17 "to discuss the political problems that are agitating the people's mind" and to seek their assistance in finding solutions to those problems.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 6 (AP) -- United States District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. rejected today Auburn University's request to delay an appearance of the Rev. William Sloane Coffin.

New York State's Superintendent of Insurance Richard E. Stewart seems to be trying to relieve himself of some responsibility, to the detriment of the public that he is supposed to protect, when he proposes to have the law changed to permit insurance companies to change rates at will.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 6 -- The military regime announced today what amounted to a seizure of all the holdings here of the International Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

Former Secretary of the Treasury Joseph W. Barr yesterday presented the Treasury's distinguished service award -- the highest recognition that the department can give to a non-employe -- to Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and to Charles A. Coombs, one of its senior vice presidents.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- The United States and Soviet delegates to the United Nations began this afternoon talks that are designed to test the prospects for a four-power meeting and a new directive for a Middle East settlement. Washington proposed such contacts yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Paul A. Volcker, the new Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, will leave tomorrow for a week of meetings in Europe carrying no new American proposals on the world monetary front resulting from the change in Administrations.

The major new element in the Nixon Administration's Mideast policy, as outlined by the President in his news conference, is prevention. "We are not going to stand back and wait for something else to happen," the President said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Federal Aviation Administration was accused today by several Congressmen and an airline pilot group of jeopardizing passengers' lives by not equipping all commercial airports with electronic systems to help pilots land in bad weather.
Sometimes a particular performer and a particular work intersect happily, when the idiosyncracies of one fit the specialties of the other.
Allie Sherman's favorite football coach; one of the first of the behemoth linemen, and three great stars of the 1950's are new members of the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio.
Volume and prices declined yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
SAN FRANCISCO Feb. 6 -- Striking teachers at San Francisco State College were invited today by S. I. Hayakawa, acting president, to come back by 5 P.M. Monday to be rehired.
A major department store here has agreed to give limited charge accounts to welfare recipients in an experimental program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Nixon took a "dim view" today of moves in the Congress to impose quotas on imports and asserted that the interest of the nation and of the world was in "moving toward freer trade rather than protectionism."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended Feb. 1 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. The year-to-year decreases are attributable, in part to dock strikes on the East and Gulf coast.

The polite impasse between the major league baseball players and club owners over rights to television income continued yesterday, but the players asked the owners to make the next move on a key issue.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Nixon, while acknowledging today that many Negroes distrusted him, said that he hoped to be "a friend of all the people."
Simeon Golar, who has been designated by Mayor Lindsay to be chairman of the Commission on Human Rights, said yesterday that his policy would be to serve all racial groups.
The city's Human Resources Administration has decided to adopt at least 50 new safeguards to prevent the loss of antipoverty funds through fraud or theft.

MODERN art works may be getting bigger and bolder all the time, but the furnishings designed to display or focus on paintings, sculptures and objects are becoming more modest. In fact, some even appear to disappear.

SINCE pitchers currently dominate baseball, there seems to be a singular appropriateness to the fact that a pair of pitchers gained election to the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown in recent action by the special Old-Timers Committee. One was Waite Hoyt, best remembered as a Yankee, and the other was Stan Coveleski, best remembered as a Cleveland Indian.

PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 61 -- The three men accused of murdering Gabriel (Johnny the Walk) DeFranco were acquitted today, and two of them immediately attacked the Passaic County Prosecutor's office, which had prepared the case against them.

ALMOST every woman has yearned for her own personal shopper at one time or another, but few can top Carol Channing's. The kewpie-doll-faced comedienne has none other than Mildred Custin, the tireless president of Bonwit Teller, in tow.
CORONADO, Calif. Feb. 6 -- Two senior enlisted men and a civilian oceanographer testified today that many of the Pueblo's crew members had been unaware of the intelligence ship's over-all mission.

The Federal Reserve System's policy of credit restraint is beginning to bite hard, banking figures published yesterday showed.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Governor Rockefeller made public today the details of his long-range proposals to cut state aid to localities. The proposals are twice and, in some cases, three times as severe as the 5 per cent cutback he has proposed in projected spending for the 1969-70 fiscal year, which begins April 1.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird has called a temporary halt in deployment of the Sentinel antimissile system around the United States, the Defense Department disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) -- Vince Lombardi, pro football's toughest taskmaster, took the reins of the Washington Redskins as head coach and part-owner today and declared he wanted a winner his first year.

A 52-year-old Brooklyn man appeared in court yesterday to plead to a charge that he had sold marijuana to an undercover policeman. But before that case could be settled, he found himself arrested again for having carried seven packages of marijuana into the courtroom.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- The United States and South Vietnam urged the other side at the third plenary meeting of the broadened peace talks today to reconsider the allies proposals for military steps to reduce fighting in Vietnam.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu pledged tonight that his Government would not withdraw from the Paris peace talks before a settlement of the Vietnam war had been reached.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Nixon is thinking of making annual "state of the world" statements on foreign policy much as other Presidents have sent economic messages to Congress, White House sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission accused the Justice Department today of trying to restrict railroad mergers to failing companies despite Congressional policy to reshape the nation's railroads into fewer systems.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Three Appellate Court jurists overturned today a United States District Court ruling and said the famed Civil War train, "The General," legally belongs to the State of Georgia.
HONG KONG, Feb. 6 -- Peking has demanded that Liao Hoshu, the Chinese charge d'affaires in the Netherland who defected last month, be handed back to Communist China.

Joseph F. Bernstein, president of Joseph F. Bernstein, Inc., announced plans yesterday for the construction of a 40-story office building on the west side of the Avenue of the Americas, or Sixth Avenue, between 41st and 42d Streets.

The Americans of Italian Descent, an organization whose aim is to eliminate "defamatory and insulting" characterizations of Italian-Americans, called yesterday for a Congressional investigation of the movie industry and other communications media.

BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 6 -- Under provisions of a "state of extreme emergency" proclamation issued late yesterday by Gov. Ronald Reagan, California highway patrolmen joined sheriff's deputies and other policemen today to prevent further disorders on the campus of the University of California here.
AN increasing number of conventional bidding devices are aimed at the problem of showing two-suited hands after the opponents have opened the bidding.
The American Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it had found three brokerage-house officials guilty of violations of the exchange's constitution or the Federal Reserve's margin requirements.
Silver futures prices took another sharp tumble yesterday under what one broker called "forced liquidation." Some holders of long positions were asked to ante up more margin -- or sell.

The orange and blue flag of New York City was raised in the chilled air over the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday as the Federal Government gave the city possession of the sprawling base along the East River.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 --President Nixon will ask Congress to make changes in the 22-year-old Taft-Hartley Act to improve Federal effectiveness in dealing with serious national strikes.

The political ground swell that has led Secretary of Defense Laird to suspend acquisition and construction of Sentinel missile sites has provided the Nixon Administration with an invaluable opportunity to re-evaluate the whole ill-considered project for a "thin" antiballistic-missile (ABM) system. That re-evaluation could be of great national benefit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The District of Columbia city government said today that misconduct, brutality and racial prejudice by the "white Southern" prison guards who man the municipal reformatory here had contributed to the antiwhite hostility and criminality of many of Washington's young Negroes.

"DEAR WORLD" -- Dear Heavens! -- Dear Tickets: that in telegraphese seems to be my message from the Mark Hellinger Theater, where last night the musical "Dear World" emerged, better late than never, for post-preview scrutiny.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Nixon declared himself at his news conference today to be strongly for peace but strongly against creating a Federal department of peace. [Question 12, Page 16.]

Seconds before midnight transformed Wednesday into yesterday, a small gray-haired woman with sparkling blue eyes was swept into the arms of Herschel Bernardi, the star of "Zorba," as the strains of "Never on Sunday" floated through the downstairs dining room of a West Side restaurant.

Any stockholder of Loew's Theatres, Inc., who attended yesterday's annual meeting expecting to receive more information about a tangled situation involving Loew's, Northwest Industries, Inc., and the B. F. Goodrich Company, must have been sorely disappointed.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 6 -- Reports have reached Israel that the Iraqi Government has released 21 to 25 Jews from prison in the last few days.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 6 -Yasir Arafat, who has just been elected leader of Palestinians in exile, has announced that he plans to move to Jordan a large part of Palestinian army units now in Egypt, Syria and Iraq, Al Ahram, the Cairo newspaper, reported this morning.

Mayor Lindsay asked the Board of Education yesterday to withdraw its plans to build new schools in the proposed linear city through Brooklyn, and, instead, to build the schools outside the massive, $500-million complex.

A self-described underground news service made public yesterday what it said were excerpts from an as yet unreleased government report dealing with "The Politics of Protest," which it charged contradicts the interim report issued last Thursday by the President's Commission on Violence.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- The old legs of Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez and the new face of Jan Kodes provoked most of the applause from 5,835 spectators tonight in the second round of the $30,000 Philadelphia international indoor open tennis tournament at the Spectrum.

PANAJACHEL, Guatemala, Feb. 2 -- Samuel Greene of New York and Montclair, N. J., retired in 1953 from a successful career of buying ailing businesses and restoring their health. Now, at the age of 76, he is as busy as ever trying to doctor a sick economic and social system in this little Central American republic.

The significance of your Jan. 31 news story on relations between blacks and whites at Wesleyan lies not in the difficulties cited but in those omitted -- namely, the problems of intellectual accommodation, not of social accommodation.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
PARIS, Feb. 6 -- President de Gaulle described Col. Frank Borman today as "a very nice young man," a sentiment voiced even more strongly by Parisians in the streets.

A 23-year-old actress and model caused crowds to gather and the police to come running yesterday afternoon when she partially disrobed on a Times Square scaffolding as part of a promotional campaign for a new book.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 6 -- The Bulletin chafes because the English-language newspapers are frequently unavailable for morning tea. It scolds the civic authorities because too many trees are being cut down and because the jewel-like Grand-Place is being despoiled by the motor car.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Edward C. Crafts, director of the Bureau of Outdoor Recreation in the Interior Department since the bureau was founded in 1962, was dismissed today by the Republican Administration.
A task force of leading New York State Democrats yesterday recommended broad changes in the party's structure and practices designed to revitalize it and help it win more elections.

Donald Dell, captain of the victorious United States Davis Cup tennis team, said yesterday he hoped a new player classification for tournaments would be adopted to enable competitors such as Arthur Ashe and Clark Graebner to compete for prize money without designating themselves as professionals.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The Council of Churches, the state's largest interdenominational Protestant organization, has come out for outright repeal of the state's abortion law.
Mike Maloy fixed a flat tire, missed his plane and gulped a ham sandwich before arriving at Madison Square Garden last night. But his exciting day was just beginning.

Albert Shanker, president of the 55,000-member United Federation of Teachers, sent a telegram yesterday to the city's Law Department announcing his intention to appeal his 15-day jail sentence for leading last fall's school strikes.
A legal effort by 12 conservative Columbia University students to oust the university's trustees was dismissed in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The evolving strategy of the Nixon Administration in the area of the cities and human resources is to move as soon as possible to achieve some short-range but politically important results that will not cost a great deal of money.
MOSCOW, Feb. 6 -- Janos Kadar, the Hungarian Communist party leader, arrived here tonight by train for what was officially described as a "friendly visit" at the invitation of the Soviet party.

Monumental is the best description for this labor of love by Roger Treat, a Connecticut newsman. Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, called a meeting of the union's executive committee yesterday in an effort to head off legal action by the National Labor Relations Board.

Frank Sinatra Jr.'s manager and six other men were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on mail fraud conspiracy charges involving the use of stolen credit cards to purchase thousands of dollars worth of airline tickets.
The Pan Am Building on Park Avenue is about to lose its claim to the title of the world's biggest privately constructed office building to a new office tower in lower Manhattan.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Courtaulds, Ltd., Britain's biggest synthetic-fiber textile manufacturer, bowed to Government pressure today and dropped its $252-million offer for English Calico, Ltd.
Nine winners, whose talent is either full-blown or just emerging, have been named by the Brandeis University Creative Arts Awards Commission.
G. B. Aydelott, president of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad, said yesterday that the road would vigorously resist any takeover attempt by the Carter Group.

MIAMI, Feb. 6 -- Lawyers for Willis Jessie, the first American to face trial for hijacking an airplane to Cuba, asked a Federal court today to delay the trial on ground that the mood of the country was hostile to their client.
BATH, N. Y., Feb. 6 (UPI) -- A man and seven children died early today when fire swept a one-story frame home on a deserted rural road near the hamlet of Wallace, 10 miles northwest of here.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 -- Enemy battle deaths increased almost 25 per cent last week over the week before, but allied losses for the same period remained essentially unchanged, according to figures made public today by United States and South Vietnamese spokesmen.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 6 -- The finishing touches were being put today on a 25-foot icy reproduction of a dragon that is to spout flames on the college green as skiers from eight colleges tuned up for tomorrow's start of the 59th Dartmouth Carnival.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- This city's board of Education adopted a resolution tonight to appeal a state order to correct racial imbalance in this city's elementary schools through busing.
The stock market put on a modest show of strength yesterday to register its first plurality -- 674 to 648 -- of advances over declining issues this week.
The death of Eduardo Mondlane in Tanzania is a tragedy not merely for the African and American friends of Dr. Mondlane, but it also may be the death of the "moderate revolution" in Southern Africa.

Hunter College's song-cycle series is dedicated primarily to the presentation of important vocal music. In engaging worthy singers for the project the school's concert bureau has come up with artists who have not been heard here as recitalists. Last night at the College Playhouse, the singer in the series was Helen Watts, a Welsh contralto who has sung here previously only with orchestra.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7 -Harvard, the defending champion, won the only two events tonight as the 10th annual Greater Boston colleges indoor track meet opened, setting meet records in both.
Mayor Lindsay has agreed to meet with the Rector of the burglarized St. Mark's in the Bowery Church to discuss ways of helping to reduce crime in the area.

AMERICAN designers' clothes are usually liveliest in the summertime when everyone takes them less seriously. What with Chester's sportswear, Oscar's flounces and Donald's gypsies, they're perkier than ever this year.

The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange havee issued their latest reports of changes in stock ownership by corporate officials, directors or large stockholders in listed companies.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 (UPI) -- A woman opposed to capital punishment and another who apparently had her mind made up as to the guilt of the defendant were excused today during selection of six alternate jurors for the murder trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan.

A policeman suspected of being connected with a "pay-off" notebook found in a telephone booth in the nearby lobby of the Criminal Court Building last month has been suspended, Police Headquarters reported yesterday.

The trading pace slowed a bit more yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as price declines outnumbered advances. Oil and mining issues were still trading favorites, but some profit taking trimmed price levels.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) -- A Federal judge granted today a request by the American Newspaper Publishers Association for a court trial on proposed Federal guidelines to bar the words male and female from classified advertising.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has suspended for 30 days all Federal funding and action on housing and city improvement programs, pending a review by him and his assistants.
COLD winds, snow flurries, strained budgets and jaded palates combine to make a winter syndrome suffered by many. Hearty, old-fashioned chicken dishes like the following might be of help.

To the Editor: We appreciate the interest in more and better street name signs expressed in your Jan. 23 editorial. This has also been a concern of ours since responsibility for erection and maintenance of street name signs was transferred to the Traffic Department in 1963.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 7 (UPI) -- Plainclothes agents equipped with Chemical Mace raided the showing of a pornographic film at the University of Notre Dame today and seized the film in a fracas in which two policemen and several students were injured.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- "Your Own Thing," the Off Broadway hit musical, opened here at the Comedy Theater last night and London's theater critics generally, found it a frolic of endearing charm.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7 -The Harvard Graduate School of Design scrapped today a course that was to have developed "an action program for the effective control and eventual elimination of riots in urban areas," after more than 100 Negro students forced cancellation of the course's first session.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 7 -- Arthur J. Goldberg, the former United States Supreme Court Justice and United States representative to the United Nations, will represent Hudson County communities in their attempt to obtain changes in a state law providing for the assessment of property at 100 per cent of true value.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Senate quickly confirmed today 25 nominations of high officials in the Nixon Administration.
High-technology stocks took center stage in the new-issue market this week, together with textile and health-related shares.
The Treasury, offering the highest interest rates in 103 years to refinance $5.48-billion of publicly held securities maturing Feb. 15, was turned down by an unusually large number of investors.

The police, responding to a report of a stabbing at a Queens apartment early today, found more than 100 teen-agers jammed into "two tiny rooms" in a haze of marijuana smoke. What was termed a "weekend pot party" ended with mass arrests.

Two merger battles moved considerably closer to realization yesterday as the General Host Corporation announced it had achieved control of more than a third of the outstanding shares of Armour Co. and NVF said it had acquired 51 per cent of the outstanding shares of Sharon Steel Corporation.
The Xerox Corporation, the nation's largest manufacturer of office-copying machines, is attempting to move into the computer business.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange declined in quiet trading yesterday. British Government bonds were weak. Gold shares were steady.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe said today that three committees had begun an intensive review for the Nixon Administration of the supersonic transport plane to determine whether the Government should continue subsidizing its development.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland -- In the campaign for the Feb. 24 general election, all the old religious animositiesbetween the Protestant majority (dressed as the Unionist party) and the Roman Catholic minority (dressed as the Nationalists) are being called up.
After 20 years as a respected, journeyman jazz pianist, Junior Mance may become one of the select group of pianists who reach beyond a jazz following to entertain a popular audience.
The Midland-Ross Corporation has elected Harry J. Bolwell president and chief operating officer, to succeed David E. Walbert who becomes chairman, it was announced yesterday.
The Columbia University committee responsible for overseeing discipline announced yesterday the cancellation of all punishments against students for participating in last spring's student rebellion.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 7 -At the end of a busy day during which a Kent State senior was named queen, a 30-foothigh ice-sculptured dragon in midcampus spouted fire and coed dates walked snowy streets in miniskirts, Dartmouth's skiers sparkled.

BELLEAIR, Fla., Feb. 7 -- The United States Lawn Tennis Association took the first steps toward expanding and professionalizing its organization today when the executive committee recommended a revised "player" category and approved the controversial Kirsch committee report.

MOSCOW, Feb. 7 -- The Soviet Government, heeding appeals from conservationists, announced today a program of stringent measures to stop the pollution of Lake Baikal, the world's largest body, in volume, of fresh water.

A dozen veterans of last fall's national political campaigns, ranging in age from 10 to 14 years, demonstrated in front of the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan yesterday against the Knickerbocker Greys, a socially exclusive organization of youngsters who conduct military drills.

PRAGUE, Feb. 7 -- Premier Oldrich Cernik said today that Czechoslovakia had obtained pledges for $200-million to $300-million in commercial credits to help make her outdated industry competitive in world markets.

The number of robberies reported to the police last year by people living, working and visiting here increased by more than 50 per cent over the figure for 1967. The increase -- from 35,934 in 1967 to 54,405 in 1968 -- was noted in a 12-month statistical study published yesterday by the Police Department.

Jim Green, Phil Tobin and Andy O'Reilly aren't exactly household names in big-time track and field. But they upset assorted Olympic medalists and national champions last night in providing the major excitement in a mundane Madison Square Garden invitation meet.
Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, yesterday was granted a stay of his 15-day jail sentence imposed for defying court orders to end last fall's school strike.
GENEVA, Feb. 7 -- An announcement of an inter-bank agreement for speeding the transfer of Eurobonds is expected "very soon" an authoritative Swiss banking source said tonight.
Nine Negro and Puerto Rican residents of Huntington, L.I., filed suit in Federal Court yesterday to block completion of the town's urban renewal program.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- A political confrontation between East and West developed today over Western demands for inclusion of West Germany in the committee for the Second Development Decade, while Moscow demanded Bonn's exclusion.
Ten detectives armed with shotguns and wearing bulletproof vests last night arrested seven men accused of transporting 100 revolvers for a gunrunning gang.

YONKERS, Feb. 7 -- Billy Myer, 52 years old and a top harness-racing driver for many years, will guide Cardinal King in tomorrow night's featured $12,500 one-mile handicap race for junior free-for-all and Class AA pacers at Yonkers Raceway.

HOUSTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) -One of the leaders of the men hired to cap the runaway oil well said today that his crew could have already plugged it, but that his men had been slowed down by "political" interference.

MIAMI, Feb. 7 -- Despite the cries of the prophets of doom, Diane Crump rode in the seventh race at Hialeah today -the first girl ever to compete against men on a Florida race track -- and when it was over the grandstand was still standing.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP) -Willis Reed asserted his mastery with a 31-point output and the control of both backboards tonight to lead the Knicks to a 105-98 victory over the Chicago Bulls for the New Yorkers' eighth straight triumph in the National Basketball Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 7 -- The White House announced today that the National Security Council would become the nation's "principal forum for the consideration of policy issues" on which President Nixon "is required to make decisions."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) -- William R. Manning, superintendent of Washington public schools, has ordered sections questioning interracial and interfaith marriages scissored out of an 11th-grade health textbook.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Justice Department asked a Federal court for the first time today to close down a plant for polluting the air.

WHY is it that expressionism always seems -- in spirit, if not always in practice -- a young man's style? There is, to be sure, an element of sheer biological verve in the expressionist manner that guarantees an identification with youth.

MOSCOW, Feb. 7 -- Soviet authorities gave a receptive reaction today to President Nixon's plans to explore the possibility of an eventual summit meeting with the Soviet Union after his West European trip later this month.

The crisis in the longshore strike along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts deepened yesterday as talks broke off in several ports and New York management attorneys filed unfairlabor-practice charges with the National Labor Relations Board.

IF the one-week season of avant-garde modern-dance at the Billy Rose Theater has proved nothing else, it has proved that there is avant-garde dancing and avant-garde dancing. Also it has indicated that some avant-garde dancing is positively retrogressive.
Three high officials of the Lindsay administration urged the City Council yesterday not to enact legislation mandating the treatment of narcotics addicts in prisons with Methodone.

In a move that company executives said would further increase its independent status, New York Airways announced yesterday that its operations at Kennedy International and La Guardia Airport would be shifted to the passenger terminals of American Airlines on Feb. 17.
Five homeowners in Brooklyn Heights have filed suit to prevent the city from moving the Fort Greene wholesale meat market to a riverfront site at the Brooklyn end of the Brooklyn Bridge.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- John G. Veneman Jr., a member of the California State Assembly, was named today to be Under Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare and a highly reliable source disclosed that James Farmer, former director of the Congress of Racial Equality, would be named next week to a high post in the same department.

Iraqi leaders continue to denounce United Nations efforts to promote a negotiated settlement in the Middle East, but Iraq has significantly eased a serious threat to negotiations by calling a halt to its witch hunt against its own Jews.

Siemens, A. G., West Germany's largest producer of communications and electro-technical equipment, had record net earnings of $70-million in the fiscal year ended last September, up $30-million from the previous year's $39,942,500 profit.

The new head of the 3,300 - member Menswear Retailers of America took over the power, responsibility and trappings of the group's presidency this week with a pledge to lead his group into a new era of professionalism.
Railroad stocks climbed to a new peak yesterday in the popular averages and pulled the rest of the market upward in the second day of a mini-rally. There were 705 advances and 619 declining issues.
The American Civil Liberties Union issued a revised policy statement on civil disobedience yesterday in which it pledged its legal assistance to challenges of laws it regards as invalid.
BUFFALO, Feb. 7 -- Governor Rockefeller will meet with President Nixon in Washington on Monday to urge him to initiate a vast restructuring of Federal aid to the states.

Paul Ehrlich is a biologist who obviously cares deeply for our planet. He is concerned about the spoiling of its air and water, the chemical pollution of its soil, the destruction of man's environment by man himself, and just why these things have happened. One of the main causes had its genesis about a decade ago, he writes, when "the stork passed the plow" and population began to outstrip food production.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Feb. 7 -- The Rangers were talking about slow dressers in their room underneath Skateland today after working out for tomorrow's afternoon game against the St. Louis Blues at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The director of the Federal Bureau of Outdoor Recreation, who was told yesterday that he would be dismissed as soon as a replacement could be found, was asked today to stay on the job by Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel.
William Maxwell, the author, has been elected president of the National Institute of Arts and Letters, which is limited to 250 members and is the highest American honor society of the arts.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UPI) -Student demonstrators today breached a cordon of security police of the University of Chicago, screamed "Fascist pig" at a university disciplinary official, and disrupted his meeting with a student charged with participating in a nine-day sit-in.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Kentucky State Racing Commission disciplined Dr. Alex Harthill, a veterinarian, and Douglas M. Davis Jr., a trainer, today in connection with the uproar over the 1968 Kentucky Derby.

MEMPHIS, Feb. 7 (AP) -- William Bradford Huie, biographer of James Earl Ray, was arrested on a contempt of court warrant today after testifying for two hours and 40 minutes before the Shelby County grand jury.

THE VALLEY, Anguilla, Feb. 7 (UPI) -- With only four dissenters, the Caribbean island of Anguilla has voted to break all ties with Britain and become the smallest republic in the Western Hemisphere, it was announced today.
MIAMI, Feb. 7 (UPI) -- A passenger on a jet that was hijacked filed a damage suit today against Eastern Airlines, charging negligence and saying the experience had aggravated a heart condition.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 7 -Princeton's basketball team combined height, defense and the hot shooting of Jeff Petrie to give Columbia's defending Ivy League champions their first league loss of the season tonight, 68-49.
The new pattern of disruption and coercion by militant students on campuses from Queens College to Berkeley poses a serious threat to the freedom of higher education.

To the Editor: The nonproliferation treaty was attacked in a letter from E. Edmund Ryder (Jan. 31). The main arguments were that the treaty would "harm the cause of Western unity" and "increase the danger of the United States becoming involved in a major war."
A 19-year-old student nurse has been indicted on a charge of attempting to murder two policemen in upper Manhattan last month.

To the Editor: In your editorials of Jan. 29 and 30 referring to the "barbaric'' public executions and to "hysteria in Iraq," you took the whole issue out of the proper context of the general interest, security and welfare of the Arab world.

BAL HARBOUR, Feb. 7 -- An air traffic controllers safety committee said today it had worked out a program that would enable the Federal Aviation Administration to postpone restrictions scheduled to go into effect April 27 at five major airports in the United States.

To the Editor: Lester Markel's thoughtful Jan. 25 column on Public TV was doubtless intended to be, and indeed was, constructive. But it expressed a certain lament and dissatisfaction with which few Channel 13 viewers could agree.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 -Bitter dissension in the 70,000member Sierra Club led David Brower, the executive director, to announce today that he would seek a two-month leave of absence to campaign for election of a slate of directors "committed to conservation, not civil war."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -Three Australians and the newest pro, Tom Okker of the Netherlands, advanced tonight into the semi-finals of the $30,000 Philadelphia international indoor open tennis tournament as Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez made his exit, but not laughing.
The United Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday the election of David C. Hewitt and Alfred W. Van Sinderen as directors.
VENICE -- Plans for a huge Congress hall and center for the Venice Biennale of Art, drawn by Louis Kahn, the Philadelphia architect, have been put on display.

WHEN the bidding is competitive at the part-score level, it is sometimes difficult to judge whether partner is hoping for game or simply fighting to prevent the opposition from making a partscore. In such circumstances a player who simply rebids his own suit is generally not interested in going further.

The offer by five major drug manufacturers to pay $120 million to settle damage claims for overcharges on tetracycline and other so-called wonder drugs is a significant breakthrough in consumer protection in a field where price abuses have long been flagrant.

DETROIT, Feb. 7 (AP) -- United States auto manufacturers scheduled 184,312 cars for production this week, 26.6 per cent above the corresponding week in the preceding year, according to the industry trade publication Automotive News.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 -- "Whatever it is, it's not beautiful," said the Boston cab driver taking the visitor to the new City Hall. "What would you call it, Gothic?" asked another. Which about sums up the architectural gap, or abyss, as it exists between those who design and those who use the 20th century's buildings.
WALL STREET stories are making the rounds over what would happen if Leasco Data Processing managed to take over Chemical Bank New York Trust or one of the other leading money market banks.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz urged the Legislature today to pass a bill that would "correct abuses" in give-away contests by establishing ground rules for their operation.
Jews were urged yesterday to continue to take part in the civil rights movement and not to permit the anti-Semitism of some black militants to cause a split between Negroes and Jews.

The Long Island Rail Road and the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen agreed yesterday to undertake a joint fact-finding mission in an effort to resolve a dispute centering on a shortage of commuter cars since last summer.

It isn't hard to make up a program of Viennese music. Just to start with, you have the works of Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert. These four, plus three others, were to be found in the Master Virtuosi of New York's concert, labeled "Royal Vienna Festival," in Philharmonic Hall last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (Reuters) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today issued amended rules that give more authority to its staff.

Martin S. Ackerman, the young financier who took over the presidency of the troubled Curtis Publishing Company less than a year ago, was away vacationing yesterday, but his problems were multiplying. He was understood to be in Puerto Rico.
A research team at Harvard Medical School has demonstrated that young men, reinforced by views of nudes appearing in Playboy magazine, can be trained to raise or lower their own blood pressure.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Joseph A. Loftus, for many years a labor reporter for The New York Times, today was named special assistant for communications to Secretary of Labor George P. Shulz.

OAKLAND, Feb. 7 (AP) -Tim Wood, the United States men's figure skating champion, took a strong lead today over the Canadian champion, Jay Humphry, after the compulsory figures competition in the North American figure skating championships.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 7 (UPI) -- The runaway flow of oil from a gusher in the Santa Barbara Channel slowed considerably today.

SALISBURY MILLS, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- A Broadway actor, a West Point major and a Cherokee youth are guarding an unused paper mill here that an American Indian family plans to use as a refuge from the harassment they say they have suffered in these Hudson highlands.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Wilie Davenport tied a world record by running the 60yard high hurdles in 6.8 seconds and Tom Von Ruden beat the American record in the 1,000yard run to highlight the ninth annual Forth Worth coaches indoor games tonight.

To the Editor: Hans Fisher's Jan. 26 reply to my letter of Jan. 19 on reopening the Suez Canal is an example of unbalanced emotional approach when he recommends avoiding outbursts of anger, empty generalities and unfair personal insinuations, instead of a serious discussion on an economic problem of vital global importance.

HOUSTON, Feb. 7 (Reuters) -- Credit companies, under fire in Congress for reported violations of the right to privacy, have adopted a code of conduct designed to protect the consumer, it was announced today.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 6 -- Tanzanians celebrated the second anniversary of the proclamation of their Socialist, self-reliant society Wednesday with parades and dances, soccer games and a huge display of school children drilling and dancing in the Dar es Salaam national stadium.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Nixon Administration committed itself today to seek Congressional enactment this year of reforms that would make the tax laws fairer.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7 -- A New York accountant testified today that at a party in the French Quarter in June of 1963 he heard Clay L. Shaw casually discuss assassinating President Kennedy.
PARIS, Feb. 7 -- There are strong indications that informal contacts have been established between the allied and Communist sides in the expanded Vietnam peace talks here.

As most commodity futures traders know, one of the keynotes of trading in futures is the quick changes in basic markets, sometimes explainable, sometimes not. For some weeks futures trading generally has been in the doldrums, with volume low and prices drifting downward in many instances.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 7 -- A New York educator said today that laws should be questioned as to whether they are reasonable and deserve obedience.

He steers it down the Saw Mill River Parkway and the West Side Highway to Wall Street, marches into the office of the old stock brokerage firm of T. L. Watson Co., and begins another day in the nonviolent, postseason world of Dave Herman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Defense Department announced today that it would award $9.4-million in contracts to three Southern textile companies after receiving assurances that they would move to eliminate discrimination in employment.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 7 -The ruling Baath Socialist party in Iraq indicated today that oil would be the next issue to be dealt with by the regime, which seized power last July in a military coup d'etat.

Wheels whir. Dials quiver. And magnetized needles send electronic mating calls. There's no lack of sound and action in a busy new show of "phenomenological sculptures" by the Greek-born artist Takis at the Howard Wise Gallery, 50 West 57th Street.

ANYBODY who thinks Bergdorf Goodman is staid and stuffy should have been on the sixth floor yesterday. Electric guitars throbbed. Teen-age girls squealed. Soda pop dribbled on racks of junior-size clothes.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 7 (UPI) -- Lieut. Paul Lamey piloted the Navy to victory in record time today in the North American two-man bobsled races on Mount Van Hoevenberg, virtually assuring a place on the United States team for the world championships later this month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -John G. Veneman Jr. had to go through a political tug of war between two of California's most powerful Republicans before he could emerge as the Under Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
A young avant garde couple whose taste in pop art objects ran to the extreme were held yesterday on a variety of charges -- among them stealing a fire hydrant and other municipal items.

A committee of the garment industry will undertake a three-point program to cut down theft, pilferage and hijacking in New York and surrounding areas, Sidney Korzenik, the committee's counsel said yesterday.
A ticket to a New York Knickerbocker basketball game, considered only a few years ago about as valuable as a midtown bus transfer, may soon become as sought after as an autograph by Joe Namath.

Negro students at Hunter College and at the State University in Stony Brook, L.I., issued demands yesterday for programs of black studies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Automobile warranties were described by members of the Federal Trade Commission today as a protection for manufacturers and not consumers.
Two University of Georgia geologists believe they have confirmed the previous conjunction of Africa and South America in terms of an intimate geologic "fit" between the two continents.

BONN, Feb. 7 -- A highly placed source said today that a Soviet note delivered yesterday offered generous consideration of West German interests if the Bonn Government signed the international treaty to bar the spread of nuclear weapons.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 7 -The Turkish Government is reported to be permitting Soviet submarines to start their passage through the Bosporus in darkness, despite an international convention forbidding this.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- President Nixon said today that as a youngster he wanted to be a Boy Scout but his parents could not afford it.
DETROIT, Feb. 7 -- An unarmed street patrol of young Negro men in semimilitary clothing has been organized in one of the high crime areas of this city's east side.
CORONADO, Calif., Feb. 7 -A naval intelligence officer said today that the Pueblo crew should have destroyed the secret documents on the intelligence ship in a one-hour "maximum all-out effort."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Nixon has sent President Gamal Abdel Nasser a noncommittal message on the Egyptian leader's appeal for a more responsive United States attitude toward Arab views on a Middle East peace settlement, according to informed diplomatic sources.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Feb. 7 -- The Nassau County Board of Elections said today that it had no way of telling how more than 20 per cent of the voters in yesterday's school bus referendum had cast their ballots.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Roy Wilkins, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said after, a 30-minute meeting with President Nixon today that they had disagreed about the cutoff of funds to five Southern school districts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel, reversing a position less than 24 hours old, ordered all drilling stopped today in the offshore oil wells in polluted Santa Barbara Channel.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 7 -- Fighting in the Vietnam war remained at a low level in the last 24 hours, according to allied military communiques. Most of the action occurred in the Mekong Delta, south of Saigon. All the engagements were small, scattered and brief.

PANAMA, Feb. 7 -- The two colonels who run Panama say that the United States will probably be asked to extradite the wife of former President Marco A. Robles.
ATHENS, Feb. 7 -- Premier George Papadopoulos has warned that the Soviet fleet in the Mediterranean "threatens not only Greece but the whole free world."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A Florida electronic equipment company is transmuting metal to produce better radio tribes. In what might be called modern alchemy, the rare-earth element lanthanum is transformed into barium.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Black skies turned cloudless blue in a turnaround of the weather today, and Rod Funseth remained in command of the 90-hole $122,000 Bob Hope Desert Golf Classic with a 54-hole score of 206.

UMUOHIAGU, Biafra (Nigeria), Feb. 7 -- A crowded market in this Biafran village was bombed and strafed at noon today. Local officials estimated that 200 to 300 people had been killed and hundreds wounded.

HONG KONG, Feb. 7 -- The defection to the United States of Liao Ho-shu, charge d' affaires of the Chinese Communist Embassy in the Netherlands, is a reminder of how few in number are the Chinese Communist officials who have turned their backs on the Peking regime and sought asylum abroad.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 - The Federal Communications Commission plans to begin an inquiry into the ownership of radio and television stations by conglomerate companies.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., showed a new high-speed, computer-controlled communications system today that could easily show giant utilities, such as the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, how to get along better with their customers.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- The Soviet Union has forbidden the publication of a book by Mikhail A. Sholokhov, winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1965, according to The Daily Telegraph.
PUTNAM, Conn., Feb. 7 (UPI) -- Former Mayor Paul J. Bourgeois of Putnam, a man plagued by personal, political and financial problems, was killed early today in an automobile accident.

Blossom Dearie is a beautiful, blond bundle of contradictions. WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- A commission that speaks for all levels of government today urged financially hard-pressed states to look to the personal income tax for the funds to meet their responsibilities.

NEW DELHI, Wednesday, Feb. 12 -- A 12-party United Front, dominated by India's two Communist parties, was well on its way early today to a stunning victory over Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's supporters in the state of West Bengal.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 11 -- Coal mining, West Virginia's largest and politically most potent industry, came under an unusually noisy attack in the State House here today for giving what its critics charged was priority to production and profits over the health of miners.

John Kenneth Galbraith has offered advice to The Washington Post on how President Nixon should contain rising prices. NABLUS, Israeli - Occupied Jordan, Feb. 11 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan plunged today into the towns and villages of the Israeli-occupied west bank of the Jordan River, drawing distinctions between demonstrations and disorder.

Prices were mixed at the close of a three-hour trading session on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company had an abundance of good news for its 62,200 stockholders yesterday. DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 12 -- The Rev. Uria Simango, a Protestant, today took over the leadership of the Mozambique Liberation Front, known as Frelimo, following the assassination last week of the party's president, Dr. Eduardo C. Mondlane in Dar Es Salaam.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- After three months of extensive recruiting in the Negro community, the Nixon Administration acquired today its first nationally known Negro leader.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Eight former aides of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy have been awarded Ford Foundation travel and study grants totaling more than $131,000, records of a House Small Business subcommittee showed today.

Poor planning, a limited budgetary approach, faulty weather reports and a tight labor market were cited as some of the reasons yesterday why the snow was still clogging some of the city's highways and streets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- High Pentagon officials have been told that the Soviet Union's missile defense is roughly three-quarters complete and has been slowed in recent months to improve the system's radar.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 -- The United States military command in Saigon announced today that a large Marine operation was under way in an area 19 miles southeast of Culu, in Quangtri Province of South Vietnam.

To the Editor: In all the latest controversy over the economic and military arguments for a volunteer army, I believe we have lost sight of one of the major advantages of a draft. Though the present draft is certainly riddled with many inequalities, one must not immediately attack the concept itself.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 12 -- The state wound up today its testimony about the alleged conspiracy in New Orleans to kill President Kennedy in 1963.
The 1969 version of "The International Paper Company, where good ideas grow on trees" campaign will soon be breaking nationally.

The New York Knickerbockers demonstrated last night that they are not at all sadistically inclined. Opposing the Phoenix Suns, the team with the worst record in the National Basketball Association, the Knicks defeated the Suns decisively, but not brutally, 112-105, before a crowd of 12,017 at Madison Square Garden.
IN the early 1960's James Leonard Farmer was a passenger on the last leg of a Deep South Freedom Ride that ended with his being jailed in Jackson, Miss.
NEWBURY, N. H., Feb. 12 -- "I don't know where they all came from," said Dick Parker, general manager of Mount Sunapee. "But there wasn't a parking spot left by 10 A.M."

CAIRO, Feb. 12 -- The United Arab Republic indicated today that it did not hold the Nixon Administration responsible for the sale of Phantom jets to Israel, with deliveries to begin later this year. The North American Watch Corporation, importers and wholesalers of watches, will occupy part of the 31st floor of the 50-story office tower nearing completion on the west blockfront of the Avenue of the Americas or Sixth Avenue, between 54th and 55th Streets.
Incomplete returns from elections in four Indian states point, on balance, toward more troubled times ahead for India and for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's ruling Congress party.

There were pockets of activity in the New York stores yesterday, some of it frenzied. They included such varied shoppers as a Marine lance corporal just back from Vietnam buying civilian clothes before going to see his girl friend, young ladies in pants with balloon cuffs shopping for sunglasses, a public relations man buying books to send to a sick employe and a copywriter buying a record by The Monkees that his 6-year-old son wanted.

BOLOGNA, Italy, Feb. 12 -- Yugoslav and Rumanian delegates to the Italian Communist party congress drew enthusiastic applause today for a blunt, unqualified condemnation of the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia last August.

DETROIT, Feb. 12 -- Government safety officials have seen test results showing, they believe, serious safety problems with two small automobiles now escaping United States safety regulations.

MARATHON, Fla., Feb. 1 -Wives and sweethearts of fishermen have always had an erroneous idea of what their men are doing when away from home on vacation.

To the Editor: For the first time in my memory as a New Yorker, hateful, bigoted and stereotyped public statements are being openly condoned or silently ignored. Suddenly, after all we have been through together, there are now "explanations" for anti-Semitism ,and "reasons" to excuse it.

BOSTON, Feb. 12 -- A newly successful young film director was confronted today by struggling student filmmakers who wanted to know how he did it, although they weren't sure they wanted to do it his way.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 12 -- The Rev. William Sloane Coffin, the peripatetic chaplain fondly called "The Conscience of Yale" by some of that university's most prominent citizens, is just back from high adventure in Alabama, where it took a court order to permit him to speak on the campus of Auburn and where he was fascinated to observe brawny bodyguards riding shotgun to protect him from the presumed wrath of Wallace Country.

Many commodity futures exchanges were closed yesterday because of the Lincoln's Birthday holiday. To the Editor: Senator Everett M. Dirksen was quoted [news story Feb. 1] as expressing concern over the sizable increase of steel imports last year and saying that legislation imposing import quotas would "restore some stability while permitting imports a fair share of our growing market."

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- The president of this city's Board of Education has resigned over the controversial busing issue.

PARIS, Feb. 12 (Reuters) -- Token strikes -- short and symbolic walkouts -- occurred at industrial plants across France today as a result of dissatisfaction with the Gaullist Government in the nation's factories and higher education centers.

Robert D. Hedberg and Alfred E. Driscoll acknowledged yesterday that they had both submitted their resignations as directors of the beleaguered boards of the Curtis Publishing Company and its subsidiary, the Saturday Evening Post Company.

Jazz at the Fillmore, a new series of concerts to be held Sunday night at the Fillmore East on Second Avenue, will begin on March 2.

City officials said yesterday that in a move to thwart the theft and forgery of welfare checks they intended to require identification cards carrying photographs for all 90,000 heads of families in the Bronx who receive welfare.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -Total business inventories rose $700-million in December, a gain smaller than those registered in the two preceding months, the Commerce Department reported today.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- President de Gaulle claimed victory today in his effort to master university unrest by liberal use of reform and limited use of the police club. But the club came into active play tonight.

New York City appeared yesterday to have got off to a slower start than the rest of the state in making referrals to a new work incentive program for welfare recipients.

BALANCHINE'S full-evening work "Don Quixote," with all its genius and all its less-than-genius, is now nearly four years old. On its revival last night by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater, its many virtues and its few limitations seemed in stronger focus than ever before.

BEER ZOFAR, Israel, Feb. 8 -- Bulldozers are carving deep trenches around this desert outpost. Nearby, dirt roads are being paved and settlements enclosed with elaborate fences.

Columbia's basketball team is backed into a corner and cannot afford another setback in the Ivy League if it hopes to retain its title. Hutton Co., Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange, will occupy the first 11 floors and most of the ground floor in the 35-story building under construction on the block bounded by State, Whitehall, Bridge and Pearl Streets, overlooking Battery Park.
