"Queens is always last," muttered Lester Stahl as he chopped at the heaped, crusty snow that imprisoned his car on Homelawn Avenue in Jamaica.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Britain's trade position showed a dramatic improvement in January, according to figures released today by the Board of Trade. Financial markets responded favorably to the unexpectedly good news.
The results of the Dec. 2 examination for admission to the New York State Bar were released yesterday by the State Board of Law Examiners.

Legislation is to be introduced in the City Council soon to extend rent controls to all privately owned apartments in the city. The measure would also roll back to last July 1 the rents on the 600,000 apartments not now under control.

Silver futures were "clobbered" yesterday, one broker commented, explaining that margin calls from previous declines induced many traders to sell out their positions. The result was a break that took silver futures down the 10-centsan-ounce daily limit in nine of the 10 delivery months.

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 13 -In what seemed like United Nations Day at the national amateur indoor tennis championships today, an Egyptian defeated a Briton and a Dane defeated a Swede in quarterfinal matches at the Civic Center.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 -- The district attorney's office said today that Sirhan Bishara Sirhan had been "stalking" Senator Robert F. Kennedy days before he shot him.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 13 -- Fighting in South Vietnam flared during the last 24 hours as Vietcong and North Vietnamese soldiers took the offensive in several sharp engagements in the north and in the area around Saigon, according to allied communiques.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- A spokesman for the Nixon Administration declared today at an economic forum of 22 nations the intention of the United States to press for further trade liberalization by mounting a new assault against non-tariff barriers.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- State Education Commissioner James E. Allen said today that he "strongly opposed" a bill passed by the Senate that would ban state financial aid to students convicted of crimes committed on the premises of any college.

The last publisher of The Saturday Evening Post, Stephen E. Kelly, was elected yesterday as president of the Magazine Publishers Association. On March 17 he will replace John K. Herbert, who will become a consultant to the M.P.A. after eight years in the job.

Pan American World Airways proposed yesterday that airlines serving Kennedy International Airport set up new machinery to cope with the kind of storm that stranded thousands of people at the airport last weekend.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- "Out of 17 fellows from my block who graduated from high school, five are in jail, seven are dope addicts or on the way, four were in the Army -- one of whom was killed in Vietnam. I am the only one attending college."

JERUSALEM, Feb. 13 -- Israeli officials declined to comment on the Cairo announcement of approval for a Suez Canal clearance survey, but they have previously agreed to permit the trapped ships to leave by the southern exit.

YONKERS, Feb. 13 -- Ko-Ko, the Lord High Executioner in Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Mikado," is not the only one who's "Got a Little List." At Yonkers Raceway, where pacers rather than potentates hold forth, it seems as if every other person with a measure of authority has "Got a Little List."

ROME, Feb. 13 -- Vatican sources said today that carbon 14 dating tests on the wood used in the so-called Throne of St. Peter indicated that the throne was not old enough to have been used by the saint.
The Federal National Mortgage Association announced yesterday a program to develop mortgage correspondents among minority groups in urban areas.

WHAT'S made the strongest impression in the summer dress collections on Seventh Avenue? Pants, that's what. It's not totally unexpected, considering the late women have been wearing them and designers have been pushing them. But long pants aren't the only kind seen in the last two weeks.
A probationary housing patrolman ran barefoot through four blocks of snowy Bronx streets early yesterday to arrest two men who he said had robbed him and had made him remove his shoes.
Al and Dick McGuire sat on opposite sides of Madison Square Garden last night concerned with Bob Lanier, the 6-foot-11-inch St. Bonaventure all-America.

Once upon a time (this was away back in 1969) there was a goat name "Scape" who was Mayor of New York City. The other animals kept him around because they had troubles and needed something or other to blame them on, and since "Scape" was an amiable goat, they naturally blamed everything on him.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -Over-all plans for the next decade of the nation's space program will be drafted this summer for submission to President Nixon about Sept. 1.
Marty Liquori has posted the fastest mile of the season, but the thought of running under four minutes for the first time indoors has not affected his mental and physical preparations.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 13 -Several hundred National Guard troops with fixed bayonets restored a measure of order to the tense University of Wisconsin campus today.
NEW DELHI, Friday, Feb. 14 -- In a bold assertion of her leadership, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi announced a major reshuffle of her Cabinet early today.

TRENTON, Feb. 13 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes threatened today to go to court unless the Legislature kills or re-writes a Constitutional amendment that, he charged, would "strip the people of New Jersey" of 400 square miles of tidal marsh and meadowland.

FOR Turk Edwards, captain of the Redskins, and for Mel Hein, captain of the Giants, the coin-tossing ceremony at midfield before the start of each Washington-New York game had elements of old home week. These two hulking brutes were long-time friends from their undergraduate days together at Washington State.

The Data Processing Financial and General Corporation, which in recent weeks has challenged the International Business Machines Corporation and the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, said yesterday that it was discussing a merger with Avnet, Inc.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four start to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
ROCHESTER, Minn. Feb. 13 (AP) -- Former President Lyndon B. Johnson will become a trustee of the Mayo Foundation, G. S. Schuster, chairman, said today.
GHENT, Belgium, Feb. 13 (Reuters) -- A Belgian policeman was speaking and breathing normally today, three days after undergoing the world's first larynx transplant.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange took a slight dip on lower volume yesterday, as Wall Street analysts began to express some concern about the technical condition of the market.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 11 -- Little more than a month after Slovakia became an equal partner in the new Czech-Slovak Federation, a sense of triumphant fulfillment of traditional Slovak nationalist demands is beginning to give way to remorse.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A major fight has shaped up in the Senate over the slashing of $100,000 from the budget of a special committee investigating hunger in the United States.
SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Spring training for strikethreatened big league baseball opened today as a rookie-dominated Chicago White Sox squad of 21 batterymen showed up for a two-hour workout.

A letter-carrier and nine other persons were indicted in the Bronx yesterday, charged with being part of a ring that used stolen welfare checks and identification papers to bilk neighborhood merchants of thousands of dollars.

In commenting upon the Pueblo's surrender by Comdr. Lloyd Bucher, novelist Herman Wouk asks [Topics Feb. 6] if the old military codes hold in this fantastic new era. He also asks if the demands of honor hold where honor, as we define it, is not understood and does not exist.
The Council of the Federation of American Scientists has issued a statement endorsing the call of a Soviet physicist for a moratorium on the development of antiballistic missile systems.
UMUAHIA, Biafra (Nigeria), Feb. 14 (AP) -- The first official United States Congressional mission to visit both sides in the Nigerian civil war arrived here yesterday from Dahomey.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- A Washington judge ruled today that a potential witness in the Shaw trial may examine the autopsy photographs and X-Rays of John F. Kennedy now sealed in the National Archives.
Prices declined in moderately active trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

When Thailand's military rulers promulgated a new constitution last June, the leader of the opposition Democratic party described it as "a set of false teeth -- not very real but with some bite." Results of elections for a National Assembly this week tend to bear out this moderately cynical assessment of a reform that gilds an eleven-year-old military dictatorship with a democratic veneer.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 14 -- The executive board of the Maritime Trades Department of the labor federation approved today a legislative program that calls for new ships for the unsubsidized segment of the United States fleet and for the reconstitution of the Maritime Administration as an independent agency.

VIENNA, Feb. 14 -- Vienna society danced until dawn today at the traditional State Opera Ball, the 191st scheduled affair of the 1969 Fasching, or pre-Lenten season, that offers balls for aristocrats as well as for butchers and bakers and candlestick makers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Nixon took another legal step today to remove from the books the decisions of President Johnson on international airline routes across the Pacific.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 14 (Reuters) -- The governing Unionist party issued an election manifesto today, pledging efforts to settle the Roman Catholic-Protestant differences that have been the source of strife in the province in recent months.
The dock strike resulted last month in a 50 per cent drop in local customs collections, compared with January, 1968.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay of the Air Force, retired, filed a $5.2-million suit today against the company that he said had dismissed him when he ran for Vice President on the American Independent party ticket headed by former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

For winning the American Football League championship and then the Super Bowl, each of the New York Jets earned $22,007.91. Player shares for the Baltimore Colts, National League champions and Super Bowl losers, amounted to $16,765.58.
Strange things happen when Eddie Harris plays his saxophone.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 14 -- Fighting in the Vietnam war remained at a low level for the last 24 hours, according to allied military reports. Most of the action took place in Quangtri Province, where several battalions of the United States Third Marine Division are engaged in a search-and-clear operation near the Laotian border.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers summoned Fernando Berckemeyer, the Peruvian Ambassador, to the State Department today to express "serious concern" over the attack on American fishing boats off Peru.

Both the General Host Corporation and the Greyhound Corporation were claiming victories of sorts last night in their contest for control of Armour Co. But the issue will come to a head next Friday at the meat packer's annual meeting.
The new-issue market continued to attract investors this week, despite the fact that no food-franchising or health-care concerns went public.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 14 -- The Princeton team bus arrived late for tonight's game against Yale, but Jeff Petrie, the Tigers' 6 - foot - 3 - inch sharpshooter, didn't waste any time getting to work.

YONKERS, Feb. 14 -- Position, post position, that is, may not mean everything in harness racing, but being close to the rail helps, as Sampson Knight proved tonight in winning the Class A-2, one-mile race, the feature at Yonkers Raceway.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 14 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan acceded today to two of the three demands of the opposition as violence erupted against his 10-year-old regime throughout much of Pakistan.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Paul Goldsmith, seasoned stock car driver from Munster, Ind., set a qualifying record of 189.897 miles an hour at the Daytona International Speedway today.

The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, one of the nation's largest banks, and the Continental Corporation, one of the largest fire and casualty insurers, may be close to an agreement on a merger, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

THE cooking course is one of the seven available and it consists of 16 lessons. By the end of Lesson IX, the student -- who might be as young as 17 and preparing for matrimony or as old as 70 and looking for something to occupy the time -- is allowed to bake an apple pie to impress the folks at home.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Radical students ended their 16-day occupation of the University of Chicago administration building in midafternoon today after their leaders conceded the demonstration had failed.

HONG KONG, Feb. 14 -- Lin Piao, deputy of Mao Tse-tung, chairman of the Chinese Communist party, renewed yesterday China's support of the Vietcong and predicted Vietcong victory against "U.S. imperialist aggression" in the Vietnam war.

A MEMO written by an authoritative observer was circulated in Wall Street this week suggesting that if the Congress followed through on planned legislation to curb surprise take-overs, several hotly contested, but nearly completed, mergers would never go through.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Dr. William Haddon Jr., who developed the Government's program of automobile safety standards, resigned today as administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Bureau.
" I'm just delivering messages for the author," said Arthur Miller to explain his presence on the stage of the 46th Street Theater.

LIKE a stable tip circulating through a race track, the rumor about the Big Giveaway has galloped from one end of Kentucky to the other. Nobody knows specifically who started it, but nearly everybody in the horsey set is talking about it.
I was much interested in the Jan. 31 news article "Racial Diversity Unsettles Wesleyan.''

RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., Feb. 14 -- Lance Alworth, Star flanker of the San Diego Chargers scored three eagles on handicap as he and Jim Davenport of the San Francisco Giants took a two-shot lead with a net 62 in the opening round of the $30,000 third annual American Airlines Astrojet golf tourney.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 14 (UPI) -- The Navy court of inquiry into the North Koreans' capture of the Pueblo switched today to the East Coast so that the five admirals on the court could inspect another intelligence ship.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Joseph Fiestmantl and Manfred Schmid, both of Austria, finished 1-2 in the men's single luge at Lake Placid today. They they won the two-man event in under a minute.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 -- In May of 1964, Emile Zola Berman, carrying a briefcase and a pair of small, white sneakers, headed south for Alexandria, La.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court today to force privately operated recreation groups to admit Negroes if such organizations are not bona fide clubs.

TORONTO, Feb. 14 -- Willie Davenport, who is setting some sort of record for records, broke the world indoor record for the 50-yard high hurdles tonight in the seventh annual Toronto Telegram-Maple Leaf games. His time of 5.8 seconds took a tenth of a second off the mark he shared with Hayes Jones.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -The former wife of Harry J. Sonneborn, retired president of the McDonald Corporation, nationwide hamburger drive-in chain, has filed suit for $20million damages from Mr. Sonneborn for allegedly defrauding her in their divorce settlement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Zeppo, one of the Four Marx Brothers, is co-inventor of a double wristwatch that checks on the wearer's heart. If something goes wrong, an alarm sounds. The retired actor, whose full name is Herbert Zeppo Marx, and Albert D. Herman, an engineer and fellow Californian, were granted Patent 3,426,747 this week.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 14 -The merger of Nassau's three town highway departments with the County Department of Public Works was proposed today by County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson to help in future snow emergencies.

FOR its third and last program of its current season -- which ends tomorrow at the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse, the Murray Louis Dance Company is giving the world premier of "Intersection." This is a work that, like "Proximities," seen in the first week, had been commissioned by the National Endowment for the Arts.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city was re-examining all its "major snow removal practices and procedures" and was investigating charges of "misconduct" in connection with snow clearance in eastern Queens.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city would provide free of charge 100,000 30-gallon plastic hags in which garbage may be placed until it can be collected by the Department of Sanitation.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 14 -- Australian health and law enforcemen authorities decided today to increase penalties for dealing in narcotics and establish a nationwide drug control committee.

The main event in boxing was held at Felt Forum last night. But for most of the 1,000-yard run in Madison Square Garden, Marty Liquori was being "bounced around" like one of the boys.

Breaking the strange silence of the airlines on this week's debacle at Kennedy Airport, Pan American World Airways has taken a useful initiative toward preventing a repetition. Your Feb. 10 editorial remarks on rent controls have long wanted saying by others than tenant and landlord.
Howard S. Turner, president and chief executive officer of the Turner Construction Company, New York, has been elected a director of the GAF Corporation.

BERLIN, Feb. 14 -- Heinz Felfe, by all accounts the most effective Soviet agent ever known to operate in West Germany, was exchanged today for three students who had been convicted by the Russians as intelligence agents.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A research team at Stanford University Medical Center in California has reported an association between the use of oral contraceptive pills and high blood pressure.

MEMPHIS, Feb. 14 (UPI) -Defense lawyers for James Earl Ray, charged with the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., reported problems today in gathering documents and evidence and obtained a second delay -- this one for 34 days -of the trial.

After a sharp drop on Thursday, silver futures recovered about half of their decline yesterday in another session marked by heavy trading. On Thursday 4,190 contracts changed hands. Volume yesterday ran about 5,400 contracts.

With a swat-and-swerve style, Juarez De Lima of Brazil projected himself as a potential middleweight challenger with a 10-round split decision over Bennie Briscoe of Philadelphia last night at the Felt Forum.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges have issued their latest insiders' lists. They show changes in ownership by major stockholders, directors or officers of listed companies.
MONTREAL, Feb. 14 -- Campus confrontations and racial conflict have come to Canada's universities.
TEPOZTLAN, Mexico -- The February sun in Tepoztlan is friendly rather than aggressive.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Jack P. F. Gremillion, Louisiana's Attorney General, was indicted today on a charge of fraud and conspiracy in the bankruptcy of a New Orleans financial corporation.

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 14 (AP) -- A $600,000 lawsuit has been filed against Brazos Tenth Street Company, which has been linked to former President Lyndon B. Johnson.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Fe 14 -- Local officials from this scenic coastal area, which is still fighting the devastating effects of a leaking oil well six miles offshore, pleaded with a Congressional subcommittee today for an end to oil exploration in the vicinity.

MIAMI, Feb. 14 -- A number of "turf powerhouses" will compete in the $69,100 Bougainvillea Handicap at Hialeah tomorrow. In the field of 15 named overnight for the mileand-three-sixteenths grass test, there are such strong horses as Fort Marcy of the Rokeby Stable, Gustave Ring's Czar Alexander, the Tartan Stable's Ruffled Feathers, the Fourth Estate's War Censor and Robert Lehman's Flit-to.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 -- A former Dallas, Tex., deputy sheriff testified at the Clay L. Shaw conspiracy trial today that he had seen Lee Harvey Oswald leave the scene of President Kennedy's murder in a green Rambler station wagon shortly after the shots that killed the President were fired.

MOSCOW, Feb. 10 -- Nothing is sacred, not even the memory of Stalinist forcedlabor camps, in a riotous, irreverent Soviet comedy film that had its premiere before an audience of 8,000 people in the Sports Palace in Moscow last weekend.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -Dr. Eugene S. Callender, New York City's deputy housing and development administrator, said today that he was considering an offer to become an Assistant Secretary of Labor in the Nixon Administration.

Three separate fires yesterday killed a woman and child, and badly damaged a four-story Jewish religious school in Brooklyn.

The Norfolk Western Railway announced yesterday that its consolidated system net income last year was $77,831,684, equal to $8.47 a common share, up from $71,519,858, or $7.80 a share in 1967. The figures for both years are revised from those issued by the carrier last month.

THE tragedy of child abuse was intelligently and movingly studied last night on National Educational Television's "N.E.T. Journal" on Channel 13. The Air Force said yesterday that its F-111 attack plane, beset by technical and political troubles since its inception, had encountered a new problem in a ground test last week.

FLAMINGO, Fla., Feb. 10 -Those who have seen a massive, gleaming tarpon hurtle out of the water in a shower of spray, shaking his great head in an effort to rid himself of the hook, are almost as much captured as captor.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 17 -An official meeting of King Hussein and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, at the palace in the Jordanian capital of Amman yesterday appears to have opened a new and more cordial relationship between the Jordanian Government and the Palestinian commandos.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- G. Warren Nutter, a former official of the Central Intelligence Agency, who was an aide to Senator Barry Goldwater iin the 1964 Presidential campaign, is under consideration for the key position of Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Affairs.

President Nixon's impending trip across the Atlantic has just brought him some excellent public advice from a distinguished European expert. That advice centers on the necessity for convincing America's European allies that he can keep strategic and political issues separate in his negotiations with the Soviet Union.
ATHENS, Feb. 17 -- The Athens regime granted the Orthodox Church of Greece today a new charter that goes far toward empowering it to run its own affairs.

Thanks to the Negro Ensemble Company, which sponsored last night's debut of the Louis Johnson Dance Theater at the St. Marks Playhouse, a dance theater that is really a dance theater has finally come into being.

SAN CLEMENTE ISLAND, Calif., Feb. 17 -- An aquanaut of Project Sealab 3 died today, apparently of a heart attack, while working on the continental shelf 600 feet beneath the Pacific Ocean on the first day of the scheduled 60-day man-in-the-sea experiment.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Jack Bodell, Britain's second-ranked heavyweight, won by disqualification from Roosevelt Eddie of New York in the first round tonight as the Briton sat on the canvas.

Since he won the prestigious Olympic decathlon in Mexico City, Bill Toomey's most conspicuous public achievement has been in defeat. He appeared on the network television show, "The Dating Game," and lost the girl.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Theodore R. Kupferman, a former Representative, was appointed to the State Supreme Court today by Governor Rockefeller. Confirmation of the appointment by the State Senate is considered but a formality.

Novels on social and political topics, which one prominent editor calls "faction," are in again. And memoirs, once considered the "old ladies'' of book publishing, are the current swingers on the best-seller lists.

" I told you so, I told you so," old-line advocates of computer time sharing are joyfully saying these days as the long-researched data processing technique has turned into a real and booming business.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A Federal judge ordered the director of the National Archives today to produce the autopsy X-rays and photographs of President Kennedy at the Clay Shaw conspiracy trial in New Orleans.

CORONADO, Calif., Feb. 17 --A thin, prematurely grayhaired Navy officer spoke quietly today of the hours that North Korean soldiers had beaten, kicked and tormented him into signing a false confession that the U.S.S. Pueblo was spying in North Korean territorial waters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Hughes Tool Company and Air West, Inc., jointly asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to approve an interim financing plan to provide the airline with funds at least through March 31.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--Governor Rockefeller has accepted an invitation from President Nixon to undertake a series of trips to Latin America.
HONOLULU, Feb. 17 -- More than 9,000 sugar workers began shutting down operations on 23 plantations today after calling Hawaii's first full-scale sugar strike since 1958.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -On the first day of the threeday 11th annual government affairs conference, the 350 boys and girls of the American Advertising Federation heard mostly from friends of the business.

It is 4667, the Year of the Chicken, or the Year of the Rooster if one chooses to use the male designation instead of the generic term for the Chinese Lunar New Year symbol. The Year of the Monkey ended, unmourned, at midnight Sunday.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia Feb. 17 (AP) -- Gertrud Gabl of Austria won the giant slalom today in the Grand Prix of Slovakia ski competition and overtook the injured Annie Famose of France in the women's World Cup standing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -Proponents of mine safety reforms called on the Nixon Administration today to reappoint John F. O'Leary, one of the Government's strongest advocates of strict enforcement of health and safety regulations, as director of the United States Bureau of Mines.

A. G. Edwards Sons, a leading brokerage house pennalized recently by the National Association of Securities Dealers, issued a statement yesterday, noting that it would be open for business throughout the days covered by its temporary suspension from N.A.S.D. membership.

KARACHI, PAKISTAN, Feb. 17 -- Zulfikar Ali Bhutto returned to the political wars here today, searching for a way to regain his place at the head of the movement that has shaken the regime of President Mohammad Ayub Khan.

The need for effective action to halt gouging in uncontrolled apartments is unchallenged. Acceptance by the Real Estate Industry Committee of Mayor Lindsay's proposal for a 21-day freeze on further increases provides a breathing space for evolving the fairest and most constructive remedy.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 18 (Tuesday) (AP) -- The New York Nets, by a coin flip, won the rights to Lew Alcinder of U.C.L.A. and selected him in a secret American Basketball Association draft, highly informed sources disclosed today.

TRENTON, Feb. 17 -- The Republican-dominated Legislature refused today to withdraw a proposed constitutional amendment that Gov. Richard J. Hughes contends would "strip the people of New Jersey" of 400 square miles of tidal marsh and meadowland.

Refusing to "break clean and wrestle," Bruno Sammartino of Abruzzi, Italy, and Killer Kowalski of Detroit were disqualified last night in the feature professional wrestling event at Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 9,639.

But for a bouquet of flowers, three welcoming posters and a small reception committee, the Dynamo-Kiev soccer team would have slipped unnoticed through New York's Kennedy Airport en route to California yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 17 -- A woman and a man will go on trial in different courts here this week, probably Wednesday, accused of having spread defamatory concoctions against the Soviet state, according to sources close to the defendants.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 17 -- With a brief visit here by Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, speculation grew today that an indemnification dispute between a Belgian mining company and the Congo might be near settlement.

The executive committee of Columbia University's faculty proposed yesterday the creation of a senate representing students and most other segments of the university to act with the board of trustees in setting policy.

IN the unlikely event that you haven't heard, Philip Roth's third novel and fourth book, "Portnoy's Complaint," takes the form of a marathon pre-psychoanalytic monologue -- perhaps four or five of those preliminary sessions (strung end to end) in which the patient describes what's bothering him and sketches in his history, while the analyst listens silently.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -From Tet to Tet almost everything here has changed except the central question surrounding the war in Vietnam: Which side is getting stronger with the passage of time?
THE stock market has to be pretty heavy not to get a lift from The Outlook, the investment advisory report put out each Monday under the logo of Standard Poors.

Forget all about arithmetic, dollar signs and complicated benefit formulas if you want to grasp the essence of the struggle between the baseball players and club owners, a struggle that took a turn for the worse yesterday.

Yost, the United States delegate, shortly after the Soviet Union circulated here an official note of protest against West Germany's plans to elect a new president in West Berlin March 5.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Feb. 17--The charter of a Roman Catholic club at the State Agricultural and Technical College here was suspended today because club members attended a mass on the campus yesterday in violation of State University rules.

A Brooklyn real-estate dealer in whose behalf Carmine Lombardozzi, reputed "money mover" for the Mafia, testified as a character witness, failed yesterday to win reinstatement of his broker's license, which had been revoked in 1965 for improper business practices.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 (Reuters) -- The mutiny trial of four young soldiers was temporarily halted today when three were granted a postponement and the fourth was granted permission to be tried elsewhere.
A Federal Court rejected yesterday a broad attack on the constitutionality of the state law governing character and fitness requisites for applicants for the bar.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The betting odds have shifted back and forth in the last week and chances are they will be about even when Teo Cruz of the Dominican Republic defends his lightweight title against Mando Ramos of LongBeach, Calif., tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Nixon invaded his wife's White House luncheon today for Cabinet wives and the women's press corps to deliver what may or may not be the last word on Willie Mae Rogers, his very temporary Consultant on Consumer Affairs.

The Mobile City Hall, a large orange and blue van that liberally offers brochures about the city's services and quiet sympathy and advice about its failures, arrived at an overpass by a crowded intersection in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn at noon yesterday and began welcoming complaints.

PARIS Feb. 17 -- The price of gold rose to a new high in Paris today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The 10 winners of the first American College Theater Festival competition were announced today by the American National Theater and Academy.
ROME, Feb. 17 -- Pope Paul VI rejected strongly today the idea of a "secularized" priesthood, working in the world almost as laymen, as a means for refilling empty churches.
After a couple of weeks of sluggishness and mild weakness, prices on the American Stock Exchange decisively declined yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- All new Presidents need to establish their own style in the White House, to put their personal stamp on an office that various predecessors have shaped to other ideas and circumstances.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Some high Administration officials who favor deployment of a missile defense around the nation are nonetheless seriously asking whether it need be as large as currently planned.

PLAYERS who invariably "cover an honor with an honor" are a regular source of profit to their opponents. The beleaguered bond market -- reacting to cross-currents of news, rumor and technical forces -- declined yesterday, pushing interest rates still higher.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- What is New York City like? It is a young city -- the average age is 35 -- and the streets are alive with "impeccable young businessmen and pretty girls with swinging hair." And a foreign tourist can see it all for less than $17 a day.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 18 -- Nathan M. Pusey, the president of Harvard University, warned today against assaults by students on academic freedom. He said that such assaults had accompanied disruptive campus protests.

RAFAEL FRUHBECK DE BURGOS is another of those conductors whose recordings have made them known here well in advance of his New York debut. He conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Philharmonic Hall.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Wednesday, Feb. 19 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan's talks with his opponents on their demannd for the return of parliamentary democracy were postponed early today after four leading opposition figures refused to attend.

CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 18 (AP) -- One of three prisoners was recaptured today following their escape from Camden County Jail during what the warden called a "riot" that followed the setting of a fire last night.

The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the state's largest bank holding company, announced yesterday that it would apply to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of the giant company, whose subsidiaries have deposits of $7.1-billion, had previously traded over-the-counter.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Bob Bailey, expected to be the regular right fielder for the Montreal Expos, reported to camp today and worked out briefly.

READING, Pa., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Leland S. MacPhail 3d, 27-year-old member of the noted baseball family, was killed today in an auto crash.

Share prices slipped sharply on the London stock market yesterday, sending key indexes to their lowest levels of the year.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange moved lower along a broad front yesterday for the second session in a row to produce a pronounced crack in the market stalemate of recent weeks.

Seiji Ozawa and Gunther Schuller will share the artistic directorship of the Tanglewood musical organization beginning in 1970, the trustees of the Boston Symphony Orchestra announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 18 -- East Germany closed a main checkpoint on the Autobahn from West Germany to West Berlin for two hours to all westbound traffic today and warned that it would conduct blasting operations to demolish a Soviet war memorial beside the highway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the milk industry called today for expanding a special school milk program for children, rather than dismantling it as proposed by former President Lyndon B. Johnson.
The United States economy will require a prolonged period of Government restraint if inflation is to be brought under

THE National Geographic Society special on Australia last night on the Columbia Broadcasting System was superficial and only sporadically interesting. Many Americans have son who have written home about pleasant military leaves in Australia, and it is natural to be curious about a land and people whose history is so much like our own.

BOBBY HULL eyed the steak with the greed of a starving man -- which he was. For six weeks the scoring dynamo of the Chicago Black Hawks had been on a liquid diet but now the wires had been removed from his broken jaw and at long last he would be able to have solid food.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 18 -- Perched about this page are drawings by Yale's Prof. Robert Jay Lifton of what he calls "the absurd underbelly" of his work."

PARIS -- President Nixon will find that his publicly expressed interest in international monetary reform as a subject for "immediate discussion" and of "major concern" that requires "new approaches" is sympathetically echoed by General de Gaulle.
National Airlines has leased space for its regional sales and reservations headquarters in a building where the Railway Express Agency once stabled its horses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 - "I'll bet Mayo knows." That sentence ran like a refrain through a famous Congressional hearing a decade ago when Democratic members of the Senate Finance Committee put on trial the economic and financial policies of the Eisenhower Ad ministration.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 18 -- Yakov A. Malik, the Soviet Union's chief delegate, today rejected the Nixon Administration's attempt to establish "linkage" between various East-West issues as a basis for United States-Soviet negotiations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- White House sources disclosed today that President Nixon had written President de Gaulle a personal letter "within the last few days."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- "Capitalist elements" in South Vietnam "constitute a primary source of financial support for the Vietcong," according to a report from the Stanford Research Institute to a House watchdog committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Babies who survive the birth defects caused by rubella (German measles) may often be able to adjust better to life than doctors would expect, it was indicated today.
Justice Tom C. Clark, who retired from the United States Supreme Court in 1967, presided yesterday in the United States Court of Appeals at Foley Square and found the job to his liking.

The election of Dr. Clifford C. Davis, chemist and business executive, to the board of the Freedom National Bank, was announced yesterday. He fills a vacancy created when Councilman Herbert Evans, a board member, was elected judge of the Civil Court of the City of New York.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that the countries of Latin America had been badly neglected by the United States.
WASHINGTGON, Feb. 18 -- Students seized the law school building at Howard University here today and chained the doors.

Should the biggest seller in a market, General Motors, for example, receive special help from the Government to assure that prices won't collapse until it gets all of its production for a model year sold?

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 -- The provost of the University of Pennsylvania announced today that he "is prepared to cancel classes in the fulltime undergraduate schools on March 4 in response to a request from members of the faculty and administration" that the day be set aside for an examination of the role of the university in American society, according to a story scheduled to appear in tomorrow's edition of the campus newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Columbia Broadcasting System has denied that one of its television stations deliberately staged a marijuana party for a documentary report, and sharply criticized the Federal examiner who said it did.

Almost unbelieving, another capacity crowd of 19,500 at Madison Square Garden learned last night that streaks always end and that, even more unbelievable, the New York Knickerbockers do not always win.

Your Feb. 11 editorial ["Full-Time A.I.D. Job"] commending the choice of Dr. John A. Hannah to head the Agency for International Development is an affront to your readers. Dr. Hannah's staff at Michigan State University were the sloppy architects of our Vietnam disaster.

The caustic exchange between Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay over the progress of the city's water pollution control program is another dismaying example of the continuing friction between the two leaders -- a friction that hurts the interests of both city and state.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 18 -- Israeli officials tonight condemned the attack against an El Al airliner at the Zurich airport and suggested that the terrorists had drawn encouragement from the "climate of forgiveness" that surrounded the last one.

The political crisis that forced Pakistan's President Ayub Khan to agree to meet with opposition leaders to discuss constitutional reforms -- a meeting now postponed -- raises some fundamental questions for United States policymakers who have held up Pakistan as a model for the developing world.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- A crisis in relations among the countries of Western Europe took a new and confusing turn late tonight.
BONN, Feb. 18 -- The East German regime has advised West German businessmen that they are welcome at the Leipzig Fair next month, regardless of tensions over Berlin, it was disclosed today.
The Circle in the Square's Broadway experiment at Henry Miller's Theater has failed. The nonprofit group's lease on the 938-seat house has been canceled to permit movies to be shown.

Governor Rockefeller's proposed cutback in the formulas that determine the amount of financial aid municipalities get from the state is an "invitation to economic disaster," John M. Leavens, executive director of the Citizens Budget Commission, said yesterday.

Is it really neither prudent nor wise to convene the Federal Assembly to elect a new German Federal President in West Berlin on March 5? The affirmative answer in your editorial of Feb. 11 does not include the important fact that, with the exception of the first time, such elections have always taken place in Berlin: 1954, 1959, and 1964, and that therefore the fourth election can hardly be called a provocation.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Governor Rockefeller urged the Legislature today to approve bills that would prevent the indiscriminate take-over of banks and insurance companies by conglomerate companies -- the rapidly growing giants of business.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 18 -- Among the items considered here today by a Congressional inquiry on consumer problems was Mrs. Alibina DeMassin's automobile, which a repairman dismantled and refused to put back together, and Mrs. Stephen Mangione's color television set, which does not work.

ZURICH, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Leaflets found near the ambush site and bearing the imprint of the Liberation Front said the raid was aimed at what it called the military personnel, "the pilots," aboard the airliner. The leaflets were in German, the language spoken in the Zurich area.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- A trashman's lot is a happy one as long as he can rummage through the trash.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18 -- Vietcong and North Vietnamese attacks on allied positions continued during the last 24 hours although the enemy's week-long Lunar New Year truce was in only its third day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (Reuters) -- The State Department tonight condemned and deplored a terrorist attack on an Israeli airliner at Zurich airport as a senseless act.

By overriding its Rules Committee and assuring adequate funding for an investigation of hunger in America, the Senate gave hope yesterday that Congress may finally act to end the cruel paradox of malnutrition in this land fat with agricultural surpluses.

CAIRO, Feb. 18 -- The Egyptian Government announced today that it would put two Egyptian journalists on trial on charges of spying for Israel. If convicted, the accused could be sentenced to death by hanging.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- A trashman's lot is a happy one as long as he can rummage through the trash.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18 -- Vietcong and North Vietnamese attacks on allied positions continued during the last 24 hours although the enemy's week-long Lunar New Year truce was in only its third day.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 18 (UPI) -- Bill Shoemaker scored the first stakes victory of his riding comeback today when he guided the favored Inverness Drive to a 1 1/2-length triumph in the $24,700 Santa Catalina Stakes for 3-year-olds at Santa Anita.

THE City Center Joffrey Ballet is back in town, ensconced in its home at the New York City Center, and with a number of new productions and a number of new dancers. The opening program last night began, as has become a Joffrey ritual, with Gerald Arpino's "Viva Vivaldi!," continued with Flemming Flindt's "The Lesson" and ended with the first of the season's new productions, Frederick Ashton's "Facade."
Three former employes of the Neighborhood Youth Corps here were indicted yesterday for their alleged part in the theft last summer of $529,737 in Youth Corps funds.

THE Sports Car Club of America still is beset with problems that were not resolved in last September's reorganization. John Bishop has just resigned as executive director, a position in which for the last six years he helped develop the S.C.C.A. into the United States' prim ary sanctioning body for both professional and amateur road racing.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Atlantic Fleet headquarters said today the submarine Chipper experienced last week a "control casualty" that sent her plunging toward the bottom of the ocean while operating off the coast of Cuba.

A program called "New Dimensions in Jazz" at the Whitney Museum of American Art last night kept one listener on tenterhooks waiting for the musicians to remove their formal masks and reveal themselves as jazzmen.

FOR an illustration of the difference between a polemic and a play, no one need venture any farther off Broadway than the Blackfriars Theater at 320 West 57th Street, where the subject under attack is a young priest questioning the Christianity of today's Roman Catholic Church.

MIAMI, Feb. 18 -- Golden Or shattered the hopes of the odds-on players in the crowd of 18,506 at Hialeah today. Competing in the main event of seven furlongs, Golden Or, owned by Wallace Karutz, scored over the Meadow Stable's heavily backed Queen's Double, with Li'l Puss next in the field of seven 3-year-old fillies.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The State Senate today made SEEK students liable to punishment under the terms of a bill passed last week that would ban state financial aid to college students convicted of crimes "committed on the premises of any college."
CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Barbara Jo Rubin became today the first woman to be licensed as a jockey in West Virginia in the 35 years that racing has been conducted in this state.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex. -- Tacked on the wall of the Inner City Apostolate were four new slips from hungry Mexican-American families asking for food.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Arab commandos of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine said today that they were responsible for the attack at the Zurich airport.

Disappointed potato futures traders sold enough contracts yesterday to lower prices quite a bit. The May contract closed at $3.05-$3.07 a hundred pounds, down from $3.25 in heavy trading of 4,097 contracts. This represented more than 75 per cent of the day's volume.

The frustrations reported by high police officers in their efforts to rid the Times Square area of muggers and derelicts lend themselves to treatment by Mayor Lindsay's pioneering Criminal Justice Coordinating Council.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 18 -- Mayor Lindsay of New York was received warmly at a Republican fund-raising dinner here today, despite warnings by some Republicans that he was about as welcome in Indiana as "a case of political Hong Kong flu."

H. Prentice Browning, president and former chief executive officer of the American Fletcher National Bank and Trust Company of Indianapolis -- one of the leading banks in the Middle West -- resigned from his positions yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams, of Delaware, long noted as a campaigner against fraud and corruption in public service, announced today he would retire from Congress when his present term ends next year.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Peru's Foreign Minister today denied published reports that he viewed the signing of a commercial agreement with the Soviet Union as the end of an era in which Peruvian trade was channeled in only one direction.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 18 -- Mayor Lindsay of New York was received warmly at a Republican fund-raising dinner here today, despite warnings by some Republicans that he was about as welcome in Indiana as "a case of political Hong Kong flu."

H. Prentice Browning, president and former chief executive officer of the American Fletcher National Bank and Trust Company of Indianapolis -- one of the leading banks in the Middle West -- resigned from his positions yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- The Government announced today it would drop prosecution of five major fertilizer manufacturers and a trade association, which it said had agreed to stop fixing prices of fertilizer sold under the United States foreign aid program.
Anonymous telephone calls to United Arab Airlines and the United Arab Republic tourist offices in New York threatened bomb attacks on their premises yesterday, but no attack occurred.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -"I'm on a selling trip," Governor Rockefeller said today as he pressed his appeal for a redistribution of Federal tax revenue to head off "an emerging fiscal crisis in this Federal system."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -Senator Edward M. Kennedy suggested today that the Defense Department was attempting to "mollify" critics of a missile defense program by pretending to conduct an exhaustive review of the Sentinel program.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A bipartisan committee of the Legislature charged today that the Public Service Commission's control over power utilities and the telephone industry was "a fiasco" that cost consumers millions of dollars a year.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Classes went on today as demonstrators took up positions in the University of Pennsylvania's College Hall, the school's administration building.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (UPI) -A request for an open, mass hearing was denied today by a special faculty disciplinary committee appointed to deal with students accused of staging a sit-in at the University of Chicago's administration building.
A bright new type of newsstand that is spacious and easy to operate was displayed yesterday at Gimbels as part of its New York Festival.
Ray McIntyre, a harpsichordist who teaches at Goddard College in Vermont, made his second New York appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. He made his local debut a year ago.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Ivan B. (Ivy) Williamson, a long-time director of athletics at the University of Wisconsin, died tonight after falling in his Maple Bluff home.

The election of Richard H. Griebel as president, chief executive officer and a member of the executive committee of the board of Lehigh Valley Industries, Inc., a diversified company, was announced yesterday.
American Airlines made public yesterday a "petition of thanks" signed by 300 persons who had been stranded in its terminal at Kennedy International Airport in last week's snowstorm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission told Congress today that only immediate Government action would prevent the demise of national railway passenger service. In its annual report, the commission said that only 575 passenger trains were now operating, compared to 1,448 a decade ago.
MANHATTAN'S CHELSEA section, latest frontier of the avant-garde, is acquiring a spiffy new look and a mellow atmosphere not unlike its London namesake.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 19 -- The Cincinnati Royals jumped to an early lead against the New York Knickerbockers tonight and then held off a last-quarter Knick rally to down the New Yorkers, 110-100, before a crowd of 4,109 at Cincinnati Garden.

Col. Bernt Balchen, polar explorer and flier, is circulating a paper among polar specialists proposing that the Arctic pack ice is thinning and that the ocean at the North Pole may become an open sea within a decade or two.

In an announcement that provoked "hundreds" of telephoned protests, season-ticket subscribers of the New York Jets were notified yesterday of an increase in prices for the world champions' seven American Football League games in 1969 at Shea Stadium.

THE recent Anglo-Dutch match, played in Flushing, South Netherlands, was a victory for the Dutch, 12-8. In the double round, ten-manteam match, R. D. Keene of England saved face and gained the point by a hardearned victory over J. Donner, the only grandmaster in the pairings.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 19 -David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said today that the Nixon Administration feels as strongly as the Johnson Administration about keeping the price of gold at $35 an ounce.

HONG KONG, Feb. 19 -- The Chinese Communists followed up their decision to cancel talks in Warsaw with the United States with a new attack today on President Nixon and the American "monopoly-capitalist" system of government.
BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Militants hurled rocks, bottles and stench bombs at the police today at the University of California.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -From the public actions and the private talk of President Nixon and his associates it is now possible to get a reasonably good impression of this Administration's direction in several important domestic areas.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Howard University students relinquished the law school building early today after a Federal marshal read them a temporary court injunction ordering them out.
BORDEAUX, France, Feb. 19 (Reuters) -- Angry women tried today to lynch the mother of two children who were shot and killed by their father Monday after a nine-day police siege.

BEEHIVE COVE, ST. JOHN, V. I., Feb. 19 -- The Tektite man-beneath-the-sea project settled into a full day of scientific work today with neighboring fish, microbes and the aquanauts themselves coming under observation.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- A rumor that Marine guards at the United States Embassy will don Revolutionary War costumes for the Washington's Birthday holiday Sunday seemed to have been knocked into a cocked hat today.

DYNAMO KIEV, the first Soviet soccer team to come to this country, is presently ensconced in San Francisco, preparing for a match next Sunday with the California Clippers. Dynamo Kiev, the national champion for the past three years and a major contributor of players to the all-Union squad, bears one of the most glorious names in all of sports. Dynamo Kiev is known in the Soviet Union as the team that chose death before defeat.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 -Aides to District Attorney Jim Garrison moved tonight for a mistrial in the case of Clay L. Shaw after the judge said he did not believe one of the state witnesses and refused to allow him to testify.

The game between New York University and Notre Dame, once the glamour event of New York's basketball season, comes up at Madison Square Garden tonight as a match between teams with renewed tournament hopes after some "down" years.
The Most Rev. Terence J. Cooke, Archbishop of New York, has been elected a trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He is the first clergyman on the board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The mantel clock went tick-tock, tick-tock, tick-tock. Mildred sat in the kidney-shaped chair reading the paper. Ernest hung his coat in the closet and sat in the egg-shaped chair, breathing smugly. Tick-tock. Tick-tock.

Oppenheimer Co., one of the financial community's largest stock brokerage and investment banking concerns, has signed a 20-year lease for three floors in the new 50-story skyscraper to be known as 1 New York Plaza along the East River near the Battery.
He is legally blind, but Anthony Cruz, a graduate student at New York University, insists that he is qualified to teach history in the city's public schools.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- "It's going to mean less and less money for what we don't have enough money for right now," said Mrs. Joyce Burson, a welfare mother of four daughters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy said today that the Government would persist in its economic policy of "firm restraint" long enough to see "unmistakable signs that we are headed back on a noninflationary path."

MIAMI, Feb. 19 -- Arts and Letters earned his degree as a stakes performer today. The Virginia-bred colt owned by Paul Mellon's Rokeby Stable rallied in the stretch to win the $32,300 Everglades for 3year-olds, beating Steven Wilson's Top Knight by three lengths.

Several members of the City Planning Commission's professional staff charged at a public hearing yesterday that the commission had disregarded planners' findings and had yielded to powerful "real estate speculators" in proposing to rezone sections of Manhattan for luxury housing.

President Nixon has chosen one of the nation's largest home builders to be an Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and to take the job of Philip N. Brownstein, the present Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, usually reliable sources said last night.

Chief Justice Earl Warren has accepted the chairmanship of the International Board of Overseers of the International Center for the Advancement of Peace, now nearing completion on Mount Scopus in jerusalem.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -Following are excerpts from President Nixon's message to Congress today on the Economic Opportunity Act:
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, Feb. 20 -- Seven persons convicted as spies for Israel were executed in Baghdad, Iraq, at dawn today and their bodies were put on public display.

The president of the newly formed McCall Publishing Company announced yesterday that the publisher of McCall's magazine, which has been losing advertising pages, has resigned and has been replaced by the publisher of Redbook, which has been showing steady gains.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -There was an explosion, and then a fire. Historic collections of Ukrainian and Jewish archives were destroyed as the blaze swept through a 17thcentury monastery library in Kiev, capital of the Soviet Ukraine.

The Board of Education yesterday rejected a resolution by its vice president, the Rev. Milton A. Galamison, that it call for the resignation of Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan and his chief deputy, Dr. Nathan Brown.

Ashes from the burning of alleged "racist" church-school literature were applied to the foreheads of about 20 demonstrators yesterday in front of the Episcopal Church Center at Second Avenue and 43d Street.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 19 -There were celebrations today by the families here of two of the guerrillas who attacked an El Al aircraft at Zurich yesterday.
RUTLAND, Vt., Feb. 19 -Ski area operators in this Green Mountain country are strongly contesting a proposal by some of this state's legislators that a tax be placed on the price of lift tickets.

While Peking's decision to call off its Warsaw meeting with the United States undoubtedly was influenced by the defection to this country of its charge d'affaires in Holland, it is reasonable to believe the impetus comes from China's internal factional struggles.
ROOSEVELT, L. I., Feb. 19 -- "Kids are always challenges," David Amram, the composer, believes.

Yassir Arafat, the head of Al Fatah, was quoted again [news story Feb. 5] as having said that he believes only in a military solution to the Middle East problem. Other Arab leaders -those of Syria, Algeria and Iraq -- support this stand, while others are weighing the merits of a "political" over a military solution.

FROM the point of view of the major league club owners, the players have little to complain about in the matter of pensions and benefits, certainly too little to justify a strike. The owners feel this way because they know how much money they have been pouring into the pension plan, and because the benefits players eventually receive are plainly generous.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin said tonight that he hoped to decide tomorrow, after consulting with state and local officials, whether a pilot food program could be instituted in Beaufort and Jasper counties in South Carolina. Widespread malnutrition has been reported there.
The Board of Education last night approved a resolution allowing high school girls to compete in interscholastic sports. Such competition has been banned in New York City since 1916.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 -The last Chairman of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers said today there was "no basis for complacency" that the existing tax surcharge would be extended, despite support from both President Nixon and his predecessor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -The top Federal maritime post, that of Maritime Administrator, will be filled by Andrew E. Gibson, an experienced shipping operator, according to authoritative sources here.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- The right of colleges and universities to expel students for conduct promoting student unrest was upheld today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

The Metropolitan Opera's production of "Die Walkure," so murky visually and so luminous musically in the staging and conducting of Herbert von Karajan, had its fourth performance of the season last night. It was distinguished by the presence in the cast of Theo Adam as Wotan and Josephine Veasey as Fricka, neither of whom had sung in the Wagner opera here before.
A Sanitation Department spokesman said yesterday that by 6 A.M. today every household in the city should have had at least one garbage collection since service was disrupted by the snow 10 days ago.

CORONADO, Calif., Feb. 19 -- The Pueblo's youngest officer buried his face in his hands today and cried before the five admirals conducting the court of inquiry into the capture of the intelligence ship.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 19 -- Each week more than 80 El Al flights leave or arrive at Israel's Lydda Airport near Tel Aviv. Aboard each flight, it now appears, is a man with a gun.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- The Bonn Government was advised today by a group of independent West German political analysts to drop gradually spectacular political activities in West Berlin, such as the controversial plan to elect the West German president there March 5.

POTOMAC, Md., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Blonds resumed their place in the white society of Cabin John Junior High today after a two-day experiment in segregation ran afoul of parental indignation. The test was to have continued all week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -President Nixon has resolved a sharply contested Republican patronage struggle between two of the party's major Congressional figures in favor of Senator John G. Tower of Texas.

The bond market performed yesterday just the way it did on Monday and Tuesday: It went down on conjecture that the prime lending rate of the commercial banks, and perhaps the Federal Reserve's discount rate, too, would be raised.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -President Nixon plans to meet privately with ordinary citizens in all but one of the countries he will visit on his forthcoming European tour, White House sources said today.
VIENNA, Feb. 19 -- Six months after the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia, the authority of the Soviet Union is once more being challenged in Eastern Europe.

Martin S. Ackerman, head of the Curtis Publishing Company, is endeavoring to arrange a meeting with representatives of trustees of the Curtis estate to attempt to resolve their differences, which resulted in one of the trustees suing him last week for fraud.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -President Nixon offered a broad outline of several major domestic themes today as he prescribed some mild and cautious change for the nation's antipoverty efforts.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 19 -- A company of South Vietnamese militia and a team of pacification workers suffered heavy losses in a Vietcong attack on their positions in a hamlet in the Mekong Delta yesterday morning, according to a South Vietnamese military communique.

Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird contends that we will be "hostages" to the Chinese in two years or so when they may have about twenty ICBM's. This idea that we are "hostages" is used by the Pentagon to justify the deployment of the Sentinel antiballistic missile program.
Mayor Lindsay was sternly lectured yesterday before an audience of 150 people at a meeting of the Washington Heights Chamber of Commerce.
The Federal Reserve System has come out swinging against its critics who have been maintaining that its anti-inflationary policy of tight money has been weak and ineffective.

Dr. Raymond J. Saulnier, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the second Eisenhower Administration, forecast yesterday a year of heavy credit demands, high borrowing costs, a further rise in labor costs and a continued squeeze in profits.
Nobody likes trouble, but when it comes it's nice to know that the Internal Revenue Service may often be able to ease the pain with a tax deduction.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The state's highest court, reversing itself because of a United States Supreme Court decision last June, ruled today that Federally chartered banks were immune from state and local sales taxes.

Five New Orleans units of the International Longshoremen's Association were ordered by a Federal judge yesterday to hold a ratification vote tomorrow on contracts that had been accepted by union leaders on Feb. 2 and 3.
Arrests in the Times Square area have reached a total of 532 in 12 days in a continuing intensive drive against crime. Of the total, 76 have resulted in convictions on various charges.

In light of your Feb. 10 editorial ["Rollback on Rents"] on the exorbitant rents in New York City's uncontrolled sector, we would like to draw your attention once again to legislation which we have sponsored in the City Council.
Archbishop Thomas A. Boland of Newark announced the appointment yesterday of two vicars to serve as liaison between the chancery and black and Spanish-speaking Roman Catholics with the archdiocese.
The stock market made a feeble attempt at a rally yesterday morning but suffered a sinking spell in the afternoon finish at its lowest level of the session.

TRENTON, Feb. 19 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes sought a court order today to block a referendum on a constitutional amendment that, he charged, is a "monumental give-away" of the state's claim to about 400 square miles of New Jersey tidal lands.

One of America's foremost aircraft designers asserted yesterday that two new fighter planes the United States now had on the drawing boards could be outmoded by superior Soviet planes long before they fly.
Mrs. Aristotle Onassis saw "The Great White Hope" yesterday and when she was leaving, actresses in the cast shouted to her, "We all love you!" Bless you!"
PARIS, Feb. 19 -- Cyrus R. Vance, a key United States negotiator during the first nine months of the Vietnam talks here, left today with the prediction that the talks would eventually succeed.

IT was a damp evening, and the dampness crept into the piano that Geza Anda played last night in Philharmonic Hail. There was a soggy sound, and there also were some out-of-tune bass notes, especially the allcritical low C with which Schumann's "Davidsbundlertanze" ends.

Manhattan Assemblyman Albert Blumenthal, one of the more studious members of the State Legislature and little given to hyperbole, calls policies and procedures for protecting the public's interest in utility rate-setting cases "a fiasco." That harsh -- but by no means surprising -- assessment stems from months of investigation as head of a joint legislative committee.

Tired after an opening period of stick-swinging and head-bumping, slowed by soft ice and high humidity, the Rangers and Detroit Red Wings gratefully took a 1-1 tie last night at Madison Square Garden.

White Consolidated Industries, Inc., filed suit in Delaware Chancery Court in Wilmington asking that the acquisition of the Standard Steel Corporation, of Los Angeles, by the Allis Chalmers Manufacturing Company be rescinded.
Morton D. Weiner resigned yesterday as president of Avnet, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -President Nixon and the Soviet leadership have opened a broad dialogue on foreign policy problems that could lead to an eventual visit to Moscow by Mr. Nixon.

The Penn Central, pleased with the response to its new "Metroliner" trains offering 2-hour, 59-minute service between Penn Station and Washington, is considering such variations as a service on the Hell Gate route that would terminate in Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -Representative Rogers C. B.. Morton is the only candidate now under consideration for Ray C. Bliss's post as Republican National Chairman, a White House political adviser said today.

PRAGUE, Feb. 18 -- Nearly six months after the Soviet occupation began, the Czechoslovak press and broadcasting media still are unquestionably the freest in the Soviet bloc, despite the surveillance of the Press and Information Office, a euphemism for the censorship.

Banking's great dream last summer of diversification is threatening to turn into this winter's nightmare. Starting last July, the nation s largest and most prestigious banks fell all over themselves rushing to take advantage of the loophole in Federal law that allows a holding company that owns one bank to expand into other fields.
Prices continued to retreat in reduced trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The Democratic legislative leaders today proposed a package of bills they described as "a comprehensive program of consumer protection."
Prices on the London stock market were steadier yesterday but failed to show any recovery from the recent downturn.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Feb. 19 -- Violence continued today as opposition leaders canceled talks scheduled with President Mohammad Ayud Khan. The leaders refused to meet with Marshal Ayub because of the absence of East Pakistan's most important leader, Shiek Mujib Rahman.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- A libel suit arising from the great international contract bridge cheating scandal of 1965 ended in the High Court today with the jury unable to agree.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 19 -- Israeli authorities appeared tonight to be seeking international assistance in finding an effective means to end Arab terrorist attacks against her airliners.

The player representatives of the 24 major league baseball clubs have rejected unanimously last Monday's offer of $5.3-million for the pension fund and have asked for a prompt resumption of negotiations with the club owners.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- The United States advised the Security Council today that urgent action was needed by international bodies to protect civilian airline passengers against armed attack.

ASPEN, Colo. -- Some people call it Aspen fever, and it is said to develop about 30 seconds after your plane touches ground. Once you've bought property here, the affliction, they add, is well nigh incurable.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -Ralph Nader accused industry today of deception in the establishment and administration of voluntary safety and performance standards for manufactured products.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Singing songs and carrying banners, students of the troubled London School of Economics returned to classes today. The school had been closed for nearly four weeks after militant students tore down gates installed within the buildings.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 -- The merged labor movement, already looking toward the Congressional elections of 1970, is planning to conduct national voter registration drives on an annual basis, rather than on a crash basis every other year, as in the past.

His long-term plans remain obscure.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange, considered one indicator of the future direction of share prices, continued to decline in the month ended last Friday, and reached the lowest level in 16 months.

A month-old labor dispute at Adelphi Hospital in Brooklyn has emptied most beds in the hospital and forced many strikers to seek welfare assistance.

FIRST stop on President Nixon's tour of Europe is Brussels and NATO headquarters; reading Hans Morgenthau's latest book on foreign policy, one could be apprehensive.
Anita O'Day is back in town and, as usual, she's winging it, or improvising.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- When Hamer H. Budge, a former Republican member of Congress, was originally named to the Securities and Exchange Commission by President Johnson, he was widely assumed to hold the view that the best regulation is the least regulation.
Welfare programs are "subsidizing abandonment" through payment to fatherless families, Councilman Robert A. Low said yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Prime Minister Wilson received a report tonight on the British-French crisis from his envoy to France amid mixed feelings here about the disruptive controversy. Ambassador Soames spent two hours at Mr. Wilson's country home, Chequers.

The effects of this nation's wrong-way agricultural policies on millions of poor continue to be etched in testimony before Senator George McGovern's Select Committee on Nutritional and Human Needs. Medical experts report that nutritional diseases long thought abolished have reappeared. They have linked irreversible mental retardation to dietary deficiencies in the very young.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 23 -- President Nixon began his eight-day working tour of Europe tonight in Belgium by summoning the Western allies to join him in the search for a durable peace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Vyacheslav Chornovil, the Soviet journalist who defied authorities by reporting on secret trials of intellectuals in the Ukraine, has been set free after 18 months in a prison camp, according to reliable reports from Kiev.

ATHENS, Feb. 23 -- Former King Saud of Saudi Arabia, the tall bearded monarch who ruled his vast, oil-rich land from 1953 to 1964, died of a heart attack today at a suburban Athens hotel, which had been his residence since 1965.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Tennis professionals under contract will play in open tournaments at Wimbledon and in France and South Africa during 1969, according to an agreement hammered out today between two American promoters, Bob Briner and George MacCall, and representatives of the three countries concerned.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Lee Trevino turned the $100,000 Tucson open golf tournament into a one-man show today, winning by seven strokes with a six-under-par 66 for his final round and 271 for the 72 holes.

Following are the highlights of President Nixon's planned itinerary for his trip to Europe [all European times are local, which is six hours ahead of New York time.]:

A special meeting of stockholders of the $2-million-a-year Harlem River Consumers Cooperative voted yesterday to oust the board of directors, substitute a new board and re-elect Mrs. Cora T. Walker as legal counsel.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 23 -- Whether the Common Market should look inward or outward is the key issue in the dispute between Britain and France, and the differing views have blocked major progress in the European Community over the last 18 months.

The city's Environmental Protection Administrator yesterday denied charges that Mayor Lindsay had issued misleading information in saying that sulphur dioxide air pollution had been reduced 25 per cent here.

A set of cryptic, coded marks on a map are currently inflaming passions in New York to an extraordinary degree. The issue is zoning, which may not make the world go round, but it does determine where and how New Yorkers live and work.
DETROIT, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings scored early and often, wearing out two goalies with a 49-shot barrage that produced a 9-1 victory tonight over the Philadelphia Flyers.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 23 -- The Yankees held their sixth day of practice today, looking forward to Tuesday when they may actually have infielders and outfielders for a whole starting team. Then it might seem like spring training.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Danny Grant's three goals powered revitalized Minnesota to a 7-2 National Hockey. League victory over faltering Toronto today.

TELEVISION station WNBC-TV, whose license to operate has been challenged by John Banzhaf 3d, a New York lawyer and anti-cigarette crusader, assigned a half hour last night to the American Cancer Society to detail the health hazards associated with cigarette smoking.

In a cramped little storefront on Amsterdam Avenue, a group of Negro and Puerto Rican youths yesterday came up with their own plan for coping with juvenile delinquency.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 23 -- Diane Crump, a blond 20-year-old jockey, today drew whistles and loud and long applause at El Comandante race track as she lost a match race against the island's leading rider.

About 85 per cent of the International Longshoremen's Association's 65,000 members have ended the costliest maritime strike in the nation's history and the remaining percentage is expected to return this week.

I am glad The Times in a Jan. 20 editorial called attention to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare effort "Toward a Social Report." The report is a significant step toward improving our understanding of our society.

ONLY Gerald Arpino's effectively sensuous duet "Sea Shadow," beautifully and reflectively danced by Trinette Singleton and Dermot Burke, was introduced into the City Center Joffrey Ballet repertory at the City Center over the weekend.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 23 -- The alumnae of Radcliffe College were mulling over today the decision of their alma mater to press for a full merger with Harvard University. Most agreed that it was in the temper of the times, but many had misgivings about Radcliffe's losing its identity.
Mayor Lindsay told the real estate industry yesterday that he wanted 100 per cent compliance with the current freeze of rents of apartments outside the rent-controlled law.

The American Automobile Association has promoted Louis P. Fenech from operations director to managing director of its World-Wide Travel Division. He succeeds E. M. K. Murray, who will coordinate the association's relations with foreign automobile clubs.
I favor the basic proposition that public employes may not strike and that fair and adequate punishment should follow a violation of this concept.

It also, of course, has Sydney, one of the world's five most beautiful harbors.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 21 -- Question: What is the best-kept secret in the state of Massachusetts?

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Lee Roy Yarbrough of[ Columbia, S.C., the hard-luck race driver of 1968, won the Daytona 500 for late-model stock cars today in much the same way he lost it a year ago -- by less than one second.
