MACON, Ga., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Manuel Orantes of Spain won the final of the Macon international indoor tennis tournament today. He defeated Mark Cox of England, 10-8, 7-5, 4-6, 9-7. Neither had been seeded.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Selective Service has rejected a plea by more than 300 Saipan Islanders and will draft their only architect, a 26-year-old Peace Corpsman.

MT. HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- The Plainfield, N.J., Curling Club Rink, skipped by Robert Fuller, won the 14th annual St. Andrew's invitation mixed bonspiel today by defeating the Winchester, Mass., C.C. No. 1 rink, skipped by Lyle Long-worth, 11-8, in the 10-end final for the Wicks Trophy at St. Andrew's Golf Club.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23 -- The Soviet Union celebrated Armed Forces Day today with the expected rhetoric from its military leaders and merry-making by its war veterans.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 (AP) -- New York State should keep its present restrictions on the weight and dimensions of trucks using its highways, a committee appointed by Governor Rockefeller recommended today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman has recovered from the flu but is remaining in Research Hospital here for routine tests, his doctors said today.

A Sayville, L. I., man was named yesterday as one of the recipients in a series of transplants in which a single donor provided organs for six persons.

Sales and earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company last year surpassed all previous records in the United States and abroad, with substantial gains made in all product lines, the annual report from the Rochester headquarters disclosed yesterday.

Gov. Richard J. Hughes said yesterday that his successor in New Jersey, who will be chosen this fall, will have no real choice other than to campaign actively for a state income tax.

A newly formed chamber-music organization will make its home in Lincoln Center and give several preview concerts there in September. The tragic and still unexplained death of aquanaut Berry L. Cannon 600 feet below the surface of the Pacific is a disturbing blow to this country's manned underwater research program. The Navy has reacted wisely by halting Project Sealab 3, on which Mr. Cannon was working when he died. A careful inquiry must precede resumption of this important project.

Three graduates of a French rabbinical academy have arrived here for post-graduate study at Yeshiva University, and rabbinical work in the United States.

MOUNT HERMAN, Mass., Feb. 23 -- American high school students can travel and study in the Soviet Union next summer and live in a youth camp with Russian boys of their own age, under a program sponsored here by the Mount Herman Summer Schools. The program will be open to students in all public and private schools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -Mortimer M. Caplin, Washington lawyer and former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, appealed to Congress today to end the "plain inequity" of permitting tax-exempt organizations to conduct commercial businesses on which they pay no taxes.

THE portrait of Ted Williams as painted by his detractors among the baseball writers pictured him as something of an ogre. They have said he was rude, crude and uncivil. He brushed them off and bawled them out. Since Boston fans never tired reading about Williams, the uncooperative hero often placed the task of chronicling him in depth somewhere between the difficult and the impossible.

The horizon for athletics in the New York City public schools was widened yesterday with the announcement that the regulation banning girls' interscholastic competition had been changed. However, the long-standing ban of competition between boys and girls remained in effect.

WASHTUCNA, Wash., Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Waters backed up behind the new Lower Monumental Dam today, forming a lake that was flooding the Marmes archeological site. Experts have called the site the most significant in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -Leo Durocher's old sporting maxim that nice guys finish last was disputed today by the Fair Campaign Practices Committee -at least as far as the 1968 election was concerned.

The Port of Rotterdam, already one of the world's biggest ports in point of cargo tonnage, is expected to increase its cargo volume by 200 per cent in the next decade and will double that figure again by the year 2000, according to a report by Frederic R. Harris Inc., an American engineering company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -The Supreme Court refused today to review a ruling by the New York Court of Appeals that New York's fullcrew law was not unconstitutional although it required the presence of firemen as "helpers" on diesel locomotives.

The Metropolitan Opera's new production of "Der Rosenkavalier" was only five performances old last night, but it had a new trio of leading women. Christa Ludwig, the Octavian of earlier presentations, switched to the role of the Marschallin.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 25 -- Enemy forces continued their shelling of towns and military installations throughout South Vietnam yesterday, but the intensity of the attacks eased considerably.

But never in epidemic form and, besides, the virus changes its strain as it travels northward across the continent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24, (AP) -- Dick Gregory, Negro comedian and civil rights leader, lost an appeal to the Supreme Court today challenging his conviction in a Chicago street sit-in demonstration.

The Union Carbide Corporation's earnings fell last year, the company reported yesterday. LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The British subsidiary of the Ford Motor company made a bold departure in British industrial relations today by seeking and winning a court injunction against further strike action by Britain's two largest unions.

The Government of Iran took title yesterday to the fivestory house at 34 East 69th Street, between Madison and Park Avenues. The house will be the residence of Iran's consul general, Parviz Sepahbodi, who now lives at 11 Fifth Avenue, at Ninth Street.

OTTAWA, Feb. 27 (AP) -The Canadian Medical Association called today for federal legislation to forbid all advertising of cigarettes and to require a warning on packages that smoking is a hazard to health.
TANHIEP, South Vietnam, Feb. 27 -- The Rev. Tran Xuan Thao shook the brick dust and splinters out of a pair of books and looked once more around his battered Roman Catholic Church.

BUFFALO, Feb. 27 -- A spokesman for the National Student Association said today that more than 6,600 youngsters had been arrested in the United States in the last two months for possession of marijuana and other drugs.

MIAMI, Feb. 27 -- It was a lovely spring morning, the kind that delights the Florida Chamber of Commerce. Though there was still a nip in the air in the early hours, the sun came barreling in with such intensity through the tall Australian pines and the palm trees at the Hialeah barn area that an afternoon of temperatures in the 70's could be guaranteed.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Gov. Ronald Reagan's popularity as Governor is at its peak, Mervin D. Field, public opinion pollster, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -The United States suffered in January its first large gold loss since last May, the Federal Reserve Board disclosed today. The loss of $64-million in the month, however, left the gold stock well above its level of last March, when massive losses ceased.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -"Modern man can no longer escape from noise. He is surrounded by a multitude of noise. He is surrounded by a multitude of noise sources in his home, office and place of work, which in turn are under the constant bombardment of noise from aircraft, traffic and scores of other outdoor sources.

Capital appropriations for new plant and equipment in the fourth quarter of 1968 by 1,000 of the nation's largest manufacturers rose to $6.47billion, or 3.6 per cent above the third quarter, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

PRAGUE, Feb. 27 -- Miroslav Kusy, the ideologist of the Slovak Communist party, charged today that pro-Soviet conservatives were seeking to gain control of the Slovak party apparatus, security police and people's militia, the party's controversial private army.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -Congressional hearings on the first inclusive health and safety standards in coal mining opened today with an industry promise to pay the cost even of "burdensome and expensive" life saving reforms and a union threat to strike if the industry does not pay the costs.
PARIS, Feb. 27 -- The United South Vietnamese cities "clearStates warned North Vietnam and the Vietcong today that the shelling of Saigon and other ly complicates our task" at the peace talks here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -Maurice H. Stans, Secretary of Commerce, told the Congress today that this year could again show a "significant" deficit in the balance of international payments and therefore the program of controls over business investments abroad could not be removed.

Lew Alcindor of University of California, Los Angeles; Pete Maravich of Louisiana State; Spencer Haywood of Detroit; Rick Mount of Purdue, and Calvin Murphy of Niagara were named yesterday as the 196869 college basketball all-America team by The Associated Press.

Victor Posner, whose NVF Company recently won control of the Sharon Steel Corporation, was elected yesterday as chairman of the steel company and chairman of its executive committee. George Perrault Jr., who had been chairman, continues as president and a member of the executive committee.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Thirteen defendants pleaded not guilty today to disorderly conduct in the first major test of mass arrests made by the Chicago police during the Democratic National Convention last summer.

Consistency is not always to be admired. Poldi Mildner's virtues and defects as a pianist seem to have persisted since she made her debut here in 1932 at the age of 17. Her playing then, as it was in later recitals, was admired for its technical strength and deplored for its lack of expressivity and depth.

THE MFG Boat Company of Union City, Pa., which cannot be found in the telephone directory under that name (it is listed under Molded Fiber Glass), has nevertheless been making a name for itself in its power and sail divisions.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The price of gold rose to $42.80 an ounce in London this afternoon, the highest level here since the gold pool collapsed and a two-price system was instituted in March of last year.
Federal officials were wary last night about commenting on a report that a New York employment agency was suspected of placing employes in Wall Street brokerage companies to steal stock certificates.

ON the face of it, it might have seemed a good idea to the City Opera to revive Borodin's "Prince Igor." There had not been a staging hereabouts for a half century; and the opera, though a pastiche put together after the composer's death by RimskyKorsakov and Glazunov, has some wonderful music.

St. John's got just what its basketball coach, Lou Carnesseca, wanted last night -- a difficult workout that forced the Redmen to play comeback ball, thus keeping them from relaxing as they prepared for the National Collegiate championship tourney starting March 8.

An intense Spanish story -the dramatic confrontation between a young novillero (a novice bullfighter) and a bull -is being told here in a series of impressionistic photographs by Bill Rodriguez, a freelancer.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Gabriele Seyfert of East Germany picked herself off the ice tonight after a spill and won the women's world figure skating championship.
TALARA, Peru, Feb. 24 -During the last half-century, palm trees, palatial villas, dazzling gardens and discotheques have bloomed along the sparkling beaches of Talara.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 27 -- The five-day-old enemy campaign of shelling and ground attacks flagged today, but few members of the United States Command took much comfort from the lull.
There were other developments yesterday in the current wave of student unrest around the country.
MOSCOW, Feb. 27 -- An American rabbi reported today that a high Soviet religiousaffairs official had said the authorities would like to help Jews set up a shop to manufacture religious articles.
"Mixed" was the word that many brokers used yesterday for most of the final range of quotations for commodity futures.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27 -- In a move to dispel rumors and controversies similar to those surrounding the assassination of President Kennedy, prosecutors at the Sirhan Bishara Sirhan trial have purposely introduced certain witnesses so that lingering reports of a conspiracy in the shooting of Senator Robert F. Kennedy would be publicly rebutted.
The principal indicators of credit policy traced a mixed pattern during the last two weeks, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

GENEVA, Feb. 27 -- The Administrative offices of the University of Geneva were occupied by about 100 students tonight after university officials refused to disband the General Association of Students. The students demanded that the university assume the social functions of the association, which the students said was a tool of university officials.

WILLIAM and Marietta Passell of Hartsdale, N. Y., outdistanced many other New York experts in the international bidding competition Wednesday night. They totaled 894 points out of a possible 1,000, a performance that should place them high in the world rankings.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 27 -- There were crowds of players around the batting cage today and the line drives sounded powerful -- particularly when Tony Solaita was hitting them. For the first time since camp opened 10 days ago, Manager Ralph Houk of the Yankees had something to watch and hear as he perched on the support railing behind the cage.
The proposed Morningside Park gymnasium that provided one of the focal points for last spring's protests at Columbia University should not be built, the school's acting president said yesterday.

Carlos Fuentes, a leading Mexican novelist with leftist leanings, was denied permission by United States immigration officials to land in San Juan, Puerto Rico, last Saturday on the ground that he was "an undesirable alien."

The Italian Communists and their allies are old hands at staging demonstrations, and President Nixon has no reason to take personally the outbursts that followed his arrival in Rome. Nor should Americans infer that the Soviet Union sparked these actions of an Italian Communist party that has gone out of its way for years to display fierce independence of the Kremlin.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The British bank rate was increased today, to 8 per cent from 7 per cent, in an unexpected move to reinforce a credit squeeze on commercial banks. Soaring international interest rates also affected the decision.

DURING interrogation of witnesses by the State Investigation Commission, Goodman Alexander Sarachan will often lean forward and remark quietly, "What I don't understand is how you can have no knowledge of this matter."

It is entirely possible that, outside of the Sheep Meadow, there is no place hereabout where Iannis Xenakis's "Eonta" would be less effective than in Philharmonic Hall. The music, composed in 1964, was presented in the latter inhospitable location last night by Seiji Ozawa, seven members of the New York Philharmonic brass sections, and the formidably talented young Japanese pianist, Yuji Takahashi.

MIAMI, Feb. 27 -- Brent's Queen and Royal Entrance staged a rattling duel in the closing phases of the feature race at Hialeah today. With Calvin Stone guiding her, Brent's Queen flashed past her Calumet Farm rival at the last step to take the six-furlong sprint for fillies and mares by a nose.

The death of 10 office workers and the critical burning of six others in the fire that swept through the third floor of a Fifth Avenue office building was attributed yesterday to the victims' failure to call the Fire Department immediately and quickly leave the building by the stairs.

DETROIT, Feb. 27 -- The General Motors Corporation said today that the first 230,000 letters to automobile owners asking them to return their cars to dealers for correction of potential safety defects would go out near the end of next week.

Bank-rate jitters helped to send the stock market downward yesterday, thereby bringing an abrupt halt to the technical rally of Wednesday, the only session in two weeks that has seen stock prices move up.
Christopher Lehmann-Haupt will succeed Eliot Fremont-Smith as daily book critic of The New York Times, James Reston, executive editor, announced yesterday.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 27 -Tens of thousands of Israelis filed past the bier of Levi Eshkol here today to demonstrate what one student called "our last love" for their Premier.
The telephone in the Roosevelt Hospital emergency room rang at 10 o'clock the other night and Pat Marsalisi, a pert young nurse, answered it.

PARIS -- Charles de Gaulle is the complete negation of Marxism because he imposes his personality on history rather than the reverse. More than that, he manages to summon as executors of his various policies those who particularly dislike the task at hand and yet must accomplish it ardently.

TRENTON, Feb. 27 -- The chairman of a legislative commission said tonight that he would inquire next week into the financial interests of the sponsor of a referendum that Gov. Richard J. Hughes has denounced as a "billion-dollar give-away."

The credit squeeze that dogged the housing market in the late nineteen sixties will do it again in the coming decade unless capital markets expand faster than is now anticipated, a McGraw - Hill economist warned yesterday.
A 36-year-old high school in a deteriorating section of Newark has suddenly found an unexpected place in contemporary American literature, delighting many and dismaying others.
A storm moving eastword from the Rockies stacked a foot of snow on the Great Plains yesterday and more light snow fell in storm-paralyzed New England.

It was understandable that Councilman Robert A. Low wanted to get rid of an abandoned Jaguar Mark IV sedan that had been sitting in front of his house, blocking a fire hydrant, since the big snow of Feb. 9.

MOORE HAVEN, Fla., Feb. 16 -- George L. Espenlaub, the lean, weathered 70-year-old guide whose bullfrog larynx handles Latin and pithy tales of his beloved Everglades with equal facility, picked the sable palm he wanted and assailed it with a hatchet.

CORONADO, Calif., Feb. 27 -- In the "Gypsy Tea Room," the Pueblo's crewmen sipped Korean wine and beer. They sat at a wooden table and listened to the quiet, even friendly, voices of a group of smiling North Korean civilians.
HADLYME, Conn., Feb. 27 -Dr. Alice Hamilton, who has helped extend the average life span of the American worker, was 100 years old today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 -- When Mrs. Harry C. Mills arrived at the black-tie auction on behalf of St. Mary's Hospital last night, she was wearing a coral crepe dress with a turquoise and diamond necklace. Several hours later, she was still in coral crepe, but she had changed her necklace.
For the sake of clarity, allow me to refer to your editorial of Feb. 21 concerning the Zurich incident.

IF Wilbur D. Mills is successful in piloting his new bill through Congress, any aspiring conglomerate company will find it increasingly difficult -- if not impossible -- to use the debt route to gianthood.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The state's highest court ruled today that although college teachers may advocate the use of illegal drugs, they must also honor subpoenas to testify before a grand jury investigating alleged on-campus "misconduct" related to such drugs.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 -- The New York Mets held their first full workout of spring training today and showed few scars from baseball's first "general strike."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The White House announced today the names of the men who will advise President Nixon whether to continue the nation's controversial, multimillion dollar supersonic transport program.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 27 -President Arthur de Costa e Silva ended his summer vacation today with a number of decrees and other acts further establishing his military regime at the center of Brazilian life.
The Trans-Lux Corporation topped the acquisition news yesterday by announcing that it was preparing an exchange offer for shares of the TwentiethCentury-Fox Film Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -Patricia Roberts Harris resigned as dean of the Howard University Law School today in the midst of a total student boycott of classes.
NEWARK, Feb. 27 -- The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra today canceled its five-concert program for March as the result of a dispute with local l of the American Federation of Musicians.
BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 27 (UPI) -- Club-swinging policemen charged repeatedly today into student dissidents forming human chains at busy entrances to the University of California campus.
Prices backed down again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, more than erasing the modest gains that were posted on Wednesday.

ROME, Feb. 27 -- About the time that President Nixon was addressing workers in the huge Siemens electrical factory in West Berlin this morning, a high Government official in Washington found himself puzzled by a section of the President's forthcoming anticrime legislation.

GENEVA, Feb. 27 -- The World Health Organization said today that coronary heart disease could become the "greatest epidemic mankind has faced unless we are able to reverse the trend by concentrated research."
The assistant supervisor of a city-funded neighborhood program in East Harlem and a former worker for the program were arrested Wednesday night and charged with possession of loaded weapons.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -The Federal Aviation Administration is planning to test soon, at one or more airports, devices to detect weapons being carried onto airliners.
Prices on the London stock market fell yesterday to new lows for the year in reaction to the one-point rise in the British bank rate to 8 per cent.
LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Poland defeated Rumania, 4-2, and Norway tied Austria, 3-3, in Group B matches of the world amateur ice hockey championships today.

Marcel Philippe, the winner of eight straight races this winter, finally met defeat last night. Three out-of-state runners finished ahead of the Mater Christi senior in an exciting one-mile run at the Eastern States indoor schoolboy championships in the 102d Engineers Armory.

Special to The New York Times NEW ORLEANS, Saturday, March 1 -- An all-male jury early today acquitted Clay L. Shaw of a charge of conspiring to assassinate President Kennedy. The jury deliberated about 50 minutes.

Special to The New York Times LONDON, Feb. 28 -- A Government-appointed expert reported today that he was satisfied with the repairs being made on the faulty turbines of the Queen Elizabeth 2. He said the $70.8-million liner should be ready for handing over to the Cunard Steam Ship Company in the last half of April.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Court of Customs and Patent Appeals will hold a rehearing Monday on its decision last November to make software-computer programs patentable. The controversy has split the computer industry.
Special to The New York Times HONG KONG, Feb. 28 -- Communist China charged the Government of Japan today with aggressive designs on Taiwan.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Barbara Jo Rubin, the first girl jockey to win a flat track race in the United States, rode Reely Beeg to a third-place finish in today's ninth race at Charles Town Race Course.

Amerind Shipping Corporation has placed the new Liberian-flag containership Gwendolen Isle in the New York-to-Berumda service. The 240-foot German-built vessel has cellular spaces for 86 container boxes of the 20-foot size. She sailed yesterday from Pier 13, Staten Island, on the first of her weekly voyages on the route.

ROME, Feb. 28 -- President Nixon's reiterated pledges of close, continuous consultation with America's allies on world problems brought his two-day conversations with Italian leaders to a close today in a glow of mutual satisfaction.

Special to The New York Times NEWARK, Feb. 28 -- Superior Court Judge Samuel A. Larner upheld today the right of the Verona Board of Education to initiate a program for the daily busing of 38 Negro pupils from Newark to the elementary schools of Verona.

The audience of 20,000 people who packed Madison Square Garden last night to hear the Temptations, Gladys Knight and the Pips and Jackie (Moms) Mabley obviously came to enjoy. They cheered every familiar note of the songs by the Temptations and Miss Knight, they roared In response to every sinuously choreographed movement that went with the songs and they clapped in time even when Miss Mabley croaked out "Down by the Riverside."
Special to The New York Times ROME, Feb. 28 -- President Nixon received a letter this morning in an incident that appeared at first to be an attempted violent attack on him.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Soviet Union appeared today to have opened the door to discussions on establishing a single global communications satellite network, provided the system was not dominated by the United States.
Special to The New York Times TORONTO, Feb. 28 -- The Bank of Canada tonight announced that the bank rate would be increased to 7 per cent from 6.5 per cent, effective Monday.

The rent freeze on the city's uncontrolled apartments, scheduled to expire today, was extended yesterday for 10 days to give Mayor Lindsay's Rent Guidelines Board more time to evaluate the real estate industry's plan for self-regulation.

Special to The New York Times WALDWICK, N. J., Feb. 28 -- Ellis Slack of Pittsford, N. Y. defeated Steve Ogilvy, 3-6, 6-2, 6-3, to gain the semi-final round in the Eastern senior indoor tennis championships tonight. Ted Schein, Harry Hoffman and Bob Herschel also advanced.

Harold Prince will leave for Austria tomorrow to scout locations for his first film, "The Dreamers." The Broadway producer will direct the movie, which is to be shot in June. It will be produced by Media Enterprises, a Prince-owned company run by an associate, John Flaxman. Cinema Center Films will distribute it.

Time Inc., the $500-million magazine publishing empire that for more than a year has been trying to move into the newspaper field, announced yesterday an agreement to acquire 22 suburban weeklies in Chicago.

LONDON, Feb 28 -- Musical revivals have been doing so well in London recently that it was only a matter of time before someone started producing modern copies of "The Desert Song" and "The Student Prince."

Picketing continued yesterday for the second day at the midtown headquarters of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York by striking members of Local 1707 of the Community and Social Agency Employes Union, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes.

Horace Clarke and Steve Hamilton also reported Friday, leaving only Mickey Mantle and Al Downing absent. Mantle was expected to sign his contract and work out Saturday. Downing, whose salary was over $30,000 last year, won three games and lost three. The Yankees say Downing deserves a slight cut. Downing's agent says he deserves a raise. Downing is leaning toward his agent.

Special to The New York Times PLAINFIELD, N. J., Feb. 28 -- An impromptu meeting of white and Negro students in the high-school auditorium here this morning turned into a brawl that resulted in six arrests, several injuries and a marked rise in racial tension In a city already tense.

Special to The New York Times PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 28 --Brown fought back from an 11-point deficit in the first half and defeated Harvard, 68-67, in an Ivy League game tonight. The victory was the first for the Bruins in 13 Ivy games and snapped an 11-game losing streak.

Special to The New York Times PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam, who has publicly advocated resumption of the bombing of North Vietnam, will confer with President Nixon here on Sunday, it was confirmed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that "vague and questionable" judicial guidelines had placed on policemen a heavy burden of judgment that could lead to indecision and even loss of their lives.

Special to The New York Times PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Calling for an end to "old slogans" and "old quarrels." President Nixon arrived in France today for the last and most difficult phase of his eight-day diplomatic effort to repair the worn fabric of the North Atlantic alliance.

Special to The New York Times BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, March 1 -- The Syrian Army, under the Defense Minister, Lieut. Gen. Hafez al-Assad, has taken control of the Government of Syria in what appears to be an attempt to force military cooperation with Iraq against Israel on the eastern front.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- The Vietcong hit three merchant ships with rockets and grenades yesterday in the Longtau shipping channel southeast of Saigon, a United States Naval spokesman said today. Damage was described as light, and no casualties were reported.

Henryk Szeryng replaced Leonid Kogan, who is ill, as violin soloist with the Moscow State Symphony at Carnegie Hall last night. Mr. Kogan had been scheduled in Beethoven's Violin Concerto, and that is what Mr. Szeryng played.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Tim Wood of Detroit gave a dynamic exhibition in free skating tonight and brought the world men's figure skating championship back to the United States for the first time in 10 years.

The stock market turned in an uneven performance yesterday after a statement attributed to Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Exchange, sent rumor mills spinning and sharply depressed conglomerate issues.
The Boston Celtics, led by Bill Russel and John Havlicek, will make their final regular-season Madison Square Garden appearance of the year tonight against the Knickerbockers.

Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., a major conglomerate concern. said yesterday that current market conditions had prompted it to withdraw a previously announced offering of shares in one of its subsidiaries, National Car Rental, Inc. The parent had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of 1,241,256 common shares and 2,068,760 class A special shares of National.

A dramatic improvement in the prevention of hijacking and pilfering in New York's garment area was reported yesterday by a spokesman for the local trucking industry, which last week threatened a stoppage unless police protection increased.

An experimental program designed to increase the time that patrolmen spend on their beats by reducing the time they must devote to prisoners after making arrests was formally opened yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

Special to The New York Times PARIS, Feb. 28 -- President Nixon's French hosts would not hear of his staying in a hotel on his Paris visit, as he did during the other stops of his European tour. They put him up in the guest house.
The court-ordered election of officers for the 50,000-member National Maritime Union ended last night with about 56 per cent of those eligible to vote having cast ballots.

A company that makes air-pollution detection equipment said yesterday that in 1966 it offered General Motors a device that would sound an alarm when carbon monoxide in a car or truck reached a dangerous level.

Special to The New York Times POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- Vassar College announced today that it would set up an interdepartmental program in black studies beginning next fall. The program will include courses related to the present and past history and culture of the Negro in the United States and African history and culture.

DAUTIENG, South Vietnam, Feb. 28 -- They call it "Killer Junior" and in its gruesome ingenuity it helps to keep American soldiers alive in periods such as the current enemy offensive in South Vietnam.
The bisexual tendencies of a 31-year-old Yugoslav man are no reason to deny him United States citizenship, a Federal Court judge said in a ruling challenged here yesterday.

HOUSTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- John H. Glenn Jr., the first American astronaut to orbit the earth, said today that though he "hates" to leave Houston, his business was forcing him to move to New York City.

A squad of 17 members and two alternates was selected yesterday by the United States Amateur Wrestling Foundation to represent the United States in the world championships in Argentina, starting Monday.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- The average rate of discount at today's tender of British 91-day Treasury bills rose to 7.717 per cent, from 6.702 per cent last week. This week's 100-million offer met applications of 189,790,000. Next week 100-million in bills will be offered replacing 120-million of maturities.

Special to The New York Times MIAMI, Feb. 28 -- Every time Tommy Aaron plays the ninth hole of the Doral Country Club he recalls the 7 and an unusual penalty that he received there in the 1967 tourney. However, today he ended his second round in the $150,000 Doral open with a par 3 and moved into a three-way tie for the lead at 135.

Special to The New York Times BRUNSWICK, Me., Feb. 28 -Bowdoin's all-time leading scorer, Ken Martin, capped a brilliant three-year career with two goals to lead the Polar Bears to a 5-2 victory over Norwich in hockey tonight. The victory assured Bowdoin of a first-place finish in the Eastern College Athletic Conference. Division II. The Polar Bears ended their best season in eight years with a 14-6-1 won-losttied record.

Thomas (Tommy Ryan) Eboli, reputed top underworld figure, was reported "resting comfortably" in University Hospital yesterday following his collapse during a rackets investigation hearing Thursday. Eboli, who is 57 years old and is known to have a heart ailment, collapsed in the witness chair at a public hearing of the State Investigation Commission, which is looking into the infiltration of business and industry by organized crime.

Special to The New York Times SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 28 -- In another raging snowstorm that soon had spectators cloaked in mantles of white, Billy Kidd, the seasoned 25-year-old star from Stowe, Vt., and pretty Berni Rauter, from Austria's Tyrol, scored World Cup slalom victories today.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- George Byers of Kansas and Wayne Long of Oklahoma equaled the world indoor mark of 6.5 seconds in the 60-yard low hurdles tonight in the opening session of the Big Eight indoor track and field championships. The clockings were made in preliminary heats to tomorrow's finals.
"We're Number 1," proclaims a notice posted outside Andrew Jackson High School in Queens. It goes on to list some of the school's achivements in recent sporting events and in other competitions.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Stillman College announced plans today to reopen the school March 10.

A YEAR ago, a high school basketball coach in Queens bought a hamburger for a very tall ninth-grader. The spirit and purpose of that meal have become stinging issues in a mounting controversy that led to a landmark decision last week by the State Supreme Court. And this week, in revolt against the decision, five Queens high schools bolted the regularly scheduled citywide playoffs and established their own private tournament.
The American Broadcasting Company, last all season in the audience ratings, will replace 12 shows next season with the same number of new programs.

Special to The New York Times PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- Five years ago, a small group of Protestant ministers and laymen came together here out of a common desire to develop what they called a "meaningful and relevant lay ministry to urban society."

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 28 -- The cold-ridden Apollo 9 astronauts, slowly regaining their health, resumed training today for a scheduled launching Monday morning on a 10-day earth-orbital test flight.

ATLANTA, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Donn Clendenon, who was involved in a controversial trade in which he went to the Houston Astros, and Rusty Staub went to the new Montreal team, said today he was retiring from baseball.

Special to The New York Times SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb 28 -- Enemy gunners shelled about 30 military and civilian targets around South Vietnam today while five companies of American infantrymen fought a day-long battle six miles from the center of Saigon.

A CAREFUL reading of the bill offered by Representative Wilbur D. Mills that would restrict interest deductions on debt offered in company take-overs suggests that acquisitions would be difficult indeed should the bill go through.

SANTA FE, N. M., Feb. 28 (AP) -- A bill to abolish the death penalty in New Mexico, except on convictions for killing policemen or jail guards on duty, was passed, 26 to 12, by the state Senate today and was sent to the House. It would commute to life terms the sentences of three men now awaiting execution in the New Mexico Penitentiary.
Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals, the following proceedings were held yesterday:

Special to The New York Times ITHACA N. Y., Feb. 28-Cornell, which was scoreless for the first 5 1/2 minutes of play, rallied in the second half tonight and defeated Pennsylvania, 64-62, in an Ivy League game.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz plans to submit legislation to Congress to change dractically the administration and funding of the Federal manpower training programs to achieve greater flexibility and local control.

PARIS, Feb, 28 (UPI) -- A White House spokesman said today that President Nixon was closely following the progress of General Eisenhower in his battle against pneumonia. The spokesman said reports on General Eisenhower's condition were being relayed to the President through his personal physician.

FREEPORT, L. I. Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Residents of the Freeport School District today overwhelmingly voted down a proposal for a new $7-million school to serve 1,900 sixth- to eighth-grade students. Christopher Warrell, superintendent of schools, said the vote was 2,657 to 1,355 against building the school, which would have been erecterd at Firemen's Field, Sunrise Highway and Buffalo Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Administration officials assured the Senate today that the treaty to stop the spread of nuclear weapons imposed no new restrictions on the United States. But Senator John Stennis, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, did not appear satisfied.

Representative Hale Boggs, a ranking member of the House Ways and Means Committee, assured a bankers' conference on mortgages yesterday that, in weighing proposed tax changes for savings banks, the Congress would give careful consideration to their impact on the housing industry.
Two giant merger developments were disclosed here yesterday.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Formation of a new Overseas Development Council, a nonprofit research organization to study ways and means of furthering economic and social development in less developed countries, was announced here today by Eugene R. Black, former president of the World Bank.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 (AP)--Temple defeated Gettysburg, 86-70, and St. Joseph's eliminated Bucknell, 83-67, tonight in the Middle Atlantic Conference's University Division basketball playoffs at the Palestra.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower suffered a serious setback today in his convalescence from major abdominal surgery. His doctors discovered he had developed pneumonia in his right lung.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- United States foreign trade, sharply reduced by the dock strike, showed a $116-million export surplus in January, the Commerce Department re ported today. The strike, which lasted the entire month, cut exports by 28 per cent from December and imports by 34 per cent. The result was an export total, seasonally adjusted, of $2,082,000,000 and an import total of $1,967,000,000.

Special to The New York Times BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 28 -- President Nicholae Ceausescu asked Rumanians today to turn the parliamentary elections next Sunday into a vote of confidence for his Government's increasingly independent foreign policies.
The New York Giants unveiled a beautiful color movie, "Highlights of the 1968 Season," yesterday during a luncheon at Leone's Restaurant. Offensively, the film was a success.
LONDON, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- Britain will cancel debts of 4-million ($9.6-million) owed by the Irish Republic for property damage in the rebellion.
DETROIT, Feb. 28 (AP)--The Baltimore Bullets maintained their 3 1/2-game lead in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association tonight by trouncing the Detroit Pistons, 134-116.
Special to The New York Times JERUSALEM, Feb. 28 -- Levi Eshkol was buried with Israel's founders atop Mount Herzl today after a simple and moving state funeral.

MILWALKEE, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Elroy (Crazy Legs) Hirsch, assistant to the president of the Los Angeles Rams and a former star receiver, accepted tonight the job of athletic director at the University of Wisconsin.

In Sicily, as in the United States, the Mafia is powerful not through visible street crimes but because of its "legitimate" business interests. It is the dollars from gambling, loan-sharking, narcotics and other crimes that are turned into millions for use in real estate, trucking, construction and all sorts of other enterprises where clean fronts are maintained.

CATANIA, Sicily, Feb. 28 (AP) -- An express train ran into a boulder dislodged by a landslide and derailed six miles from here tonight, the police reported. Two of the train crew were reported dead and a third injured critically. Nine passengers were reported injured.

Special to The New York Times PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Following are the texts of President de Gaulle's welcoming statement at Orly Airport, in unofficial translation from the French, and of President Nixon's reply:

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel called today for tougher laws to protect off-shore waters from any pollution, including oil, and promised to seek more authority as needed to clean up the country's water supplies.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Philadelphia won the support of Govs. Rockefeller of New York and Russell W. Peterson of Delaware today as the site of the nation's bicentennial celebration in 1976.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Mrs. Patricia Nixon entertained at a luncheon today in the small private dining room on the first floor of the White House in honor of the wives of the nation's Governors.

Special to The New York Times CORONADO, Calif., Feb. 28 -- Weeping convulsively, Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher was led out of a Navy court of inquiry today while a 20-year-old sailor quietly testified that his faith in God and his skipper had helped him survive the North Koreans' kicking and interrogating of the Pueblo crew.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 (AP) -- U.S. auto production this week was scheduled to reach 182,068, an increase of 6,857 over last week's output, but a drop of 2,614 from production in the corresponding week of 1968.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 28 (AP)--Davidson's balanced scoring and power under the boards swept the nationally fifthranked Wildcats to a 97-83 victory over Richmond tonight in a semi-final game of the Southern Conference championship basketball tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Republican party strategists have come up with a "top sacret" plan to win control of the House of Representatives by nineteen-seventy. Backers of the program will say only that it will cost a lot of money.
Special to The New York Times DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- The General Motors Corporation established today a separate parts division aimed at improving auto parts shipments to car dealers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Louisiana and Arkansas have been asked by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to submit desegregation plans for their state-owned colleges and universities under threat of possible loss of Federal funds.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, and 17 other Senators introduced legislation today that would significantly change and liberalize the Small Business Investment Company program.
BIG RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Negro and white students battled with fists and clubs in a dormitory at Ferris State College today and 22 persons were injured. Two were hospitalized.

The realty investment partnership of Sol G. Atlas and John P. McGrath, joined by W. E. Savage Co., Inc., building contractors, have filed suit in State Seupreme Court to void a landmark designation for Schermerhorn Row in the Fulton Fish Market area.

FORT IRWIN, Calif., Feb. 28 (AP) -- A seven-member court-martial board convicted Pfc. John Colip today of nonviolent mutiny involving 27 soldiers in the stockade at the San Francisco Presidio Oct. 14.
Robert T. Connor announced yesterday his candidacy for a second four-year term as Borough President of Staten Island.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today the nominations of six Pentagon aides and two Agriculture Department officials.
Special to The New York Times PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Eight centuries of colorful and turbulent history are drawing to a close this weekend as Les Halles departs from the medieval heart of Paris.

Ten years ago the Port of New York Authority made public a well documented warning that the New York metropolitan area would need a new jetport within five years. Despite intensive efforts, a decade has gone by without even the assurance of an acceptable site. Today the jetport is as far off as it was ten years ago, and the need for it is vastly greater.

Special to The New York Times FORT DIX, N. J., Feb. 28 -- The first soldier to flee from South Vietnam to another country and then return to the United States for trial watched his image on a movie screen today and heard himself say he had come home because "I didn't want to live like a tramp in a country I can't find work in."

Special to The New York Times FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Joe Pepitone made a concession today -- about an inch's worth. Before reporting for his first workout of the spring, he trimmed his sideburns, bringing them above the bottom of his ear.

Special to The New York Times MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- The Soviet note requesting East German action to restrict access to West Berlin and granting advance approval for such measures caused Western diplomats here tonight to revise a professed optimism that there would be no full-fledged Berlin crisis.

The Council of Churches of the City of New York, which represents Protestant faiths, has asked seven major television stations and nine radio outlets to examine the applications for renewal of their licenses to operate on the air. Under Federal law a citizen can ask to see the applications on March 1, before the Federal Communications Commission acts on extending the new permits on June 1.

Special to The New York Times SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 28 -- The student senate of the University of Notre Dame last night censured the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, the Notre Dame president, for his recent "get tough" policy statement on student demonstrations.

Special to The New York Times BRUSSELS, Feb. 28 -- Experts from Britain and West Germany are exploring various criteria for the use of tactical and strategic nuclear weapons if there should be a Soviet attack on the North Atlantic alliance.

The American Waterways Operators have chosen George H. Blohm, vice president and general manager of the Cities Service Tankers Corporation, as chairman of the nationwide barge and towing industry association for the coming year.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Uruguay will trade canned goods and women's apparel for Soviet agricultural and industrial machinery under terms of a one-year, $20-million trade agreement announced here today.

Negro youths have been catching up to whites in school attendance. Negro women's earnings are just about matching those of white women in year-round jobs. And the rise in Negro family income has been faster than the whites'.

TOKYO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- About 200 coal miners stormed into the parliament building today, demanding nationalization of the mining industry. Policemen and guardsmen ousted the miners after a scuffle. Meanwhile, the 54,000-member federation of Japanese coal miner unions began a 24-hour strike to protest Government policy to streamline the coal industry.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 28 (AP)--Mrs. Billie Jean King of Berkeley, Calif., and Rod Laver of Australia were victorious in the international pro tennis invitation tourney last night in the Memorial Coliseum.

Seven hundred members and friends of the New York Council Pioneer Women are expected to attend the council's annual Purim festival and dance the afternoon of March 9 in the Grand Ballroom of the Commodore Hotel. Mrs. Rose Wachs is president of the council and Mrs. Elsie Wattenberg is chairman for the event. Pioneer Women, a Zionist labor organization, has headquarters at 215 Park Avenue South.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) -- Henry L. Giordano, associate director of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs, retired today after 28 years of Government service.
THERE are several thousand miles of ocean between Togo in West Africa and Jamaica, Queens, but the children of both areas have found a common bond -- fashion.

OLD jewelry that follows traditional design is at the present time lumped together as "Victorian," and as such has not attracted serious collectors. Fine pins of the eighteen-fifties are put into show cases at antique shops with crude commercial work of the nineteen thirties.

Special to The New York Times ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- High school girls will be allowed to participate with boys in noncontact sports in an experimental program that will determine whether such activities are feasible, State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. announced today.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city had reached an agreement with a municipal employes' union that would require nonunion city employes to pay the union a "service fee" equivalent to the dues that union members pay.
Hearing an unknown conductor make his New York debut with the Verdi Requiem is like watching a fledgling actor make his Broadway debut as Hamlet.

The Commonwealth Edison Company reported yesterday operating revenues of $749,256,592 for the year ended Jan. 31. This compared with $693,622,072 a year earlier. Net income rose to $131,979,753, or $2.99 a share, from $130,540,413, or $2.97 a share on fewer shares, in the comparable period a year before. January operating revenues were $67,090,234, against $63,178,310 a year ago, while net income of $11,876,760 compared with $11,660,913 in January, 1968.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A special House Armed Services subcommittee will begin hearings next Tuesday into the capture of the Pueblo and the crew's imprisonment.

Princeton won the Ivy League basketball championship last night and the ensuing trip to the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tourney when the Tigers held on to edge Columbia, 60-59, in a fast, thrilling game at University Hall on Morningside Heights.
World sugar prices rose yesterday in moderate trading of 2,070 contracts. As a result, the spot price was increased from 3.40 cents a pound to 3.47.
Andrew Heiskell, chairman of Time Inc., was elected chairman of the New York Urban Coalition yesterday.

Special to The New York Times BUFFALO, Feb. 28 -- Scientists are still baffled by what marijuana does or does not do to people who smoke it, a California physician said today, but some medically sound answers may be near.

Doug Lyons of the New York Athletic Club won the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's Limited A tournament yesterday by defeating a clubmate. Pete Yaman, 15-17, 15-11, 15-5, 15-11, at the Yale Club.
Special to The New York Times PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- "How are you going to make 18 feet, if you can't try it?" Bob Seagren said today. "I'd like to try 18 feet more, but I never get the chance."

Three directors of Liquidonics Industries Inc., were elected to the board of UMC Industries, Inc., it was disclosed yesterday. They are N. Norman Muller, chairman and president of Liquidonics; Roy C. Turner, and Alphonse A. Jacobellis.

Special to The New York Times AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 28 -- James K. Keefe, Maine's Commissioner of Economic Development, said today the state had had so much snow that ski area operators were offering free skiing on Memorial Day, so convinced were they that the snow would last that long.

THE Greater New York Bridge Association, which often experiments with new contest forms, has scheduled a special team event at the New York Hilton Hotel, beginning today at 1:30 P.M. and continuing tomorrow. A total of 64 teams will compete, and entries are now closed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Nixon Administration has picked James Smith of Omaha to be Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Water and Power development.

Special to The New York Times COMMACK, L. I., Feb. 28 -The New York Nets blew a 9-point lead in the last 2 1/2 minutes of regulation time tonight and the Miami Floridians went on to post a 124-120 overtime victory in an American Basketball Association game at the Long Island Arena.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The United States expressed its concern to the Soviet Union today about what appeared to be a mounting Soviet and East German campaign to impede access to West Berlin.

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 28 (UPI) -- A student boycott of seven Negro schools kept an estimated 3,500 of the 4,151 students enrolled out of classes for the second day today in protest over plans to close or change the operation of the schools.

ANNA SOKOLOW'S "Opus '65" is not so much a ballet as a social manifesto. When it returned to the City Center Joffrey Ballet's repertory at the New York City Center last night, its forceful, even aggressive, virtues were once more apparent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee today scheduled hearings next week on the controversial Sentinel anti-missile system.
The International Utilities Corporation reported yesterday record net income for 1968, despite a decline in sales.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges have issued their most recent lists of changes in corporate stock holdings by major owners, directors and officers. The list included the following:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- The State Department said today the United States Government still had not determined whether the current enemy offensive in South Vietnam violated its understanding with Hanoi.
Queens and C.C.N.Y. last night advanced to the final round of the fifth annual City University of New York tournament.
Following is the text of the Soviet note to East Germany as distributed here by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

Riverdale, paced by Willie Young's 24 points, clinched the Ivy Prep School League basketball championship yesterday by overwhelming Hackley, 7729, on the Riverdale court in the Bronx. It was the 12th straight league victory for the Indians. Riverdale has a 15-1 won-lost season record.

New York City will require $18-billion over the next decade--four times what it can expect to receive--to meet its housing, urban renewal, school construction and recreational needs, a report to the City Planning Commission said yesterday.

Special to The New York Times NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 28 -- Nearly 3,000 Rutgers College students filled the gymnasium here today for a non-mandatory convocation designed to explore the problems of a black student in the American university.

Five assistant vice presidents have been promoted to vice presidents of the Chemical Bank, it was announced yesterday. They are Leonard S. Allen, Neal M. Allen, Robert F. Lewis, Jack Lee Ray and William E. Rowand.
The West Side Savings Bank, based in Greenwich Village in lower Manhattan, and the Prudential Savings Bank in Brooklyn announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge.

Special to The New York Times MADRID, Feb. 28 -- The Spanish Government, which had hoped for closer ties with the United States under the Nixon Administration, has been alarmed and outraged by accounts in the American press depicting differences in Washington over the negotiations to renew military base rights here.
BOSTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -Billy Cunningham scored 38 points tonight to pace the Philadelphia 76ers to a 123-102 victory and snap the Milwaukee Bucks' six-game winning streak.

Columbia University, whose plan to build a gymnasium in Morningside Park was thwarted by protestors, is studying a former trouble spot -- its neighborhood property -- as an alternative site for the gym.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company said today it plans to close its La Crosse, Wis., farm machinery plant as part of a drive to dispose of excess facilities. The company said about 375 employes will be affected by the shutdown. The plant has been operating at less than half capacity for several years.
Max Hirsch, recuperating from a broken nose at a hospital in Columbia, S. C., received some encouraging news yesterday.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Richard W. McLaren, the new head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, indicated today that he expected to bring antitrust suits against "pure" conglomerate mergers -- that is, mergers involving companies in totally unrelated lines of business.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The United States and Czechoslovakia signed in Prague today an air-transport agreement providing Pan American Airways with a permanent basis for its flights to the Czech capital.
A parade of price increases in petroleum products continued yesterday, as several of the industry's largest companies announced upward adjustments.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday that it would hold its annual meeting on April 2 in the Pittsburgh Hilton Hotel. The announcement and proxy material were mailed yesterday to 28,429 stockholders who hold 5,308,799 shares of the company's stock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The National Association of Broadcasters today urged the Federal Communications Commission to defer action on its proposal to regulate future ownership of more than one radio or television station in the same market.

Special to The New York Times GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 28--The fifth annual cham_pagne dinne' dance for the benefit of the Mental Health Association of Nassau County will be held next Friday in the Georgian ballroom of the Garden City Hotel.

A wave of selling rolled into the securities of conglomerate corporations yesterday in the wake of a pessimistically interpreted statement made in Atlanta by Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Exchange.

The Brotherhood of Railway Carmen was forbidden yesterday to carry out its threatened strike against the Long Island Rail Road. The union, whose 1,200 members maintain and repair the line's commuter cars, had announced the strike for 12:01 A.M. Monday.

The New Jersey Turnpike Authority announced yesterday it would market a $100-million series of revenue bonds March 12 in connection with the authority's turnpike widening and improvement program. Smith, Barney Co., Inc., Lehman Brothers, Lazard Freres Co., Kidder, Peabody Co., Inc., and John J. Ryan Co. will head a nationwide group of underwriters.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

Special to The New York Times BERLIN, Saturday, March 1 -- The Soviet Union and its ally, East Germany, threatened last night to impose restrictions on traffic on the lifeline access routes between West Berlin and West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Prices farmers receive for their products advanced 1.5 per cent during the month ended Feb. 15, but prices they pay for items used in production were a record 5 per cent more than a year earlier, the Agriculture Department reported today.

The easing off of Communist shelling of South Vietnamese cities, after an indirect warning that the United States might resume the bombing of North Vietnam, gives hope of ending a crisis that might have endangered the Paris peace talks and led to full-scale resumption of the war.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Ted Williams, manager of the Washington Senators, named as a coach today Johnny Pesky, former Boston Red Sox shortstop who managed the sox in 1963 and part of 1964.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- A private study group has recommended that the farflung system of United States military exchange stores be consolidated into a single organization, the Pentagon announced today.

Two Fire Department lieutenants assisted last night in the birth of a girl in a Bronx apartment after rushing with their apparatus -- a ladder truck and an engine -- to a jangling alarm box outside the building.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Thousands of gallons of oil gushed up anew today in the Santa Barbara Channel from a leak that for a time appeared to have been nearly stopped, and another large slick washed toward the coast.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The question of whether a lawyer who once represented the Ku Klux Klan should become a United States Attorney has been injected into an Alabama patronage dispute between the state's Republican leaders and Postmaster General Winton M. Blount.
Mayor Lindsay strongly criticized the Transit Authority yesterday for what he called undue delays in subway construction and maintenance.

Special to The New York Times JERUSALEM, Feb. 28 -- Robert H. Finch, the United States Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, created a brief stir here tonight by suggesting that President Nixon intended to visit Israel soon.

HARTFORD, Feb. 28 (AP) -Ray Widelski of New York, seeded No. 3, and Ken Binns of Montreal, seeded No. 4, scored victories today in the opening round of the world open squash racquets tournament at the Hartford Golf Club courts.

PARIS, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- Joao Nobe, a Portuguese electrician went to the Elysee Palace today to return a gold cuff link that President Nixon lost during an exuberant handshaking bout with French crowds.
Following are the highlights of the rest of President Nixon's itinerary for his trip to Europe (all European times are local, which is six hours ahead of New York time):

By any standard, Syria is perhaps the most politically unstable country in the Middle East. The power shift reported during the night was the nation's ninth upheaval in 20 years, a period that has also witnessed at least five unsuccessful coups d'etat and frequent shifts in government policies.

The Midland Capital Corporation, an investment concern based here, announced yesterday the election of Robert E. Rich as a director. He is chairman and president of the Rich Products Corporation, Buffalo.

Councilman Robert A. Low, a candidate for the Democratic mayoral nomination, charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay had inherited a program of 108,043 apartments under construction or in planning from the administration of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Nobody who receives a substantial income should escape income tax entirely, Mortimer M. Caplin, former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, told Congress today.

Special to The New York Times ATHENS, Feb. 28 -- A nine-year prison sentence given to Athansios Grieveas, a 27-year-old law student who insulted King Constantine, now in exile, was reduced today to six and a half years. Loukas Papaefthymiou, 35, was sentenced today to eight years' imprisonment for having disseminated Communist propaganda.

Special to The New York Times GENEVA, Feb. 28 -- Switzerland protested today to Jordan, Syria and Lebanon over the machine-gunning of an El Al airliner by Arab guerrillas at the Zurich airport 10 days ago. The protest notes condemned the attack and asked all three Arab Governments to take steps "to prevent any new violations of Swiss territory."

HONOLULU, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Lava was reported spewing 400 feet high last night in three fountains east of the Alae Crater of Kilauea Volcano on Hawaii island. Scientists said the activity was "perking up" in the second phase of the eruptive cycle now in the volcano's most rift zone. They also reported one new eruption. The eruptive cycle begun Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission gave final approval today for the Penn Central Railroad to increase its long-haul passenger service rates.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A Negro sociologist, Dr. Nathan Hare, a black power advocate who has been a central figure in four months of turmoil at San Francisco State College, has been dismissed effective June 30, college officials confirmed today.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 28--Alex Winn scored 26 points to pace Dartmouth to a 74-62 victory over Yale in an Ivy League game tonight. The victory ended a streak of 17 triumphs by the Elis over Dartmouth.

Special to The New York Times PARIS, Saturday, March 1 -- President Nixon and his principal advisers retired last night after a long round of talks with French leaders without any apparent action in the developing Berlin dispute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd, charging that juvenile inmates "are often beaten, brutalized, exploited, sexually abused and even killed" in prison, announced today public hearings on juvenile institutions and prisons, to be held next week.
TOKYO -- Katsuposhi Takayama, 123 pounds, Japan, out-pointed Eulfredo Basco, 123, the Philippines, 10 rounds.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 (AP) -- The New York Mets reported all their players signed today as Ron Swoboda and J. C. Martin agreed to terms.

Special to The New York Times TOKYO, Feb. 28 -- "Oppose Yasokuni Shrine law!" a gray-haired man with a huge green banner shouted into the din of passing traffic "We ask everybody for their cooperation."
The London stock market showed a slightly easier tone at the close yesterday. The Financial Times index closed down 1.8 points at 463.9.

Special to The New York Times MILWAUKEE, Feb. 28 -- A United States District judge ruled here today that the Pabst Brewing Company's purchase of the Blatz Brewing Company in 1958 violated Federal anti-trust laws.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee plans to look into talks in Madrid concerning United States bases and operating rights in Spain.

An advisory committee to the faculty council of Queens College recommended yesterday that the college reinstate an open military and industrial recruitment policy. The proposal will go before the next faculty council meeting, April 17.
MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 28 (AP)--Jerry Walker, a former major league pitcher, was named manager today of the Manchester Yankees of the Eastern Baseball League.

The "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" at the New York City Opera last night was half good and half bad. The bad half was "Cavalleria," poorly sung with a lack of coordination between stage and pit that bordered on the outrageous.
Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's novel about people in a Russian cancer hospital is now being sold in four editions. Two are hard-cover books and two are paperbacks.

Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel is proving a quick learner--to the country's benefit. After his initial fumbles in coping with the Santa Barbara oil pollution disaster, he has emerged as champion of the toughest possible measures to guard against future trouble of the same sort.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A 61-year-old woman patient died at the Georgetown University Hospital today about four hours after she was burned in an operating room explosion and flash fire. The patient. Mrs. David Rothberg, was undergoing thyroid surgery at the time. Dr. John F. Stapleton, the hospital's medical director, said the operation was nearing an end when volatile gas in the anesthetic exploded.

John J. O'Rourke has been named president of the retail division of the Hat Corporation of America. Mr. O'Rourke was previously senior vice president of Edgeworth Knitting Mills and before that he was vice president for marketing at Kennedy's of New England, a retail chain.

Special to The New York Times SAN FRANCISCO -- A bus with singers, conductor and instrumentalists, a station wagon with technical crew and a truck full of costumes, sets and a portable stage left the War Memorial Opera House recently and traveled into the northeastern corner of Arizona. These "forces" and their equipment transformed the stage of the new Navajo Community College in Mani Farms into the immortal never-never land of Mozart's melody and laughter.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Six business executives were named today to help in the proposed overhaul of the nation's postal system.
Prices on new stock issues declined this week for the second consecutive period, but general stock market weakness has not yet affected the number of first public offerings being made.

A New York furrier was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of evading $8,000 in income taxes for 1962 and 1963. He was also charged with filing false returns for those years. The defendant, Abraham Graff, 49 years old, of 1701 West Third Street, Brooklyn, was associated with Graff Furs, Inc., 242 West 30th Street, at the time.

Special to The New York Times LISBON, Feb. 28 -- A heavy force of Portuguese shock police, armed with rifles and submachine guns, thwarted a student demonstration in front of the United States Embassy here today.
TOKYO, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- Japan's gold and foreign exchange reserves now total $3.09-billion, surpassing the $3-billion mark for the first time, Government sources said today.

Special to The New York Times TOULOUSE, France, Feb. 28 -- "The date for the first flight had nothing to do with Nixon's visit," a manufacturer's spokesman insisted today. "Turcat would never have allowed it."

Special to The New York Times PRAGUE, Feb. 28 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party newspaper today condemned any "return to outdated centralist forms" of world Communist unity. It implicitly rejected the doctrine of "limited sovereignty" that the Soviet Union enunciated last year to justify the invasion of Czechoslovakia.

A member of Dr. Denton Cooley's heart transplant team said yesterday that the heart had turned out to be a less privileged organ for transplant patients than anyone had thought a year ago.

Special to The New York Times LISBON, Feb. 28 -- A heavy force of Portuguese shock police, armed with rifles and submachine guns, thwarted a student demonstration in front of the United States Embassy here today.
TOKYO, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- Japan's gold and foreign exchange reserves now total $3.09-billion, surpassing the $3-billion mark for the first time, Government sources said today.

Special to The New York Times TOULOUSE, France, Feb. 28 -- "The date for the first flight had nothing to do with Nixon's visit," a manufacturer's spokesman insisted today. "Turcat would never have allowed it."

It implicitly rejected the doctrine of "limited sovereignty" that the Soviet Union enunciated last year to justify the invasion of Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, said today modern coal-mining machines increase the "hazards of explosion and lung disease." He called for development of new and safer mining systems.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Five hundred students and faculty members at Cornell University, meeting tonight ta discuss Cornell's relations with South Africa, watched in stunned silence as an unidentified Negro youth briefly seized the shoulder of the university president, James Perkins, and another Negro threatened the proctor 7/8 Loweli R. George, with a plank.

Special to The New York Times SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 28 -Eleven students and former students of the University of Puerto Rico were sentenced yesterday to six to 14 months in jail on each of three counts in connection with riots on the Rio Piedras campus in September of 1967. They were released on $3,000 bail apiece, pending an appeal to the island's Supreme Court.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON -- "Number One, these two children were driving us crazy and it's too cold to go to the zoo. Number Two, I'm inerested in what's going on here. And Number Three, I'm a secret scout for my husband -- I'm looking for a camper."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A scientific instrument patented for a Massachusetts company is replacing other means of determining the fluoride content of water. The invention is an electrode that produces an immediate reading on a dial.
A FEATHER-LIGHT coffeecake filled with a swirl of fruits and nuts or topped with cinnamon-flavored apple slices would be appropriate to serve at a Sunday brunch or a weekday kaffee-klatsch.

Special to The New York Times THE HAGUE, Feb. 28 -- The seven Roman Catholic bishops of the Netherlands have agreed to experiment with a new kind of religious ceremony in which married priests are allowed to preach.

Special to The New York Times LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 -- In a voice seething with anger, Sirhan B. Sirhan interrupted his trial today to demand that he be allowed to change his plea to guilty of the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and to request his own execution.
The Curtis Publishing Company may be without a president after Monday afternoon.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Philadelphia's 22 Municipal Court judges threatened today to strike late next month unless they are paid.
The police were accused here yesterday by two teen-age former drug users not only of allowing the open sale of narcotics but also of selling drugs themselves "to make a little extra money."
DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The steel framework of the new University of Dayton Field House collapsed today injuring thre plumbers working on the $5-million project. None was hurt seriousiously.

BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Sheriff's deputies and a half dozen National Guardsmen with bayoneted rifles used tear gas late today to break up strike pickets blocking the main entrance to the University of California.

Special to The New York Times MIAMI, Feb. 28 -- The Hialeah Turf Cup will be the feature on the card at Hialeah tomorrow, the final Saturday of the eminently successful meeting. With a field of 12 listed to compete in the mile-and-a-half event on the grass, the Turf Cup will have a gross value of $111,350, its richest ever.

Special to The New York Times VIENNA, Feb. 28 -- The Roman Catholic bishops of Austria approved today an advisory study that contends that the practice of birth control is to be left to the conscience of individual Catholics.
"PHEDRE," a French classic written by the playwright Racine about 300 years ago, may be great, but, at least in the version being presented here by La Comedie de Bourges, it is not timeless.
A foot of snow fell in the Middle West yesterday blocking highways and closing schools. More light snow fell in New England, which was still digging out from up to eight feet of snow.

The nation's savings and loan associations, the largest single source of home-mortgage credit, had a net outflow of savings of $73-million during January, substantially less than the $238-million outflow in the comparable month last year, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

Special to The New York Times PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Scattered anti-American violence, a march of several thousand extremist students and the arrest of nearly 200 demonstrators marked the arrival of President Nixon in Paris today.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 28 (UPI) --Burley M. Crowe was appointed today assistant defensive coach for the Cornell University football team.
