CAPE KENNEDY, March 3 (AP) -- After monitoring two manned Apollo missions, ground controllers are confident they can accurately handle all systems on the orbiting spaceship. As a result, the three Apollo 9 astronauts will sleep at the same time.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 3 (UPI) -- At least 45 government soldiers were killed and more than 100 were wounded in attacks Saturday and yesterday by eight battalions of Communistled guerrillas on Laotian outposts in the northeastern province of Samneua, according to high-ranking officials.

Business formations in the United States are holding steady in the face of higher operating costs, riots and tax difficulties, it was disclosed yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., the credit reporting agency.

Everyone interested in Mideast peace will hope that the Government of Iraq is not dissembling in its disavowal of plans to hang seven more persons, three of them Jews, on charges of spying for Israel. Baghdad must have learned by now that it contributes nothing to its own security by executions based on star chamber proceedings and then publicized through gruesome exhibitions in the public square.

MIAMI, March 3 -- Bob Johnson's new 73-foot racing machine, Windward Passage, from Freeport, the Bahamas, was slamming into the seas to her home islands today with characteristic alacrity at the head of the fleet engaged in the Miami-Nassau Race, a major sailing event in the Southern Ocean Racing Conference series.
" I had some misgivings when I accepted this invitation," Peter Gay, the author, said. "They have not diminished in the least in the last half-hour."
FORT DIX, N. J., March 4 -- A court-martial here considered today whether to admit testimony that Edwin C. Arnett decided to desert after meeting people from a Japanese peace committee.

The election of David A. Chernow and Howard S. Feldman as directors and executive vice presidents of Schenlay Industries, Inc., was announced yesterday. Both had been vice presidents. Adolph Slone, the company's newly appointed director of manufacturing, was elected a vice president.
College track and field coaches in the metropolitan area unanimously predicted yesterday that Villanova would win another I.C.4-A team title Saturday night at Madison Square Garden.

Lew Alcindor of the University of California, Los Angeles yesterday became only the fourth player to gain first-team recognition on the United Press International all-America squad in three successive seasons.
YONKERS, March 3 -- While spectators took cover inside the heated stands, drivers continued looking for a different kind of cover tonight out on the windswept track at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The Supreme Court rejected today a contention that Federal tax agents should be required to warn people before questioning them about their returns that the inquiry could lead to criminal prosecution.

I am appalled at the incongruities contained in the full page advertisement placed by the real estate industry in The Times of Feb. 24. In it the industry is trying to say that because of substantially higher costs, the recent increases in rents are obviously justified.

MONTREAL, March 3 -- The International Civil Aviation Organization Council approved a United States proposal today to consider the hijacking of commercial aircraft and armed attacks upon them at the present session.

A New York University senior was expelled yesterday after a disciplinary panel found him guilty of leading demonstrations against Nguyen Huu Chi, South Vietnam's Permanent Observer to the United Nations, and James Reston, the executive editor of The New York Times.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 3 -- The Apollo 9 astronauts rocketed into orbit today and successfully executed the first of the complex maneuvers necessary to prove the fragile lunar module capable of landing men on the moon.
MIAMI, March 3 (AP) -- Boog Powell, the Baltimore Orioles' big first baseman, ended his holdout today by accepting a salary reported at $45,000.

The job of flying the extremely complex lunar module for the first time, on the Apollo 9 mission, was entrusted by the space agency to a former water boiler repairman whose flying career is uncomplicated by romanticism.

JERUSALEM, March 3 -- The Israel Labor party took another step tonight in the process of naming Mrs. Golda Meir to succeed Premier Levi Eshkol, who died last Wednesday.

JERUSALEM, March 3 -- The Israel Labor party took another step tonight in the process of naming Mrs. Golda Meir to succeed Premier Levi Eshkol, who died last Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower continued to show progress today in his recovery from major surgery and the pneumonia that complicated it.
Seven youths were arrested in a battle with the police yesterday outside William Howard Taft High School in the Bronx as student unrest continued to plague the city's schools.

NEW ORLEANS, March 3 -Declaring that he had "just begun to fight," District Attorney Jim Garrison charged Clay L. Shaw with perjury late today. Mr. Shaw was declared not guilty last Saturday morning on a charge of conspiring to assassinate President Kennedy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 3 -- Scientists across the country are preparing to put aside their research tomorrow to gather to consider the uses and misues to which their discoveries are put by Government and society.
ALBANY, March 3 -- Industry spokesmen raised sharp objections tonight to pioneering proposals to limit the amount of heated water that may be added to lakes, rivers and the ocean shoreline.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The 15year war between the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor and the leadership of the International Longshoremen's Association entered a new phase today.
Mayor Lindsay brushed aside yesterday Governor Rockefeller's contention that he was overestimating the city's financial difficulties.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- The Canadian flag, the French language and the Montreal Expos are here -and with them begins an unusual adventure in the history of major league baseball.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Navy's highest officer maintained today under presistent Congressional questioning that the Joint Chiefs of Staff gave "proper consideration" to the risks involved in widespread intelligence activities such as the use of the U.S.S. Pueblo.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 4 (UPI) -- Iraq strongly reaffirmed today her right to execute spies, saying that "no power in the world" could stop her.
The Afro-American Society of Columbia University demanded yesterday that an all-Negro board be set up to direct "all programs for black students or for the study of the black experience."

A 15-story apartment house in Greenwich Village has been purchased as an investment by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York for about $850,000.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel told the coal industry today that unless it agreed to drastic reforms in its "inexcusably" bad safety practices it would find men unwilling to work in the mines.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) -- A former Arkansas prison head, dismissed after he had stirred up an investigation of inmate murders, told a Senate hearing today that the nation's prisons were brutal "monster -producing factories."
Prices of silver futures rose sharply in active trading yesterday, apparently reflecting in part speculation that the French franc would weaken and trigger a new monetary crisis.

The 101st running of the $125,000 added Belmont Stakes, at Belmont Park on June 7, has drawn 153 nominations. The list was released yesterday by Thomas E. Trotter, racing secretary of The New York Racing Association.

Three hundred and three persons were arrested in the Times Square area during a seven-day period that ended Sunday, Inspector Edmund A. Donnelly of the Third Division of the Police Department reported yesterday.

Victory, the one that established a club record for triumphs in one season, came hard for the New York Knickerbockers last night at Madison Square Garden, but Dave DeBusschere came to the rescue in the final minutes and lifted the Knicks to a 102-99 triumph over the Detroit Pistons.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Thomas C. Morrill, vice president of the State Farm Insurance Company, warned Senators today of "profound and threatening overtones" in absorption of auto insurance concerns by conglomerate companies.

PARIS, March 4 -- The defense in a sensational murder case demanded today that former Premier Georges Pompidou and his wife be questioned about conflicting testimony by two witnesses.

LONDON, March 4 -- British reserves of gold and convertible currency rose 8-million ($19.2-million) in February to about 1.02-billion ($2.45-billion), the Treasury announced today.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 4 -- The faculty of the University of California here went on record tonight as favoring the speedy establishment of an ethnic studies department, a principal demand of minority students on strike for the last 42 days.
BRUSSELS, March 4 -- Gold prices rose to new highs in Europe today, reflecting tensions in Berlin and the Middle East and concern about the French franc.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 5 -- North Vietnamese troops attacked an American Special Forces camp in the Central Highlands yesterday.

BERLIN, March 4 -- East German border troops closed the main autobahn out of Berlin this afternoon for two hours at both ends -- a somewhat stiffer measure than the two previous blockades at the western end Saturday and Sunday.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 4 -- Violence erupted today in East and West Pakistan after a comparatively quiet period of about two weeks.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- It may have been the lower pitching mound, or the smaller strike zone or even the 25-mile wind howling toward left field. But, whatever it was, the New York Mets slugged five home runs today in their first practice game of spring training.
YONKERS, March 4 -- Like a chariot in a relay race, Roosevelt Raceway will pick up tomorrow night where Yonkers Raceway left off tonight.
Prices on the London stock market showed a mixed trend yesterday as leading industrial shares declined moderately and secondary issues gained on selective buying.
Two top figures in contemporary music have teamed up in an album to be released by Columbia Records in two weeks.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 4 (AP) -- The man who planned Japan's air attack on Pearl Harbor is receiving a generally warm response from the representatives of the same Navy he tried to destroy 27 years ago.

GENEVA, March 4 (AP) -The United Nations Commission on Human Rights adopted unanimously today a resolution on the Middle East that avoided directly blaming either the Arab states or Israel for the current situation.
Four of the Sanitation Department's top supervisors were reassigned yesterday by Sanitation Commissioner Griswold L. Moeller.
The state Human Rights Agency said yesterday it had ordered a Dobbs Ferry club to pay $100 to a 5-year-old Negro boy for having barred him from the club swimming pool.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 4 -The Florida sun was blazing one spring morning many years ago when Frank Lane came out of his general manager's office waving a newspaper and grinning a large grin. His star home-run hitter had been obdurately holding out in the frozen North and the ebullient Lane had not been smiling often.

LOS ANGELES, March 4 -Sirhan Bishara Sirhan testified today that several weeks before the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy he saw the Senator on television helping Israelis to celebrate their independence and became so enraged he wanted to kill him.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- While Richard M. Nixon is assuming the powers of the Presidency, a small band of workers here is striving to memorialize his predecessor, Lyndon B. Johnson.
TEL AVIV, March 4 -- Israel's chief of staff, Gen. Haim BarLev, warned the United Arab Republic today to end its campaign of sniping along the Suez Canal.

The trustees of the Cyrus H. K. Curtis estate plan to ask the Curtis Publishing Company to call a special stockholders' meeting to elect a new board of directors, an attorney for Cary W. Bok, a trustee, said yesterday.

Investigators from two agencies have reported indications of mismanagement and possible fraud in the investment of city employe pension funds in mortgages by the office of Controller Mario A. Procaccino.

The Tennessee Volunteers, finishing a surprising second to Kentucky in the strong Southeastern Conference, were named yesterday the sixth team to compete in the National Invitation Basketball Tournament at Madison Square Garden.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 4 -- Informants from Damascus said today that Lieut. Gen. Hafez al-Assad, Syria's dominant military figure, had carried his struggle with Maj. Gen. Salah Jadid, the Baath party leader, to the Baath party's congress.
MONTREAL, March 4 (UPI) -- The police raided a rooming house early today and arrested a man believed to be linked with a terrorist group involved in a series of bombing incidents in recent months.

To the Editor: Your Feb. 19 editorial "Friction Between State and City" was replete with charges and countercharges between Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay. Each attempted to blame the other for the lack of progress in public improvements in the city.
The formation of Standard Poor's InterCapital, Inc., a new financial management organization initially supervising $3-billion in assets, was announced yesterday.
Dr. Bernard E. Donovan announced yesterday that he would step down as Superintendent of Schools on Aug. 31.

ALBANY, March 5 -- State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. has asked the New York City Board of Education to reinstate immediately the Ocean Hill-Brownsville governing board, which has been suspended since Oct. 6.
In his news conference responses on Vietnam, President Nixon obviously tried to strike a balance between caution and threat, between realism and measured optimism.

HELMSTEDT, West Germany, March 5 -- East German Army sentries closed the autobahn from Helmstedt-to-Berlin from 8 A.M. to 11 A.M. and from 2 P.M. to 6 P.M. today, the fourth closure of the road since Saturday, but traffic was light so delays were not as serious as had been expected.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) -- Congress itself must accept some responsibility for the continuing pollution of the Great Lakes by the Army Corps of Engineers, members of the House public works Committee said today.
The hundreds of Italian seamen visiting the Port of New York every month are keeping a sharp eye on the progress of a small construction project on West 44th Street.

LONDON, March 5 -- Lloyd's of London has given "a good heavy chip at the rocks of Britain's Male Establishment,'' as one elated businesswoman here put it, commenting on the recently announced decision of the world's leading society of private insurance underwriters to admit women as members next January.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Nixon today named Dr. Thomas O. Paine, a scientist, administrator and World War II submarine officer, to head the nation's civilian space program.

PRAGUE, March 5 -- The leader of Czechoslovakia's biggest and most progressive trade union today rejected Government entreaties that the labor movement remain obediently silent. He warned that "we cannot tolerate at any price that uncontrolled power be established in our country."

ALBANY, March 5 -- State-Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges charged today that Albert M. Bowker, Chancellor of the City University of New York, had been giving the Legislature "phony" enrollment figures to gain more state aid for the university.
LAGOS, Nigeria, March 5 -- Why do the bombings go on? Why doesn't the federal Government realize it is only hurting its own cause? In short, why doesn't someone do something?

The Columbia Gas System, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday total operating revenues of $706,856,000 for 1968. This compared with $683,082,000 a year earlier. Net income rose to $77,045,000, equal to $2.53 a share, from $72,500,000, or $2.39 a share, in 1967.

MOSCOW, March 5 -- A prominent Soviet economist has charged that progress in economic reform was being slowed by rigid theoreticians and well-entrenched bureaucrats who feared changes in the Soviet system.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Consumers expended record amounts to pay off their debts in January, cutting the expansion of consumer installment credit to the lowest level since last April, the Federal Reserve reported today.
PARIS, March 5 -- Several million documents pertaining to the history of France were donated today to the official National Archives here by Henri, Count of Paris, a pretender to the French throne.

EIGHT-YEAR-OLD Brian Berk looked forlorn as he watched his father train Volchi, the 9-month-old Husky, at an A.S.P.C.A. obedience class. Brian had wanted to train Volchi himself, but there was a problem: The dog was stronger than he was.

The outlook for major power action to bring movement toward peace in the Middle East was brightened considerably by President Nixon's report. Though he avoided predictions that Israel would soon be sitting down opposite the Arabs in direct talks, he provided hope for a break in the stalemate by reporting "substantial progress" toward reconciling the views of the Western nations and by terming "encouraging" his talks with Soviet Ambassador Dobrynin.
Having worked in someone else's backyard these last six weeks, Gordon Davidson thinks that he will find the grass a little greener when he returns home to Los Angeles shortly.
Mayor Lindsay has proposed that the Federal Government turn over to the cities part of the $18-billion a year it is now spending for research and development in space and defense programs.

LONDON, March 5 (AP) -- Prince Philip fired another broadside at Britain today, asserting that far too many people were "just sitting around," others were smothered by government controls and the truly creative were inadequately rewarded.

In what was described as "a daring move, bringing someone in to head a major store from outside the world of retailing," William M. Fine, the 42-year old publishing director of Harper's Bazaar, House Beautiful and Town Country, yesterday was named president of Bonwit Teller, the Fifth Avenue fashion apparel chain.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 -- Tom Seaver, of all people, was touched for four runs in one inning today as the New York Mets held their final tune-up for the exhibition baseball season.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Apparently more by accident than by design, a Nixon-Kennedy confrontation is shaping up over whether the United States should deploy a missile defense system.

The establishment of an automated system of block trading by a private concern in competition with the New York Stock Exchange was announced yesterday. The new system, operated by the Institutional Networks Corporation, will compete for business from institutional investors with a comparable system being established by the exchange. However, it also will enable institutions to avoid paying commissions on transactions in listed securities.
WESTBURY, L.I., March 5 -- The marshal "called the pacers" again tonight, just as he has been doing since Jan. 3.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 5 -- The Gulfstream Park meeting of 43 racing days started today in bright, crisp and clear weather.
BERLIN, March 5 -- For a day, this divided city seemed like the capital of all of divided Germany, with leaders of the Eastern and Western parts on their respective sides of the wall.

Following are highlights in the flight plan of the Apollo 9 spacecraft for the remainder of the 10-day mission. Because of Russell L. Schweickart's space nausea, today's activities were altered to omit Mr. Schweickart's scheduled "walk" in space.

WHEN Mrs. Pat Connor of Melbourne, Australia, was 8 years old, her father gave her an Australian terrier. That was 24 years ago. Mrs. Connor now is the top-winning fancier of the breed in her native land and her Aussies are gaining fame in other countries as well.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 5 -- Classrooms in the University of Puerto Rico's School of Social Sciences were empty or near-empty this morning as hundreds of students held a peaceful protest rally in the open-air lobby, demanding curriculum reform.

A State Supreme Court justice warned four city commissioners yesterday that they faced 30-day jail sentences for "their apparent wilful disobedience" of another justice's order to hold examinations for the post of warden of the city's correctional institutions.

WALL STREET circles are getting more and more concerned about the current high level of speculation. The latest to fly the warning flag is the Investment Bankers Association of America, whose members bring to market most new issues of securities.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 5 (AP) -- A four-engine plane carrying 17 passengers and two crewmen to San Juan from St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands vanished today over eastern Puerto Rico while strong winds buffeted the island.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, expressed concern today that the financial policies of some conglomerate companies that have taken over insurance companies may make it harder than ever for some people to get automobile insurance.
Gold and silver stocks gave the market its chief dazzlers yesterday, as blue-chip issues extended their technical rally with diminished force.
A plan to establish new high schools in disadvantaged areas of the city, under the complete operation of the City University, is being considered by the Board of Higher Education.
A break in a major water main outside Lincoln Center sent water lapping over the curbs of Broadway and Columbus Avenue last night, disrupting subway and surface traffic.
LONDON, March 5 -- "Life doesn't stop at 75. What keeps a man young is using his head. I mean really using his brain. Deep mental exercises. That's why lexicographers live to ripe old ages."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 6 -- The heaviest and most damaging rocket attack of the year hit Saigon early this morning, killing at least 22 civilians and wounding scores.

HOUSTON, March 5 -- Russell L. Schweickart and ground physicians were equally puzzled today about the cause and the extent of the illness that forced the cancellation of the astronaut's "space walk" scheduled for tomorrow.

Increasing numbers of actors are joining the fight against cigarette smoking. Some are refusing to participate in radio and television commercials. Others are speaking out about the hazards of tobacco.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- H. Rex Lee, the newest member of the Federal Communications Commission, told the Senate today that he had a strong interest in the quality of broadcasting and "no reluctance to urge network officials to improve their programing."

The City Investing Company had the highest sales and profits in its history for the three and nine months ended Jan. 31, quadrupling its earnings from the year-ago level, according to the company's report issued yesterday.
PARIS, March 5 -- Small business almost came to halt in France this afternoon as merchants closed their shutters to protest rising taxes.

Why, then, did he go on to use "words threatening deeds" by stating flatly and publicly that the United States "will not tolerate" continued attacks of a certain kind by Communist forces in Vietnam?
COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 5 (UPI) -- Bob Ward resigned today after serving two seasons as head football coach at the University of Maryland.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 5 -- The first soldier to flee the war in Vietnam to a foreign country and come home for trial was found guilty of desertion today.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -President Nixon drew praise from Congressional leaders of both parties today for what was regarded as his restrained attitude toward international crises from Vietnam to Berlin.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Justice Department began today to initiate its lawyers into the mysteries of a complicated new timekeeping system designed to help the department convince Congress that it is understaffed.

The contest between Northwest Industries, Inc., and the B. F. Goodrich Company took two new turns yesterday as Northwest revised the terms of its proposed tender offer for the rubber company's stock and Goodrich announced a small acquisition that could place a big obstacle in the way of Northwest's take-over plans.

AMMAN, Jordan -- Friendly but grave, and a little tense, the commanding officer of the training camp of Al Fatah sat in a tent set among thick trees with his back to an oversized colored sketch of his leader, Yasir Arafat.

NASSAU, The Bahamas, March 5 -- Bob Johnson of the New York Yacht Club and Freeport, the Bahamas, lost a protest hearing against the Southern Ocean Racing Conference race committee today. With that went the last chance his big ketch, Windward Passage, had to become the circuit's champion.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Antioch College in Yellow Springs, Ohio, has been told by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare that it will lose Federal funds if it continues to operate a segregated black studies program.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- A Washington lobbyist and a South Carolina advertising executive were named today as top assistants to Postmaster General Winton M. Blount.

HOUSTON, March 5 -- The squat spacecraft designed to land men on the moon passed its first manned flight test today and was declared in good shape -- which was more than could be said for one of the Apollo 9 astronauts.

Two frightened restaurateurs told the State Investigation Commission yesterday that they had paid tribute to a Mafia-tainted independent union in which they enrolled their employes, often without the employes' knowing the boss was paying their "union dues."

VAIL, Colo., March 5 -"Those crazy French, no wonder they're such speed demons on the slopes," said a local ski official today as she watched some of the world's top Alpine racers engage in tune-up, nonstop downhill runs today.

A National Labor Relations Board examiner has ordered the National Maritime Union to stop denying employment opportunities to seamen who engage in intraunion activities or otherwise oppose the union's leadership.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) -- The Canadian Embassy said today that it had received hundreds of letters from seal lovers and conservationists decrying the baby seal hunt to begin Friday in the Gulf of St. Lawrence.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -A Senate Armed Services subcommittee prodded the military services today to get tougher with deserters, especially those who fled to foreign countries.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 5 -- The Chicago Cubs romped, frolicked, hollered and hustled while rehearsing baseball today in the tiny tidy Scottsdale stadium. They enjoyed the goading by their highly visible and vocal manager, Leo Durocher, who had a needling word for almost everyone.
PEREIRA, Colombia, March 5 -- An anti-United States protest at the Technological University of Pereira has collapsed.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -Ruth Eisemann-Schier, accused in the kidnapping of the daughter of a wealthy Florida real estate developer, was arrested today in Norman, Okla., by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Fairleigh S. Dickinson 3d, the son of New Jersey State Senator Fairleigh S. Dickinson Jr., died here yesterday afternoon. The 18 - year - old freshman at Columbia was found unconscious in the room of a fellow student and was pronounced dead a few minutes after his arrival at St. Luke's Hospital.
The Nixon Administration called on business and labor yesterday to use restraint in raising prices and wages.

California was unable to sell a $40-million bond issue yesterday, because credit conditions had become so tight that no one would lend the state the long-term funds at an interest rate lower than the 5 per cent maximum it is allowed by statute to pay.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 5 -Arnold Palmer, who has won more money playing golf than anyone else, was forced to quit the pro tour today for two weeks. Five women will receive the National Community Leadership Award from the National Women's League of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America next Thursday at the New York Hilton.
PARIS, March 5 (Reuters) -- President de Gaulle told his Cabinet today that President Nixon's visit last weekend deepened their personal and political relations.

Reflecting the changes in the surrounding area, an old 15-story loft building opposite the new Madison Square Garden will be modernized for office use.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Nixon Administration, in its first major farm policy decision, cut the Federal price support of soybeans today by 25 cents a bushel.

After a respite of scarcely three months since last November's crisis, the international monetary system is again in turmoil. The price of gold, which rises as the confidence in national currencies wanes, yesterday was at its highest since the London gold market was freed from government intervention last year.

ALBANY, March 6 -- Segments of organized labor began a last-minute campaign today to kill or soften the impact of a Republican bill to impose tougher penalties on striking public employes and their unions.

Fordham's basketball team apparently played its way into the National invitation Tournament last night by beating Manhattan, 85-75, at Madison Square Garden. The victory closed out Fordham's regular season with a 17-9 won-lost record, and a formal invitation is expected to be tendered today.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants' are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

KARACHI, Pakistan -- On leaving the Middle East one is impressed by this blazing fact: There can be no peaceful settlement without an arms freeze and there has probably never been a better time to institute such an embargo.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., March 6 -- An injunction was issued today to prevent Vassar College from changing its rules concerning visiting by men in the dormitories.

LONDON, March 6 -- The Ford Motor Company's British subsidiary today lost the first round of an unusual legal action against Britain's two largest labor unions. The case represented a Ford attempt to tighten this country's lax industrial relations practices.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- If ever there was a demonstration that no decision in Washington is final and that the struggle for a President's mind never really ends while he remains in office, it came a year ago this month.
PARIS, March 6 -- Fresh monetary jitters hit Europe today. They were aggravated by worsening labor problems in France and new rumors that the franc would be devalued.

This week's technical rally in the stock market ran into an abrupt selling squall yesterday in which only gold issues showed signs of group strength.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) -- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel named three new assistants today.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A drug reported to show promise for mass treatment of one of the most widespread of human infectious diseases was described here today.

OPENINGS and closings on Broadway are standard fare for the Great White Way. One opening, slated for March 25th, which bids fair to have a long run, is for the new $25,000 Red Carpet Shoe Salon at Cye Martin's, the clothing impresario who has held forth on Broadway for some 38 years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 6 -- Israel pressed Secretary General Thant today to call on Arab governments to crack down on terrorist organizations, based in their countries, that are responsible for attacks against Israel.

The Republican county leader in the Bronx, Councilman A. Joseph Ribustello, has now joined his opposite number in Staten Island in fighting Mayor Lindsay's renomination by the G.O.P. Two New York City schools were closed yesterday, one because of a barricade by parents demanding the appointment of a Negro supervisor and the other because of a rampage by youngsters protesting the disciplining of a fellow student.

PIERRE BOULEZ, in town to start a four-week appearance with the New York Philharmonic, made a prior appearance in the Hunter College Auditorium last night. With a hand-picked group of musicians, and with Bethany Beardslee as the soprano, he participated in the kind of program so dear to his heart -- a program mostly devoted to the Viennese atonalists, with an excursion into Debussy, and the inclusion of one of his own works.
A group of experts on American Indian affairs, meeting here yesterday, called on Congress to alleviate the "catastrophic" disruption of Indian home life.

WHITE PLAINS, March 7 -Westchester County Sheriff's deputies with a search warrant entered a large printing plant in Mamaroneck this afternoon and seized what Sheriff Daniel F. MacMahon called "two or three tons of obscene material."

MOSCOW, March 7 -- Demonstrators broke about 100 windows at the Chinese Embassy in Moscow today while the Soviet Union charged that its own embassy in Peking was "under siege." Tens of thousands of marchers trooped by the Chinese Embassy for three hours this afternoon to protest the border battle in the Far East last Sunday.

LONDON, March 7 -- The pound came under pressure in the foreign exchange market today in the backwash of the troubles of the French franc. The market was also ruffled by a gloomy assessment of the British outlook by the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

BALTIMORE, March 7 (UPI) -- Barbara Jo Rubin, 19-yearold girl jockey, stole the show at the opening of Pimlico's 52day race meeting today when she rode one winner and finished a close second in her other race.
A champagne supper dance will be held at the Americana on April 1 after the New York premiere of the motion picture "Sweet Charity" at the Rivoli Theater.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI) -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today proposed regulations that would liberalize requirements for the amount of cash on hand required to be held by savings and loan institutions.
A DECLARER tries to play trivial cards in a manner that will conceal information from the defenders or hamper their exchange of signals, but it is not always easy to know how to do this.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- With two optimistic predictions, the New York Mets ended the noncombat phase of spring training today and moved crosstown for their first exhibition game of the season.

The Allied Chemical Corporation's net earnings for 1968 were down to $17,814,000, or 64 cents a share, from $73,251,000, or $2.62 a share, in 1967, the annual report disclosed yesterday. Sales and operating revenues, however, improved to $1,278,071,000 in 1968 from $1,243,411,000 the year before.
CAIRO, March 7 -- The editor of the influential Cairo newspaper Al Ahram said today that the Arabs could win what he termed the forthcoming battle with Israel if it lasted six or eight weeks.

With its pretty girls in Indian headbands, elderly bohemians, friendly and hatted women from the Lower East Side, the audience at Cooper Union's free programs is not only the most gregarious in town but also part of the show.

With little citywide fanfare the Lindsay administration has launched an important new planning program for Staten Island -- one whose long-run effects could be momentous. On this and two other critical Staten Island issues, the Mayor ought to have citywide support; the island's development is no parochial matter.

THE history of Italian art in the 20th century boasts at least one outstanding movement -- futurism -- and at least three outstanding painters -Giorgio de Chirico, Amedeo Modigliani and Giorgio Morandi -- whose stature shows no sign of diminishing with the passage of time.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 7 -- Secretary General Thant announced today that he would advise the Security Council tomorrow on his efforts to assist in the evacuation of Spaniards from Equatorial Guinea.
JERUSALEM, March 7 -- Mrs. Golda Meir, a former Foreign Minister, today accepted her party's call to succeed the late Levi Eshkol as Premier of Israel.

DETROIT, March 7 (AP) -The Detroit Pistons rallied from a 15-point deficit with five minutes left in the third period to trounce the Cincinnati Royals, 114-105, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
HOUSTON, March 7 -Following is a partial transcript of radio conversations today between ground controllers here at the Manned Spacecraft Center and the crewmen of Apollo 9.
INVERCARGILL, New Zealand -- Muttonbirds are controversial even in Invercargill, where the New Zealand supply of this exotic game reaches the market.
LONDON, March 7 -- With Queen Elizabeth II riding a subway for the first time in 30 years, London today proudly opened "the most modern underground line in the world."

American technology scored a stunning triumph yesterday when the lunar module -- known to the men who fly it as the "spider" -- maneuvered successfully in space. The feasibility of the entire American strategy for landing men on the moon and returning them safely to earth was at stake in that crucial experiment.

To the Editor: A recent letter to the editor [Ruth Perlmutter, March 1] has urged the boycott of Canadian furs in response to a news film which described the brutal killing of baby seals in New Brunswick, including skinning alive to produce unscarred pelts.

PARIS, March 7 -- As fears of labor unrest spread in France, monetary anxieties intensified today in European financial centers. The French franc and the pound sterling came under renewed pressure, and prices for gold in London, Zurich and Paris reached new highs.
LONDON, March 7 -- Criticism by shareholders of the management of F. W. Woolworth, Ltd., erupted at the annual meeting of the company here today.

NEWARK, March 7 (AP) -Several Negro students at the Rutgers University campus here began boycotting classes today in the aftermath of a faculty vote opposing an admissions agreement between the dissident students and the administration.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Following are the official results of new tests reported by the Federal Trade Commission's laboratory of tar and nicotine content of 126 brands of cigarettes. The results are listed according to increasing amount of tar content and compared with a report of October, 1968. The numbers represent the number of milligrams of tar and nicotine in the smoke of the cigarettes tested.
PARIS, March 7 -- Laperouse, a 200-year-old temple of rich dining and comfort that has long been a symbol of Paris to many Americans, lost one of its three stars in the Guide Michelin today.

MESA, Ariz., March 7 -- The holdout capitulated -- as all holdouts do -- and went to work today for the Oakland Athletics, a team no longer a joke but rather a threat in the Western Division of the American League.

Most of the major oil companies have now followed Texaco's lead and raised their crude oil prices in amounts ranging from 5 to 20 cents a barrel. When those advances are fully reflected in higher retail prices, the American consumers' total bill for gasoline, heating oil and other petroleum products is likely to increase by some $400 million.
HOUSTON, March 7 -- About $100-million worth of space hardware will literally go up in smoke as a result of the casting adrift today of the Apollo 9 lunar module's two stages.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, March 7 -- Salty Tiger, a 46-foot aluminum yawl that make her competitive debut with the six events that comprise, the series, became the winner of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference championship today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7 -The New York Knickerbockers, who are spending a three-day weekend here in an attempt to take over second place in the National Basketball Association Eastern Division from the resident 76ers, drew an easy opponent tonight at the Spectrum and walloped the Phoenix Suns, 119-87.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee urged the Administration today to delay the deployment of an antimissile defense system while it sought a strategic arms control agreement with the Soviet Union.

Hope for some reform of New York State's savage and antiquated abortion law seems brighter now than at any time since its enactment in 1883. The law, which permits legal abortion only to save the life of the mother, has caused a scandalously large number of deaths and immeasurable suffering.
Prices on the London stock market were down at the close yesterday as currency pressures added to weekend caution.

THE American man, used to the slow brewing of masculine fashion, can look forward to a more exciting cup of tea next fall. The designers who showed collections this week-weren't focusing on minor matters like the width of a lapel or the slant of a pocket. Unleashed from old restraints, they're giving men such things as jersey suits, suits with longer (but not nipped) jackets or with topcoats instead of jackets, or jackets without sleeves.

LOS ANGELES, March 7 (AP) -- The unbeaten University of California, Los Angeles, saved from defeat in a first overtime on a desperation shot, scored the first 8 points in the second overtime to turn back Southern California, 61-55, in a Pacific-Eight basketball game tonight.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., March 7 -- Charles Pasarell displayed a blistering service here tonight as he topped No. 1 ranked Arthur Ashe, 31-23, in the opening round of the third annual Long Island indoor tennis tournament.
While preparations for Monday's opener continued yesterday at Aqueduct, the Pinkerton Security Forces approved a new three-year contract with the New York Racing Association. The vote was 103-25.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 7 -- A military Court in Baghdad has acquitted two Iraqis and two Iranians accused as spies, the Baghdad radio reported tonight. The report added, however, that the Iranians were sentenced to three years in prison on charges of having given false evidence against the other two.

PRAGUE, March 7 -- Czechoslovak trade unions ended their seventh congress today by unanimously endorsing a resolution that underlined their determination to comment on policies of the Communist party and Government.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., March 7 -- The Plainfield Board of Education announced plans today to reopen the city's 15 schools on Monday and to make changes designed to end racial confrontations.
THE rampant speculation that has alarmed so much of official Wall Street has also raised temperatures at the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 7 -- Playing in the sunshine today, Johnny Pott tied for the lead, a chance he lost yesterday on the 18th hole in the wind and rain with a double bogey. He scored a 66 on the second round for an aggregate of 136 in the $115,000 Florida Citrus open golf tourney, drawing even with Bert Yancey and Tommy Aaron.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 7 -President Nixon's low-keyed, pragmatic political approach may be the kind of tranquilizer America needs at the moment, a visiting French scholar said here in an interview.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -Marshall Green, a career diplomat with long experience in Asia, is reported to have been picked by President Nixon as Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs.
The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen and Harold J. Pryor, who heads its Long Island Rail Road local, were declared in contempt of court yesterday by Federal Judge Walter Bruchhausen of Brooklyn.

MOSCOW, March 7 -- The Soviet Union charged tonight that Chinese soldiers during last Sunday's border battle killed Russian soldiers who had been wounded by shooting at pointblank range or by bayoneting them and mutilating them beyond recognition.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -The Federal Trade Commission reported today that new laboratory tests had shown significant increases in the tar and nicotine content of many cigarettes.

CORONADO, Calif., March 7 -- A naval captain who is an authority on methods of enduring enemy prison camps and escaping from them appeared today before the court of inquiry investigating the seizure of the Pueblo.
Silver futures ended an unusual week with a price decline yesterday. The declines from the Thursday level amounted to just under four cents an ounce to a little more than six cents.
Of the 800 or so Roman Catholic priests, brothers and nuns who leave the active ministry each year to enter secular life, about 20 per cent find their way to Bearings for Re-Establishment, Inc.
Four teen-age girls stepped off an uptown train in the Columbus Circle IND station at 4:30 P.M. yesterday and began an apparently senseless series of attacks on passengers, the police said.

Betty Klaric, a reporter for The Cleveland Press, won first prize of $1,000 in the 1968 Edward J. Meeman Awards of the Scripps-Howard Foundation for her year-long crusade against the pollution of Lake Erie. The awards are for articles, editorieals and cartoons in the cause of conservation published in American newspapers.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., March 7 (AP) -- The president of the State University here told students staging a hunger strike today there will be no amnesty for the three students ordered penalized for demonstrating last Dec. 12 against Marine Corps recruiters on campus.

The Clevite Corporation and Gould-National Batteries, Inc., announced late yesterday a preliminary agreement to combine the two concerns as Gould, Inc., in an exchange of stock and warrants with an estimated value of more than $225-million.

LONDON -- There is no doubt that the visit of President Nixon was at first received here with a good deal of condescension. But the adroitness he displayed during the trip itself created a favorable impression and reversed the charges that he wished to impose American leadership. His modesty and attitude smoothed the ruffled feathers of Europe.

The American Bankers Association has expressed alarm over a recent ruling by the Attorney General of North Carolina, which, if it spreads to other states, could hurt the ability of banks to finance automobiles.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -American policymakers, studying the kinds of retaliation that might be used if enemy gunners continued rocket attacks on Saigon, are faced with a dilemma.

The signs of labor strife are almost always visible in New York City -- pickets shuffling back and forth, union leaders shouting into television microphones, and frustrated consumers saying, "Somebody do something!"

PEKING, March 7 -- The demonstrations over the SovietChinese border clash that began Monday morning ended last night with millions taking part in provincial capitals. On one day alone, Wednesday, the Chinese said a total of almost three million marched in Peking and Shanghai.
BEFORE tackling some current shows in the galleries, we had better mention what's on in a couple of the museums.
PARIS, March 7 (Reuters) -The annual French Home Furnishings Salon, which opened here this week, is expected to draw 1.5 million visitors.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 7 (AP) -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today he had not made a final decision on seeking re-election in 1970.
To the Editor: The public was terrified at the news of the fire which occurred on Feb. 25 in the building at 48th Street and Fifth Avenue.

Following, as distributed here by Tass, the Soviet press agency, is the statement on the Chinese-Soviet border clash delivered yesterday at a press conference in Moscow by the head of the press department of the Soviet Foreign Ministry, Leonid M. Zamyatin:

William O. Smith, a clarinetist and composer with the University of Washington Contemporary Group, joined the Philadelphia String Quartet at Carnegie Recital Hall last night in a program of three newly composed works.

To the Editor: On more than one occasion Lyndon B. Johnson, when President, said that his objective in South Vietnam was to build a base upon which its people, by popular vote, could choose their own government.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates took advantage of Les Cain's wildness in the fifth inning today to defeat the world champion Detroit Tigers, 6-2, in the opening exhibition game for both teams.

TEANECK, N. J., March 7 -More than a score of students led by a science teacher ended a 19-hour occupation of the principal's office at Teaneck High School early today but continued to picket outside to demand a Negro history course and other changes in the curriculum.
The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday it was raising the price of styrene monomer by one-half of a cent a pound, effective April 1.

Van Buren High gained the final round of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship tournament yesterday by defeating Brandeis, 71-50, at DeWitt Clinton High in the Bronx. It was the 16th straight victory for the undefeated V-Bees.
POUGHKEEPSIE, March 7 -Vassar College's 1,600 women students have won the right to vote on whether they want to allow men visitors in the dorms at any time.
ENTHUSIASTIC collectors will be waiting at the doors when the New York Antiques Fair opens at 1 P.M. Monday, hoping to find good plain Pennsylvania country furniture.
OTTAWA, March 7 -Federal fishing authorities flew to Canada's maritime regions today to investigate charges that the annual slaughter of baby seals, which began this morning, is "barbaric and cruel."

IF the English poet Basil Bunting is better known to poets than to the public, there are reasons. For one, there hasn't been much of his verse around. This collected edition numbers only 160 pages, but it represents work going back more than 40 years. The earliest poems are marked 1924.
The New York International Sport, Camping, Travel and Vacation Show will open with a bang at 11 A.M. today at the Coliseum. Last year, Mrs. John V. Lindsay opened the show by sawing a birch log.
BONN, March 7 -- Nearly 25 years after he mistakenly bombed a Frankfurt church during a World War II flying mission, an American has written the Mayor of Frankfurt to ask forgiveness.

Investigators studying the pension fund investments of the office of Controller Mario A. Procaccino are looking for a stockbroker's representative who received more than $40,000 in city commissions before apparently fleeing to Greece.
VAIL, Colo., March 7 -Form stood up today as Patrick Russel, a Frenchman from Grenoble and Gertrud Gabl, a brunette from the Austrian Tyrol, scored slalom triumphs.

IS it too soon to suggest that "The Ballad of Baby Doe" might be an American classic? Seen at the New York State Theater last night its first New York City Opera performance since 1966, this work had an air of authenticity and rightness about it that was irresistible.
A former state assistant attorney general in charge of the charity-frauds bureau was convicted early yesterday of having lied to a grand jury investigating the shakedown of a Long Island publisher.

Charles Castleman, a veteran violin recitalist at the age of 27, made his only appearance of the season last night in Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Samuel Sanders was his pianist, and together the artists provided a very satisfying evening of music-mak ing -not so easy when the program is relatively conventional.

ALBANY, March 7 -- The Republican leaders of the Legislature, after twisting arms for five hours to round up the necessary votes in the Assembly, pushed through tonight their Taylor Law revision imposing tough new penalties against public-employe strikes.
An influential Democrat laughed the other day when he was asked what the condition of his party was in this city, and he kept on laughing.
Between 3:05 this afternoon and 9:35 tonight, barring an unexpected injury or disqualification, Ery Hall will run nine races at Madison Square Garden.

JERUSALEM, March 7 -On June 29, 1946, following the dynamiting of frontier bridges by Haganah, the Jewish underground army, the British interned most leaders of the Jewish community in the Palestine mandate.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -Manuel F. Cohen, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today he thought the agency might need some new statutory authority to deal with a current wave of corporate take-overs.
To the Editor: In your editorial of Feb. 15 concerning general elections in Thailand, you have once again misled your readers about the fact and the consequences of the elections.

The corporate battle that led to the merging of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company into American Standard, Inc., last June 7 stirred again yesterday when it was reviewed before the United States Court of Appeals.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- President Nixon paid his first visit to the Central Intelligence Agency today and joked about it.
A full slate of companies made the transition from private to publicly owned status this week, and investors gave their shares a good reception despite generally unsettled market conditions.
The governing board of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school district, suspended during the teachers' strikes last fall, was reinstated yesterday by the Board of Education.

Any performer who has pretensions to being a headliner ought to be wary of the Checkmates, Ltd. Last June, Herb Alpert and the Tia Juana Brass played Madison Square Garden and used the Checkmates as an opener, a warm-up act. Before a full house of 20,000, the Checkmates, a bouyantly energetic group of five singing instrumentalists, cut the ground out from under Mr. Alpert's very popular combo.
WESTBURY, L. I., March 7 -A recently revised and controversial rule was put to its first test tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, but it proved next to nothing.

Following are highlights in the flight plan of the Apollo 9 spacecraft for the remainder of the 10-day mission. The plan is subject to change at any time, depending on how the flight progresses. Times are Eastern Standard.
MEMPHIS, March 7 -- Circuit Judge W. Preston Battle today scheduled a court hearing for 9:30 A.M. Monday for James Earl Ray.

LOS ANGELES, March 7 -Defense witnesses at the murder trial of Sirhan Bishara Sirhan testified today that the behavior of the defendant was markedly different after he had received a head injury in a fall from a horse.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Defendants in what they call "one of the longest disorderly conduct trials in the annals of American jurisprudence" explained today why they had come here from New York and other cities at considerable sacrifice of time and income to fight the minor charge.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A speech unscrambler, which won its inventor two scientific achievement awards from the Navy, enables divers' voices to be heard clearly from hundreds of feet below the surface.

MOST opera houses count themselves lucky if they can produce one good Marschallin each decade. The Metropolitan Opera has, at the moment, no less than three: Leonie Rysanek, Christa Ludwig and Regine Crespin.
Gerard Arpino's dream-infested ballet, "Nightwings," is a mysterious work subject to a variety of interpretations, none of which are totally satisfactory.

Some students at Columbia said yesterday that drugs -especially marijuana -- were being used openly on the campus and in the dormitories, where a 19-year-old freshman died this week after using opium and LSD.

The days since the Sino-Soviet skirmish on the frozen Ussuri River have revealed a significant difference in the two powers' reaction. Moscow, which first announced the clash, sought initially to play it down in domestic propaganda and to avoid any major aggravation of the traditional Russian fear of China. Only yesterday did Moscow change its tactics and organize a large "spontaneous" protest demonstration before the Chinese Embassy there.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -President Nixon came to grips today, for the first time, with the momentous question of how and where he is going to spend Federal funds for domestic programs over the next few years.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (Reuters) -- Walter H. Annenberg, United States Ambassador-designate to Britain, said today that a jail term his father served for tax evasion was a tragedy that has since become a source of inspiration.

PARIS, March 7 -- Communist labor leader Georges Seguy stomped out of the meeting room off the Champs Elyses and told a crowd of reporters: "The negotiations are dead -they were dead from the very beginning." The Paris outside the Social Affairs Ministry at 7 Rue Tilsitt -- a honey-colored mansion that used to belong to one of Napoleon's generals -- was just settling down for an evening of serious gaiety.
UMUAHIA, Biafra (Nigeria) -- Each day here begins with the sound of singing and the tromp of marching feet.
A lawyer and a businessman were convicted Thursday night in Federal Court of conspiracy to obstruct justice and bribery in an attempt to fix an investigation by the Internal Revenue Service.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 -- A New York-born political scientist identified with liberal causes throughout his adult life has been for months the target of a campaign of abuse and harassment on and off the strife-marked campus of San Francisco State College.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 7 -St. John's and Princeton will meet in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship tomorrow with neither team established as a favorite. It is a case of height for Princeton against the defense and the control skills of the shorter men from St. John's.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7 -- Despite repeated warnings from the United States, enemy forces have continued to attack cities and military posts in South Vietnam with rockets and mortar shells.

PARIS, March 7 -- Supporters of the Vietcong here sought out international diplomats and newsmen today to deny that the current wave of guerrilla attacks in South Vietnam was aimed at civilian targets.

To the Editor: In his vitriolic and obviously political letter (March 5), Reuben A. Lazarus, who for many years has regarded himself as the czar of governmental organization in New York City, takes to task, as one of the supposed "shortcomings" of Mayor Lindsay, the reorganization of the executive branch of the government of the city proposed by the Mayor.
MEMPHIS, March 7 (AP) -The Huntsville (Ala.) Times said today that Ray would plead guilty in exchange for a 99-year sentence instead of a possible death penalty.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 7 -- Governor Rockefeller found today that a snappy retort was a dangerous weapon to use at a public meeting where speakers protested his proposed 5 per cent cut in projected state spending.

HOUSTON, March 7 -- For those who have spent their lives rooted by gravity to the earth's surface -- or held by gravity in the seat of an airplane -- maneuvers in orbit, such as those that took place during the flight of Apollo 9 today, have strange results.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 7 (UPI) -- Commissioner Bowie Kuhn "declined to accept" Donn Clendenon's retirement today and ordered Rusty Staub and Jesus Alou to start working out with their new clubs.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -The Federal Trade Commission announced today its intention to file an antitrust suit against the acquisition of the AllisChalmers Manufacturing Company by White Consolidated Industries, Inc.
JERUSALEM, March 7 -Israeli security forces destroyed five Arab houses in Jerusalem late last night after having found arms and explosives in them.
Tickets will go on sale at noon tomorrow for the Metropolitan Opera's 29th week, which begins March 31.
Traders maintained their bearish views again yesterday and the American Stock Exchange lost more ground.

To the Editor: Demands by the public and public officials like California Governor Ronald Reagan to investigate campus dissent and bring the full force of the state and police to bear on the dissidents presage an alarming trend. University administrators and government officials are already under increasing pressure to use force against campus disruptions, to fight fire with fire. And the future bodes no better.

Fears of a new crisis in the international financial system and a possible escalation of the war in Vietnam sent the stock market lower yesterday morning, in a continuation of Thursday's sharp drop. But an abrupt turnabout in psychology shortly before the closing bell produced a brisk rally.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7 -Poorly designed ignition systems are causing tens of thousands of motorists needless inconvenience and expense, a top official of the American Automobile Association charged today.
DETROIT, March 7 -- Salaries and bonuses for all directors and officers of Chrysler Corporation last year rose by $2.8million as sales and profits climbed sharply.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 7 -Observers who have been following developments in Arab guerrilla activity believe that the recent series of explosions in Jerusalem signals the start of an intensified campaign against Israel.

SINCE when did you come out of a theater humming a tune you weren't humming when you went in? Well it might just happen to you at the New Anderson Theater, where last night they boldly and perhaps not that wisely disinterred the 1931 Gershwin musical "Of Thee I Sing."
Newsmen and on-the-air personnel at radio station WNEW AM and FM went on strike yesterday for more money and improved conditions, including lighter work loads.

BOSTON, March 7 -- Cornell University's Ivy League champions took another step toward a third straight Eastern championship tonight by beating a scrappy Boston University team, 3-2, in a sudden-death overtime period.
A larger worldwide ownership of stock in multi-national corporations was urged yesterday by Donald M. Kendall, president and chief executive officer of Pepsico, Inc.

HOUSTON, March 7 -- The Apollo 9 astronauts flew wide loops around each other in two separate spacecraft today to demonstrate that men who land on the moon should have no trouble in rejoining the craft taking them home again.

A taxpayer suit was filed yesterday in State Supreme Court asking that the city recover $2.5-million in alleged overcharges by two hospitals and Columbia University under city contracts to supply medical services to municipal hospitals.

Brooks, Feb. 16) and the history of the commune called Oz (same issue) provide revealing examples of the differences in the motivations of the black and the white activists who cause so much commotion in our society today.

THE National Theater of the Deaf ended its first Broadway season last night at the Longacre Theater. This two-week engagement, prior to a national tour, has provided an excellent showcase for the company.

A spunky widow and her four kids occupy the center stage in Mrs. Telfer's novel, eking out a hard living by virtue of squatters' rights and taking in laundry.
MOSCOW, March 1 -- An American Hebrew scholar has completed a Talmudic jigsaw puzzle with the help of the Leningrad library.

A NEW gallery for the display and sale of original photographs on a level designed to achieve the status of an art gallery was opened here last week. It is The Witkin Gallery at 237 East 60th Street, one flight up.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Spring has arrived in Bermuda. The red-coated cardinals are whistling for their pretty but less flamboyant mates, the handsome yellow-breasted kiskadees are shouting from the treetops and the herald of spring itself, the graceful black and white longtail, is winging in from the ocean with his raucous "quork" to start a new season of diving after fish in the warm depths of the blue and green sea and mating in cliff caves.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 8 -- If the winning of the United States Open golf championship last June made any changes in the buoyant personality of Lee Trevino, they are so subtle as to be indiscernible. He still bubbles as he talks and that warm grin never loses its infectious charm.

GREGORIO PECES-BARBA, a young lawyer from Madrid, was walking up and down the stretch of road that leads into Villafranca de Montes de Oca, a village in the hills of Burgos Province. With him on this January day six weeks ago was his mother, a sturdy old woman who has known various kinds of adversity.

WASHINGTON, D. C. EARLIER than most American critics and connoisseurs, the late Duncan Phillips was convinced that the best work of modern American painters could stand comparison with that of the most important artists Europe had to offer.
CHESTER, W. Va., March 8 (AP) -- Barbara Jo Rubin, the country's first winning female jockey, rode two winners today at Waterford Park.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Another evil of twentieth century life is that it produces people like Bates Batts. In any other century Bates might have become a great painter. Some years ago, he enjoyed remarkable success at using house paints on sofas.

ATHENS, March 8 -- An economic battle between two Greek shipping millionaires -- Aristotle S. Onassis and Stavros S. Niarchos -- burst into the open today as the two competed for an oil-refinery concession from the Greek Government.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 8 -- Nodouble, 4-year-old chestnut colt star of the Verna Lea Farms, scored a smashing victory today in the $145,000 Santa Anita Handicap, rallying from last in a field of 16 starters to win by 1 1/2 lengths.

Nixon is honorary chairman for the event, which will be underwritten by the 40 organizations exhibiting at the International Automobile Show at the Coliseum April 5 through 13.

Reagan adds an intriguing chapter to this theme in THE CAPER (Putnam's, $4.50).

The National Federation of Priests Councils, a Roman Catholic organization formed a year ago to promote church reform and renewal rather than rebellion, yesterday displayed the first issue of its bimonthly "house organ."

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania -- Measures aimed at developing tourist facilities in Tanzania's northern game areas and depriving tour operators based in Nairobi, Kenya, of the lion's share of this country's vacationist traffic are being planned by the Government here.

A United States immigration official, invoking an 18-year-old law, recently refused to permit Carlos Fuentes, a leading Mexican novelist with leftist leanings, to leave a passenger vessel in San Juan, Puerto Rico, and spend a few hours sightseeing in the Spanish colonial city.
I WAS a boy of 12 when I met Boris Karloff and asked him for his autograph. His name, of course, was synonymous with fright and the horrific characters he portrayed.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan -- "History would never have forgiven us if the present chaotic conditions were allowed to go any further." With these words Pakistan's leading soldier, Ayub Khan, seized political power in October 1958. Today almost the same words are being used by the contestants struggling to succeed him.

KARACHI, Pakistan -- New hotels providing modern comforts are being built in this ancient two-part country. The two parts are West and East Pakistan, which are separated by 1,000 miles of foreign territory in the way that Alaska stands apart from the Continental United States.

Snow-weary New Yorkers have something new to see this week: orchids and tulips. The flower show is in town. Though only a make-believe land of gardens and garlands indoors, somehow when this annual International Flower Show and Garden Fair arrives at the New York Coliseum, it brings assurance that the longed-for season, spring, will follow.

Possessions spoil as many interiors as they enrich. This apartment in an old building on the Left Bank in Paris was carefully planned to offer relief from the "suffocation of things," while managing to accommodate the usual furnishings and a carefully edited collection of paintings and art objects.

As a Mickey Mantle fan for 14 years, I want to express my admiration for this simple, yet great, man. I'm sure I speak for many, many people. Superlatives often seem trite and misused, but in this case they seem applicable.
KARACHI, Pakistan -- "There is hardly a developing country which would not profit from looking over Pakistan's shoulder today," declares an official publication of the United States aid mission here.
VIKERSUND, Norway, March 8 (AP) -- Bjoern Wirkola or Norway won the International Ski Flying contest on the giant Vikersund Hill Saturday.

DONGHA, South Vietnam, March 8 -- Allied forces operating south of this combat support base are winding up a major campaign in which about 100 United States marines seized several hilltops just inside Laos, military sources said today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 8 -Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird spent the second day of his inspection tour here in conference with United States and South Vietnamese officials today.

The Mafia's infiltration of legitimate business -- as documented in current hearings of the State Investigation Commission -- has created a new, more subtle way for the sons of the men who run organized crime to follow their fathers into the underworld.

MIAMI, March 8 (AP) -- Wheatley Stable's Funny Fellow sloshed to a half-length victory in the $64,200 Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park today the triumph was trainer Eddie Neloy's first in a stakes this, session in Florida.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- Thirty years ago scientists in America responded to the nation's call and pitched in to build the atomic bomb. As the weapon neared reality, a few scientists -- men like Leo Szilard, Niels Bohr, James Franck and Eugene Rabinowitch -- were overcome with doubt about whether this fearsome device should ever be used on human beings.

PARIS -- Just one year ago, when the nation was basking in peace and prosperity, a leading journalist here wrote an article headlined, "France Is Bored." Ever since then, it's been one thing after another, and a good many Frenchmen would like nothing better than to lapse into boredom.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 8 -- A United Nations agency has expressed doubt that human life can survive on this planet unless early action is taken to halt the rapid growth in pollution of land, water and air.

When Oz broke up ("Life and Death of a Commune Called Oz," by Robert Houriet, Feb. 16, the story of a hippie "family" living on a farm in Pennsylvania), my husband and I had to go someplace quick and settle down so I could have the baby. So soon we found ourselves (having no other choice and not very happy about it) New York City-bound.

HOMEOWNERS and apartment dwellers who have been reluctant to tackle the job of putting down their own floor tiles because they felt that the project called for working with messy adhesives and hard-to-cut tiles, will be interested in several newly introduced varieties.
Adopting the popular idiom, "business expansion is alive and well" as it starts its ninth year.

WASHINGTON -- After six weeks of searching, the Administration finally settled last week on an Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs. He was Charles Appleton Meyer, a 50-year-old Boston Brahmin, with wide business experience as a Sears, Roebuck vice-president in Latin America, a good command of Spanish and what one top Administration official called "a relaxed sort of charm."
MINNEAPOLIS, March 8 -- Wheat growers in the upper Middle West have lost about $4.2-million in sales as a result of a 10-week embargo on purchases by the Japanese market.
COLUMBIA, S. C , March 8 -- A "food by prescription" program for expectant mothers and preschool children will begin Monday in Beaufort and Jasper Counties in South Carolina.

"Those kids must be at it again," he said.
