THE twin problems of racism and poverty have converged in our society to become the problem of the inner city itself. Where once our cities were cultural meccas, they are now miserable slums. Where once the immigrants to our cities came from abroad with hopes for a better, happier life, now they come from the South, despairing if not desperate.

The great antiballistic missile debate centers on lives, not dollars. The pivotal question for President Nixon in the decision he is to announce this week is whether the deployment of a Sentinel missile system will not in fact contribute to national insecurity by intensifying the nuclear arms race, already at the overkill stage.

At the conclusion of the 48th annual I. C. 4-A. track and field championships last Saturday night, Jim Kehoe of Maryland offered congratulations to his coaching colleague at Villanova, Jim (Jumbo) Elliott.

The Times editorial of Feb. 25 praised as "rational" the Park Association's position on the proposed Police Department installation and commercial riding stable in Central Park. While the Park Association is gratified by the compliment, the editorial, unfortunately, has inadvertently given many people the impression that the Park Association has, with a few reservations, approved this complex in its present form.

Playing at the time of day when they normally take their pregame nap, the Rangers woke up suddenly yesterday, put in a powerful third-period effort and skated to a 2-2 tie with the Montreal Canadiens.

Middle East tension exploded again over the weekend, this time in the neighborhood of the Suez Canal. An initial Israeli-Egyptian aerial battle was followed by two days of intensive artillery exchange across the whole length of the waterway.

Mayor Lindsay was accused of brinksmanship, lack of organization and failure of leadership yesterday by six public figures -- two of them Republicans, as is the Mayor -- who want to get him out of City Hall in the November election.

WHITE PLAINS, March 9 -- Huntinghouse Telstar, a West Highland White terrier, was named best of breed today at the 29th Saw Mill River Kennel Club Show at the Westchester County Center. He was one of 95 to get the purple and gold rosette in his particular breed.
HOW does Mrs. Charles W. Yost, wife of the new United States Chief Delegate to the United Nations, turn the luxuriously impersonal American Embassy at the Waldorf Towers into a family home?

Another battle in the never-ending struggle to protect natural resources against encroachment by private interests seeking profit will come up soon before the Connecticut Legislature. This one revolves around whether Cockenoe Island, off Westport, in Long Island Sound, should be preserved for recreational purposes or become an industrial site.

Earl Wild was the piano soloist at yesterday afternoon's concert of the American Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, and he gave a triumphant, flashing performance of Liszt's "Hungarian Fantasy," with bravura support from Leopold Stokowski, who conducted, and the orchestra.

THE truism Polonius pointed out in "Hamlet" some four centuries ago held good yesterday as people filled the Greenwich Gallery at 43 Greenwich Avenue to look over about 400 costumes and accessories that had been used by the American Shakespeare Festival at Stratford, Conn., during the last 15 years.

Tile Cross Brown Co. has named Robert E. Waldron to the post of senior vice president, and has appointed five new vice presidents, Peter J. Berman, Joseph Cooper, Thomas M. Emma, Joseph P. Kremene. zky and Michael F. Simcich.
A traffic safety program, designed to strengthen Gov. Rockefeller's traffic safety legislative proposals of last month, was recommended yesterday by the State Traffic Safety Council.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Arms Control and Disarmament Agency reported today that a field test had shed new light on inspection techniques for a future accord.
The new City Human Rights Commissioner said yesterday that the city should change "some of our old civil service arrangements" to allow more Negroes to become teachers, policemen and sanitation men.
The shot that echoed through the college basketball world Saturday night brought new hope to 15 teams that remain in the running for the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship.

Theodore W. Kheel yesterday urged Governor Rockefeller not to sign the tough revisions in the Taylor Law passed by the Legislature Friday night until he could assess objections by critics of the changes.

NUCLEAR power troubles the mind of the layman for two reasons. First, it is a mystery, and when physicists try to explain the mystery to us, it takes on the structure of myth: creation and destruction, mass converted into energy, fission and fusion, chain reactions, the spiraling of ion particles in a cyclotron.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 9 (UPI) -- Diane Crump got within a length of becoming the first woman jockey to win a race at El Comandante race track today when her horse was beaten in the last few paces of the sixth race.
The final curtain on 71 years of worldwide troop-transport operations for American military personnel started coming down here last week.

Two leading Wall Street economists believe the so-called "standard" forecast for the economy in 1969 -- a slower rate of growth in the first half followed by a resurgence in the second half -- is due for revision.
The credit markets this week once again face the difficult task of handling a large volume of new fixed-income securities at a time when interest rates seem certain to climb still higher.

William West has been appointed an executive vice president of Charles I-L Greenthal Co., Inc., a realty management and renting organization. Mr. West, who joined the firm in 1961, has been a director of its management department for the last three years.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 9 -- The president of Cornell University, who last week was hauled from a podium by Negro students while defending the university's ownership of stock in banks that have lent money to South Africa, has belatedly learned that the university sold the last of the stock weeks age.
"And now," Herbert Fechter said with a slight smile, "I would like to talk about what we call the phantom pharmacist."

ROCKINGHAM, N. C., March 9 (AP) -- David Pearson, driving in rain, gusty wind and escaping several brushes with disaster, won the Carolina 500 stock-car race today to complete a sweep of the South's major speedways.
KONTUM, South Vietnam, March 9 (AP) -- A German nurse captured by the Vietcong more than a year ago walked out of the jungle to freedom today on her 28th birthday.

The young man sitting expressionlessly with his lawyer in the paneled and softly lighted courtroom was accused of having run naked through the street, broken into an apartment and beaten an old woman.

MBUTU-NGWA, Biafra (Nigeria), March 2 -- Once a week, a relief truck of the Catholic relief organization Caritas leaves this quiet, peaceful mission station at dawn with two Biafrans -- Brother Thomas and a driver.
MINDEN, Nev., March 9 (AP) -- Defying high winds to drop hay onto a snow-covered ridge, helicopter pilots are keeping 70 wild horses alive and safe from poachers who would sell the herd for pet food.
LARK, Utah, March 9 -- A miner was rescued tonight after eight days of entombment in a rocky niche deep in a lead and zinc mine.

About 100 Barnard College girls moved into two men's dormitories at Columbia College last night to dramatize demands of students at both colleges for coeducational dormitory arrangements begining next fall.

BASEL, Switzerland, March 9 -- A feeling of guarded optimism that the French franc can survive the crisis of confidence that broke out on the exchange markets last week emerged today from a meeting of central bankers of the major industrial countries.
Demonstrators demanding rent controls rushed toward Mayor Lindsay's sedan yesterday, shouting and waving their fists, but they were held in check by the police.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9 -- United States forces fought two small but costly engagements in the strategically important area around Saigon early today.

DANANG, South Vietnam, March 9 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that he would ask Congress to increase the budget for the Vietnam war by $70-million in the next fiscal year to finance a build-up of South Vitnamese armed forces.

Army and Kansas were added to the field yesterday for the 32d annual National Invitation Tournament which opens Thursday night at Madison Square Garden. The final berth in the 16-team tournament is reserved for the runner-up team in the Missouri Valley Conference.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 9 -- The impact of the worldwide movement toward containerization of maritime cargo dominated discussions at the sixth biennial conference of the International Association of Ports and Harbors here. The weeklong meeting, concluded yesterday, was attended by more than 300 delegates from 35 countries.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Nixon's unexpectedly cordial honeymoon with a Democratic-controlled Congress may come to an abrupt end this week over the issue of whether the United States should deploy a missile defense system.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A member of the Federal Reserve Board came close over the weekend to recommending for the first time that Reserve requirements be imposed on Euro-dollar borrowings by the big money market banks, but he did not quite cross the line.
HOUSTON, March 9 -- Tom Bigelow of Whitewater, Wis., won the Astro Grand Prix championship for midget cars today without winning either of the two nerve-wracking races on which the title is based.

CORONADO, Calif., March 9 -- Each evening, Capt. William Richard Newsome drives to a guarded pink stucco barracks here to talk for hours with a group of sailors who recount their 11 months in a North Korean prison.

Eugene List was soloist with the New York Philharmonic Saturday night in a concert conducted by Andre Kostelanetz. Mr. List played two pieces -- Liszt's Piano Concerto No. 1 and the Gottschalk-Kay Grand Tarantella for Piano and Orchestra.

CLOSE to 300 people squeezed into the Amron Gallery, 228 West Fourth Street, and around the 55-gallon tank of goldfish yesterday afternoon to preview a new collection of Eskimo sculpture, prints, toys and artifacts and to nibble on whale meat in Spanish sauce, Arctic char, and marinated muktuk in mustard sauce.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 9 -- President Nixon's readiness to join in a major-power guarantee or a Middle East peace settlement has moved the United States closer to one Soviet proposal for dealing with the Israeli-Arab conflict.
The president of the Board of Education characterized recent school disorders yesterday as "very serious," but he advised the public not to "panic" and said the city schools were reasonably safe.
A City University study has found hat investigations of relief eligibilty are resented by most recipients and that this hampers social services.

Members of a black self-help organization seized a virtually empty, state-owned office building in Harlem yesterday and took steps to turn the structure into a center for the treatment of narcotics addicts.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover said today that reported violent crime increased again last year.

The NCNB Corporation, one-bank holding company that owns the $1.1 - billion North Carolina National Bank, issued a special report yesterday stating that its earnings per share were 35 per cent above 1968 during the first two months of this year.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 9 (AP) -- Despite the death of an aquanaut and extensive delays, the Navy plans to continue man's biggest undersea adventure, the $10-million program called Sealab 3.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A House committee is as baffled as Government and industry officials about how to stop the hijacking of aircraft.
DURING the current Manhattan Chess Club championship, International Master Bernard Zuckerman, as White in a Ruy Lopez, faulted the form when he was upset by Master George Kramer.

Within the next two weeks, British airlines are going to decide whether they want the new Anglo-French airbus, designed by Sud Aviation, or the British rival, the BAC-311, according to Sir Anthony Milward, chairman of British European Airways.
Mediation efforts will resume tomorrow in an effort to end the strike by 300 staff members of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York that started Feb. 27.

To the 19th century, Mozart was a little prig in knee pants who wrote reams of music-box pieces and then, inexplicably, produced "Don Giovanni." That idea has long since been discredited, but the Washington National Symphony's "Mozart Concerto Festival" at Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon did what it could to revive the old view.

TOKYO, March 9 -- A report by a Japanese study committee with close governmental ties recommended yesterday that the United States should return Okinawa to Japan by 1972 at the latest. The United States has controlled Okinawa since the end of World War II.

MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina March 9 (UPI) -- Don Behm of Lansing, Mich., defeated Soukhebator of Mongolia today in a bantamweight match that opened the second day of competition in the world free-style wrestling championships.

SAN MARCOS, Tex., March 8 -- This seems an odd place for cowboys. It seems just as odd a place for a political fight, but one is brewing, and the lean young men in broad hats and fancy tooled boots are fidgeting uncomfortably.

MIAMI, March 9 -- "For centuries virtually second-class citizens, women of Latin America are today in the midst of a real cultural and social awakening,'' the editor of one of the Spanish-language magazines published here said recently.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., March 9 -- Gene Scott of New York, ranked 10th in the country, survived a weekend of class competition against three members of the victorious Davis Cup team to win the four-man Long Island round-robin indoor tennis tournament at C. W. Post College today.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) -- The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said today that South Vietnamese troops were incapable of winning the Vietnam war by themselves and American forces might have to remain there for as long as 10 years.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 9 -- Under direct pressure from Moscow, the Communist parties of five Warsaw Pact countries, including occupied Czechoslovakia, have agreed to join the Soviet Union in boycotting the Yugoslav Communist Congress opening here Tuesday.

French business may be facing new uncertainties in strikes and inflation at home, but in the American and other world markets, a "new wave" of Gallic salesmanship is confidently expanding orders and earnings.

Pari-mutuel clerks who work for the New York Racing Association voted yesterday to walk off the job at Aqueduct on March 28 unless they obtained a new contract by then. The vote was reported to be 450-0.

BECKLEY, W. Va., March 9 (AP) -- West Virginia's striking coal miners, only partly satisfied with a "black lung" compensation bill passed last night, voted today to remain away from work until Gov. Arch Moore Jr. signed the bill.

Your editorials "What Future for Auto Safety?" of Feb. 8 and "Calling Five Million Cars" of Feb. 27, expressing opposition to the nomination of Francis C. Turner as Federal Highway Administrator, unfortunately suggested that he is "an old-line, road-building bureaucrat" who would be antagonistic to an effective automobile and traffic safety program and indifferent to the problems of highway construction in urban areas. Your editorial cited no basis for this.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- At the very moment Monday that Atomic Energy Commissioner James T. Ramey was testifying here in favor of Federal controls on the hot water emissions of power plants, power industry representatives were testifying in Albany that complementary state controls would be "unrealistic" and "unduly restrictive."

MEMPHIS, March 9 -- A special court hearing for James Earl Ray, accused of assassinating the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., remained scheduled for tomorrow after a series of unusual meetings in the Memphis courthouse tonight.

Renata Tebaldi returned to the role of Tosca in Puccini's opera at the Metropolitan on Saturday night. It was good to have her back in a part congenial to her, particularly since she was in excellent voice.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 -- The trial of 27 soldiers charged with mutiny for staging a sit-down demonstration in the stockade of the Presidio here has been criticized by a growing number of military men.
TEL AVIV, March 9 -- Israeli and Egyptian forces bombarded each other across the Suez Canal for the second day today.
COCOA, Fla., March 9 -- When Ron Swoboda arrived in the Mets camp 10 days ago, he vowed to turn over a new leaf and "make it up to Gil" for some of his escapades last year.

BONN, March 9 -- Campaign fireworks started this weekend as West German political parties prepared for the federal election Sept. 28 in the aftermath of the presidential victory of Gustav Heinemann last Wednesday.

GENEVA, March 9 -- A mild-mannered Venezuelan diplomat took over the other day as Secretary-General of a United Nations body that for four years has led the campaign by poor countries for increased economic help from the rich.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- An attitude of icy calm, though not of unconcern, prevails here as Western Europe heads into another potential monetary crisis.

Seven policemen accused of laxity in enforcing the state liquor laws were ordered transferred last night from their precincts in Harlem. Four civilians in the case were held on charges of illegally possessing and selling alcohol.
HOUSTON, March 9 -- The Apollo 9 astronauts cruised through a restful Sunday in sighting navigation landmarks and observing the moons of Jupiter.
DETROIT, March 9 -- An 85 pound American foxhound, which held attention by his soundness, was judged best in the Detroit Kennel Club's annual show in Cobo Hall tonight.
The United Nations Human Rights Commission's resolution [news story March 4] castigating Israel for "continuing violations of human rights," particularly its sponsorship by India, calls for comment.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 9 -- The long wait ended for Kenneth Allen Still today as he scored his first triumph on the golf tour by winning the Florida Citrus open. With a' 72-hole aggregate of 278, the 34-year-old Tacoma, Wash., professional, who twice left the circuit discouraged, posted a final-round 70 to win by one stroke.

POPE AIR FORCE BASE, N. C., March 9 (AP) -- Camouflaged C-130 Hercules cargo planes sped toward South Korea from North Carolina today in a display of the long reach of America's strategic reserve forces.

GUADALAJARA, Mexico -- A retired American diplomat makes what probably is the best ice cream in Mexico, a young American conductor is trying to revolutionize local musical standards, the wife of the United States Consul General is improving the local culinary level and thousands of other Americans are making their presence felt economically and socially in Mexico's second biggest city.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 9 (AP) -- The United Nations Children's Fund, UNICEF, says its work in South Vietnam was hard hit last year by increased military action and general mobilization.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9 -- The New York Knicks, whose splendid defensive work this season has been one of the main reasons for their high position in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division race, found Wally Jones and the Philadelphia 76ers shooting with an incendiary touch today and bowed to the 76ers, 110-101, at the Spectrum.

His long business background in Latin America and his fluency in Spanish are good qualifications for his first job in Government, but his abilities face a severe immediate test in the crisis confronting the United States in its relations with Peru.

VICTORIA, British Columbia -- In his pine-paneled office in the ornate Parliament Building, Premier W. A. C. Bennett of British Columbia recently displayed a radically changed map he has devised for Canada.

CAIRO, March 9 -- An Israeli shell killed the chief of staff of the Egyptian armed forces during a raging artillery duel today across the Suez Canal. His death was disclosed in an official announcement.

TEAMS led by David Strasberg and Peter Leventritt, both of New York, survive unbeaten in the Greater New York Double Knockout Championship from an original entry of 64 teams, and will clash in the sixth round.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 9 -- A program for the black academic community at Nassau Community College has been agreed on by the college administration and the black faculty and students, Dr. George F. Chambers, president of the college, said today.

I tell my hygiene class, you have to strike out with the bases loaded, play football before 55,000 people before you really understand.

The question "What Is Modern Jazz?" was examined in brief and somewhat inconclusive terms at Town Hall on Saturday afternoon by Ira Gitler, associate editor of Down Beat, the jazz magazine, and the Thad Jones Quintet.
ADEN, March 9 -- Descendants of Greek and Portuguese colonists still live happily on Socotra island, 500 miles offshore in the Indian Ocean.
Carol Neblett made her New York City Opera debut at the New York State Theater Saturday afternoon, appearing as Musetta in Puccini's "La Boheme."

Archbishop Molloy, rallying for 11 points in the final three minutes while holding Power Memorial scoreless, won the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball title, 70-64, yesterday at the Fordham University gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Representative John M. Murphy, contending that organized crime has the cash and contacts to infiltrate the securities business, said today he would propose legislation to do something about it.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Jewish college students took issue today with a notion prevalent among their elders that the campus had become a "disaster area" for Judaism and Jewish life.

The use of illegal drugs, particularly marijuana, has soared among students in the city's public and private high schools and has reached a point where open use, even in school buildings, is steadily growing.

Many of our Criminal and Family Courts -- the places where respect for our system of justice is either bred or destroyed -- are housed in shoddy, sixty-year-old buildings with inadequate courtrooms and prisoner facilities designed for a half or a third of the prisoners jammed into them.

After its emphatic rejection of either guideposts or mandatory controls to curb wage-price inflation, the Nixon Administration seems to be stumbling back toward the most discredited of all approaches -- "jawbone" control.

As one of the many distinguished sponsors of the Cosmopolitan Young Peoples Symphony Orchestra, Percy E. Sutton took more than a passive interest in the ensemble's concert in Philharmonic Hall Saturday afternoon.
The American Bankers Association endorsed yesterday -- with some major qualifications -- the Federal Reserve System's proposals to overhaul the ground rules under which it lends to its member banks.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 9 -- President Nixon met for about two hours today with John D. Ehrlichman, Counsel to the President, and H. R. Haldeman, the White House chief of staff, at his waterside retreat on nearby Key Biscayne.
The American Bankers Association endorsed yesterday -- with some major qualifications -- the Federal Reserve System's proposals to overhaul the ground rules under which it lends to its member banks.
Francis I. duPont Co., the largest remaining brokerage partnership on Wall Street, indicated yesterday that it planned to abandon its traditional structure to become a corporation.

The first day at the Big A was a big day for all concerned: The State of New York, the management, the long-shot players and even the form adherents. In weather that was bright, sunny and typically March in its breezy quality, the thoroughbreds opened the 1969 campaign at the Aqueduct track with a crowd of 40,145 in attendance.
MEMPHIS, March 10 -- James Earl Ray pleaded guilty today to murdering the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and was sentenced to serve 99 years in the Tennessee State Prison in Nashville.
Mayor Lindsay directed Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary yesterday to prepare a plan for speedier police response to violence in the schools.
The Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association, once dominated exclusively by the Boston Celtics, is in the midst of the wildest three-way finish in the history of the league.
City Council President Francis X. Smith charged yesterday that the Lindsay administration had permitted community power struggles to halt initial planning of the Model Cities program.

American companies, predicting a rapid rise in their international sales in the next three years, expect most of the gain to come from overseas production rather than exports, according to the survey by the National Industrial Conference Board. The results were announced yesterday.

WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- Frank J. Mather 3d, a scientist at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and one of the country's pioneers in the tagging of oceanic fishes to determine growth rate, migration patterns and population, has hit a snag in is continuing research with bluefin tuna.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 10 (UPI) -- A Federal judge sentenced Richmond Flowers, the former Alabama Attorney General, to eight years in prison and fined him $10,000 today after his conviction on four counts of conspiracy.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 10 -- For a 19-year-old rookie pitcher named Jonathan Matlack, spring training with the New York Mets became a cold and brutish thing today. The Boston Red Sox hit three homers off him in the eighth inning, broke a 3-3 tie and defeated the Mets, 7-4.

The Washington Square Journal, the undergraduate student newspaper of New York University's downtown campus, has expanded its publication yesterday from twice weekly to four times a week in a move, according to the tabloid's editors, to make The Journal the first newspaper to cover all of the university.

R. Hoe Co., Inc., a machinery manufacturer, announced yesterday that the company and certain of its officers and directors had been served in a suit brought by two stockholders who allege that the financial statements for the year ended Sept. 30, 1967, and for subsequent interim periods, contained certain misstatements.
President Nixon has received a favorable rating from the public on his first six weeks in office, according to the results of a Louis Harris poll published yesterday in The New York Post.

One the sharpest divisions these days is between composers who believe that true craft consists in relying only on pitched tones to make musical effects and those who feel it is legitimate to mix in whatever is handy, including visual, theatrical materials.
A coalition of 26 educational, religious, civic and labor organizations has been formed to rally support here for school- decentralization and community control legislation.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen, a consistent supporter of the antiballistic missile system in the past, maintained today he had "come to no conclusion" on the controversial issue.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Supreme Court placed heavy penalties on illegal governmental eavesdropping today by ruling that espionage and racketeering defendants can search through certain of the Government's surveillance transcripts to see if their rights were violated.

The aborted trial of James Earl Ray for the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is a shocking breach of faith with the American people, black and white, and of people the world over still numbed and puzzled by the gunfire that struck down this international leader.

Unless President Nixon moves swiftly to appoint a Special Trade Representative -- an ambassador from the White House charged with conducting such negotiations as the successful Kennedy Round of tariff cuts -- the cause of freer world trade is likely to suffer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 10 -- Secretary General Thant rejected today a reproach from Israel for his refusal to transmit a proposal to the Arab governments that they restrain guerrilla organizations acting against Israel.
ROME, March 10 -- Rome University, closed since student occupiers were routed by the police 10 days ago, reopened today and so did a new round of student agitation.

This year the Metropolitan Opera's closing performance -- scheduled for Saturday, April 19 -- will not really close the season, as it has in the past. After the traditional spring tour the Met will present a June Festival Week of seven performances from June 2 to 7.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Labor Department said today that employment rose in February by almost 380,000 jobs, the largest monthly increase ever recorded.
STONY BROOK, L. I., March 10 -- The president of the State University here engaged in a shoving match today with students who were making copies of faculty members' research files.
OTTAWA, March 10 (UPI) -- Canada's Fisheries Minister today ordered a halt in the annual seal hunt until 6 A.M. Friday because of poor ice conditions threatening the seal herds.

ZACATECAS, Mexico -- From morning until night the peasants of Zacatecas crowd into the Governor's office airing their problems. They are poor and unkempt and bear no witness to the wealth that once made this little provincial capital and the surrounding state one of the most prized possessions of the Spanish crown.

While more than 100 Barnard College girls continued their sleep-in yesterday at two Columbia dormitories, Dr. Carl F. Hovde, dean of Columbia College, said that there was a genuine likelihood that the two colleges would begin an experiment in coeducational living next fall.

Britain's Royal Ballet will open a six-week engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 22. Six ballets or productions new to the United States will be presented during the season, which marks the 20th anniversary of the company's American debut.

Shortly after President Johnson's statement that the United States would cease some of its bombing of North Vietnam and be willing to begin talks in the interest of peace [news story April 1, 1968] the Vietcong and North Vietnamese forces began easing their guerrilla and military pressure and actions in South Vietnam.
Federal agents' yesterday reported the confiscation of what they said was $8-million worth of pure heroin that arrived in this country in a shipment of canned fish.

ATLANTA, March 10 -- The widow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his successor as president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference both said today they believed his murder in Memphis last year was the result of a conspiracy and not the unsponsored act of a lone assassin.
New price schedules for a number of important chemicals were posted yesterday. The adjustments were in both directions.

A 24-year-old visitor at Bellevue Hospital went berserk with a knife in the lobby of the psychiatric ward yesterday, stabbed two security guards and fled into the street, where he slashed the faces of two city detectives who tried to subdue him.
Under a traffic speed-up experiment, buses had the curbside lane all to themselves for a long stretch on Fifth Avenue yesterday except for:
EMANUEL UNGARO is admittedly a revolutionary, but a revolutionary with a sense of humor.
CORONADO, Calif., March 10 -- Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher said in a voice quavering with emotion today that the North Koreans were "cruel and brutal savages" who pulled the legs off baby birds.

If there is still any question whether fashion has become a major factor in selling boys' apparel, a look at the trade show of the Boys' and Young Men's Apparel Manufacturers Association this week would provide an immediate affirmative answer.

PARIS, March 10 -- South Vietnamese specialists said today that the current tension between the Soviet Union and Communist China was causing strains in and between the North Vietnamese and Vietcong delegations to the Paris peace talks.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Rockefeller today appointed Paul J. Curran as chairman of the State Investigation Commission.
IMMOKALEE, Fla., March 10 -- A special Senate committee investigating hunger in America found migrant squalor and a furious Florida Governor waiting for them here today.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 10 -- Samuel Edward (Sam) McDowell of the Cleveland Indians is the strike-out king of the American League. In three of the last four seasons, McDowell led the league in strike-outs with from 225 to 325 each time and last season he had the second lowest earned-run average, 1.81.

DENVER, Colo., March 10 -- Surprising enthusiasm is running rampant in this mile-high city over the possibility of playing host to the 1976 Winter Olympics although the International Olympic Committee has intimated that the classic may never even be held.

The Arnold Constable Corporation, the Fifth-Avenue based chain of specialty stores, announced yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement to acquire William Castle Enterprises, Inc., an independent producer of the film, "Rosemary's Baby," and four other motion picture features.
The Federal Reserve's policy of restricting credit continued to disrupt the financing plans of major borrowers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -Mr. Nixon's interesting custom of setting dates upon which he will deliver major policy pronouncements has this capital positively quivering in anticipation or dread of his promised decision on the antiballistic missile system. In fact, the case against ABM deployment is so overwhelming that it is hard to see how the President could decide for it.
When someone admired Herve Filion's slick haircut, he said with alarming frankness:

PATERSON, N. J., March 10 -- Three persons were arrested here today while picketing Eastside High School, where about 175 Negro students were staging a sit-in in the school's cafeteria. Two of those arrested were charged with interfering with the police and the third with using abusive language.

The Western Electric Company, Inc., manufacturing and supply unit of the Bell System, reported yesterday that its 1968 sales reached $4-billion for the first time in its 100-year history. The 1968 total of $4,050,657,000 compared with the preceding year's $3,733,906,000, a figure that gave it 11th sales ranking in Fortune magazine's listing of the 500 largest industrial corporations.

The Associated Hospital Service of New York, which supervises Blue Cross, announced yesterday the election of five new directors -- Merril Eisenbud, Msgr. James H. Fitzpatrick, Thomas Thacher, Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr. and Judge James L. Watson.

PARIS, March 10 -- A power blackout marked the beginning tonight of a 24-hour general strike, which caused tremors in world money markets when it was announced Thursday. The strike began officially at 10 P.M. as workers in the Government-owned electricity system cut off power in industrial plants.

A DECLARER who has been forced to ruff can sometimes find it expedient to string along with the defenders and force himself to ruff. An interesting example of such a maneuver occurred during the weekend at a sectional tournament in New Jersey.

Chronological age is not a very good indicator of driving fitness, the National Safety Council said here yesterday in releasing a report on a massive study of the problems and opinions of aged drivers.

Eighty volunteers and 22 drug addicts who had estab lished an improvised narcotics hospital in a state-owned build ing in Harlem walked out early this morning past ranks of policemen. They vowed to hold a series of demonstrations.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- James M. Rochford, Chicago's deputy superintendent of police, testified today that New York delegates who demonstrated during the Democratic National Convention last year rejected his offer of a police escort to the convention hall, choosing arrest instead.

A preview party at the Wildenstein Gallery the evening of March 26 will benefit the American Association of Museums, sponsor of the Renoir retrospective show that will be open to the public there from March 27 through May 3.

Directors of Northwest Airline, Inc., voted yesterday to offer stockholders the right to subscribe to 1,307,095 common shares. The board also voted to recommend to shareholders that they approve a 2-for-1 split of the common stock at the annual meeting May 19.
Stock prices climbed slowly but steadily yesterday, with investors mindful of the optimism expressed abroad that the French franc could survive its current crisis of confidence.

Last night the North Dakota State University Concert Choir appeared at Town Hall. New York, making good its reputation for hospitality, greeted the choir with an audience of exactly 31 persons. Since there were 44 on stage, the effect was, to say the least, striking.
Prices on the London stock market closed moderately higher yesterday as the easing of currency tensions outweighed domestic labor and Mideast uncertainties.
Mayor Lindsay's Rent Guidelines Board proposed yesterday that the owners of 400,000 uncontrolled apartments limit themselves to rent increases of 15 per cent on two-year leases.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 10 -- A 23-year-old graduate student in chemistry at Princeton University was found dead in his room here early this morning.
A sit-in was conducted yesterday by 200 union employes of E. R. Squibb Sons, Inc., at the pharmaceutical manufacturer's laboratory building at 25 Columbia Heights in downtown Brooklyn.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 11 (UPI) -- Enemy forces fired seven rockets into the old imperial capital of Hue last night, killing at least two civilians in the first attack on the city since the start of their offensive Feb. 23.
PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- Eight years ago, Thomas David Diamond was born in a suburban Philadelphia hospital without arms and with a number of other physical defects.

SMITHTOWN, L. I., March 10 -- Macy's and Abraham Straus showed off their new suburban branch stores today in a huge shopping center here that has the potential of becoming for Suffolk County what 34th Street and Broadway is for Manhattan.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 10 -- Back in the Golden Twenties the New York Yankees established their modus operandi -- the big hit. It was to become their trademark. This was the era of Murderers Row, when Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig slammed more home runs one year than the team totals of all but two clubs.
Does a husband who has been held legally responsible for the breakdown of a marriage have the right to sue his wife for divorce on the ground that they have not lived together for two years?
LOS ANGELES, March 10 -- A clinical psychologist who administered tests to Sirhan B. Sirhan in hs jail cell said today that the Jordanian immigrant exhibited "paranoid and schizophrenic tendencies."

HONG KONG, Tuesday, March 11 -- Peking has sent a strong protest note to the Soviet Foreign Ministry condemning the anti-Chinese demonstrations in Moscow that followed the clash between Chinese and Soviet troops on the Ussuri River boundary on March 2.
FORT BENNING, Ga., March 10 (AP) -- A general and his staff sat down today to a meal that could mean the end of kitchen police duty for Army privates in the field.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 10 (Reuters) -- South Vietnam's most prominent political league issued a statement today that cautiously criticized the current Government's suitability and suggested a more liberal attitute toward the peace negotiations in Paris.

TOKYO, March 10 (AP) -- Communist China charged today that the Soviet Union provoked the Manchurian border clash of March 2 to divert the attention of Russians, who are massing for a "revolution" against "Soviet fascist rule."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Pressures from the White House and the Budget Bureau to gain Federal income, and from oil companies to protect their exploratory investments, were cited today as major elements in the decision to lease Federal oil lands off California.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Retail sales held steady in February at the advanced January level, the Commerce Department reported today.

THERE will be a touch of New York playground basketball in the National Collegiate tournament as it moves into its second round at four sites across the country Thursday night. Mike Maloy of Davidson and John Warren of St. John's, who used to battle each other during summer basketball programs at Grover Cleveland Park in Queens, will clash in an East Regional semi-final game.
SAIGON, March 10 -- For the third consecutive day, North Vietnamese regular forces have stood and fought allied troops in strategic areas near Saigon and in the Central Highlands.
A special stockholders' meeting of Resorts International, Inc., called for this morning in Miami, will be adjourned to a new date, not yet determined. James M. Crosby, chairman, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear arms ran into a momentary snag in the Senate today as objections were raised that under it the United States would assume new commitments to protect nonnuclear states against attack.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -The Supreme Court rejected today an appeal by eight former Students at Bluefield State College in Bluefield, W. Va., who were suspended from the state-supported institution for taking part in an unruly demonstration at a football game in 1967.
JERUSALEM, March 10 -- Israeli authorities expressed the view today that Israel had stood up well militarily and politically in the artillery exchanges across the Suez Canal over the weekend.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Supreme Court declared illegal today a widely used joint venture arrangement by which competing daily newspapers share advertising and circulation departments.
HOUSTON, March 10 (AP) -- Col. James A. McDivitt and Col. David R. Scott, both born under the sign of Gemini, learned today that their horoscope called for group activity.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -The all-purpose opera, composed during a coma induced by a Saturday-afternoon broadcast of "Die Walkure," or perhaps "La Pasticerria di Seviglia":

" It's impossible to be a junkie and concentrate on your studies at the same time," the black-bearded City College student, at ease in a student club, said yesterday. "Heroin gets in the way of functioning normally as a student."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Most of the witnesses before the House Ways and Means Committee agreed today that something should be done to prevent rich individuals from operating farms as a hobby -- and at a loss -- to reduce their taxes.
Savings banks in New York State are continuing to pull in new deposits despite the tight-money squeeze, the Savings Banks Association of New York State reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Justice Department said today it was continuing its investigation into a possible conspiracy in the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

TRENTON, March 10 -- The overwhelming Republican majorities in the Legislature voted tonight to call off a November referendum that Gov. Richard J. Hughes had attacked as a "billion-dollar giveaway" of more than 400 square miles of state-claimed New Jersey tidal lands.
TEL AVIV -- The railroad built across the sands of Sinai by the British in their campaign against the Turks in World War I is no more.
A SECOND-GRADE class was painting its impressions of a tour around the school that the youngsters had taken the day before.
Maritime employers in the port of Boston yesterday rejected a return-to-work offer by members of the International Longshoremen's Association on a "no contract" basis.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that despite his reduced budget there was "no need" for an enrollment cut at the City University.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 10 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said on departing from South Vietnam tonight that it would be "desirable and possible" to replace some of the 540,000 American military men in this country with South Vietnamese troops.

PITTSBURGH, March 10 -- Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe said today that the Nixon Administration would seek Congressional approval this spring of a vast program to help American cities build mass transit systems.

Sears, Roebuck Co., the country's largest merchandising organization, is planning what sources in the home furnishings industry believe will be one of the most ambitious, chain-wide home goods promotions in retailing history.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
One hundred Columbia University faculty members, declaring that the university has "the obligation to defend itself," have called for stronger action against students who disrupt classes.
The Commonwealth Edison Company and the Central Illinois Light Company announced yesterday that they had resumed "exploratory talks" about a possible affiliation of the two companies.
Thousands of New Yorkers are peering out upon the city through a glass, darkly in the waning winter days. Nearly 3,000 professional window cleaners are on strike.
WEST PALM BEACH, March 10 -- Ralph Houk has a theory about the best way to conduct spring training but the Yankees are not cooperating, they just keep winning.
Senator Walter F. Mondale said yesterday that he would seek bipartisan Congressional support for an easing of this country's restrictions on trade with East European communist countries.

I am appalled by the letter of Dr. Cyrus W. Stimson (March 6) comparing the abortion of prospective mongoloids with the destruction of babies, the murder of ssnior citizens, and tile slaughter of Jews. I would not have thought it possible tllat a physician could equate these four acts.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- An extension of two years, rather than of five years, was proposed by the Nixon Administration today for a school program beamed toward helping the educationally disadvantaged.

BONN, March 10 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger announced today that he would call in Dr. Gustav Heinemann, President-elect of the Federal Republic, to remind him that the Chancellor is constitutionally in charge of making policy for West Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Supreme Court let stand today an order that the General Electric Company plant at Gainesville, Fla., must bargain with a union that apparently no longer represents a majority of the workers.

COLOGNE, West Germany, March 10 -- Bleary-eyed students wound up an eight-day conference of the West German National Union of Students this morning after having approved a new leftist course that critics said would turn the organization into a "socialist combat force."
WASHINGTON, March 10 -Scientists have reported finding nearly conclusive proof that measles virus sometimes causes a deadly, mysterious disease that attacks the brain and central nervous system.

The numbers "01," "10" and "11" in computerese or new math mean, simply, one, two and three. The League-International Society for Contemporary Music is using this system of numbering for a series of three concerts this season.

CAIRO, March 10 -- The Foreign Ministers of the nation's of the Arab League opened a meeting here tonight to draft new measures and to seek greater unity in the struggle against Israeli occupation of Arab territories.

PIERRE LAVAL, whose political history is minutely recounted in Geoffrey Warner's study, is something of a paradox. He is a symbol of one of the most unhappy periods in French history, and of all that was most shameful and disgraceful in French collaboration with the Nazis. He came to be as universally hated as a public figure can be.

A shy 21-year-old New Jersey miler, who helps to pay for his college education by scrubbing floors in the school field-house, left last night for the Soviet Union and West Germany on a two-week international track tour.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was posthumously cleared by the Supreme Court today of charges of parading without a permit during civil rights demonstrations in Birmingham, Ala., in 1963.

DETROIT, March 10 -- The Chrysler Corporation said today it would increase production of its compact cars at a Detroit area plant to 960 a day from 864. The increase will begin March 24 and mean the addition of 370 workers at the Hamtramck, Mich., assembly plant.
Until the news about Barbara Jo Rubin began circulating, it was just like old times.

A four-day strike by newsmen and on-the-air personalities against radio station WNEW ended last night with agreement on a three-year contract providing for higher pay and continued discussions of work loads.

Two floors containing 51,500 square feet in One Astor Plaza, the 54-story building under construction on the site of the old Astor Hotel in Times Square, have been leased by Quality Bakers of America Cooperative, Inc., a service organization for independent wholesale bakers.
ROMEO, Romeo . . . is that you running around the streets of Manhattan this summer? Could be, if Ohrbach's new collection of imported men's wear -- dubbed "The Return to Elegance'' -- sells well.

MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, March 10 (Reuters) -- Curam Sacaradse of the Soviet Union and Ivan Iliev of Bulgaria were disqualified tonight on charges of collusion to prevent the United States from winning the middleweight gold medal in the world free-style wrestling championship.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Rockefeller and the leaders of the Legislature are expected to announce final agreement shortly on a budget pact that would substitute selective cuts for his proposed 5 per cent across-the-board cutback in projected state spending.

ESSEN, West Germany, March 10 (Reuters) -- The Fried Krupp group broke about even last year, despite a decline in gross revenues to the equivalent of $1.45-billion, or about 3 per cent less than 1967 turnover, Guenter Vogelsang, chairman of the executive board, said here today.

The Panamanian cruise liner Caribia has been forced to abandon her current voyage and cancel a subsequent one because of an engine-room explosion that resulted in a complete failure of her electrical system at sea.

In a 10-round bout between unbeaten neighborhood rivals, David Melendez, known as El Toro to his loyalists in the Bronx, was awarded a majority decision over Willie Munoz last night at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, March 10 - What began over the weekend as a confrontation ended today in a measure of rapport between organized Jewish life and its college generation.
MIAMI, March 10 -- Cuba is reorganizing her officers corps, apparently to insure its loyalty to the ruling Communist party and Premier Fidel Castro.

WICHITA, Kan., March 10 (UPI) -- Willie McCarter and Don Draper sparked Drake to a 77-73 victory over Louisville tonight in a Missouri Valley basketball championship playoff game that earned the Bulldogs a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Charles Appleton Meyer admitted publicly today -- probably for the first time in his life -- that he was "a little bit frightened."
MEMPHIS, March 10 -- James Earl Ray's decision to plead guilty to the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today leaves a number of unanswered questions.

Steel production in the week ended March 8 totaled 2.75 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Senator Barry Goldwater, who concedes he could not have won the Presidency in 1964 under any known electoral reform plan, came out today for immediate major changes in the Presidential selection system.

The rent guidelines put forward by Mayor Lindsay's special board are a great improvement over the plan for self-control advanced by the real estate industry. The Mayor's swift acceptance of the recommendations as "tough but fair" now leaves it up to the City Council to decide whether they should get the city's full blessing.

CAIRO, March 10 -- Guards whipped and clubbed a crowd that hemmed in President Gamal Abdel Nasser today as the funeral of the Egyptian Chief of Staff turned into a vast demonstration calling for vengeance against Israel.

Federal agents seized a 25year-old draft resister yesterday afternoor/in the chapel of Union Theological Seminary as he attended a "sanctuary of conscience" service designed .to "give meaning and perspective" to the arrest.
BALTIMORE, March 10 -- Sing Man Sing, a son of Tudor Minstrel, won the six-furlong feature at Pimlico Race Course today in his first start as a 3-year-old.

Mayor Lindsay, whose election four years ago may have been helped unintentionally by William F. Buckley, may get some help this year in the Republican primary election from another conservative, Vito P. Battista.

The 1968 National Book Awards were announced yesterday, and protest against the Vietnam war, repression in Eastern Europe, devastation wrought by nuclear warfare and racial confrontation emerged as the central themes.

The Atlanta Arts Alliance, operator of the new $13-million Memorial Arts Center in Atlanta, has formed its own theater company and will present four plays this season.
NEWARK, March 10 -- Noxious liquids were splashed this morning throughout the corridors of a building at the Newark campus of Rutgers University, forcing the calling-off of most classes.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Supreme Court declined today to block the induction of five graduate students who had sought deferments to complete their courses.

TATSUYA NAKADAI'S knowing performance as an ex-samurai warrior turned derelict gambler clears the general confusion, holds the plot together and gives to "Kill!" what little artistic merit this new Japanese import possesses.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- The prime rate mechanism used by commercial banks in lending money to business is out of date and should be made more flexible. This was the view taken here today by four senior bankers -- who advanced the idea of instituting several prime rates -- during a panel discussion sponsored by a unit of the American Bankers Association.

Florida orange juice futures have been wavering recently, with some traders worried about a larger-than-expected 1968-1969 crop.

ZURICH, March 10 -- The French Government no longer believes there should be an increase in the official price of gold.

The March 1 New York Times carried a news article entitled "Low Says Mayor Inherited Wagner's Program on Housing." Thanks for your March 1 editorial criticizing the timidity in public policy relating to experimentation with the drug L-Dopa for Parkinson's disease. Understandably, the Food and Drug Administration became more cautious after the tragedy with the drug thalidomide.

TOKYO, March 10 (UPI) -- Kazuyoshi Kanazawa, Japan's bantamweight champion, ripped open the scar tissue around the left eye of Jesus Pimentel of Mexico tonight to score an upset ninth-round technical knockout.

SOUTHDOWN, INC., an oil and sugar company run by self - professed country boys, tried a city slicker's gambit yesterday in its defense against a take-over by Zapata Norness. Operations of Revlon, Inc., in the quarter and year ended Dec. 31 resulted in record sales and earnings, according to the annual report yesterday of the diversified cosmetics and toiletries producer.

Prices picked up yesterday in slow trading on the American Stock Exchange.

CAIRO, March 11 -- New artillery fighting broke out today between Egyptian and Israeli forces across the Suez Canal, the military command announced here.

There are really two crises over the ABM. One is over what the initials mean: do they stand for an essential Anti-Ballistic Missile, or for the Administration's Biggest Mistake? It depends on who is talking. But the second, and maybe even more important crisis, is not so much over what to do about the ABM, but how to decide what to do.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- President Nixon announced today that he would retain William B. Buffum as United States Deputy Representative to the United Nations. However, he is replacing two others high in the American U.N. delegation.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The State Public Service Commission today broadened its charg of laxity against the Penn Central company and is seeking $40,000 in penalties from the railroad for substandard service.

The American Arbitration Association, dedicated to the wider use of impartial third-parties to settle commercial and labor disputes, reported yesterday some modest initial successes in adapting its peace methods to the adjustment of community disputes arising out of racial tensions.
Yields on highest-quality corporate bonds reached 7 3/8 per cent yesterday, and still failed to spark the enthusiastic interest of investors.

With one more crisis apparently over, silver futures prices shrugged off much of the recent price increase by dropping more than four cents an ounce for most deliveries. Trading ran at a moderate clip of 1,955 contracts.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 11 -- After 18 days of fighting, allied officials say they are more certain than ever of the enemy's goal in the current general offensive but still confused by his tactics.
LONDON, March 11 -- The giant British Petroleum Company, long regarded as a sluggish Middle East oil producer, has blossomed into a high-flying glamour issue on the London Stock Exchange.
BONN, March 11 -- Dr. Werner Best, one of the founders of the Gestapo, was arrested at his home in Mulheim today on suspicion of responsibility for the murder of 11,000 Poles in World War II.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI) -- Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel announced today the nomination of James R. Smith of Omaha, Neb., as assistant secretary for water and power. Opposition appeared almost immediately.
LONDON, March 11 (UPI) -- Paul McCartney, the last bachelor among the Beatles, announced today that he would marry Linda Eastman, an American photographer.
HONG KONG, March 11 -- Communist China has asserted that the Soviet Union, during border discussions in 1964, acknowledged that a disputed island in the Ussuri River was Chinese territory.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel expressed confidence today that neither the United Arab Republic nor his own Government wanted to allow the present artillery exchanges across the Suez Canal to expand into a "generalized war."

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The new Republican leadership at the Pentagon has decided to continue the Defense Department activity in domestic social welfare that was started by the Johnson Administration.
THE plight of the small investor is (choose one): A -- Imaginary. A trader can buy and sell as few shares as he likes.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Senator Philip A. Hart said today that oil import quotas are costing consumers and oil-using industries several billions dollars each year.
The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday that its mining and metals division would increase prices for selected chromium, manganese and silicon products effective April 1.

" It was a must game for us," said Dave DeBusschere as he cracked open a can of beer in the dressing room after the New York Knickerbockers had routed the Philadelphia 76ers, 121-101, last night at Madison Square Garden.

BALTIMORE, March 11 (AP) -- A Federal bankruptcy referee approved today the conditional sale of the Philadelphia Eagles football team for $16,055,000 to Leonard H. Tose, a trucking executive from Norristown, Pa.

DETROIT, March 11 -- Representatives of the nation's Negro Roman Catholic priests asked the American church's hierarchy today to surrender substantial control over the work of the church in Negro areas to a new agency operated by Negro clerics and laymen.

The State Investigation Commission made public yesterday private testimony by a Long Island businessman that explained how he had got into deeper trouble when he sought the protection of a Mafia figure against a gang of hoodlums who had extorted $25,000 from him at gunpoint.

LOS ANGELES, March 11 (AP) -- Shrieking youths rampaged through schools in south-central Los Angeles today in the second day of a classroom strike called by Negro militants to protest alleged police brutality. Seven adults and five juveniles were arrested.

ZURICH, March 11 -- Gold prices tumbled in European financial centers today. The French franc held its own and the British pound strengthened. Late in the afternoon, there was a slight recovery as the professionals bought in at the lower price to make good their deliveries of the gold they had sold short.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, (Reuters) -- Premier Tran Van Huong announced the appointment of four new Cabinet Ministers today.

The debate over school decentralization appears at last to be moving into a more constructive, less emotional phase. In an atmosphere of cooperative rationality, representatives of the Board of Education, the Regents, Mayor Lindsay and retiring State Education Commissioner Allen have been merging their separate proposals in hopes of submitting a unified measure to the Legislature in Albany.

Spartans Industries, Inc., reported yesterday 6 per cent higher net income from operations of $10,939,000, or $1.14 a share, for the quarter ended Jan. 26, against $10,360,000, or $1.09 a share, in the like 1968 quarter.

Championship playoff time, rapidly approaching for professional hockey and basketball players, co-incides in those sports with Internal Revenue payoff time. This year, simultaneously, the subject of prize money is very much alive in baseball and football too, because decisions are in the works about changes in traditional patterns.

BALTIMORE, March 11 -- Brother Campbell, the even-money choice owned by Charles Robins, shook off a challenge by The Kraken early in the home stretch and pulled away. to post a two-length triumph in the Dark Star Purse today at Pimlico.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Both Republican and Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee indicated strong convictions today that something must be done to limit the ability of individuals to receive considerable income tax-free by investing in the bonds of state and local governments.

HAUPPAUGH, L. I., March 11 -- Two youths, arrested late last night in the March 4 slaying of a plastics company executive, were booked at the county police headquarters this morning on murder charges.

ATLANTA, March 11 -A small coupon on the last page of the George C. Wallace News-/ letter tells how the publication/ can wind up in your mailbox. each month while indicating] that the former Alabama Governor is not done with national politics. "

THERE wasn't much dancing in the streets early this year when spring couture collections were introduced in Europe's fashion capitals. Bare bosoms, which seemed to be the message of the season, do not a fashion make.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 11 -- Rafael Caldera was inaugurated today as the 43d President of Venezuela and immediately invited all political parties to join him in fighting for "peace, human advancement, liberty and justice."
About 200 demonstrators led by the Students for a Democratic Society drove a recruiter for General Electric off the Queens College campus yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Justice Department may be forced to drop some of its most important criminal prosecutions as a result of a Supreme Court ruling yesterday that gives defendants a right to see highly sensitive wiretap transcripts.
THERE is a special joyousness in the classic dance. Apart from anything else there is the dance's economy and finesse, the trained bodies moving through space, athletes, yet much more than athletes.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- There has never been another state like Pakistan whose national cement is compounded solely of hatred and religion. Its two geographical provinces, together holding about 125,000,000 people and comprising the second largest Islamic power, are separated by a thousand miles of enemy India.

Prices continued to edge ahead yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Volume remained well below the average daily volume so far this year.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- "Dear Mr. President: The South elected you in 1968. The South will defeat you in 1972 if you don't fulfill campaign promises."
If Wolfgang Sawallisch could have ended his Carnegie Hall concert with the Philadelphia Orchestra at intermission last night, he would have seemed a very interesting conductor.
LONDON, March 11 -- British involvement in Europe progressed today in two fields: one practical and immediate, the other theoretical and long-term.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Nixon Administration was reliably reported tonight to have raised with the Soviet Union the problem created by North Vietnamese shelling of South Vietnamese cities.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 10 -- President Tito voiced grave concern today over new Soviet attempts to force "unprincipled compromises" on Communist countries seeking independent development.
Three major corporate merger proposals moved forward yesterday:

LOS ANGELES, March 11 -- Sirhan B. Sirhan was described by a clinical psychologist today as not having the mental capacity to "rationally and meaningfully' premeditate the fatal shooting of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.
Real estate concerns and other property owners now owe the city more than $140-million in delinquent taxes, Finance Administrator Fioravante G. Perrotta said yesterday.

DHARMSALA, India, March 10 -- To a bright and seemingly hopeful flute accompaniment, several thousand Tibetan exiles sang a prayer here today for the spiritual redemption of the Chinese Communist rulers of their country.

Four young women who worked in the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy's presidential campaign have chipped in $30 to form a Stephen Smith for Mayor Committee that has caused something of a stir among city Democrats.
A Federal judge ruled here, yesterday that Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., had issued a "false and misleading" proxy statement before taking over the General Outdoor Advertising Company in 1963.

A State Supreme Court justice reversed a ruling of the city yesterday and ordered it to issue a foundation permit for construction of a 42-story building opposite Lincoln Center that has been the cause of a policy and legal fight between two city agencies.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., March 11 -- Plainfield High School, now a symbol of this city's deep and divisive racial problem and a symbol of the racial problems of many schools throughout the metropolitan area, opened for a wary four hours today after having been closed all last week following a brawl between white and Negro students in the auditorium.

The warning by a hundred members of the Columbia faculty that it is the university's own obligation to defend itself against student disruption comes at a critical moment in the history of the American campus.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Senate backers of the treaty to stop the proliferation of nuclear weapons won an important test vote today as the first of a series of attempts to modify the agreement was rejected.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 11 -- An attempt to hijack a Colombian airliner to Cuba ended today when the would-be hijacker and some passengers and crewmen struggling to subdue him fell from the emergency door of the cabin to the landing ramp.
Tony Curtis, whose father had a lung removed because of cancer, is the latest star to join the crusade against cigarette smoking.
PARIS, March 11 -- France weathered a 24-hour general strike today in nearly total calm and relatively good humor.
Opinion makers and young Americans are two markets that advertisers seem very anxious to get close to these days. Suggestions on how to were made at separate places yesterday.

BERLIN, March 11 -- The United States, Britain and France protested today to the Soviet Union over harassment of West Berlin traffic as East Germany continued its tactics of barring shipments of goods imported or exported by the city.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 11 -- Harvard University responded today to a series of classroom disruptions by ordering the arrest of four young men and a girl who had been on the campus a week.
The stock market continued its mild rally yesterday, fueled more by the absence of negative developments than by any stirring positive news.

PANMUNJOM. Korea, March 11 -- American and North Korean troops exchanged fire in the demilitarized zone today as troops began arriving in South Korea from the United States for a huge paratroop exercise.
THE intercity bidding competition held recently as part of an international bidding event was won by Montreal, whose team totaled 4,719 points out of a possible 6,000.
ALBANY, March 11 -- Mayor Lindsay's campaign aides are making preparations for a news conference next week at which the Mayor is expected to announce he will run for a second term.

The creation of a Department of Communications, which would supersede the Federal Communications Commission in many of its broad and fundamental policy-making functions, will come up for consideration by the White House, Congress and the public.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A member of the Federal Reserve Board said today that the weekly Thursday money banking statistics, eagerly scrutinized by the financial community for years, are essentially worthless. learned lesson from Economics It is not a true statement of the operational facts."

ALBANY, March 11 -- The Senate passed a bill today that would close a loophole whereby city residents who also own country homes in or out of the state have been dodging state and New York City income taxes by claiming the country house as their legal residence.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Robert L. Rand, the acting chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bankboard, has submitted his resignation to President Nixon, thus clearing the way for the nomination of Preston Martin to the position.

A week from today a Boeing 737 jetliner is scheduled to touch down on a gravel-surfaced runway at Resolute Bay, in Canada's Northwest Territories, to bring jet service to that weather station and oil exploration base.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 -- The amazing Mets finally did something amazing today after three straight defeats in spring training.

Robert B. Rivel has been elected a trustee of the Central Savings Bank. He is an executive vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank and executive officer of its portfolio and investment banking department.

The harsh and punitive measures which have been incorporated into New York State's Taylor Law mark a grave set-back in the area of public employer-employe relations in partitular and of labor relations in general. [Editorial March 11.]

ALBANY, March 11 -- The Democratic leaders in the Legislature formed a committee today to investigate a proposed nuclear plant to be owned by the New York State Power Authority and operated by the Niagara Mohawk Power Company.

DETROIT, March 11 -- The Ford Motor Company accepted today a proposal by the United Automobile Workers to study "inverted seniority" as a method of reducing layoffs for newly hired workers who were among the hard-core unemployed.

MOSCOW, March 11 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, general secretary of the Communist party, told recent high-level visitors from Czechoslovakia that the Soviet leadership was dissatisfied with the degree of "normalization" achieved by Prague.

The Anne Wilson Dance Company and Samuel Avital, a mime known as Avital, shared the program last night at the Cubiculo, 414 West 51st Street. Iowa, the eyes of advertising are upon you. It's not your wonderfully yellow ears of corns or your darling chubby hogs, though, that has made you the cynosure of adland. It's that 3 per cent sales tax on advertising and what's going to happen to it.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 11 -- If only eight of the 106 still eligible standardbreds -- 58 colts, 48 fillies -- start in the 14th annual Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway on the night of May 10, the gross value of the one-mile race for 3-year-old pacers will offer $191,140. This would set a sulky sport record for purse-money in a single race.
A union official was accused in Federal Court yesterday of having illegally used $12,000 in union funds for the 1965 mayoral campaign of Abraham D. Beame.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 11 (AP) -- Majestic Prince, unbeaten in his five races and a leading Kentucky Derby prospect, was assigned high weight of 126 pounds today for the $50,000-added San Felipe Handicap Saturday at Santa Anita.
The New York Stock Exchange may abandon its century-old building at the corner establish a new headquarters on landfill in the East River as a result of current negotiations with the city.
CHICAGO, March 11 -- Independent Democrats in special City Council elections upset today one candidate of Mayor Richard J. Daley's Democratic organization and forced another into a runoff April 8.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., March 11 -- Several dozen students at fashionable Briarcliff College held a sit-in today at Dow Hall, a combination dormitory-administration building, to demand a greater student role in the college's operation.

In a Feb. 26 letter to The Times opposing the antiballistic missile (ABM) Sentinel system, Senator George McGovern stated: "Neither the 'thin' nor the 'thick' proposed ABM systems could hope significantly to reduce the catastrophic damage our country would suffer in the event of a heavy Soviet attack."

MOSCOW, March 11 -- A Soviet newspaper called today for strict vigilance at home to counter what it called an anti-Soviet campaign being waged from New York to Peking.

Irving Maidman, the New York realtor who owns more than 80 per cent of the voting securities of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railway, said yesterday he had decided to drop his three-year battle to have the 70-mile line included in the giant Penn Central system.

PATERSON, N. J., March 11 -- A second day of sit-ins by Negro students at Paterson's Eastside High School was ended this afternoon when the police moved in to arrest 56 students, 15 of whom were carried from the building.

The statement about the latest Soviet - Chinese border incident that was made Monday by the Chinese Foreign Ministry revived claims to territory that Peking contends was seized by the Russians more than a century ago under "unequal treaties."

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission has opened discussions with White Consolidated Industries, Inc., over the company's proposed acquisition of the Allis - Chalmers Manufacturing Company.
A schedule of reduced Medicaid fees designed to save nearly $5-million a year, mostly in dentist's fees, was announced yesterday by city welfare and health officials.
FORT MYERS, Fla., March 11 -- Many of the poor of this coastal city told United States Senators today they were afraid to seek free Government food from the man they call "Mr. Crab."

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Nixon announced today that John N. Irwin 2d, a New York lawyer and former Defense Department official, would fly to Peru later this week as a "special emissary" to discuss troublesome United States-Peruvian issues.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel is drafting a plan to enlarge the area where oil drilling is prohibited off Santa Barbara, Calif. This would be part of a package to combat pollution and afford full public review of future leasing of Federal offshore lands.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 11 (AP) -- More than 75 Princeton University students occupied an administration building today to protest the school's investments in companies doing business in South Africa.

HOUSTON, March 11 -- Apollo 9 recovery forces off Bermuda were alerted tonight to be ready, if necessary, to move south into calmer waters for the orbiting astronauts' scheduled splashdown Thursday morning.

PARIS, March 11 -- Ambassador Valerian A. Zorin of the Soviet Union called at the Foreign Ministry today and discussed the recent incidents on the Soviet-Chinese border. No details of the conversation were made available.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- Richie Allen, one of the most feared right-handed hitters in baseball, is going to make a serious effort to become a switchhitter this spring.
Some real-estate leaders indicated privately yesterday that they would reluctantly accept the rent guidelines endorsed Monday by Mayor Lindsay.

CARLOS CHAVEZ, that most American of composers (one of his grandfathers was an Indian), returned to the New York concert scene last night in Philharmonic Hall as guest conductor of the Little Orchestra Society, bringing with him one of his newest works.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- The top-seeded team of Joyce Davenport and Mrs. Terry Thesieres of Cynwyd, Pa., defeated Mrs. Runyon Colie and Mrs. E. Mower Lewis, from the home club, 15-5, 15-7, 15-4, in the first round of the United States squash racquets doubles championship today at Philadelphia Cricket Club.
The re-election of Joseph Curran as president of the National Maritime Union was announced yesterday when he was declared the winner of a court-ordered election.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Jewish student leaders who complain that the campus is "disenfranchised" in the Jewish community will get some of what they have been asking for -- a piece of the decision making action.

Sister Kathleen Daly, dressed in a light gray jumper and a turquoise sweater sat sipping a beer at Clancy's Bar, 48th Street and Third Avenue, and philosophized about what she and her friends were doing to theology.

JERUSALEM, March 11 -- The third major artillery battle in four days between Egyptians and Israelis was fought today across the Suez Canal. One Israeli soldier was reported to have been killed in the three-and-a-half-hour engagement, making a total of five Israeli dead since Saturday.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Protesting Howard University students, faced with a court order, today abandoned peacefully the three buildings they had occupied.

For the third night in a row New York has been host to college choirs in its concert halls. Last night, the visitors were the Simmons College Glee Club from Boston, a women's group, and the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute Glee Club and Orchestra from Troy, N. Y., made up of young men.

QUIXOTIC innocence is an unlikely style for modern satire and Joseph Morgenstern's "World Champion" is a novel as unfashionably innocent as a dewdrop. His hero is Wro Wraninan, a zanily gentle schoolteacher from Dororo, a Pacific island nation wracked by a desperate civil war.

CORONADO, Calif., March 11 -- Five admirals on the court of inquiry here pressed Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher today on his decision to keep the Pueblo's two .50-caliber machine guns silent when North Korean submarine chasers and torpedo boats opened fire on Jan. 23, 1968.

LONDON, March 11 -- Arthur J. Goldberg, the former United States representative at the United Nations, said today that any effort by the Big Four to impose a settlement on the Middle East was bound to fail.

TOYKO, March 11 -- Premier Eisaku Sato indicated in the Diet (Parliament) yesterday and today that he favored an Okinawa free of nuclear weapons and with American bases there subject to the same restrictions as those in Japan proper.
