The Westchester Chamber Chorus and Orchestra is a tiny group of people that, even on the miniature stage of Carnegie Recital Hall where it performed last night, looks sparse,
Trading on the London stock market turned quiet and cautious yesterday with a slide in gold-mining shares providing the major price movement.
A nationwide alarm was issued yesterday for an attractive blond actress who disappeared Sunday night after going to a West Side street corner in an attempt to recover a stolen dog.

MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, March 11 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union received 10 gold medals today and the United States two as the first world wrestling championships ever to be held in South America ended.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Roger L. Stevens, whose term as chairman of the National Council and National Endowment for the Arts ended today, will not be reappointed.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- The chief architect of a Federal Reserve proposal to overhaul the administration of its discount window" said here today that the banking industry had "offered a general endorsement" of the plan, and that a final draft would be released for comment this month or next. Hotel, said that, as a result of suggestions, some modifications had been made in the original proposal.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 11 -- In August of 1967 an errant pitch gunned in with sickening velocity on Tony Conigliaro of the Red Sox. The ball struck him on the left cheekbone. It shattered the cheekbone in three places, dislocated the jaw and severely damaged the vision in the left eye.

A former convict awaiting trial on charges of having swindled four jewelers, a real-estate developer and a stock-broker out of more than $500,000 was arrested yesterday on charges of having added a bank to his list of victims.

MEMPHIS, March 11 -- James Earl Ray was taken to the state prison at Nashville before dawn today to begin serving a 99-year sentence for the murder of the Rex. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

The precipitous about-face of the New Jersey Legislature on the tidelands referendum is as welcome as it was unexpected. Hughes for blocking this threatened giveaway of public lands worth a billion dollars or more.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., March 11 -All things being equal (which they haven't been for the Rangers in recent weeks) Don Marshall will play left wing tomorrow night for the New Yorkers against the Pittsburgh Penguins at Madison Square Garden.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 12 -- Enemy mortar and rocket attacks decreased substantially during the last night.
NEWARK, March 11 -- The Newark City Council reversed itself today and granted a reprieve of at least nine months to the financially threatened Newark Museum and the city public library system.

Yet another spiffy Jockey Club opened here last night with the usual party and an appropriately glittering array of reasonably young guests, and, like a lot of establishments of the same name, the club at 123 East 54th Street isn't a club at all but a reasonably charming restaurant.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Nixon will probably be urged by his advisers to continue Federal support of the multi-million-dollar program to build a supersonic transport.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- As Senate opposition to the Sentinel antimissile system mounted, President Nixon today delayed until later this week a decision on whether to deploy the missile defense.

BONN, March 11 -- Ambassador Semyon K. Tsarapkin of the Soviet Union called on Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger today for the fourth time in three weeks to talk not about Berlin but, according to an official source, about Communist China.
Boys and girls created disorders at Brooklyn's Eastern District High School yesterday, but the school stayed open with police guards.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr. introduced legislation today that would require the governing bodies of colleges and universities to draw up regulations to "maintain law and order" on the campus or lose their state aid.
" WE can do anything in custom," Arnold Scaasi said.

More than 200 authors, publishers and critics, declaring that the United States was "secure enough in its democratic values," urged yesterday that immigration restrictions against foreigners because of dissenting political views be abolished.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A sampling of 20 apparel items in three typical department stores has disclosed that present trade barriers are costing American consumers up to 40 per cent in higher prices on widely demanded imports, a leading retailer said today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Tabacco Institute, Inc., accused the Federal Trade Commission today of not taking account of "vital information" in reporting the results last week of new tests for tar and nicotine in 126 varieties of cigarettes.

The commanding officer of the Police Department's Third Division reported yesterday that of 453 arrests made in the Times Square area from March 3 to March 10, only 163 resulted in convictions. And only 68 of those convictions, he said, resulted in jail sentences ranging from fewer than five days to a maximum of 15 days.

YONKERS, March 11 -- The president of Sarah Lawrence College today announced the formation of a group to study the issues of high tuition, coeducation and diversity that brought on a sit-in demonstration now in its seventh day today at the women's institution here.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 11 -- It was before the game today, and the Yankee dugout was noisier than Yankee dugouts used to be. A little man was standing on the top step telling jokes. Old jokes.
WATERBURY, Conn., March 11 -- Two top police officers here were suspended after they were arrested early this morning and charged with intoxication and breach of peace.
The National Easter Seal Society for Crippled Children and Adults is described as the oldest and largest national voluntary agency serving the physically handicapped.

TRENTON, March 11 -- Representative Henry Helstoski, the liberal Democrat who has won three straight Congressional elections in predominantly Republican Bergen County, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for Governor on the front steps of the Newark Public Library.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird is considering a withdrawal of 40,000 to 50,000 American combat and support soldiers from Vietnam this year, according to Administration sources.

The structure of a Columbia College course in Afro-American history has been altered by agreement between the instructor and a committee of Negro students in the class.

Grand jury action on a variety of crimes will result from the State Investigation Commission's disclosures of racketeer infiltration of legitimate business here, in Westchester County and on Long Island, it was indicated yesterday.
Mona Sherman, an actress who was missing for three days, turned herself over to the police last night and said she had been held captive by kidnappers.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, over the objections of the State Department, approved today a resolution calling upon the Executive branch not to enter into any further foreign commitments without the express approval of Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Dealer markups, not inequities in the Government oil-import program, account for high heating-oil costs in New England, Senator Russell B. Long. Democrat of Louisiana said today.

CORONADO, Calif., March 12 -- Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher has told the court of inquiry here that the U.S.S. Pueblo's intelligence mission was unproductive during the 11 days that the ship sailed from Japan before she was captured by North Korea.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Signs of delay on abortion reform cropped up in the Assembly today amid indications that the Republican leaders intend to bring up the reform bill in the Senate first -- where its chances of passage are considered poorer than in the Assembly.
BEHIND the brownstone fronts of Murray Hill's side streets, where backyards still intertwine like laced fingers, quiet memories of the past are evoked in the midst of a clangorous, changing city.

An executive of Haryou-Act, the Harlem antipoverty agency, was arrested yesterday and accused of having cashed $466,150 in fraudulent checks drawn on the account of the Manpower and Career Development Agency.
PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (AP) -- A $2.5-million damage suit brought by parents of a deformed child against a manufacturer of the drug thalidomide was settled today out of court.
Fifteen members of an armed hijacking ring that terrorized truckers in the garment center in 1966 received prison sentences of two to 10 years yesterday from Federal Judge Milton Pollack.

The Landmarks Preservation Commission said yesterday that it would hold a public hearing at City Hall April 10 on the controversial skyscraper that Morris Saady, a British real estate man, proposes to erect over Grand Central Terminal.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Doing nothing, when it comes to choosing courses of high policy, actually is doing something. And it is that kind of "nothing" that Israel's Foreign Minister, Abba Eban, will counsel Mr. Nixon to do in their conversation at the White House.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 12 -- "I like the way Father Hesburgh of Notre Dame handled students who acted up," said a middle-aged Illinois housewife. "He gave them 15 minutes to shape up or ship out."
The fastest-growing fashion in air-cargo thefts are wigs, wiglets and the basic raw material, human hair, according to the American Institute of Marine Underwriters.

HOUSTON, March 12 -- With close to 10 successful days of orbital flight behind them, the Apollo 9 astronauts were set tonight to ride their spacecraft to a splashdown in calm waters off the Bahamas at 12:01 P.M. Eastern Standard time tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI) -- Robert E. Short, a Minneapolis businessman and owner of the Washington Senators, resigned today as treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, and Patrick J. O'Connor, a Minneapolis lawyer, was named acting treasurer.

DURHAM, N. C., March 12 (UPI) -- National Guard troops were ordered into Durham today following a violent outburst by groups of students from Duke University and North Carolina College who rioted last night, smashing store fronts and overturning cars.

The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art announced yesterday the appointment of John F. White as president of the historic educational institution. He will become the eighth president of the century-old school, which is tuition free.
WITH BIAFRAN FORCES, Near Owerri, March 3 (delayed) -- For a month, the Federal Nigerian brigade in Owerri has been surrounded and cut off. The last armored Nigerian relief column got through Feb. 9.

LONDON, March 12 -- A British official sent to Anguilla to discuss the rebel West Indian island's future decided today that the time had come to leave after shots were fired at the house where he had gone to lunch.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Government's survey of business plans to invest in plant and equipment will confirm a private survey and show a substantial increase for 1969. The Government figures are due before the end of the week.
Frankie De Paula, the popular Jersey City light heavyweight has withdrawn from his March 24 bout with Don Fullmer because of a fall on ice during road work, Madison Square Garden said yesterday.
The city's real estate industry agreed yesterday to accept the entire package of rent guidelines, rollbacks and refunds endorsed by Mayor Lindsay.
The stock market's two-day rally ended yesterday as activity slowed and most issues held within narrow trading ranges.

Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant, the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, criticized her hosts yesterday at a luncheon in her honor by exhorting them to greater efforts to protect the "fed-up" consumer. The former Miss America and television personality told a luncheon of the Better Business Bureau of Greater New York at the Plaza Hotel that it should publicize the names of those stores that generate "an unusually high proportion of valid complaints.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The Legislature, after some partisan wrangling in the Assembly, unanimously passed a resolution today urging Congress to set uniform minimum standards for welfare payments throughout the country.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 12 -- St. John's will try for the second time in three years to get beyond the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship tournament when the Redmen meet an old antagonist, Davidson, in a semi-final game of the Eastern Regional playoffs tomorrow night.

DETROIT, March 12 -- New car sales in early March were down from the year before, automakers reported today. The four leading United States automakers reported 176,586 deliveries of United States models March 1-10, down 7 per cent from 189,675 a year earlier.

The Commercial Solvents Corporation said yesterday that effective April 1, it is increasing the price of methanol 1 cent a gallon for bulk deliveries of 4,000 gallons or more on all sales at less than the published rates of 25 cents east and 27 cents west of the Rocky Mountains.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, said today that he was dissatisfied with information provided by the Small Business Administration on its dealings with Charles G. Rebozo, a close friend of President Nixon.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 12 -- Baseball, the grand old game as American as apple pie, is having a hard time adjusting to change. The experimental rule concerning the designated pinch-hitter, for example, has come upon hard times in the Cactus Circuit, the spring training league of the Southwest.
LOS ANGELES, March 12 -- Almost nine out of 10 persons employed in aerospace, one of this area's largest and most prestigious industries, are white persons of the category known locally as "Anglos."

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Following are excerpts from the statement delivered today on conglomerate mergers to the House Ways and Means Committee by Richard W. McLaren, Assistant Attorney General, antitrust division:

Representative James H. Scheuer, bidding for the mayoralty, was told yesterday that he would lose votes in the Jewish community through fear that, since he is Jewish, his election would increase anti-Semitism in the city.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 12 -- About 50 Pathet Lao and North Vietnamese commandos attacked the military section of the Luang Prabang Airport early today, destroying three planes.

PERIGUEUX, France, March 12 (AP) -- Josephine Baker, the former music hall star, was hospitalized today for a chill that she contracted when the buyers of her bankrupt chateau-orphanage forcibly ejected her yesterday.

Much as I agree with W. J. Mindlin (letter March 5) that the United States should adopt "a more flexible approach" in applying the Hickenlooper Amendment to Peru and other countries with whom foreign investment disputes arise, it is to Congress and not to the Administration that he should direct his plea against "any dogmatic actions."

SAIGON, March 12 (UPI) -- The United States Command announced today that American artillery had fired two barrages into the demilitarized zone, killing at least 14 North Vietnamese soldiers and silencing three machine-gun positions.

BONN, March 12 -- German and East European specialists suggested today that the Soviet diplomatic approach to Bonn and other Western governments yesterday on the border incident disclosed a classic Russian desire to avoid "encirclement."

Most of the commotion about the deployment of the Sentinel ABM system is misplaced. Sentinel or even a thicker system will not disrupt the strategic balance with the Soviet Union and may have desirable effects.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 12 -- Laotian officials indicated privately today that they felt Melvin R. Laird, the United States Secretary of Defense, by acknowledging that American troops had entered Laos, had embarrassed the Laotian Government and the American mission in Laos.
BALTIMORE, March 12 -- In one of the most exciting games of the National Basketball Association season, the Baltimore Bullets edged the New York Knickerbockers tonight, 111-110.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., March 12 -- Casting themselves in the role of the social conscience of Briarcliff College, more than 50 students talked their way today genteely through the second day of their sit-in demonstration at the exclusive girl's school here.

SACRILEGE and reverence seem an unlikely pair to find flourishing harmoniously under the same roof, especially if the roof hangs above a basement in the heart of Greenwich Village and the time is very late at night.

A Yale psychiatrist, accepting the 1968 National Book Award in science for his study on the survivors of Hiroshima, expressed the hope yesterday that mankind would not succumb to "a debased religion of nuclearism."

Student leaders at the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University said yesterday that they would not accept a tuition increase until an audit backed by the Student Council was made of the university's fiscal records.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 12 (UPI) -- Gov. Raymond P. Shafer denied today there was segregation -- de facto or any other type -- in any of the state-owned and operated colleges in Pennsylvania.
An agreement between the City of New York and The Port of New York Authority for a new $60.5 - million passenger ship terminal faces a major challenge before the Federal Maritime Commission.

PATERSON, N. J., March 12 -- A sit-in by Negro students at Paterson Eastside High School ended this after a day of tense meetings among student leaders, parents, clergymen, community representatives and school board members.
Spyros P. Skouras, one of the film industry's last executive giants, announced yesterday his retirement after more than half a century of activity.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- Wayne Bartz, a 30-year-old Milwaukee truck salesman, became tonight the first motorcycle rider to be killed during Daytona Speedway's 10-year history when his vehicle slammed into two other cycles on the first lap of a heat race to qualify drivers for a 76-mile novice cycle event Saturday.
" YOU'LL get over it, Joe," Willie said in a 1944 Mauldin cartoon from an Italian battlefield where they kept in foxhole touch with the historic soil.

LONDON, March 12 -- Britain's drive to strengthen and elevate relations with other European nations advanced another step today with the nomination of a Minister of State to replace a Foreign Office official as permanent representative on the Council of the Western European Union.

MANILA, March 12 -- Two Senate committees voted today to investigate charges by a leading opposition Senator, Jovito Salonga, that President Ferdinand E. Marcos had violated the anti-graft law by his actions in the recent exchange of stock between Benguet Consolidated, Inc., a Philippine mining company, and the Grand Bahamas Port Authority Ltd., a land and resort developing company.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 10 -- Investigations in the field have indicated in case after case that the intensity and results of the current enemy offensive were understated in communiques and by official allied spokesmen.
The International Controls Corporation and the Electronic Specialty Company announced yesterday that their boards of directors had agreed in principle to a merger of the companies.
Mayor Lindsay named a 13-member committee, including top city officials yesterday, to "coordinate" efforts to stem student violence in the city schools.

The terms of an exchange offer for the publicly held shares of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation were disclosed yesterday in a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Jones Laughlin Industries, Inc., a recently formed subsidiary of Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges released yesterday their latest lists of changes in stock ownership by corporate directors, officers and large shareholders in listed securities.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A top Federal air official declared today that the Government was planning to incorporate "area navigation" procedures into its system for handling air traffic.

Alexander B. Trowbridge has been elected a trustee of the Bowery Savings Bank. Mr. Trowbridge, 39 years old, is president of the American Management Association. He was Secretary of Commerce from February, 1967, until March 1968.

NATURE is red in tooth and claw. It is the custom of the young to destroy the old. Let in the light on the dusty places. Lyle Kessler, whose play "The Watering Place" opened at the Music Box Theater last night, has no shortage of messages. It is only the messenger he lacks.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- American officials, noting a subtle shift in emphasis in North Vietnamese declarations in Paris, suspect that Hanoi may be hinting at an eventual willingness to enter secret discussions about mutual troop withdrawals.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The new Republican chief of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division said today he expected to look at, and possibly bring suit against, some conglomerate mergers that have already been put into effect.
Just about every small business -- or so it seems -- is a franchise operation today.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court held today that a State Court of Claims judge "was worked to death" trying to clear up a logjam of cases, partly resulting from the capital's South Mall project.

AN educational program geared to all levels in the dog-show world was called for yesterday by Larry Kalstone of McKeesport, Pa., breeder, exhibitor and club official, in an address before the Dog Fanciers Club at the Overseas Press Club.

DETROIT, March 12 -- The Ford Motor Company recalled 16,400 Econoline trucks today for the correction of potential safety defects, and the General Tire Rubber Company of Akron recalled 31,000 General Jet tires size 8.1515.

MOSCOW, March 12 -- The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia suggested tonight that deployment of an American antimissile system might set back the chances for successful United States-Soviet talks on arms control.

KATONAH, N. Y. -- When a recipe was printed on these pages some time ago for Ed Giobbi's pasta with ricotta, it turned out to be one of the most popular recipes of the year. It also elicited a response from Portland Hoffa, whose first husband was the late Fred Allen, the master comedian of radio.

Four thousand chanting high school students protesting proposed cutbacks in state aid to education marched and shouted outside Governor Rockefeller's Manhattan offices yesterday, at times halting traffic on Fifth Avenue.
The Coast Guard's International Ice Patrol started its 55th annual season yesterday by looking for a "rare berg."

ROME, March 12 -- Pope Paul VI announced today the creation of a new Vatican group, the Committee for Human Development, to co-ordinate the efforts of the Catholic Church with those of other international bodies in wiping out illiteracy and other obstacles to social progress in developing countries.

Although man today is changing the face of the land at an almost catastrophic pace, the process is one that began thousands of years ago with the birth of agriculture. Patches of virgin forest or virgin prairie are hard to find. The process has grossly altered the animal populations of our planet.
The 16-team National Invitation Tournament begins at Madison Square Garden tonight when Florida faces Temple at 7 o'clock and Tulsa plays St. Peter's in the second game of the double-header.

The stable in Central Park is essential. Mounted police are needed because horses can patrol areas of dense shrubbery where scooters and cars cannot go. This function is vital in summer, especially, when there are so many evening concerts and theater events.

NO sooner had architects promoted the open-floor plans for dwellings in the nineteen-forties than the people who lived in them began to long for a greater sense of intimacy and privacy. Result: They started closing off space with room dividers.
Customs officials announced yesterday afternoon that they had found 62 pounds of heroin hidden in a cargo of canned food from Spain -- the second such seizure in three days.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 12 (AP) -- Four American fliers who were captured in Cambodia a month ago arrived here today after a letter from President Nixon to Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Cambodian Chief of State had brought them their freedom.
PRAGUE, March 12 -- Gustav Husak, the leader of the Slovak Communist party, today dismissed Miroslav Kusy, the chief ideologist of the party and a liberal, accusing him of "rightist opportunism."

The Most Rev. Terence J. Cooke, Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, became yesterday the first prelate of his church to preach in the chapel at Union Theological Seminary, a Protestant institution.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- There is a musty smell at the Capitol these days and the corridors of the Senate Office Building are so still you can hear the salaries rising.

In the final period of last night's weird game at Madison Square Garden, it appeared as if Joe Daley wanted to cry. The Penguins' goalie buried his face in his glove after stopping a smash by the Rangers' Vic Hadfield.

ROME, March 12 -- A newly discovered fragment of a play trilogy projected by the late Boris Pasternak, Russian novelist and poet, has been smuggled out of the Soviet Union and was published here today.
ALBANY, March 12 -- The State Public Service Commission turned down today a proposal by utility companies that they be allowed to tie consumer rates to changes in their tax bills.

PARIS, March 12 -- President de Gaulle told President Nixon during their recent conversations here that France would object to any United States - Soviet talks dealing with European affairs unless France was consulted.

JAMES A. McCULLOUGH, a tall, professorial economist at the respected Wall Street firm of Scudder, Stevens Clark, took a long-range view of the economy yesterday, touching on the influences of inflation and the flow of funds into the stock market.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The presidents of the three commercial television networks told the Senate today that they would cooperate with the Surgeon General in his study of the connection between television and violence.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 -- This was not the "B" team of the Philadelphia Phillies but the "A" team of the Detroit Tigers. Yet the mighty Mets manhandled the world champions, 12-0, today with the same bullying disdain that has revolutionized their spring-training relations in 48 hours.

PARIS, March 12 -- Following yesterday's general strike, Information Minister Joel Le Theule said today that the Government stood firm on its decision to raise wages of its employes by 4 per cent this year, no more, no less.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today President Nixon's nomination of Walter H. Annenberg, the publisher and philanthropist, as Ambassador to Britain.

WESTBURY, L. I., March 12 -- Harness racing's Stan the Man, Stanley Dancer, who at the moment has a 101-horse stable, the largest in his 24 seasons in the sulky sport, is looking forward to an even greater year than he enjoyed in 1968.

Indications are strong that a trade-off is being negotiated in the Albany talks between Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders on modifications in the Governor's proposed 5 per cent across-the-board cut in the state budget. What seems in prospect is a budget balanced through smaller cuts for state aid to schools and bigger cuts for aid to welfare and Medicaid.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Three banks, two in the billion-dollar class, were authorized today by the Federal Reserve Board to form one-bank holding companies.

MOSCOW, March 12 (AP) -- Charlie Greene, world record- holder in the 100 meters, and Madeline Manning, Olympic gold medalist in the women's 800 meters, headed the United States track and field forces who face the Soviet Union's top talent in a two-day meet tomorrow and Friday.

Ten Negro and Jewish leaders said yesterday that potential cuts in the budget and student admissions at City University "threaten a new confrontation between religious and racial groups" that "could exceed the destructiveness of previous controversies.''

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers tried today to temper Israel's fears of four-power efforts toward an eventual Middle East settlement. He conferred for more than an hour with the visiting Israeli Foreign Minister, Abba Eban.

BONN, March 12 -- With visions of contracts, West German businessmen and officials returned today from the international trade fair at Leipzig, still pleasantly surprised at Communist hospitality throughout the latest Berlin tension.
The stock-brokerage concern of Lief, Foster, Werle Co. has signed a $4-million lease for space in the 29-story office building under construction at 100 Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee was urged today to investigate conditions at the nation's 23 military prisons, particularly the Army stockade at the Presidio in San Francisco.
PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics, paced by the scoring of Bailey Howell and Sam Jones and the playmaking of Emmette Bryant, defeated the Philadelphia 76ers tonight, 126-117.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, was designated today by President Nixon to be chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights.
World sugar futures rose sharply early in the session yesterday, then fell back a little.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI) -- James O. Eastland, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said today that he was assembling all the facts in the slaying of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 12 -- The authorities investigating a fatal shooting uncovered a secret military training base for Haitian exiles deep in the Everglades today and arrested two Americans said to be in charge of the camp. Ten Haitians were also arrested.

LONDON, March 12 (Reuters) -Mrs. Coretta King, the widow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., will start a British memorial fund for her husband Sunday when she preaches at St. Paul's Cathedral here.

FORT LAUDERDALE, March 12 -- Jerry Kenney made his manager happy twice today -- the first time when he made a magnificent diving catch in left center field, the second time when he did not break a leg.

The royal family, male side, was new to the New York City Opera's production of "Prince Igor" last night at The New York State Theater. Singing their roles for the first time with the company were David Clatworthy as Igor and Harry The yard as his son, Vladimir.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 12 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Terence O'Neill today announced a series of Cabinet appointments, none of which included his opponents in a recent leadership crisis.
DETROIT, March 12 -- The United Auto Workers accused a Negro extremist group today of trying "to spread terror'' in Detroit auto plants.

QUEBEC CITY, March 12 -- Last week France's Alpine racers were chastised for having sped through the narrow streets of Vail, Colo. Today 20 international skiers made members of the local World Cup committee nervous by lobbing snowballs playfully at the platform on which Mayor Gilles Lamontagne was delivering a welcoming speech.
HONG KONG, March 12 -- A Hong Kong doggerel-writer recently addressed a song to the Governor, Sir David Trench, containing the following verse:

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 12 (UPI) -- Gary Player of South Africa who has been virtually unchallenged as the best foreign golfer in the United States during the last decade, rejoined the American tour today after a six-month layoff.

THE madness that hits New York on March 17 seems to have afflicted even those who have no noticeable Irish ancestry. Take the house of Roux, for instance. The company thinks it's a dandy idea if the daughters (and sons) of Erin color their hair green in honor of St. Patrick.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., March 12 -- The Plainfield Board of Education today offered Negro high school students a program designed to meet a number of their grievances.

For the second year in a row, Glen Campbell, the pop singer, figured importantly in the annual Grammy Awards, the top recording industry prizes announced last night in New York, Nashville, Chicago and Los Angeles.
When the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra comes to town, it brings a pleasantly varied program, including at least one work new to this city.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 12 -- A group of Princeton University alumni, alarmed by the advent of coeducation here and angered by yesterday's student demonstrations against the university's investment policies, announced a drive today to elect an insurgent slate of alumni trustees pledged to restore the old values at Old Nassau.
A pair of fillies that had run in the Black Helen -- albeit with little distinction -- in Hialeah a couple of weeks ago, finished one, two in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.
FOR the first time in years Norman Norell hasn't made any sailor dresses. But never mind. Other designers have provided them for summer.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The White House announced today that Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster would replace Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer as the Supreme Allied Commander in Europe on July 1.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI) -- Bills with strong bipartisan backing were introduced in the Senate and House today to amend the antitrust laws to permit competing newspapers to merge their commercial and business operations to ease the pressure of rising costs.
AUSTIN, Tex., March 8 -- For five years Austin was a weekend world capital, regularly extending its hospitality to the likes of Ludwig Erhard and Henry Ford 2d.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, has notified the Senate Commerce Committee that the nomination of Charles H. Meacham, a fellow Alaskan, to be Commissioner of Fish and Wildlife is "personally objectionable" to him and has asked the committee to reject the nomination.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 13 -- United States infantrymen invaded a Vietcong stronghold in the Mekong Delta and killed 57 of the enemy in 13 hours of fighting, the allied command reported yesterday.

Mignon Dunn added a major role to her Metropolitan Opera repertory last night when she appeared as the Nurse in the company's performance of Strauss's "Die Frau Ohne Schatten." The Nurse in this gigantic operatic fantasy is no ordinary attendant.

BERLIN, March 12 -- The East Germans, continuing their harassment of West Berlin, fired shots today at a man trying to escape to the West, arrested a traveler, refused free access to others and leveled new charges of arms production and arms exports against West Berlin countries.
Prices on the London stock market continued an easing trend yesterday. In Paris, domestic shares again advanced to put the Bourse index at a new high for the year.

An Upper West Side apartment building has become a battleground between tenants ordered to vacate their decontrolled apartments and a landlord who wants to upgrade their 57 apartments for new tenants who would pay higher rents.

As the scientific testimony accumulates and the resistance in Congress intensifies, President Nixon has decided to put off until tomorrow his decision on the deployment of the Sentinel antiballistic missile system. If this delay means that Mr. Nixon is looking beyond the recommendations of Secretary of Defense Laird and personally studying the technical issues, there are grounds for hope that he will decide against the ABM.

Three large Eastern utilities disclosed plans yesterday for increasing their expansion efforts over the coming years, while a major Midwestern pipeline said it was cutting back its efforts "after a careful assessment" of present conditions.
IT is possible that a giant oak quails when a burly woodsman approaches it with an ax, or grows apprehensive when a fox kills a rabbit nearby.

" WILLIAM TELL," Rossini's rarely performed opera, provided not only an overture to gallop by (see the Lone Ranger, Tonto, Silver) but also music for a beautiful little divertissement by the celebrated 19th-century Danish dancer, teacher and choreographer, August Bournonville.
The Queens College administration has rejected demands for control of the Queens SEEK program by the Coalition of Black and Puerto Rican Students at the college.

MOSCOW, March 12 -- Pravda began publication today of chapters from a long-awaited novel by Mikhail A. Sholokhov that says Stalin's eyes were closed to the illegal arrests made by his secret police on the eve of World War II.

A combination of rising production costs and the inroads on circulation and advertising of television and other communications media has made it difficult for newspapers to stay alive in many cities. Out of that difficulty has come a trend toward preserving diversity in news presentation and editorial expression through the pooling of publishing facilities by separately owned morning and afternoon papers.

PARIS, March 12 -- The chief allied negotiators are expected to urge North Vietnam again at the eighth session of the peace talks tomorrow to start discussing a mutual, phased withdrawal of external forces from South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Top executives of the coal industry, acknowledging an "unsatisfactory" safety record, endorsed today many of the sweeping mine safety proposals submitted to Congress since an underground explosion last November killed 76 miners at Farmington, W. Va.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- a bipartisan group of 28 Congressmen proposed a law today that would require commercial and private airplanes to carry automatic beacons that could guide rescuers if the planes crashed.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 12 -- The Douglass College faculty, at a meeting late last night, recommended that more Negro faculty and staff members be hired, that an expanded summer orientation program be offered to specially admitted students and that a special residence hall be set up for Negro and white students in the Afro-American studies program.
ONE of the biggest exhibition matches ever seen in this country was played recently at the Miami Beach Chess Club. It pitted Anthony Santasiere against Sammy Reshevsky.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 12 (UPI) -- The Kentucky State Racing Commission filed an amended regulation today aimed at clarifying the official placing of a horse found to have unlawful medication, such as last year's first-place derby finisher, Dancer's Image.
Mayor Lindsay will address the Correctional Association of New York at its 125th anniversary dinner March 25 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom.
MEMPHIS, March 12 -- "Next to cotton, James Earl Ray is Memphis's biggest industry," Percy Foreman said last fall after he succeeded Arthur J. Hanes as Ray's lawyer.

The attempted or successful disruption of public affairs meetings from coast to coast has become a dangerous threat to American civil liberties and democracy. In New York State in the week of March 1, rude and noisy demonstrators invaded three important symposiums and seriously interrupted the proceedings.
LOS ANGELES, March 12 -- The slayer of Senator Robert F. Kennedy was said today to have been motivated by a fantasy in which the Senator replaced the killer's father as the victim of the shooting.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today its expedited procedures for handling the heavy volume of investment company registrations and other filings. They are similar, but not identical, to those adopted last month for registrations of other securities.

Secretary of Defense Laird has taken the step best designed to nudge the Paris negotiations off dead center by expressing his conviction that it would be "desirable and possible" to withdraw some American soldiers from Vietnam. He will strike a major blow for peace if he persuades President Nixon to order a substantial start on troop withdrawal this year.
" We are trying to make newspaper's look prosperous, exciting, healthy and the 'in' medium," said Jack Kaufman, newspapers' No. 1 salesman, hastily adding, "They are."
PEKING, March 12 -- Anti-Soviet demonstrations resumed here today as a huge crowd gathered in front of the Soviet Embassy.

STONY BROOK, L. I., March 12 -- Student demonstrators occupied part of the administration offices and library at the State University center here this evening, vowing they would not leave until the center's president agreed to end all war-related research and recruitment.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI) -- Student protesters joined the airline industry today in a battle to save youth discount fares. They argued before the Civil Aeronautics Board that discrimination by age could be good in some cases.
PARIS, March 12 -- The price of gold continued to retreat in European financial centers today as fears of an imminent devaluation of the French franc receded.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Justice Department is expected to ask the Supreme Court tomorrow to change a far-reaching decision on eavesdropping.
Net profit of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation last year declined to $13,752,000 from $15,420,000 in 1967, despite an increase in gross income to $196,049,000 from $195,457,000.

HONG KONG, Thursday, March 13 -- Peking depicted the Soviet Union today as engaged in an effort, in collusion with the United States, to contain Communist China. It asserted that the effort was sure to fail in the face of the power of the thought of Chairman Mao Tsetung and "the world influence of Socialist China."
FOR many years past -- ever since the great Italian Blue Team won the first of its string of world titles in 1957 -- the American team has finished second in the contests for the Bermuda Bowl.

CALMNESS and efficiency are the words usually used to describe Gen. Andrew Jackson Goodpaster, whose appointment as commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the American forces in Europe was announced yesterday.

After two sessions of moderate advances, the American Stock Exchange lost some ground yesterday. Volume dropped to an extremely slow pace. In recent weeks, the exchange has failed to put more than two days of advances together.

The seemingly unending climb in interest rates continued yesterday. Fixed-income securities as different as Federal tax-exempt notes and railroad equipment certificates were sold at record borrowing costs.

MOSCOW, March 12 -- The Soviet Union has apparently decided to exploit the March 2 border clash with China for maximum effect in its relations with China, the world Communist movement and possibly the West.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 12 -- In a realignment of the South Vietnamese Government today, President Nguyen Van Thieu further consolidated his political power and displayed increased concern for civil and postwar problems.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Nixon will disclose at a news conference Friday his decision on the future of the controversial Sentinel antimissile system, the White House announced today.

LONDON, March 12 (UPI) -- Paul McCartney, the last of the bachelor Beatles, married a New York photographer today, then took the bride on his arm and plunged through a mob of weeping teen-agers who screamed: "I love you, Paul!"

The Citizens Budget Commission proposed yesterday that the city provide land for housing, parks, commercial and industrial development by filling in the sites at city-owned piers along the Hudson and East Rivers.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Cyrus R. Vance, a chief architect of the Oct. 31 understanding that ended American bombing of North Vietnam, held a series of unannounced meetings today with top Nixon Administration officials.
Four tug crewmen were plucked from the cold waters of Hell Gate yesterday after their vessel collided with a tanker and sank quickly 100 yards off the Queens shore.
ROME, March 12 -- Pope Paul VI has released an Italian priest who is a member of the "Papal family" from his vows so that he may marry.
BELGRADE, March 12 -- President Tito, remarking that "some of us are rather advanced in years," proposed a collective leadership today for the Yugoslav Communist party.

The $175-million merger of Benguet Consolidated, Inc., a Philippine mining company specializing in gold and copper, and the Grand Bahama Port Authority, Ltd., a land and resort developing company, was announced early last year and is expected to be consummated next week.
David Rockefeller said yesterday that a further increase in the prime lending rate of the commercial banks was "just a question of time," barring some easing of interest rates in the open market.

LONDON, March 12 -- A loss of 12-million ($28.8-million) was reported today by the nationalized British Steel Corporation for its first year of operations. Sales in the year ended last Sept. 30 totaled 1.07-billion ($2.57-billion).

Mayor Lindsay's committee on student disorders began organizing "task forces" for individually troubled schools in the city yesterday in an effort to root out disruptive youngsters and ward off future violence.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) -- President Nixon sent his congratulations by telegram to the Apollo 9 astronauts shortly after their splashdown today, praising them for "10 days that thrilled the world."
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) -- Representative Samuel S. Stratton, Democrat of upstate New York, accused the Army today of covering up "bumbling ineptness" in its troubled tank program.

WHEN the Hudson River Sloop Restoration, Inc., began its quest for a name for the boat being built in South Bristol, Me., for a scheduled launching on May 3, it held a contest among its members and said, a la Shakespeare: "Although a rose by any other name would smell as sweet, you didn't catch Juliet saying, 'Ah, Higginbottom, wherefore art thou, Higginbottom?' " In other words, the $180,000 sloop deserved a proper name.

THEODORE KALEM (or "One-Act" Kalem as he is affectionately known in the trade) is a man of few gestures. He has now left in the intermission of the last five Broadway comedies -- that is if you count "The Watering Place" as a comedy, Last night at the Booth Theater where Laird Koenig's "The Dozens" opened, Mr. Kalem scored his fifth.
Senator Herman E. Talmadge warned yesterday that, unless the countries of Western Europe and Japan remove restrictions hampering American exports, "we shall put up reciprocal barriers."

GREENSBORO, N. C., Friday, March 14 (UPI) -- Riot police dispersed a large group of rowdy students with tear gas last night and later reported returning the fire of "snipers" at a darkened street intersection. No injuries were reported.
New York University's team will be the defending champion in the Intercollegiate Fencing Association three-weapon championship being held today and tomorrow at N.Y.U.'s Alumni Gymnasium in the Bronx.

Dognapping -- a crime pointed up by the bizarre case of an actress who told of being abducted when she answered a call promising the return of her missing poodle -- was described yesterday as a big, sometimes violent, business in New York City.
Now hear this. After 30 years of smooth sailing with just two basic ads, Cutty Sark Scotch is changing its advertising approach but not scuttling the ship.
The Phillips Petroleum Company made a bid yesterday for the oil-rich Amerada Petroleum Corporation to the surprise of Wall Street and the consternation of the Hess Oil and Chemical Corporation.

The CNA Financial Corporation, a major insurance organization that has expanded into mutual funds and consumer finance operations, announced yesterday that it planned to acquire a leading home-building and real estate operation.

TOKYO, March 13 (Reuters) -- A plan to create one of the world's biggest steel producers met a stumbling block today, when the Japanese Fair Trade Commission turned down preliminary merger proposals from the Yawata Iron and Steel Company and the Fuji Iron and Steel Company.

PIERRE BOULEZ, no stranger to the New York concert scene, conducted the New York Philharmonic for the first time last night in Philharmonic Hall. He will be on the podium the next four weeks, concentrating on the repertory he knows best and loves best, Aside from two Haydn symphonies, his programs will be devoted entirely to music of the 20th century.
James Earl Ray's brother said yesterday he was convinced that there was a conspiracy in the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., to which Ray pleaded guilty in Memphis Monday.

HONG KONG, March 13 -Communist China charged today that the Soviet Union had made six "intrusions" into Chinese territory following the armed clash between Soviet and Chinese border guards on March 2.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) -- John H. Shaffer, President Nixon's choice to head the Federal Aviation Administration, told Congress today that he hoped Mr. Nixon would approve going ahead with the American supersonic transport plane.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -A House committee narrowly approved today an Administration proposal for "maximum feasible participation" by parents and community leaders in planning and operating federally aided programs in schools of low-income areas.

Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo is planning to announce formally his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Mayor before the end of the month, probably within a day or two of March 28, when former Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick has scheduled his announcement.
Snack Foods may be a way to ease the urban crisis.
PEKING, March 13 (Agence France-Presse) -- Wave after wave of Chinese demonstrators swept up to the Soviet Embassy today as the embassy staff began to settle down for a long siege.

PARIS, March 13 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger of West Germany and President de Gaulle started two days of talks here today in an atmosphere clouded by disagreements over monetary questions and the future of Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Most of the early discussion of the Nixon Administration's economic policy and strategy -- which, unlike most other policies, is decided and announced -- centered on whether the effort to curb inflation would raise unemployment and worsen the nation's deep social problems.

LONDON, March 13 -- A British official driven out of the tiny Caribbean island of Anguilla Tuesday by gunfire said on his return here today that the islanders were "completely dominated by a gangster-type element."

Remarks by Robert Montgomery, the actor, producer and author of a new book critical of network televison, were censored early yesterday morning during a guest appearance on the Johnny Carson "Tonight" show.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 13 (UPI) -- Bruce Crampton, an Australian who lives in Texas, had an eagle, six birdies and four bogeys in a round of 67 today and tied Lee Trevino, Tommy Aaron and Larry Hinson for a first-round lead of one stroke in the $100,000 Monsanto open golf tournament.

IN March, most of us look forward eagerly to the coming of spring, knowing that it is only a matter of time, and the occasional inconvenience of foul weather, before the snow is gone and the land is green.
LONDON, March 13 (Reuters) -- Richard Chamberlain, television's Dr. Kildare, won critics' acclaim today for his British stage debut as Hamlet.

CAIRO, March 13 -- The Egyptian Government press agency announced today that Maj. Gen. Ahmed Ismail Ali had been named to succeed Lieut. Gen. Abdel Moneim Riad, the Chief of Staff who was killed Sunday by Israeli shelling in an exchange across the Suez Canal.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 13 -- Differences between the Palestinian Arabs and Arab governments over any political settlement in the Middle East appear to be intensifying.

UMUAHIA, Biafra (Nigeria) -- If Biafra survives its war with Nigeria intact, the tall, stately wife of Biafra's rebel leader is almost sure to emerge as one of Africa's most celebrated women -- certainly on a par with the wife of President Honphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast, whom Life magazine once graced with a full-page color portrait alongside other such worldly beauties as Princess Grace of Monaco and Empress Farah of Iran.
A jury in Federal Court yesterday held a dentist and an anesthesiologist responsible for the wrongful death of a patient and awarded his widow $250,000.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The coal industry was accused at a Senate hearing today of needlessly endangering the life and health of miners.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel announced today the appointment of David D. Dominick, 32 years old, of McLean, Va., as Commissioner of the Federal Water Pollution Control Administration.

Some of the most spectacular color pictures in television's history enabled millions of viewers to witness yesterday afternoon in breathtaking detail the splashdown and recovery of the astronauts of Apollo 9.
For two commodities, yesterday proved to be one to remember. The two, potatoes and silver, swung widely in price, much to the surprise of some traders.

BERLIN, March 13 -- Western allied officials said today that the Soviet Union had accepted the allied protest over harassment of traffic to and from West Berlin, thus denying an East German statement alleging that Moscow had rejected the diplomatic move by the United States, Britain and France.

Disappointing British trade figures had little effect on the London stock market yesterday. Prices continued the downward drift begun earlier in the week.
The stock market attempted to scale a massive wall of worry yesterday but fell back in defeat.

The season's second performance of "The Ballad of Baby Doe," last night at the State Theater, introduced a new, and rather red-hot Mama to the cast of Douglas Moore's opera. Nell Evans, making her debut with the New York City Opera, made a strong impression in the part of Baby Doe' large-hearted mother.

THE V's are proliferating at Lord Taylor. They're all over shoes, scarves, pockets and belts of clothes by Valentino, and their perpetrator couldn't be more pleased.
LOS ANGELES, March 13 -- The nation's most militant conservation organization, the Sierra Club, is nearing the peak of a bitter internal struggle that could affect its future policies and influence.

Temple and St. Peter's, the "home" teams in the opening round of the 32d annual National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden, disposed of Florida and Tulsa in somewhat similar fashion last night before a crowd of 12,661.

The real estate concern of Douglas Gibbons-Hollyday Ives, Inc., has named four senior vice presidents. Three are management executives presently with the concern, and the fourth is new to the company.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

Juliet, a Florida filly, owned by Gustave Ring, had no difficulty adjusting herself to our 40-degree weather as she stepped to victory in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Nixon will support a direct popular election system for the Presidency if Congress approves one, but he will not work for it in Congress, Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 13 -- Davidson wore a path to the foul line tonight and literally free shot St. John's out of the National Collegiate basketball championship, whipping the Redmen, 79-69, in a second- round game at the University of Maryland's Cole Fieldhouse. White Trophy, which annually goes to the driver with the most victories at Roosevelt Raceway, required a second presentation tonight at the Nassau County harness racing course. CHICAGO, March 14 -- A New York alternate delegate to the Democratic National Convention testified today that she had not heard a police and National Guard order that she is charged with disobeying.

Barbara Jo Rubin demonstrated to a crowd of 25,557 curious horseplayers at Aqueduct yesterday that she certainly has a way with a horse. The 19-year-old Miami Beach girl, in her role as the first girl jockey ever to compete in a pari-mutuel betting race in this state, rode Forrest Lawson's Bravy Galaxy to a convincing triumph in a five-furlong sprint.
A mugger fatally attacked a 46-year-old Brooklyn widow on a Brownsville street early yesterday as she was returning to her home from her job as a nurse's aide at New York Hospital.

Ben Shahn, one of America's most popular painters, who made his art serve the liberal social and political causes in which he believed, died late last night at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 70 years old.
A determined effort to prevent any further attempts by American-flag passenger ship operators to abandon liner operations was announced yesterday by the National Maritime Union.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A specialist in coal miners' occupational disease said today that the Nixon Administration had proposed a health standard in new mine-safety legislation that would be half as effective in preventing lung damage as the standard recommended last year by the Johnson Administration.
MIAMI, March 14 -- Premier Fidel Castro has acknowledged that Cuba is beset by serious economic, political and social problems.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -President Nixon and Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird were photographed yesterday looking over a voluminous document officially described as the Secretary's report on his recent trip to Vietnam.
Coney Island's most famous carrousel -- the biggest and gaudiest in the world -- has found a new home in Japan, where it will play Sousa marches and Strauss waltzes at the Osaka World's Fair of 1970.

IF imaginative fiction is really in a scrape these days; if most people would rather have nonfiction, or memoirs and reportage disguised as novels; if the kids are going to poetry for feeling and to the movies for stories, where does that leave "Finnegans Wake," James Joyce's anagrammatical, doublecrossticky, superpon tifical "drema" of civilization's downfall and riseup? It is, after all, a book that cannot be read without first being read about.

MOSCOW, March 14 -- Soviet newspapers and scientists today had warm praise for the Apollo 9 flight, and indicated to the Soviet public that the United States may soon attempt to send the first men to the moon.

PEKING, March 13 (Agence France-Presse) -- Huge crowds formed tonight throughout Peking following the publication of a "new instruction" by Chairman Mao Tse-tung and of a warning by the Communist party to the nation to "hold itself ready in case of war."

President Nixon has put the best possible packaging on a bad decision. It would have taken bold executive leadership to reverse the policy on the Sentinel antiballistic missile system which Mr. Nixon inherited from the Johnson Administration; to overrule Secretary of Defense Laird and the Pentagon planners, and to confront the military-minded Congressmen on Capitol Hill who automatically equate more weapons with more security.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Nixon said at his news conference today that he did not plan to deliver his State of the Union Message to Congress this year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- Spain complained here today that Equatorial Guinea was not fulfilling an agreement for the evacuation of Spaniards from their West African colony.

The Times of March 3 carried a news article entitled "Voluntary Hospitals Crowded In The City; Priorities Are Set Up," by Michael Stern. In that article reference is made to the fact that because of the crowding in the city's voluntary hospitals -- the nonprofit, privately supported institutions -- cruel choices are forced on physicians. One internist who practices at Polyclinic Hospital is quoted as saying:
BONN, March 14 -- The Soviet Embassy assailed the West German Government today for casting what it called a "false light" on Moscow's role in the latest Berlin tension.
The nation's reaction to President Nixon's announcement that the Sentinel antiballistic missile system is to be modified ranged yesterday from disappointment to delight.
CLEVELAND, March 14 -- The Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began here this afternoon at the Sheraton-Cleveland Hotel.

Your recent editorial opposition to Senator Mark Hatfield's bill to eliminate conscription is apparently based on the same errors, in both logic and fact, as was the report of President Johnson's National Advisory Commission on Selective Service.

The acting president of Columbia University last night told 400 alumni, faculty and friends of the university that he did not anticipate a major disruption at Columbia this spring, and said that he would "not allow it to happen."

Price increases for copper and brass tubing, ethyl alcohol and high-grade synthetic rubber were announced yesterday by a variety of producers. At the same time, a chemical company announced lower prices for some items.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Nixon's decision to proceed with a modified anti-missile defense system appeared today to have strained but not broken his amicable relations with the Democratic-controlled Congress.
At a time when bigness is the vogue for new airliners, the Boeing Company says it may opt for smallness in a new bid to enter the multibillion-dollar "airbus" race.

Victor Muscat, the embattled chairman and president of Defiance Industries, has signed a 15-year employment contract with the company providing for him to receive $667,500 in compensation through 1981.
The Million Dollar Ole, a charity ball that raises money for the Waldemar Medical Research Foundation, had its pre-ball cocktail party at the New York Hilton last night.
Navy's team cleared the decks in a final bid for the intercollegiate fencing three-weapon championship by taking a slim lead against 12 challenging squads last night in the 72year-old tournament.

President Nixon has wisely availed his Administration of the unusual rapport with Latin-American Governments that Sol M. Linowitz has built up as United States Representative to the Organization of American States. By asking him to stay on until May 1, the President assures the presence in the State Department of an adviser expert in negotiating the minefields that lie just ahead in hemisphere politics. Full-scale reappointment of Mr. Linowitz would be an even sounder move.
It had all the makings of a happening, but it wasn't. It was the first meeting of a 15-week lecture and workshop series for parents on how to help their children learn.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- In the first major decision of his Administration, President Nixon asked Congress today to approve a modified Sentinel antiballistic missile system.

THE influence of the Coca-Cola bottle continues to loom large over the dining table. The image comes not from the pale green color or the ribbed female shape of the beverage bottle, but from all those bubbles locked in the glass and from the frosted look bottles have emerg ing from a bed of ice.

The New York Stock Exchange indicated yesterday that it planned to compete vigorously against outside interests that are attempting to obtain a portion of the exchange's institutional trading business.

To aid Barnard College's scholarship funds, Mrs. Eliot Janeway, who is Elizabeth Janeway, the author and a member of the class of '35, will open her home at 15 East 80th Street Tuesday afternoon for a Japanese tea ceremony.
ROME, March 14 -- A sociologist, four doctors and a junior government minister opened Rome's first birth-control clinic today, thus risking, at least in theory, a year in jail.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- As expected, President Nixon dealt with what he called his first "great," meaning difficult, decision by occupying a broad middle ground and leaving himself flexible for the future. He approved deployment of a missile defense system, but held it for the time being to minimum proportions and a modest pace.

MIAMI, March 14 -- Thurman Munson is supposed to spend the summer in Syracuse, according to the master plan. But there are days when Ralph Houk can envision Munson in the Bronx, squatting behind home plate, doing things that Yankee catchers haven't done in several years.

NEW ORLEANS, March 14 (UPI) -- Jim Garrison, the District Attorney who contended he had "solved" the assassination of President Kennedy, says he lost the Clay L. Shaw case because he was forced to present a modern "James Bond novel" type of conspiracy in a trial bound by old rules.

Tennessee proved too strong for Rutgers, and Ohio University outscrambled West Texas State in Madison Square Garden last night as the top half of the first-round draw was completed in the 16-team National Invitation basketball tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Three leading Ku Klux Klansmen from the South were sentenced today for refusing to turn over Klan records and documents in 1965 to the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 -- The New York Mets, still behaving like the furies of fate with baseball bats, riddled the St. Louis Cardinals with 22 hits and a 16-6 pounding today.

BEAUPRE, Quebec, March 14 -- Petite Michele Jacot, the shy brunette from the French Alps community of Chambery, who seems to have few inhibitions when it comes to speed, shot into contention for World Cup honors today with a sparkling victory in a onerun woman's giant slalom.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 14 -- Davidson and North Carolina will meet tomorrow in a third-round game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship. The winner will advance to the national semifinals at Louisville next Thursday.

ALBANY, March 14 -- The Lindsay administration, the New York City Board of Education and the State Board of Regents reached general agreement today on a plan for decentralization of the city's schools.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 14 -- A "pioneering program" was promised today by Rutgers University to accept all "educationally and economically disadvantaged" high school graduates who live in the cities in which the state university maintains campuses and who seek admission.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Northwest Industries, Inc., told the Interstate Commerce Commission today it would sell an Indiana trucking concern when it assumed control of the B. F. Goodrich Company.
The new-issue market retreated this week, reflecting general weakness among listed and over-the-counter shares.
The University Christian Movement, a national organization of Protestant, Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox student groups, will be disbanded on June 30.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- Anguilla invited the United Nations today to investigate charges by a British official that the tiny Caribbean island was "completely dominated by a gangster-type element."
Clothing for walking a dog in any kind of weather and on any occasion will be shown Thursday at the annual luncheon and fashion show of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 14 (AP) -- Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, leader of the leftist People's party, today rejected President Mohammad Ayub Khan's concessions to his opponents and called for Mr. Ayub to resign to make way for a caretaker government.

In 1910 Mrs. William H. Baldwin, a mild, quiet woman who was the widow of a former president of the Long Island Rail Road, invited a group of Negro and white leaders to her home to discuss what could be done to help black migrants from the South adjust to the rigors of life in New York City.
TOKYO -- Pumpless gas stations are becoming more ubiguitous than topless restaurants in Japan.

John W. Waterhouse, president of the American Safety Equipment Corporation, has also been named chief executive and operating officer of the company. He succeeds the late Kenneth Krasnow, who was chairman and chief executive.

THERE were raised eyebrows in Wall Street yesterday after the president of Amerada Petroleum reacted to a new offer for the company from Phillips Petroleum by saying the company was not in a position to consider the proposal due to a "binding agreement" with Hess Oil Chemical.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Nixon made the surprise disclosure today that his Administration's defense budget would be about $2.5-billion less than the one proposed by President Johnson.
WHITE PLAINS, March 14 -- The State Supreme Court today directed that a Westchester County Board of 17 legislators replace the 286-year-old Board of Supervisors next year.
The stock market continued to drift downward yesterday as declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outpaced advances by better than a 2to-1 ratio.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Nixon disclosed today that he had ordered a Federal examination of disorder on the nation's campuses. He promised a detailed statement about the unrest early next week.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The National Security Agency issued a written warning a month before the U.S.S. Pueblo was captured that the danger of its mission had been under-estimated and protection for the intelligence ship should be given serious consideration.

HAS there been a staged performance of the "Goyescas" by Granados in recent years? The Little Orchestra Society gave a concert version some years back, but last night's performance at the Manhattan School of Music probably was the first on any New York stage since the Metropolitan Opera gave the premiere during World War I.
LOSTMANS RIVER PATROL STATION, March 14 -- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel came out of the Everglades empty-handed today.

TWO plays by Euripides, "Iphigenia in Aulis" and "The Bacchae," although they were written nearly 2500 years ago, seem to have a particular relevance to today. "Iphigenia in Aulis," with its discussions of conscience and a dirty little war, is obvious, but also "The Bacchae," with its evocation of the Dionysiac spirit, has a strangely contemporary tone to it.
GOOD early blue-and-white delftware may still be found at lower prices than many late Victorian rarities.
TEL AVIV, March 14 (Reuters) -- Four Israeli jets today attacked Arab guerrilla bases east of the Jordan River, according to reports from Israeli farmers working on the west bank.
Volume rose a bit yesterday on the American Stock Exchange but prices did not. As a result, the market closed out the week on another declining note.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that farmers will plant 64,409,000 acres of corn this year, down 0.6 per cent from the 64,787,000 acres planted last year.
PARIS, March 14 -- Edmond Bourgeois, a Frenchman, looked enviously at the American paying his Zurich hotel bill with an American Express credit card.
A court action was started here yesterday in behalf of a score of children who have been maimed during the last 10 years by dynamite blasting-caps.

PARIS, March 14 -- There were signs here today that the United States and North Vietnam were inching toward resumption of private talks to end the war in Vietnam, and that the Saigon regime and the Vietcong might eventually join.

LOS ANGELES, March 14 -- With Lew Alcindor making his last home stand, the University of California, Los Angeles, Bruins appear anything but bearish against the Santa Clara Broncos tomorrow in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Western Regional basketball final.
In the vapid prettiness of Cilea's "Adriana Lecouvreur," the role of the Princess of Bouillon stands out like a pepper pod in a vat of blanc mange.

Shouts of "slave labor" are now echoing across the city and state from union leaders who are outraged at the passage March 7 by the State Legislature of tougher penalties against public employe unions and their members who strike.

ALTHOUGH he was never more than a fringe member, Kenzo Okada was one of the most sought after abstract painters of the New York School in its triumphant days. And from exhibition to exhibition, as the school waned and its hangers-on were weeded out, his position became more and more secure.
DETROIT, March 14 -- Capital spending this year by the automotive industry's Big Three will rise about 30 per cent from the 1968 level to an estimated $2billion.

In a spirited struggle that produced a spirited reaction and several broken window panes in the Eighth Avenue doors, Chuck Wepner was awarded a majority decision over Roberto Davila of Peru last night in the 10-round heavyweight bout at the Felt Forum.

The Dayton Corporation, an operator of specialty stores, based in Minneapolis, reported yesterday that net income for the fiscal year ended Feb. 1 increased 7.7 per cent to $15,568,659 from $14,450,469 in the previous year.

MEMPHIS, March 14 -- Although James Earl Ray's biographer, William Bradford Huie, now says that he no longer believes Ray was part of a conspiracy to murder the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., much of the information given to Mr. Huie by Ray was verified by the state of Tennessee when it investigated Dr. King's slaying.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Members of the House spent nearly $750,000 traveling around the world last year, including one Representative whose last trip before leaving office cost taxpayers $8,453.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Nixon said today that there was no prospect for reduction of American military forces in South Vietnam in the foreseeable future because of the current enemy offensive.

MESA, Ariz., March 14 -- To play baseball successfully in the big leagues you have to be mean, according to Alvin O'Neal McBean. His teacher, when he first came up to the Pittsburgh Pirates, was Don Hoak, the club's angry third baseman.

HOUSTON, March 14, -- The Apollo 9 astronauts are scheduled to undergo a medical examination tomorrow to see how they withstood their 241 hours in orbit. Doctors on the Guadalcanal reported that the men appeared to be in good health.

The Democratic minority in the Legislature has come up with a tax program better designed than Governor Rockefeller's to meet the state's needs without punishing cuts in state aid for education, welfare and Medicaid.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 14 -- Yugoslavia designated today a new federal Premier -- a Communist progressive -as the party's ninth congress approved new statutes opening the way for establishment of a powerful collective leadership body.

QUITO, Ecuador, March 14 (Reuters) -- Two American oil companies have accepted Government demands for higher royalties and the return of part of the land on which they have mineral rights rights, the government announced last night.

The Xerox Corporation will shift its headquarters from Rochester, N. Y., to Stamford, Conn., next fall. It thus becomes one of a growing number of industrial giants to place office facilities in the New York suburbs.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy said today that he was "frankly disturbed" by the inflationary implications of the prospect that business investment would rise 13.9 per cent this year.
OLYMPIA, Wash., March 14 (AP) -- Arthur A. Fletcher, special urban affairs aide to Washington's Gov. Daniel J. Evans, was named Assistant Secretary of Labor today by President Nixon.
Except for a spurt in oil shares, the London stock market continued to drift lower yesterday in light trading.

May potato futures had another big day yesterday with volume at the active pace of 5,589 contracts, compared with more than 8,000 on Thursday. Prices for the key May delivery moved up to close at 3.61 to 3.65 cents a pound, compared with 3.50 the day before.

President Richard M. Nixon's comments during his televised press conference following his European trip will do much to allay the fears of many concerned with the Administration's Mideast foreign policy. [News story March 5.]

ALBANY, March 14 -- Two bills aimed at repealing the section of the State Constitution that bans state aid to church-supported schools were introduced in the Legislature today by Earl W. Brydges, the Republican majority leader in the Senate.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 14 -- The International Committee of the Red Cross has again taken up the case of the 45,000 Vietnamese refugees in northeast Thailand, and is investigating their complaints of persecution by the Thai authorities.

The Board of Estimate and the City Council added about $20-million yesterday to Mayor Lindsay's proposed $1.1-billion capital budget for next fiscal year and approved the allocation of $30-million to the Human Resources Administration's controversial regional manpower training program.

The Department of Hospitals announced yesterday that it would reopen on Monday morning the Lincoln Hospital Mental Health Service that the department officially closed March 6 in a community-control dispute.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Garfield A. Wood Jr. of Miami was granted a patent this week for an electric bicycle drive. Stelber Industries, Inc., of Elmhurst, Queens, plans to begin producing two and three-wheelers powered with the equipment by next fall.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Former Secretary of Commerce C. R. Smith said today that Senator Thomas J. McIntyre, Democrat of New Hampshire, had tried to damage Mr. Smith's reputation in a dispute over an application for a foreign-trade zone on the Maine coast.
PEKING, March 14 -- In Peking, as in any other city, a foreigner is confronted by a succession of small surprises as he strolls through a variety of shops.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Federal Communications Commission agreed today to renew the licenses for two West Coast radio stations owned by R.K.O.-General, Inc., conditional to the outcome of an antitrust suit against the company.

MOSCOW, March 14 (AP) -- Mamie Rallins of Chicago tied the world record for the women's indoor 50-meter hurdles and a sprinter, Charlie Greene of Lincoln, Neb., matched the season's best mark in the men's 50-meter dash today as the United States and the Soviet Union dominated the opening day of a track and field meet. Soviet athletes took four first places and the Americans three.
A simplified procedure for removing abandoned cars from city streets was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

MOSCOW, March 14 -- Sources close to the Soviet Foreign Trade Ministry said today that Communist China had halted all Soviet shipments to North Vietnam at the frontier, apparently in reprisal for the border clash of March 2.

Amid charges "deception" and "political procrastination," the City Council last night set up an 11-member committee to inquire into excessive rent increases reported by tenants not protected by rent controls.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel emphasized today the "complexity and peril" of big-power guarantees for a Middle East settlement.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- A maritime union spokesman proposed today that Congress tax the earnings of ships owned by United States interests but registered under foreign flags.
NEW HAVEN, March 14 -Yale swimmers, as expected, won four of the six finals tonight in the 29th annual Eastern Seaboard collegiate championships in their home pool.
