A $20-million refund to private hospitals, offered by five major drug manufacturers to offset alleged overcharges for broad-spectrum antibiotics, or wonder drugs, was rejected yesterday in Federal Court here by lawyers who said they represented most of the nation's private hospitals.

The Diversified Metals Corporation and the Proler Steel Corporation announced yesterday that they had reached a formal agreement under which Diversified would acquire Proler through an exchange of stock valued at about $35-million.

LOS ANGELES, March 14 -Officials of the three major television networks took their turn today answering questions on their minority hiring policies.

The French general strike has come and again without an upset of the franc, providing a respite for an orderly overhaul of the world's creaky monetary machinery.
The city and the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association reached agreement yesterday on contract adjustments reflecting changes already accepted by policemen and firefighters.
A modernization of the traffic and pedestrian signals along upper Park Avenue is expected to be substantially completed by summer, the Traffic Department reported yesterday.

The Municipal Concerts Orchestra gave a benefit concert for itself in Town Hall last night. The organization was justified in this because it gives free concerts around the city. Last year it played 19 in the parks and 14 in day centers for older adults.

Neither heroes nor villains emerge as the Navy concludes its court of inquiry into the seizure of the Pueblo and the conduct of its captain and crew. Reliving the incident for eight weeks of testimony was an excruciating experience for both the men and the nation. Yet even now the public does not -- and cannot -- know all the facts because the Pueblo was a spy ship and certain intelligence information was deleted.

Margaret Mead, the anthropologist who won fame describing primitive peoples to the more culturally evolved, sought to explain the young and old to each other in a lecture at the American Museum of Natural History here last week.

LETICIA, Colombia -- To its tradition as a remote military outpost near the borders of Peru and Brazil in the extreme southeast part of Colombia, this little town on the north bank of the Amazon is beginning to add a reputation as a center for jungle adventure, rain - forest exploration, studying the Ticuna Indians and for hospitality.

THE late William C. Handy would have appreciated the postage stamp that will memorialize him. It will be issued May 17 at Memphis, Tenn., to commemorate that city's sesquicentennial.

WEST POINT, March 15 -- Penn State, which had won the team title and the individual all-round titles last night, took three of the six individual crowns in the finals today of the Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastics League tournament.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 16 -- The Indonesian Government has called a temporary halt to an unusual experiment in food production, since for the moment at least there is no market for the product.

ATLANTA -- When Lester G. Maddox ran for Governor three years ago, the rightwing, Bible-quoting, pistol-waving segregationist told everybody he was against big government, big spending, welfare and Federal control.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- "I strongly support legislation to cut off aid from students who disrupt educational institutions,'' a Cornell University professor wrote one of his Senators. "When are you going to act courageously on this crucial issue?"
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Skirts had their ups and downs last week at the White House.
Campus campaigns to reject disruptive demonstrations have been started by students at Columbia University and at the State University at Stony Brook, L. I.

NEW ORLEANS, March 16 -- A full page advertisement will appear in The New Orleans States Item tomorrow and in The Times-Picayume on Tuesday praising District Attorney Jim Garrison for his investigation of the slaying of President Kennedy.
New evidence of the clear visibility that exists in space -- and of the marvelous acuity of the human eye -- was gathered by the Apollo 9 astronauts on their 10-day orbital flight.

FORT LAUDERDALE, March 16 -- The first meeting of the spring against the world champion Detroit Tigers became a success for the Yankees today when they erupted for five runs in the sixth inning for a 5-3 victory.

MOSCOW, March 16 -- The Soviet Union charged today that Communist China used forces on the scale of an infantry regiment in yesterday's border clash over a disputed island on the frozen Ussuri River. For the first time, the Russians accused the Chinese of an invasion aimed at seizure of Soviet territory.
CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., March 16 (AP) -- Barbara Jo Rubin finished third in the ninth race at Charles Town last night, but two fans greeted her performance as if she had just booted home a 50-1 shot.
ATHENS, March 16 -- No longer will the name of Aristotle Socrates Onassis be linked exclusively to ships, airlines and society gossip.

NEW DELHI, March 16 -- The leader of a Naga underground force that went to Communist China for training in guerrilla warfare techniques was captured early today in Nagaland and flown to New Delhi, the Defense Ministry announced.

CORONADO, Calif., March 15 -- Last Thursday morning, Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher made a final speech in a shaky voice before a Navy court of inquiry here. By 11 A.M. Vice Adm. Harold G. Bowen Jr., the president of the court, closed the folder before him, stared for a moment at the Pueblo's skipper and said: "This court is closed."
The Poison Control Center of the City Health Department will move tomorrow from 125 Worth Street to 455 First Avenue, at 26th Street. The telephone number will be 340-4495.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 16 -- A new group called the Coalition of Democratic and Independent voters of Pennsylvania was organized here today by Democrats who opposed the nomination of Hubert H. Humphrey last year.
Mayor Lindsay informed his closest political associates yesterday that he would announce his candidacy for re-election this week, probably tomorrow.

ATLANTA, March 16 -- Bishop James K. Mathews of the Boston Area of the Methodist Church said here today that at "concrete and specific plan" to unite nine Protestant denominations would be completed by March of next year.
BEAUPRE, Quebec, March 16 -- Three Austrians figured prominently in today's developments as the three-day du Maurier World Cup competition came to an action packed close.

CAIRO, March 16 -- King Hussein of Jordan flew here today, amid quickening military and diplomatic activity in the Arab-Israeli dispute, for two days of consultations with President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

Some day in Morristown, N. J., where Gen. George Washington made his headquarters in the Ford Mansion and wrote a lot of American history fighting the British, a plaque may be placed on a wall of the local library, reading: "Sherman Edwards Worked Here."
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A close relationship has been found between the Hong Kong flu virus and influenza that naturally infects horses.

Giffen Industries, Inc., a distributor of carpets and other home furnishings products, announced yesterday that it had acquired a 49 per cent interest in Keller Industries, Inc., a producer of building products, for $49.8-million.
Those of us who are Irish only once a year, and the rest of us who are Irish every last day, marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 17 -- Rutgers University expects to admit "only several hundred" students in September under its new program to allow all "educationally and economically disadvantaged" high school graduates from Newark, New Brunswick and Camden to attend the state university.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 17 -- The State of Kentucky began today a closed, quasi-judicial trial of one of its most widely known civil rights and criminal lawyers. He is accused of showing contempt for a pistol packing judge from Louisville.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) -- The accuracy of recent tests indicating an increase in nicotine and tar content of cigarettes was defended today by the Federal Trade Commission.
DETROIT, March 17 -- Automobile manufacturers are scheduling second-quarter car production 7 per cent below year-before levels.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 17 -- New Brunswick High School reopened this morning after the police broke up a threatened confrontation between several hundred black and white students outside the school.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Courtroom decorum was shattered today when a city prosecutor clashed verbally with a Bronx lawyer who is charged with disorderly conduct during last summer's Democratic National Convention here.
" Zorba" and "Promises, Promises," with eight nominations, headed the list of candidates announced yesterday for Broadway's Tony awards.
BOSTON, March 8 -- During the last five years, under the provisions of two new laws. Massachusetts started a program to preserve its coastal wetlands.
The stock market, confronted at its opening bell with an increase the prime lending rate to a new high of 7 1/2 per cent, moved hesitantly lower yesterday morning and then rose during the afternoon.

Representative James H. Scheuer, a candidate for the Democratic mayoral nomination, formally asked the Liberal party to make him their candidate or, failing that, to authorize him to run in their primary.
MONTPELIER, Vt., March 17 (UPI) -- Vermont filed antitrust suits today against nine major United States plumbing fixture companies, alleging price-fixing, from 1962 to 1966.

TRENTON, March 17 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court said today that lawyers appointed to defend juvenile delinquents should be paid, but it ordered that they continue to work without pay until the Public Defender's office could take over the burden.

Nineteen persons were arrested in the East Village yesterday in the wake of the slaying of a youth who was trussed up and set afire. The apartment in which he was killed had been used as a "crash pad" by a motorcycle gang and was the target of a firebombing Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The French Government, in a shift of position, has informed Israel and the United States that it no longer advocates that Israel withdraw completely from occupied Arab territories as part of a Middle East settlement.
One day this spring the pilots of two "airlines" will take aim at each other on a "collision course" in the skies off the New Jersey coast.

MIAMI, March 17 -- In a duel of giant 73-foot yachts that ended almost as soon as it began, Windward Passage demonstrated her amazing sail power to Kialoa II 15 minutes after the start today of the 811-mile race from Miami to oMntego Bay.
The Government's drive against inflation pushed the cost of money to a new high yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff have abandoned their previous stand in favor of a heavy missile defense for the country against an all-out Soviet attacks, according to Pentagon sources.

A grandnephew of an army major who had served under Col. George Custer lost a $25-million damage suit yesterday in which he contended that a recent movie had misrepresented the role of the major at the time of the Battle of the Little Bighorn 93 years ago.

ALBANY, March 17 (AP) -- Representatives of insurance companies told a legislative hearing today that the Rockefeller Administration seeks to go too far in its attempt to keep holding companies from acquiring banks and insurance companies in New York State.
WASHINGTON -- When, people asked Golda Meir if she felt handicapped at being a woman minister, her answer was, "I don't know -- I've never tried to be a man."

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 17 (Reuters) -- David Carlson, a 26-year-old Peace Corps worker, failed a medical test for induction into the armed forces today -- and that should please the 7,500 residents of the Pacific island of Saipan.

FORT POLK, La., March 17 (UPI) -- More than 20,000 Army infantry recruits are not being permitted to visit their families and their physical activity has been "decreased to the minimum" because of 21 reported cases of meningitis and one death during the last five months, officials said today.

The Blue Nile Group, an orchestra-dance company from Ethiopia, offered an attractive concert at Town Hall last night. It was introduced by the group's versatile business manager, a lanky mustached Peace Corps volunteer named Charles Sutton, who plays a one-stringed instrument named the masenko.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Treasury bill rates moved m opposite directions at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
Thanks to an observant editor, the stationery of the United States Ambassador to South Vietnam no longer carries the watermark "Conqueror.''

LOS ANGELES, March 17 -- The prosecution in the murder trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan began an attempt today to discredit the testimony of a defense psychologist because his report on the menial state of the defendant contained material similar to that in a book published last year.

It also precisely describes Russell McGrath's adaptation of the novel, now at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater and that I saw at one of the critics' previews on Saturday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) -- President Nixon wore a sprig of artificial sharmock and played host to Ireland's Ambassador today in observance of St. Patrick's Day.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Dr. Donald E. Gatch, once a lone crusader against hunger and intestinal parasites among the poor of coastal South Carolina, has entered a Government hospital here for treatment of what he termed "a combination of malnutrition and parasites."

The New York Irish and their friends, who usually march on St. Patrick's Day in snow, rain, cold, wind or wet, were smiled upon by a bright sun yesterday.

CLEVELAND, March 17 -- A lieutenant in the Cleveland police department remains in county jail for contempt of court after he refused to divulge where he had obtained a copy of a civil service police promotional examination.

PARIS, March 17 -- Though France has long opposed the idea, monetary officials in Paris expect the French Government to join other nations in using a new form of international liquidity, nicknamed "paper gold."

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Secretary of the Interior, Walter J. Hickel, is pushing the Budget Bureau to approve a request for more money to keep the national parks and other preserves on a seven-day-a-week operating schedule.

There must be something about Spain that produces so many pure voices with aristocratic styles. The latest example of this kind of Spanish singer made her New York debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 17 -- "When you see that fresh little kid," said Casey Stengel last night, "tell him I wanna wish him the best of luck."

GENEVA, March 17 -- A high Swiss official apologized in Berne today to members of the executive committee of the Universal Postal Union who were marooned for 12 hours Saturday on a cable car in the Bernese Oberland.
NEWARK, March 17 -- A nightmare that haunts many urban dwellers across the country appears today to be turning into a reality in this city of 402,000 people.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The first significant rumblings of discontent with the Administration's Vietnam policy were heard in the Senate today as Senator George S. Mc-Govern criticized President Nixon for continuing the "tragic course" of the Johnson Administration.

Georg Solti, who becomes musical director of the Chicago Symphony next September, will take the orchestra on its first European tour in August and September, 1971. Mr. Solti also plans a Far Eastern tour with the orchestra in April and May, 1972, he said yesterday at a news conference in Chicago.

Your March 11 editorial "Tongue-Tied Justice" objected to the recent abbreviated trial of James Earl Ray on the ground that its abrupt termination failed to develop whether Ray was part of a conspiracy to kill Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. You suggest that a full-fledged trial should have been held in order to answer this question.

Governor Rockefeller, Senator Jacob K. Javits and Senator Charles E. Goodell are scheduled to join Mayor Lindsay this morning at a news conference at which the Mayor is to announce that he is a candidate for re-election.

August Heckscher, Parks Commissioner and Administrator of Cultural Affairs, yesterday warned representatives of 15 cultural institutions that get aid from the city to prepare for cuts of "from 24 to 32 per cent." He said they were reflections of cuts in the state budget.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., March 17 (AP) -- A threatened strike at the General Electric Company plant here was amerted today when union and management came to terms on how and when closed-circuit television cameras could be used to photograph employes at work.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 17 -- The Al Downing holdout apparently ended today, but with a different ending than most holdouts.

LOS ANGELES', March 17 -- The California State Senate approved four bills today that would impose stiff penalties on students and faculty members involved in campus disorders.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -A new Committee to Investigate Assassinations charged today that the Justice Department had ignored evidence that a mysterious figure called "Raoul" might have engineered the killing of Dr. King.

CLEVELAND, March 17 -Alvin Roth, Paul Trent and Jim Cayne of New York, with Chuck Burger of Detroit, won the men's team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here last night, overtaking the Dallas Aces, who were the defending champions, in the final session.

SANA, Yemen, March 17 -- Yemen began her first experience with parliamentary democracy this morning when the National Assembly held its first meeting here after nearly 1,000 years of theocratic rulers, colonial administration or military government.

BUDAPEST, March 18 -- For the first time since the Moscow-led invasion of Czechoslovakia in August, the top leaders of all the seven member countries of the Warsaw Pact met today in Budapest. The meeting, postponed for five hours, lasted two and a half hours.
Radio astronomers, gazing deep into the heavens, may for the first time be witnessing the stormy birth of one or more planets like the earth.

MRS. MARION H. PARKER, a former executive director of the Association of Operating Room Nurses and a naturally gregarious woman, was recently confined to her bed with Hong Kong flu.

MARACAIBO, Venezuela, March 17 (AP) -- Searchers probed through charred ruins of homes today for more victims of the crash yesterday of a Venezuelan jetliner. Five of the victims died of injuries today, raising the known death toll so far to 155.

THE central fact in this collection of historical and political essays and, it would appear, in the life of the author is the Vietnam war. WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) -- Vice President Agnew announced today that Navy Capt. James A. Lovell, the astronaut, would head a $4.5-million day camp sports program for 75,000 ghetto youths this summer.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Soviet Union has proposed broadening official contacts with the United States by establishment of an American consulate in Leningrad and a Soviet consulate in San Francisco, diplomatic sources said today.

Yesterday's rise to 7 1/2 per cent in the prime lending rate of commercial banks will mean higher costs for loans to buy stocks and bonds on credit, brokers said yesterday.

LIMA, Peru, March 17 -- John N. Irwin 2d, a special envoy of President Nixon, met for one hour today with President Juan Velasco Alvarado in an attempt to resolve the crisis between the two nations.
PARIS, March 17 -- Cuba announced today that she had become the first country to establish formal diplomatic relations with the Vietcong.

JOHN DENIS JOSEPH MOORE, a genial six-footer who has visited Ireland for business or pleasure 40 times, recently confided to a friend the regret that he could not spend even more time in the homeland of his ancestors. Now he can. President Nixon observed St. Patrick's Day yesterday by naming Mr. Moore Ambassador to Ireland, and associates of the 58year-old business executive were delighted.

LAKE CARMEL, N. Y., March 17 -- A New York State trooper was arrested today and charged with the murder of an 18-year-old youth whose body was found in the trooper's home here.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 17 -- A militant Buddhist leader who was sentenced to 10 years at hard labor Saturday was found guilty today of two additional charges.
HOUSTON, March 17 (AP) -- White and Negro students clashed briefly on the University of Houston campus today, smashing windows and dishes and overturning tables and chairs.

Hundreds of men's sportswear buyers saw a musical fashion show yesterday at which the style trends for fall 1969 were outlined.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 17 (UPI) -- Plodding relentlessly, but cautiously from start to finish, Freddie Little of Las Vegas tonight won the vacated world junior middleweight championship by scoring a unanimous 15-round decision over Stanley ("Kitten") Hayward of Philadelphia at the Las Vegas Convention Center.
South Africa will continue to stockpile gold and keep the bulk of its massive production off the free market, an embassy official said yesterday.
Steel production climbed 1.8 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
ATLANTA, March 17 -- The first outline of a plan to unite nine Protestant denominations in one church with some 25 million members was made public here today.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Grim predictions of a quarter million more highway deaths by 1972 illustrate the need for further auto safety developments, Congress was told today.

ALBANY, March 17 -- A charge that an agreement between the State Power Authority and a private utility contained more than $4.5-million in "unnecessary hidden costs" was described by the authority chairman today as "a thinly veiled political effort" that was "laced with distortions" and "inaccuracies."

Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., one of New York's largest retail chains, is expected to announce today that it will open a major department store on Manhattan's West Side in the nineties. It would be the first important retail outlet in the area.

LONDON -- "Pianos have become abominably dull," Stanley Murdoch of Harrods said. His opinion counts, too, because for 19 years Mr. Murdoch has been the man who buys and sells pianos on the second floor of the store. There seems to be almost an acre of them.

LAKE KIAMESHA, N. Y. March 17 -- For the first time the heads of American Conservative and Reform rabbinic bodies shared the same platform today as the president of the powerful Rabbinical Assembly, the Conservative group, recommended that Jews throughout the world accept the Jewish religious calendar as it is observed in Israel.

The third performance of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of "Il Trovatore" had two new singers. One of them, Renato Bruson, made a last-minute appearance, replacing an indisposed Sherrill Milnes. The other was Martina Arroyo as Leonora.

MIAMI, March 17 -- Mrs. Holcomb said today that her husband, who is 40 years old, had been visiting Anguilla frequently over the last few months. He left for the island a week ago, she added in an interview in The Miami News.

HAVANA, March 17 (Reuters) -- Two hijacked airliners -- one from Peru, the other from the United States -- sat side by side on the runway at Havana Airport tonight while their hijackers exchanged experiences over drinks.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 17 -- The Atlanta Braves traded Joe Torre to the St. Louis Cardinals tonight for Orlando Cepeda.

It's too appealing even though such gifted writers as Bruce Catton show us, along with the fire and the glory, that it really wasn't quite as popular at the time as it has since been made to seem by the elegists.

Both the United States and the Soviet Union contributed positive notes to yesterday's resumption of the United Nations disarmament deliberations in Geneva. Now the superpowers must provide action to match their rhetoric by getting down to serious talks on the matters that really count in the arms race.
CAIRO, March 18 (AP) -- The United Arab Republic has agreed to buy two additional Boeing airliners in the United States, reliable sources said today.

A study of public utilities, scheduled for Sunday night on the Public Broadcast Laboratory of National Educational Television, has prompted expression of concern from the nation's power companies and some of the educational network's affiliates.

ATHENS, March, 18 -- Ron Hubbard, the American founder of the Church of Scientology, and about 200 of his disciples have been branded "undesirables" by the Greek Government and ordered to leave the country, it was announced today.
The Marine Midland Banks, reacting to the recent pronounced climb in interest rates, decided yesterday to postpone the sale of $60-million of debentures scheduled tomorrow.
Goodbody Co., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, reported yesterday that its income from operations in 1968 rose 31 per cent while profits declined 18 per cent.
ST. JOHN, Antigua, March 18 -- The British frigates Minerva and Rothesay sailed for the island of Anguilla tonight with 315 paratroops aboard.
" Who needs another award?" asked Robert Grayson of Daniel Charles over his scrambled eggs. It was his way of introducing another award.

John A. Masiello Sr., described as a Mafia loan shark and a major racketeer in the metropolitan area, was indicted yesterday with four Post Office officials on charges of bribery, conspiracy and violation of the Federal anti-racketeering laws in connection with a mail-truck contract.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., March 19 -- Prof. Eli Ginzberg of Columbia University cautioned 500 rabbis late last night that the American Negro's quest for power, as he seeks full equality, must not be interpreted "always as a racial issue."
ROME, March 19 -- Pope Paul VI announced today that he would visit Uganda in July. This will be the seventh foreign visit of his six-year reign and the first by any reigning pontiff to Africa.

The Police Department's Third Division made 367 arrests in the Times Square area from March 10 to last Sunday and obtained 194 convictions, the commanding officer, Inspector Edmund A. Donnelly, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The National Association of Broadcasters asked Congress today to give the established owners of television and radio stations greater protection from competing license applicants.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 19 -- The idea of equalizing welfare payments, basing them on the cost of living in a particular area of the nation, appeals to a substantial majority of Americans, according to the Gallup Poll.

Fordham University, which has experienced only a few minor incidents of student disruption, will permit Paramount Pictures to stage a mock demonstration on its campus for the forthcoming film "On a Clear Day You Can See Forever."

THE commissioner, J. Walter Kennedy, was vamping till ready. "When I was 10 years old," he said, "I loved to watch Marshal Montgomery. He was on the old Keith circuit. He could smoke a cigarette and talk while he was drinking a glass of water."

WHAT does a lady wear over her evening pants? A long Givenchy toga that fastens on one shoulder and curves upward at the hem to show the legs. Or a two-tiered black silk organdy cape by Valentino as wide as a pup tent.
LONDON, March 19 -- The British Government defended the landing of troops and policemen on Anguilla today as necessary to the stability of the Caribbean and to prevent rule by an armed minority.

Native Tree's victory in the $27,500 Correction Handicap and Barbara Jo Rubin's acceptance that "You can't win them all" were the main offerings at Aqueduct yesterday. To the 28,416 fans, the developments were disappointing, inasmuch as both resulted in the failure of favorites.

LOS ANGELES, March 19 -- Another psychologist, the second to be called by the defense in the trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan, said today that the defendant did not have the "mental capacity" to premeditate the murder of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.
The toll of trees killed or maimed in the city by the Feb. 9 snowstorm has risen into the thousands, and it will be months before the task of removing and salvaging them is completed.

A phased withdrawal of U.S. troops from Vietnam, the long-range plan being advocated by both the Pentagon and the Saigon regime, avoids the crucial issue: how to reach a political settlement, which is the only means by which the United States will be able to extricate itself from Vietnam.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- In one of a multitude of trials growing out of protests at the 1968 Democratic National Convention. Prof. Staughton Lynd and nine other demonstrators were convicted today of interfering with a policeman.

To enemies of the antipoverty program, the report by the General Accounting Office is a wet firecracker. There are no sensational revelations of fraud, corruption, gross misuse of funds or scandalous waste. Instead G.A.O. has produced a careful assessment of the program's strengths and weaknesses. On balance, the report finds more to praise than to censure.
Stephen Baker, executive vice president of Griswold-Eshleman, has quit the agency and is going to start one of his own. It won't be the first time.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 19 -- Bob Johnson's 73-foot ketch Windward Passage had a 20-mile lead today on her nearest pursuer in the 811-mile Miami-Montego Bay yacht race.
A Consolidated Edison Company $80-million bond issue, offered to investors at a record 7.90 per cent yield, was sold quickly yesterday, and sparked a recovery in the credit markets.
ATLANTA, March 19 (AP) -- Donn Clendenon, whose recent retirement from baseball created a controversy, said today that he did not plan to return to the game.
An early rally on the London stock market ran out of steam yesterday and prices remained close to levels reached in Monday's sharp slide.

The supporters of school decentralization have entered the battle of Albany with an unfortunate, self-imposed handicap. They have chosen to obscure their agreement on most major issues by rowing publicly over the future of the city's Board of Education.
SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Calif., March 19 (AP) -- The swallows came back today -- the very day they were due -- to Capistrano.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Nixon Administration has about decided that it cannot possibly prepare a full tax reform program in time for Congressional consideration this year.

The Baltimore Bullets, the National Basketball Association Eastern Division leaders and seemingly the team that the third-place New York Knickerbockers will be matched with in the opening round of the playoffs next week, played championship basketball last night at Madison Square Garden before the ninth capacity crowd of the professional season -- for one half.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A combination of a Republican President and the House Democratic leadership defused the usual controversy over the debt limit today.
Alas, the Metropolitan Opera's 10th performance this season of its surpassing new "Der Rosenkavalier" last night was its last until next season.

A twin-engine transport plane that crashed into a 3,500-foot mountain near San Juan, P. R., March 5 had been cleared by ground controllers to fly the course down to an altitude of 3,000 feet, the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- President Nixon spent 20 minutes today with former President Dwight D. Eisenhower. They discussed Mr. Nixon's antiballistic missile proposal and his recent European tour.
Columbia University's Jewish and Protestant chaplains have been notified that their appointments will not be renewed when they expire this summer.
ALBANY, March 19 -- Republican Assemblymen today pushed through, over sharp Democratic objections, their plan for local government reapportionment.

A project 10 years in the discussion stage cleared a major hurdle yesterday when the City Planning Commission approved the early development of 130 acres of the projected 500-acre College Point industrial park in Queens.

LONDON, March 19 -- Strikers at the big British subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company voted overwhelmingly today to return to work tomorrow, ending an acrimonious dispute that involved politics as well as industry.

The Federal Reserve Board staff is working actively on a proposal that would effectively eliminate the practice of selling loan participations under repurchase agreements as a device for raising funds in the present tight money market, a board spokesman said yesterday.
A rifle bullet fired out of an apartment house window and apparently aimed at a street light below killed an elderly man on a Bronx sidewalk early

THERE was booing in Philharmonic Hall last night, and from the sedate Boston Symphony audience yet. The occasion was the conclusion of Edgard Varese's "Deserts." During the performance there was considerable laughter and talking.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 19 -- Lew Alcindor returned to the scene of his first National Collegiate basketball championship effort today with a revised cast of supporting players. And most likely they will nail down a record third straight title here and make the University of California, Los Angeles, the first to win the championship five times.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- The British representative walked out today when the issue of troop landings on the island of Anguilla was raised "as a matter of urgency" in the 24-member Committee on Colonialism.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (Reuters) -- The latest seizures of American tuna boats off the Peruvian coast today provoked demands in Congress for the immediate recall of the United States destroyed Isherwood, which has been on loan to Peru.

Last night at the McMillin Theater of Columbia University, a member of the audience sported a button, "Ives Lives." This reference to the great innovator in American music, Charles Ives, might just as well have read "Cowell Lives."

Helen McGehee seemed more concerned with narrative than character in her newest dance work, "Ceremonies of Remembrance," given its premiere last night at Kaufmann Concert Hall of the Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association. As a result, Miss McGehee's frequently inventive retelling of the Antigone story lacked the thrust and power of her oldler piece, "The Only Jealousy of Emer," dealing with Yeats's view of the Irish hero Cuchulaian.

ALBANY, March 19 -- Republican legislators from Nassau County have temporarily stymied efforts of the Republican legislative leaders for swift passage of the $6-billion state budget by announcing they will not vote for it if it contains cuts in aid to local school districts.

THE HAGUE, March 19 (Reuters) -- Fifty-four persons were rescued after two ships collided and another reported her engine room ablaze in the North Sea today. One of the vessels that collided was later reported sunk.
Is the Long Island Rail Road fair to men?

SYDNEY, Australia, March 19 -- Johannes Bjelke - Petersen, Premier of Queensland, announced today an expansion of Queensland Alumina, Ltd., at Gladstone, Queensland, that will make it the world's biggest alumina refinery.
The Occidental Petroleum Corporation plans to expand its coal-mining operations through the acquisition of the Maust Coal and Coke Company for about $30-million.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Several months ago someone sent over this splendid computer. At first it was quite pleasant. The computer wrote the columns, answered the telephone, threw away the junk mail and brewed tea every afternoon at 5 o'clock.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 19 -- Allied forces, seeking to clear the French-owned Michelin rubber plantation of enemy troops, reported having killed 114 of the enemy today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Nixon ordered today an increase in the sale of timber on publicly owned lands and restrictions on Government purchases of lumber in an effort to stem skyrocketing increases in lumber prices.

Nine years ago the wrecker's ball was swinging toward the hallowed walls of Carnegie Hall, and only the quixotic determination of Isaac Stern and a few friends of the old auditorium deflected its arc. Today, Carnegie Hall is not only safe, but sound financially, while Lincoln Center, its wealthy brother and sometime rival, as well as some concert managers and cultural centers in other cities, are running up distress signals.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The morning after Richard M. Nixon's election as President, Otto Fred Otepka was exuberant. When he strode into the State Department cafeteria, a friend flashed him the "V for victory" sign, and there was much merriment.

IN the introduction to this gathering of short reviews, Anthony Burgess offers an apologetic disclaimer: they were written on order -- for money -- and to a deadline. They are, he concedes, part of the small dividends of literary life. All this suggests something out of the bargain basement. But no apology is necessary.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 -- New and tougher disciplinary measures for use against students violating University of California policies have been imposed by Charles J. Hitch, its president.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 17 -- Sugar, once the mainstay of the Puerto Rican economy, has entered a critical period and those who produce and process it are trying to save it from what they fear might be oblivion.
Martin S. Ackerman, who recently oversaw the end of the 148-year publishing life of The Saturday Evening Post, now says he is about to end his own brief career as a corporate executive.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Nixon has elaborated a sort of chicken-or-egg argument that, for a number of months past, American forces have not been conducting an offensive in Vietnam -- just spoiling operations to blunt a Communist offensive they knew was coming. The Communist offensive came anyway, and now the allies have mounted a counter-offensive. This is the same old game of lethal leap-frog.

To the casual observer, the Lower East Side block where a youth was tortured and burned to death this week is a grimy string of dingy tenements, murky storefronts and nondescript industrial establishments.
PARIS, March 19 -- The chief United States negotiator at the Paris peace talks, Henry Cabot Lodge, may fly to Washington later this week to join consultations on Vietnam, it was learned today.

Trading volume declined but stocks moved up yesterday for the second straight day on the American Stock Exchange.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 19 -- Arnold Palmer is back on the golf tour.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Betty Furness testified today that business had made "some slight movement" toward voluntarily protecting consumers, but she said a strong, centralized Federal office was needed nevertheless.
A warning that the nation's cities face disaster unless the Federal Government comes to their financial assistance was voiced last night by John W. Gardiner, chairman of the Urban Coalition.

SEOUL, South Korea, March 18 -- The joint military exercise that United States and South Korean forces are conducting this week has brought into sharper focus the uneasiness in Seoul over the reliability of its American ally.

Striking ground service employes of American Airlines voted overwhelmingly yesterday to accept settlement terms that will provide hourly wage increases of 25.5 per cent or $1.05 an hour for the key group of line mechanics.

SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, March 20 -- After an acrimonious debate, the Australian Parliament dismissed a move today to investigate allegations that were said to have concerned the personal life of Prime Minister John E. Gorton.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 19 -- The nation's textile industry will back the Nixon Administration fully in an effort to work out additional voluntary agreements for restricting textile imports, officers of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute said here today.

The British lion has subdued the Anguillan mouse that roared, without spilling any blood. That is one of the few credit marks earned by any of the parties involved in this strange Caribbean drama. An estimated $65-million has been lost by all United States and foreign-flag steamship lines operating regularly scheduled general cargo services out of American Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports as a result of the protracted longshore strike.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported a rise in earnings for its final fiscal quarter, ended Feb. 28. Per-share earnings of the Bell System declined slightly in the year ended on that date.
City and state officials called yesterday for new and intensified efforts by government and communities to educate youths to the dangers of drug abuse.
Asked about President Nixon's decision to nominate Otto F. Otepka to the Subversive Activities Control Board, the White House press secretary said, "I think the appointment speaks for itself."
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A Congressional committee investigating campus unrest received evidence today that a very small number of students receiving Federal aid were involved in disruptive protests.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges issued yesterday the following list of changes in stock ownership by corporate directors, officers and major shareholders in listed companies:

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 19 -- The New York Rangers closed out their National Hockey League campaign against the West Division tonight by beating the North Stars, 4-2, before a standing-room-only crowd of 14,869 fans in the Metropolitan Sports Center.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 19 -- On a recent drive down the Florida Turnpike, Yankee General Manager Lee MacPhail and his long-time friend, Joe Iglehart, found themselves counting home runs that had not yet been hit.

THREE large white dogs on the spaniel benches at Westminster attracted the attention of the fancier and the casual spectator in the dog show world. They were clumber spaniels, a breed so rare that only 10 were registered with the American Kennel Club last year.

The fact that 13,000 students of the City University were concerned enough about projected state budget cuts to make a protest pilgrimage to Albany should give the lawmakers real concern about the effects on the institution of the scaled-down appropriations recommended by Governor Rockefeller.
World sugar futures rose again yesterday, setting another string of life-of-contract highs. On the tone of the market, the spot quotation was raised from 3.75 cents a pound to 3.80.
MEMPHIS, March 19 -- James Earl Ray has written Judge W. Preston Battle Jr., saying he plans to seek a review of his plea of guilty to the slaying of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

DETROIT, March 19 -- The General Motors Corporation said today it was putting a No. 1 priority on the repair of potential safety defects on school buses. Letters to the school bus owners are being prepared and will be mailed within a day, asking the owners to take the buses to dealers for repairs.

The Board of Education voted last night to call the controversial chairman of the Intermediate School 201 governing board before it on March 26 to show cause why disciplinary action should not be taken against him for allegedly harassing union teachers.
WASHINGTON, March. 19 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that he was accelerating the program to prepare South Vietnamese troops to replace some American soldiers.

Stockholders of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company approved yesterday the formation of a one-bank holding company, to be called J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., that would allow the bank to expand its operations into related financial fields.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 19 -- Shaken by recurring racial strife among high school students here that has all but paralyzed the educational process, the adult community, the city administration and the educators worked late into last night and throughout today groping for a formula to restore peace.
FRANKFURT, West Germany, March 19 -- Should the West German economic authorities face a choice between inflation and revaluation, it is almost certain they would choose revaluing the mark upward.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark charged yesterday that nearly 700 students, most of them Negroes and Puerto Rican had been recently dropped from the rolls of Franklin K. Lane High School in "flagrant and knowing" violation of their legal and human rights.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 19 -- New Orleans will be the site of next year's Super Bowl game to determine the championship of professional football. The Louisiana city was awarded the rich contest today when the owners of the National and American League teams paused long enough in their unresolved debate over realignment to take up the subject.

" IN New York," Pablo Zappi-Manzoni said recently, "they use an abuse of garlic and tomato sauces in Italian restaurants, and as for meat balls. . . ." The voice paused as though trying to find the proper inflection. "They are an American invention."

WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., March 19 -- It was snowing lightly this afternoon as Jean-Claude Killy, once the pride of the French skiing corps, demonstrated new fiberglass skis that are going to bear his name.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird disclosed today that his budget review would mean a saving in actual expenditure in the new fiscal year of $500-million, or far less than the more than $2-billion reduction that President Nixon predicted last week.
MOSCOW, March 19 -- Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the poet, said today that Peking dreamed of the day it could ravage the Soviet Union and destroy its culture.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 19 -- The faculty of Brown University was voted overwhelmingly to strip the school's R.O.T.C. program of academic credit and departmental status and thus eliminate it from the curriculum. The action taken yesterday brings to an end an intensive review begun last fall, of Brown's R.O.T.C. commitment.

IT is clearly more than beans that come out of Boston. Last night at Stage 73, the Theater Company of Boston, formed in 1963, came to town with three one-act plays by James Leo Herlihy. The triple bill is called "Stop, You're Killing Me," and it was first produced with the assistance of a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation.

LIMA, Peru, March 19 (AP) -- The Peruvian Navy seized two American tuna boats about 23 miles off Peru's northern coastline today, but freed them after having forced their captains to pay fines in port.
Mary Anne Harrison Lindsay says she had a few reservations about her husband's running for re-election as Mayor of the City of New York. But they have given way to a wholehearted endorsement.
In a modern version of the Sutter's Mill gold rush, football fans began staking out claims yesterday for tickets to the Jets-Giants charity football game next Aug. 17 at the Yale Bowl.
Fueled by renewed hopes of peace in Vietnam, the stock market extended its rally yesterday along a wide front.

COMMACK, L. I., March 19 -- A District Court judge here sentenced 21 students to 15 days in jail today for having held an all-night sit-in at the library of the State University Center in Stony Brook.
Richard C. Bond, chairman and chief executive officer of the John Wanamaker stores, will relinquish those posts on June 1 to become president of the board of Wanamaker trustees.

BONN, March 19 -- Foreign Minister Willy Brandt disclosed today that West Germany was seeking membership in the Geneva disarmament conference and a permanent seat in the governing council of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna.
In village elections in Rockland County Tuesday, Republicans gained a slight advantage over Democrats, and the Conservative party elected its first official in the county.

CLEVELAND, March 19 -Two teams headed by New York experts faced tough California opposiiton in the second knockout round of the Vanderbilt Team Championship at the Sheraton-Cleveland Hotel here this afternoon.

PARIS, March 19 -- The French Government, in spite of a recent British rebuff, is waging an energetic diplomatic campaign in favor of discussions on a large, loosely organized European grouping. The grouping would include Britain and other European countries that are not members of the Common Market.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The nation's railroads, under threats of sabotage from anti-Vietnam war groups, have placed the tightest security precautions in history on shipments of munitions and military supplies.

Leading choices in Mayor Lindsay's still-fluid consideration of running mates yesterday were Sanford D. Garelik, now the Police Department's chief inspector, for Council President, and Fioravante G. Perrotta, now Finance Administrator, for Controller.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to rule that wiretapping and other electronic eavesdropping by Federal agents is not unconstitutional when used to gather "foreign intelligence information."
FORT LEWIS, Wash., March 19 (UPI) -- The court-marital of five Army privates accused of mutiny was moved here today because of anti-military demonstrations in San Francisco.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Soviet and United States diplomatic cables flashed back and forth between Moscow and Washington instantaneously today over a new official communications system.

BOSTON, March 7 -- Although Massachusetts is moving rapidly to protect its coastal wetlands, action pending in Plymouth County Superior Court, the Commissioner of Natural Resources vs. S. Volpe Co., Inc., poses a challenge to conservation interests.

VIENNA, March 19 -- A decision to create a joint command and a combined multinational staff for the Warsaw Pact, the Soviet bloc's military alliance, was disclosed today in Prague by Alexander Dubcek, the Czechoslovak Communist party leader.
GROSSINGER, N. Y., March 19 -- It started with the dark blue sign. Its two-inch yellow letters read:
TOKYO, March 19 -- Japan's two biggest steel producers, the Yawata and Fuji Iron and Steel companies, filed a formal application for merger today with the Fair Trade Commission.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 19 -- The Government of President Mohammed Ayub Khan, saying that "mob rule is the order of the day," announced today that it would not tolerate any further violence in any part of the country.
CAIRO, Thursday, March 20 -- A turboprop of United Arab Airlines crashed today at Aswan Airport, 400 miles south of Cairo, killing 91 persons and injuring 10.

The four teams that have displayed the soundest approach to basketball, and the best discipline when facing some more talented players, will meet in the semi-finals of the 16-team National Invitation Tournament tonight at Madison Square Garden.

OTTAWA, March 19 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliot Trudeau categorically denied today that his Government had been asked by the United States for permission to fire antimissile missiles over Canadian soil.
PHILADELPHIA, March 19 (UPI) -- Hal Greer scored 34 points tonight to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 136-115 victory over Seattle in a National Basketball Association game.
LUSAKA, Zambia -- The swirling blades of a helicopter are proving a potent new weapon in the fight against poachers to save the wild game in this part of Africa.

NEW ORLEANS, March 19 (AP) -- An attempt to hijack Delta Airlines' Flight 918 to New York wah foiled late tonight as its Convair 800 jet was being refueled on the ground here, the Federal Aviation Administration said in Atlanta.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 -- The New York Mets kept galloping along today, as if the money were on the table. They defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-4, for their fifth straight victory and the seventh in their last eight starts.
The City Planning Commission yesterday approved the creation of a 15-block district around Lincoln Center, in which buildings would be designed to harmonize with structures in the center.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Nixon today named Otto F. Otepka, a controversial State Department official who was suspended from a key security post by former Secretary of State Dean Rusk, to a post on the Subversive Activities Control Board.

LONDON, March 19 -- Anguilla is the latest in a series of foreign adventures for British policemen since the end of World War II. Under the Overseas Service Act of 1945, British civil police authority has been established in such far corners as Germany, Austria, Greece, Trieste, Malaya, Cyprus and Nyasaland.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- On Feb. 7 the Defense Department announced that Deputy Secretary David R. Packard had worked out an oral agreement with three textile companies whereby they would move to eliminate job discrimination and the Government would award them $9.4-million in contracts.

THE Manhattan Chess Club triumphed 7-1 -- six wins and two draws -- over Columbia University in a recent eight-board match at the Manhattan quarters. This was the first of a series of Manhattan matches against Ivy League teams, sponsored by Manhattan's director, Dr. H. Bakwin.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange increased slightly during the month ended March 14, the exchange announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Officials said today that the United States position on Anguilla was that Britain clearly had the responsibility for maintaining order there.

ATLANTA, March 19 -- At proposed merger with the million-member Presbyterian Church in the U.S. (Southern) has been defeated by the Reformed Church in America, which has a membership of 235,000, mostly in the Middle West.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- At the Gridiron Club dinner here last Saturday night, Henry A. Kissinger, Presidential Adviser on National Security Affairs, was introduced to Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

ALBANY, March 19 -- John Lotz, chairman of the New York City Board of Education's decentralization committee, told legislators today that only "major surgery in Albany" to achieve decentralization will save the city's school system.

Senator Lee Metcalf, Democrat of Montana, invited the heads of the nation's electric power industry yesterday to appear before a Senate subcommittee "to explain the utilities' attempts to prevent the showing of a national television documentary on electric power."

I., manufacturer of hobby kits and miniature electric car and roadway sets.
