Loans to four countries totaling $92.4-million were announced yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the World Bank.

Human Resources Administrator Mitchell I. Ginsberg said yesterday that the city's need for day-care centers for children was so great that he was considering the use of profit-making organizations, such as nursery schools to handle the overflow.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Federal Aviation Administration demonstrated today three devices for detecting weapons carried by potential hijackers of airliners.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 (UPI) -- Arthur Ashe, America's No. 1 seeded entry, defeated Britain's Peter Curtis, 6-2, 6-3, today to become one of the two seeded men remaining in contention for the Masters tennis tournament honors.
At 2:08 P.M. yesterday, a fair young woman, newly christened Miss Springtime, whispered into the ear of a grumpy old man -- name of Winter -- that he had overstayed his welcome, if he ever had any.

SAIGON, Friday, March 21 (AP) -- Enemy forces heavily bombarded an American artillery base northwest of Saigon today with mortars and rocket-propelled grenades, then followed up with an infantry assault using tear gas, military spokesmen reported.
The bills of New York State's 5.6 million telephone subscribers would rise by $175-million a year under new rates proposed to the Public Service Commission yesterday.

A letter by Dominic P. Cerulli under the heading "Costly Rent Pact" (March 18) plainly is misinformed, particularly since details of Mayor Lindsay's settlement plan were clearly outlined in the March 13 news story in The Times.

THE distinction between melodrama and tragedy is narrow, distinct, but, let us admit, subjective. James Hanley, the English playwright and uncle of the American playwright William Hanley, presumably thinks that in "The Inner Journey," first seen last night at the Forum Theater of the Lincoln Center Repertory Company, he has achieved the span and depth of tragedy.
STOCKHOLM, March 20 (AP) -- Canada routed the United States, 5-0, in the world amateur hockey tournament today, sending the Americans, who have yet to win, to their fourth setback.

The city's largest union of retail workers is on the verge of splitting from its parent international in a dispute over the local's desire to cooperate with the United Automobile Workers and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in the new Alliance for Labor Action.

Only in its closing seconds, last night in the New Image of Music concert at Hunter College Assembly Hall, was the title of Eric Salzman's "The Nude Paper Sermon" fulfilled. By then the revelation was an anticlimax.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Kenneth B. Keating, the former New York Senator and now an Associate Justice of the State Court of Appeals, will become United States Ambassador to India.
Radio astronomers have recorded evidence that in many parts of the Milky Way there are clouds of a material used as a laboratory preservative and thought, as well, to be a chemical precursor of life.
NORTHWEST Industries filed an amendment yesterday to its registration statement, indicating that the Justice Department was looking into Northwest's plan to take over the B. F. Goodrich Company.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 20 -- The United States command reported today that American battle deaths were 351 last week, the third week of the enemy's current offensive. The figure the week before was 336.

Two important coaching adjustments, by Bob Cousy before the first game and by Harry Litwack with less than seven minutes left in the second game, carried Boston College and Temple into the final round of the National Invitation Tournament last night at Madison Square Garden.

ABOARD THE HAMBURG, in the North Sea, Marcia 20 -- In a ceremony on the Elbe River outlet to the North Sea, the German Atlantic Line doubled the size of its passenger ship fleet from one to two today by dedicating the new Hamburg, the first large German-built liner since 1938.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., March 20 -- Austin E. Gumbs, one of about 6,700 Anguillans who live in the New Jersey-New York area and make up the largest overseas colony of the world's smallest republic, says he will never forget the moment when he learned the British were invading his homeland.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The merger of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway into the Norfolk Western Railway was recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission today by its hearing examiner, Edward L. Boisseree.

The many ways in which inflation is hacking away the purchasing power of the dollar are highlighted by yesterday's announcement that the New York Telephone Company is seeking a rate increase of $175-million a year. The average householder and business will get a 10.5 per cent increase in basic monthly charges if the increase is approved by the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The deputy director of the Budget Bureau insisted today that the bureau gave "essentially the same" scrutiny to requests for defense spending that it gave to other spending requests.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 -- A peace agreement was reached today at violence-wracked San Francisco State College ending a winter-long strike of militant students and sympathizers.

A smoldering dissension in the top hierarchy of two companies of equal size that merged two years ago broke into the open yesterday with the resignation of Gene C. Brewer as president and chief operating officer of U. S. Plywood-Champion Papers, Inc.
A skyscraper will rise on 42d Street at the Avenue of the Americas on the site of Stern Brothers department store and across from Bryant Park and the New York Public Library.
JERUSALEM, March 20 -- Mordechai Rachamim, the Israeli security agent who killed one of four Arab attackers of an Ell Al airliner in Zurich last month, returned home tonight to a hero's welcome.

REPRODUCTIONS of four 18th-century fabrics from the collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art have just been introduced by Brunschwig Fils, Inc., the decorative fabrics concern at 979 Third Avenue (58th Street).

PARIS, March 20 -- Despite what was considered fairly effective exchange controls, France lost $82.8-million of reserves during a week of currency jitters earlier this month, the Bank of France disclosed today.
The chairman of a Presidential commission proposed last night that the Federal Government fight poverty by providing "cash income to all the poor," including supplements for low-wage workers.

The landscape architect who is designing a 3,200-acre state park that would overlook the Consolidated Edison Company's controversial Storm King plant testified yesterday that the proposed power station was a "good use of park land."

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Dr. Lee A. DuBridge, science adviser to President Nixon, urged universities today to begin to end secret weapons research they are doing for the military. He said he agreed with those contending that this work was inappropriate on the campus.

WHERE there is camping, there is usually water. Where there is water, there are usually boats. Therefore, camping and boating go together. That's putting it mildly. Campers not only are hitching their dreams to a star these days, but also their boats to their cars and heading in greater numbers for the great outdoors.

Nearly 1,000 drawings by the late Reginald Marsh have been received as a gift by the New York Public Library. The collection, containing the artist's first rough sketches to finished product through successive refinements, represents illustrations for 15 books.
BONN, March 20 -- The West German Government has decided to raise import quotas for trade with Communist bloc and Asian countries in another move to fight inflationary tendencies at home.
A first-day-of-spring snowstorm struck the Midwest yesterday, dropping up to 10 inches of snow on flood-threatened southern Minnesota and leaving five-foot drifts on northeast Nebraska highways.
THERE is no plaque or sign on the door of 327 East 22d Street. In fact, the neat gray and black four-story building looks like any other renovated brownstone.

Mayor Lindsay submitted a bill to the City Council yesterday that would place under existing strict rent control regulations the property of any landlord who failed to comply with voluntary rent guidelines.
A Brooklyn Criminal Court judge yesterday dismissed charges against a man accused of practising medicine without a license.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Henry A. Kissinger, Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs, plans to name an official of the United States Information Agency to his staff.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- President Nixon today named Governor Rockefeller to the nonpartisan review board that will help determine the course of the antiballistic missile system.
New York State will conduct a special study of abuses in the issuance and distribution of new securities, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday.
DAYTON, Ohio, March 20 -- This city, home of the Wright brothers, is hard pressed to keep a tiny suburban city from taking over its airports.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 20 -- Mike Martin, a defending champion, helped the University of California at Irvine take the first-day lead in the National Collegiate Athletic Association college division swimming and diving championships by winning the 500-yard free-style event in the record time of 4 minutes 41.36 seconds.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Spokesmen for major lumber and plywood companies said today that improved management of Federal forest lands is needed to increase lumber production needed by an expanding home-construction market.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A three-month United States project described as "the most extensive investigation ever made over a large ocean area" will begin in May east of the island of Barbados to study the key sea-air interactions that shape the world's weather.
HOUSTON, March 20 (UPI) -- The chief of the civilian space agency called today for the development of a joint civilian-military spacecraft and launching complex during the 1970's.
Why did Stan Freberg, the satirist who reserves some of his sharpest barbs for ad agencies, hold a news conference yesterday?

Twenty - three persons -- psychologists, social workers, nonprofessional workers and medical students -- were arrested yesterday afternoon at Lincoln Hospital Mental Health Services during a sit-in on the 18th day of dispute over control.

Boys High, the nation's top-ranked team, won as expected the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship yesterday in the bandbox Wingate High gymnasium in Brooklyn, where the posted fire law signs limited capacity to 570.
TWO years from now, while racial strife sunders the world outside, five hunbands and wives who founded a village for integrated couples like themselves, meet for a birthday party.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, March 20 (AP) -- Willard L. Boyd, 42-yearold vice president for academic affairs and dean of the faculty at the University of Iowa, was named president of the university today by the State Board of Regents.
GIBRALTAR, March 20 -- (UPI) -- John Lennon married Yoko Ono, a Japanese artist, today.

A directors meeting of the Phoenix Steel Corporation adjourned yesterday in Claymont, Del., until next week after selecting Harold B. Freeman Jr., president, as chairman. Mr. Freeman replaces Stanley Kirk, who was dismissed by the company on Monday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 -- Arthur Ashe now finds himself in the bizarre never-never land that the tennis fathers have created. He likes it. He now belongs to a new category of "player," a semantic distortion that means he isn't exactly an amateur and isn't exactly a professional.

The Claiborne Farm's fine filly, Taste, had little trouble registering her third straight victory yesterday as she raced to a two-length triumph in the main event at Aqueduct. With many of the 24,387 fans backing her with great confidence, Taste returned $3.80 for $2.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 20 -- The University of California, Los Angeles, had more of a battle on its hands than expected before doing the expected and beating Drake, 85-82, in the semi-finals of the National Collegiate basketball championship tournament at Freedom Hall tonight.
" Come Summer," the musical, with Ray Bolger as the star and Agnes de Mille as choreographer and director, will close after its seventh performance on tomorrow night at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.

IN London three years ago Barbra Streisand sang for an invited audience in the auditorium of the United States Embassy. She was introduced by the Ambassador, David Bruce, who recalled his first visit to the the ater -- on his fourth birthday, in Baltimore, as the guest of his 102-year-old great-grand- mother.

The Brooklyn Democratic organization, which is expected to deliver the largest single bloc of votes in the party's crowded primary election for Mayor, is beginning to form an alliance with important Manhattan Democrats to promote the unannounced candidacy of Representative Hugh L. Carey.
The Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that it "will not resort to a proxy fight to block the proposed merger of the Amerada Petroleum Corporation and the Hess Oil and Chemical Company.

WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., March 20 -- By the margin of only one-hundreth of a second, Bernie Rauter, the attractive 20-year-old brunette from the Austrian Tyrol, beat two Americans in a bitterly contested World Cup giant slalom today.

CLEVELAND, March 20 -- The quarter-final stage of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship began here this afternoon at the Sheraton - Cleveland Hotel with four teams led by New York experts in contention.

The best show in New York this year is Mayor John Lindsay's race for re-election. It covers the whole range of the theatrical art from Hamlet to all-in wrestling, and it has the funniest cast of characters since the days of Bert Lahr and Billy Minsky.

Proponents of abortion reform won an important victory yesterday when a bill to liberalize New York State's 86-year-old law was voted out by the Assembly Codes Committee. But they must not make the mistake of thinking the battle has been won. A long and hard fight still lies ahead before this much-needed modification of a cruel law is finally enacted.

Budgetary woes of urban areas and states across the country call for a re-examination of Federal-state relations and new budgetary procedures. Rising rapidly, local needs have outstripped yields from local and state taxes. First the locality, then the state has found itself incapable of funding the increase in demands for service.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- New orders for durable goods soared by $1-billion in February to a record level of $30.7-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- Johnny Nerud, the trainer and part-owner of Dr. Fager, and Raymond Guest, the owner of Sir Ivor, a winner of the Washington International, were named today to receive honors at the National Turf Writers Association annual awards dinner in Louisville, Ky., on April 30.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 20 -- The 73-foot ketch Windward Passage was speeding toward a course record tonight in the 811-mile Miami-to-Montego Bay yacht race.
Prices on the London stock market were moderately firmer yesterday. Trading remained quiet.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel met today with Secretary of State William P. Rogers to try to persuade the United States to abandon big-power initiatives for a Middle East Settlement, according to reliable informants.

RUMSON, N. J. -- The difference between "decorator" and "interior designer" and whether these terms can be used to designate professional status are currently being contested in this exurban community, one of the wealthiest in the United States.
The credit markets continued to recuperate yesterday.
President Nixon's case for deploying a modified Sentinel antiballistic missile defense becomes less credible with each elaboration by Administration spokesmen.
The University Council of Columbia University endorsed yesterday the recommendations of a student-faculty committee to alter the status of the Naval R.O.T.C. program.

The winter of 1969 will probably be remembered by the Metropolitan Opera as the one when singers fell before the flu like canaries before an icy wind. It was a winter that severely taxed the Met's system of having alternates available for each role in every opera.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- President Nixon received a report today that more than one million employes of minority origin had been hired by private business concerns united in Plans for Progress, set up in 1961.

The proposed $452-million merger of Crum Forster and Walter Kidde Co., which had been ailing for several days, died yesterday. So did the $100-million proposal of Santa Fe International, an oil field services company, to acquire Global Bulk Transport, Inc., and States Marine Lines, two of the nation's largest privately held shipping companies.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 20 -- South Vietnamese forces fought three battles with Vietcong troops south of Danang yesterday, according to South Vietnamese Government reports.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- There is considerable apprehension in the Pentagon and elsewhere in the Government about the implications of a part of the Soviet Union's draft treaty proposing to forbid military uses of the ocean floor.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 20 -- The textile industry has been penalized unfairly by the guidelines for mergers and acquisitions instituted by the Federal Trade Commission, Harold W. Whitcomb, president of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, said here today.
MOSCOW, March 20 -- The Soviet press said today that large numbers of Russian settlers were continuing to migrate to Far Eastern regions bordering on China despite the recent frontier clashes.
ATLANTA, March 20 -- The first glimpse of what a united Protestant church of the future might look like came into sharp focus here this week.

" ANIMALS IN DANGER" (Dodd, Mead Co., illustrated, 181 pages, $4.95) by Frances and Dorothy Wood, and "The Albino Blue" (Doubleday, 19 pages, $2.95) by Carl L. Biemiller, are two excellent recently published books for youngsters who want to know more about birds, animals and fish and man's relationship to them.

BARNSTABLE, Mass., March 20 -- Kurt Vonnegut Jr. is an author who lives on Cape Cod with a wife and six children, meditating on the Sodoms of our age, wondering whether the next brimstone shower will be the last.
BUFFALO, March 20 -- Work on construction projects at three state university campuses in the Buffalo area was halted today in response to demands for the integration of workers on the projects.
CHICAGO, March 20 -- A Federal grand jury indicted eight persons today on charges of conspiracy to incite a riot during the Democratic National Convention here last August.
BRUSSELS, March 19 -- Some politicians, diplomats and soldiers of the North Atlantic alliance are questioning the strategy of flexible response to any Soviet aggression.
PARIS, March 20 -- The chief United States negotiator, Henry Cabot Lodge, said today that there had been "some progress" at the ninth plenary meeting of the Vietnam peace talks here.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 20 (AP) -- Diane Crump became the first woman jockey to ride two winners on one program as she broke the sex barrier at Gulfstream Park today, bringing home Tou Ritzi in the first race and Blinking Bulldog in the third.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 20 -- The will of James Thompson, the Bangkok silk tycoon who disappeared in March, 1967 while on a holiday in Malaysia; was found this week in the office of the Thai Silk Company, which he started in 1948.
Three New Yorkers and three Florida men were accused by a Federal grand jury yesterday of engaging in a worldwide illegal stock deal with the help of secret accounts in Swiss and German banks.

A plan to move the New York Stock Exchange from its present site at the corner of Broad and Wall Streets to a new location on landfill in the East River was approved yesterday by the exchange's board of governors.

Defense Secretary Laird's ultracautious testimony on prospects for American troop withdrawals from Vietnam is a disappointment to all who had hoped for a bold Nixon Administration initiative to advance the Paris peace talks. It represents a retreat from the Laird statement in Saigon March 10 that it would be "desirable and possible" to replace some Americans in Vietnam.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy called on the Nixon Administration last night for a sweeping overhaul of United States policy on China, the withdrawal of American military forces from Taiwan and the establishment of consular missions in Communist China as a prelude to eventual diplomatic recognition.

LOS ANGELES, March 20 -- A court-appointed psychiatrist testifying in behalf of the defense said today that Sirhan B. Sirhan saw himself as the "savior of society" when he killed Senator Robert F. Kennedy last year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 20 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was named today to receive the Atoms for Peace Award May 14 in recognition of his contribution to international efforts for the peaceful use of atomic energy.

The National Catholic Office for Motion Pictures and the National Council of Churches named "Rachel, Rachel" and "The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter" recipients yesterday of their third annual award as the best films of 1968.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- President Nixon is under intense pressure to retain personal responsibility for United States trade policy rather than shift it to the Department of Commerce.

The N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., said yesterday that it had not decided to support the inquiry of Russell X. Thompson, a lawyer who said in Memphis on Wednesday that he would continue an investigation into the possibility of a conspiracy in the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King. Jr.
VERNON, Calif., March 20 -- The railroad car in which Harry S. Truman whistle-stopped across the country and gave them hell in 1948 was sold into history today.

Nathan Horwitt's association [letter March 17] of anti-Zionism with anti-Americanism is an example of the stream of deceptions that is being aimed by the Zionist propaganda machine at the American people.

BOSTON, March 20 -- The University Academic Senate at Boston College has voted approval of making the Jesuit institution coeducational by September, 1970. It has also voted to reject a student petition for a review of the dismissal of a woman theology teacher.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Defense Department opened a televised counter-offensive against opponents of the Sentinel today by asserting that a missile defense was necessary to prevent the Soviet Union from acquiring the ability to destroy the United States with a surprise nuclear attack.

WASHINGTON, MARCH 20 -- A University of Chicago psychology professor told Congress today that some student protesters had not matured emotionally beyond the temper tantrum level and were guilt-ridden as a result of their exemption from military service.
The Federal Reserve System held the nation's money markets in a tight grip during the last two weeks, banking data reported yesterday showed.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Under pressure from liberal and conservative elements in Congress, the Defense Department is reducing its social and behavioral science research in foreign policy problems.
LONDON, March 20 -- The British consumer is feeling the impact of the Government's credit squeeze. But corporations are continuing to increase sharply their volume of outstanding loans.

PISCATAWAY TOWNSHIP, N. J., March 20 -- The 1,300-student high school here was closed today in the wake of a "crisis" that grew out of a scuffle among several boys yesterday, which led to false reports of racial clashes.

The leader of a Lower East Side motorcycle gang and a youth described as a prospective member were seized by the police yesterday and charged with homicide in the fire death of a 21-year-old rival gang member last Monday.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., March 20 -- When last seen, nearly a year ago, Jerry Quarry was backing toward the ropes, where he was secure and dangerous, but Jimmy. Ellis wasn't following him. In a scientific but unexciting bout. Ellis was awarded the World Boxing Association heavyweight championship -- and Quarry virtually vanished.

Fred Nauman, a Brooklyn teacher who played an important part in the city school dispute last year, yesterday lost his court fight for reinstatement at Junior High School 271, in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville district.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 20 -- The United States voted with the majority of the Security Council today to condemn South Africa for maintaining illegal control over South-West Africa in defiance of the United Nations.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 20 (AP) -- Four men who invaded a Harvard University class March 11 and broke up a lecture have been given jail terms on charges resulting from the incident.

The Buckingham Corporation, sole importers of Cutty Sark, reportedly the nation's best-selling scotch, proposed yesterday a reorganization by which it would become a subsidiary of a new Delaware holding company that it has created -- BHM Industries, Inc.

It was not exactly like the country mouse visiting the city mouse, but a group of non-big city Congressmen did get a close look yesterday at New York City's problems and a stern lecture on the need to provide more Federal money for Model Cities.
A City Council committee postponed action yesterday on a request that the Legislature pass a bill permitting greater flexibility in police assignments here.
Researchers at Columbia University have demonstrated experimentally in animals how smoking during pregnancy can harm unborn babies.

For his second program with the New York Philharmonic, presented last night in Philharmonic Hall, Pierre Boulez chose two works that looked like old friends but actually were not. These were Haydn's Symphony No. 89 in F and Bartok's First Piano Concerto.
Prices gained again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, marking the first time in weeks that the market has managed to put together three advances in a row.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Both houses of the Legislature moved the controversial New York City school decentralization issue closer to floor debate today as plans for compromise legislation also advanced.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The Assembly gave final approval today to a bill that would allow insurance companies to set rates for premiums on property and liability insurance without prior approval of the State Department of Insurance.

As Albany took a belated first step yesterday toward enacting a bill to give New Yorkers increased police protection in high - crime hours when they need it most, the City Council curiously chose additional delay. Its inaction makes no sense.
BOSTON, March 20 -- An eyewitness in the case against three men charged with the murder of three members of a Negro self-help agency last November was found shot to death today.

KIEL, Germany, March 20 (UPI) -- A second-string United States track team, criticized by German officials as being inferior, defeated West Germany's top athletes, 110-89, tonight in a dual indoor track and field meet.

An auction of American art yesterday, the second of two sessions at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, grossed $1,150,250. Peregrine Pollen, gallery president, characterized the sale as a "landmark event."

The summer program of the Neighborhood Youth Corps, allegedly defrauded of more than $1-million in the last two years, was transferred yesterday from one division of the city's Human Resources Administration to another.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- An Air Force general said today that he had dispatched United States fighter planes "with orders to attack" and considered seeking assistance from the South Korean Air Force in an attempt to halt the seizure of the Pueblo.

SEBRING, Fla., March 20 -- A preview of how fast Saturday's 12-hour endurance race will be emerged today from a brisk practice session in which 11 race cars broke the lap record for Sebring's 5.2-mile road course.
All cocoa futures, with the exception of spot March, closed up the limit of a cent a pound yesterday on sales of 2,092 lots. The March contract closed up 90 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).

LONDON, March 20 -- Richard Ingrams, editor of the satirical weekly magazine Private Eye, said here today that the Australian allegation about an interview for his magazine was "a complete myth" and mystified him.

The head of an electric power trade association has asked for the names of all National Educational Television stations scheduled to carry a Public Broadcast Laboratory documentary Sunday night on the power utilities.
In a continuation of the strength that it has shown since the banks' prime rate was increased on Monday, the stock market scored a dynamic gain yesterday.

The Moscow State Symphony closed its American tour last night at Carnegie Hall with a program of Russian opera excerpts. Extractions might be the better word, for one frequently felt that the music was being drawn out of the orchestra like bad teeth.
Following are excerpts from a speech delivered last night by Senator Edward M. Kennedy at a meeting on United States-China relations at the New York Hilton:

The New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association announced yesterday the formation of a special "contract board" for the admission of new men into the harbor's waterfront labor force.
The High School Principals Association accused the Board of Education yesterday of responding to recent school disorders with "a maximum of words and a minimum of action".
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 20 -- Lionel Hebert outscored the field and his brother, Jay, with a 67 in the first round of the $100,000 Greater Jacksonville open golf tournament today.

GENEVA, March 20 -- Britain, Canada and Nigeria today urged the Disarmament Conference to give priority to negotiations on prohibition of underground nuclear tests over the question of banning nuclear weapons from the seabed.
Victor Muscat, chairman and president of Defiance Industries, has challenged the ability of a dissident group of stockholders to unseat him as a director of the company at the annual meeting April 7.

LISBON, March 20 -- "We are all a bit nervous," a Socialist lawyer, Mario Soares, said early this morning during one particularly turbulent moment of a political debate here. "But in view of the uncertainty of our being able to meet again I propose we continue."
The 140-acre Spring Rock Country Club in Spring Valley Rockland County, has been sold by Irving Maidman, a New York realty man, to Joseph Norban for $1.7-million.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was following price increases initiated by the United States Steel Corporation on certain steel pipe products. The increases, effective March 31, were said by U. S. Steel to average 3.9 per cent.

Foreign banks have become 'more cooperative generally" -- though problems persists -- during investigations of the use of secret foreign accounts to over stock frauds in this country, United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday.

CARTAVIO, Peru, March 19 -- Don Manuel took a swig of beer and reflectively rubbed the white stubble on his chin as he watched fellow sugar workers tying packets of gunpowder to the big fireworks scaffold.
The Potomac River is just about as badly polluted as it was a decade ago, despite an extensive cleanup program, the Federal Water Pollution Control Administration reported yesterday.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The drive for liberalization of the state's abortion law made a major advance today when an Assembly committee reported out a broad abortion-reform bill and the Senate decided to let the Assembly vote first on the sensitive issue.

LONDON, March 20 -- Moscow broadcasts beamed to Communist China have told the Chinese people not to believe their leaders' assertions that the Soviet Union is "a paper tiger with false teeth" and is afraid of China's might.
ANGUILLA, March 20 -- Hundreds of Anguillans marched and demonstrated today to protest the military seizure of their tiny island yesterday by British land, sea and air forces.

NEW ORLEANS, March 20 (AP) -- A chartered plane carrying 24 Memphis area sportsmen to a hunting expedition in British Honduras crashed in a heavy fog and burned at New Orleans International Airport today, killing 16 men -- 13 passengers and a crew of three.
MANILA, March 20 (UPI) -- A spokesman for the Philippine Congress today announced the imminent withdrawal of all 1,500 Filipino troops in Vietnam, to be replaced by doctors and nurses.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 20 -- What is happening down here? The Yankees keep on winning and there must be some logical explanation.

YONKERS, N. Y., March 20 -- Bishop Broderick, a former baseball pitcher, publicly accepted "with joy" the appointment during a news conference at the St. Joseph's Seminary here, from which he had graduated and where he had been rector from 1964 to 1967.

" MANY young people today see no use in the past, perhaps because the immediate past has had so little to teach them. The history of American radicalism, in any case, is largely a history of failure and therefore not a source of comfort to those who look to the past to find ancestors and heroes."
The medical board of Harlem Hospital voted yesterday to shut down the 800-bed public facility within a week because of severe shortages of nurses and other personnel.
SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, March 21 -- New questions about the personal conduct of Prime Minister John G. Gorton were raised in Parliament yesterday by a member of his Liberal party.

Carter L. Burgess has been re-elected a director of American Airlines, Inc., and will rejoin the board in April after having completed service as United States Ambassador to Argentina. The former chairman of the American Machine and Foundry Company was first named to the airline board in 1959.

The Glen Alden Corporation, a diversified company, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for 1968 even without the results of Schenley Industries, Inc., the 88 per cent-owned subsidiary acquired Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, for years one of the most powerful men in the Senate, announced today that he would undergo cobalt treatment for a lung tumor.

NEW DELHI -- The primordial reason for Russian interest in India is the same as that for American interest -- to prevent any other power from gaining ascendancy in this immense triangle, thereby tipping the strategic balance. Any other power means above all China.

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would resume accepting brokers' deposits of shares in its Central Certificate Service, beginning Monday. The exchange had halted such acceptances in its newly automated program two weeks ago because a heavy influx of deposits threatened to get out of control.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it would withhold renewal of the operating license of a San Francisco television station until it had fully investigated accusations that the station had "managed" news programs for its own corporate benefit.

A first payment of $1,579,856.04 has been made by Richard Rodgers and the estate of the late Oscar Hammerstein 2d in a settlement involving the producers and 52 backers of "The Sound of Music." The case hinged on the sharing of profits from the sale of the film album of the Broadway hit.
The stock market reversed a downtrend late in yesterday's session and closed virtually at a standoff in a vivid demonstration of its sensitivity to developments relating to the war in Vietnam.

Vintage movies acquired by the Museum of Modern Art from Mary Pickford and the Soviet Government will be shown in the series that begins today with "Stella Maris," a 1918 feature-length drama starring Miss Pickford and directed by Marshall Neilan.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 21 -- An engineer - economist charged here today that the deficit financing policies of the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations have led to an over-supply of money that has hastened the rate of inflation and eaten into corporate profits.
AMMAN, Jordan, March 21 The Jordanian Army, in announcing today the downing of the Israel Jet, said that two Israeli vehicles had also been destroyed and three artillery positions silenced.

LOS ANGELES, March 21 -''The Adventures of the Black Girl in Her Search for God," a play by Christopher Isherwood based on the novella by George Bernard Shaw, received lukewarm reviews after its world premiere at the Mark Taper Forum here last night.

Stolen merchandise worth "more than $1-million" was recovered in a raid late yesterday afternoon on a Lower Manhattan building by detectives and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, the police reported.
A Long Island Rail Road rider who was beaten by a railroad policeman on Christmas morning six years ago has been awarded $528,750 by a State Supreme Court jury.
WILLIE MAE ROGERS has gone back to her kitchens, but the heat is still on the Good Housekeeping Consumers' Guaranty Seal, familiarly known as the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night marked Erich Leinsdorf's final New York City appearance in his official capacity as the orchestra's principal conductor and music director.

Liggett Myers, after a couple of years of planning, is preparing to take a multi-million-dollar gamble and go national with its Chesterfield coupon promotion.
HARLAN, Ky., March 24 -- Hobart Ison, a mountain man quick to anger, pleaded guilty today to voluntary manslaughter in the slaying of a Canadian film producer and was given a 10-year prison sentence.

Albert Shanker warned yesterday that the teachers' union might "as a last resort" be forced to strike again unless the Board of Education and the State Commissioner of Education protected the rights of seven union teachers at a Harlem school.

LONDON -- The huge English breakfast so loved by tourists is not being eaten any more by the natives. Men who can remember their fathers munching five courses in unheated dining rooms, while butlers skimmed in and out, now take coffee and toast themselves.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -Robert H. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, disclaimed today any connection with a departmental memorandum that seemed to cast further doubt on how strenuously he intended to enforce school desegration in the South.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Assembly gave final passage tonight to a bill denying state aid to students convicted of a crime "on the premises of any college." The vote was 86 to 60, with the Democrats voting heavily against it.
A student leader from Kenya took issue yesterday with the position of Tom Mboya of Kenya that black Americans should not leave the United States for Africa.

WALTHAMSTON, England, March 24 (AP) -- Defense Minister Denis Healey, bombarded with bags of flour and tomatoes at an election rally tonight, jumped off the speakers' platform and ran down an assailant.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Judge Nathan M. Cohen of Circuit Court held unconstitutional today a provision of the 108-yearold state charter of the Young Men's Christian Association of Chicago that specified the religious makeup of the organization's 12-member board of trustees.

TRENTON, March 24 -- Conservationists made an important gain today when the Assembly voted to preserve Sunfish Pond on Kittatinny Ridge in western New Jersey by authorizing the state to buy back the land it is on.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -The Supreme Court ruled today that it is not unconstitutional for states to spend more money on public education in wealthy districts than is spent in poor neighborhoods.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, March 24 -- Proposals to shorten the Winter Olympic Games and reduce the ceremonies, surrounding them will be placed before the International Olympic Committee in Warsaw in June, Avery Brundage, the committee's president, announced today.

CHICAGO, March 24 (UPI) -Mayor Richard J. Daley announced today that the city of Chicago would take over security at Chicago ports, where cargo pilferage has been reported to run into the millions of dollars.
Shoe manufacturers, showing their fall and winter lines to the trade here this week, are finding a generally favorable response from buyers and merchandise managers, despite slightly higher prices.

BERLIN, March 24 -- Carat Harmetall, a West Berlin company under investigation for possible violation of four-power arms control regulations, halted production today and sent its 96 workers home for lack of funds.

BRANDOA, Portugal, March 24 -- This community of 12,000 people, which recently faced demolition because it had been built illegally and was tainted by construction scandals, has been reprieved because it withstood an earthquake that caused extensive damage in other areas.

LOS ANGELES, March 24 -The fatal shooting of Senator Robert F. Kennedy was vividly recounted in court today as a psychiatrist who hypnotized Sirhan B. Sirhan in his jail cell told how the defendant had re-enacted the killing.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The surge of investment by American business in plant and equipment in foreign countries apparently is slowing down, particularly in manufacturing, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada is "shyer than he looks and doesn't really realize how interested the ladies are in him," Mrs. Edgar Ritchie, wife of the Canadian Ambassador, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -Personality is supposed to be dead in world politics. With the exception of President de Gaulle in France and Mao Tse-tung in China, the major governments are now run by political and economic technicians -- President Nixon in Washington, Prime Minister Wilson in Britain, Premier Sato in Japan, Kiesinger in West Germany, and Kosygin and Brezhnev in the Soviet Union.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 25 (UPI) -- Diane Crump, the first woman jockey to ride two winners in one day, recorded another first at Gulf-stream Park today when she rode in a stakes race, but the 20-year-old rider finished second in the event.
An overnight thunder-and-lightning storm soaked the New York area yesterday, congealing city traffic and interrupting electrical service but bringing the spring to lawns and parkland.
LONDON, March 25 -- Rhodes Scholars have run into problems with their local draft boards back home.

Eleven years after the murder of Albert Anastasia, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office reports it has "new information" that gives some hope that the murderers may be caught.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 25 (UPI) -- The unclothed body of a 16-year-old girl who had been strangled was found today close by a lovers' lane section of this university city. She was the fourth murdered girl found in a 15-mile triangle in the last 21 months and the second in four days.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The United States suffered a gold loss of $27-million in February, the Treasury disclosed today.

THE new head of the Pakistani Government, Gen. Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan, has come to power not because of his personality or popularity or statesmanship, in the judgment of, expert observers of the Asian scene at the United Nations, but simply because he is commander in chief of the army.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Federal Communications Commission renewed today a radio and a television license in California for the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company.

DACCA, Pakistan, March 25 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan resigned tonight, and martial law was declared throughout Pakistan.
LONDON, March 25 -- A consortium of four American and four European banks has been formed to set up a new London-based bank.

CHICAGO, March 25 (UPI) -- Gulf Western Industries, Inc., filed a counter-suit against the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company today seeking to retain profits it made in selling a large block of Allis shares it had aquired in a tender offer opposed by Allis management.

NEW HAVEN, March 25 -Movie theater managers in Connecticut have been told by the state police to delete a scene from "The Killing of Sister George" that deals with lesbianism or face prosecution under the state's obscenity and licensing laws.

AKRON, Ohio, March 25 -The management of the B. F. Goodrich Company was voted two new weapons but denied two others requested as defenses against take-over bids at the annual meeting held here this morning.

Much maneuvering is going on behind the scenes in Albany these days as the Republican legislative leaders seek to line up their slender majorities in support of the compromise budget they have worked out with Governor Rockefeller. Senator Earl W. Brydges, the majority leader, points to the need for haste because the state's new fiscal year begins next Tuesday.

AKRON, Ohio, March 25 -The management of the B. F. Goodrich Company was voted two new weapons but denied two others requested as defenses against take-over bids at the annual meeting held here this morning.

Funding to develop black and Puerto Rican construction contractors here was disclosed yesterday with $935,000 committed or anticipated from the Ford Foundation, the New York Urban Coalition and government programs over the next three years.
Four executives have been admitted as general partners in the investment firm of Salomon Brothers Hutzler, it was announced yesterday.

Cazzie Russell and Phil Jackson remained doubtful competitors as the New York Knicks began workouts at St. John's gym yesterday for their National Basketball Association four-of-seven game series with the Bullets that opens tomorrow night in Baltimore.

KARACHI, March 25 (Reuters) -- In a voice betraying only slight traces of emotion, President Ayub said in his speech of resignation that the condition of Pakistan was deteriorating day by day and ackmowledged that the economy "is paralyzed."

WASHINGTON, March 25 -Spokesmen for major Federal regulatory agencies denounced today, with one voice, proposed legislation that would permit all rate-regulated companies to figure their depreciation by any legal method and require their regulators to recognize that method in setting the company's rates.

Seven persons and their two North Carolina companies were indicted here yesterday on charges of mail fraud in selling cigarettes in a way that cost New York City and state $500,000 a year in lost taxes.

MANCHESTER, England, March 25 -- The first regional ballet company in Britain, Northern Dance Theater, had a preliminary showing at the University Theater last night. The success of the program makes it virtually certain that the company will set up here permanently later this year.
Stockholders of the Chase Manhattan Bank, the nation's third largest, approved yesterday formation of a one-bank holding company to be called the Chase Manhattan Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Treasury announced tonight that it had sold $1.8-billion of bills during the day at an average discount rate of 5.027 per cent. The financing consisted of a series of six issues of bills maturing from May 8 through June 12, or in an average of 55 days.
The Queens Republican leadership gave its support to Mayor Lindsay yesterday in his bid for re-election.

MOSCOW, March 25 -- Pyotr Y. Shelest, a member of the ruling Communist party's Politburo, has warned that the Soviet Union faces danger both from East and West after what he called China's "stab in the back."

ALBANY, March 25 -- Governor Rockefeller today assured a citizens' group lobbying for a broad school decentralization plan for New York City that the racially sensitive issue would not be taken up by the Legislature until action on a new state budget was completed.

Five performers and five production members from the Off Broadway play "Che!" were held on $500 bail each yesterday in a Criminal Court case that may test the theater's right to explicitly portray intercourse and other sexual practices.

The local school board of District 2, which includes most of the East Side between 21st Street and 109th Street, yesterday protested a decision by the Superintendent of Schools to transfer their acting district superintendent to another district tomorrow.
Byron Dobell will leave his position as editor of Book World on Tuesday to become editor in chief of the new book division of the McCall Publishing Company, a subsidiary of Norton Simon, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- President Nixon repeated today his belief that progress toward peace in Vietnam would come only in secret talks with Hanoi. He said that his Administration would not be able to tell the American people when and where they would begin.

Charles Durand-Ruel, who plans to be the last of his family's five generations of Paris art dealers, sat in a room whose main decor was wall-to-wall Renoirs and recalled how he used to talk about everything but art with Pierre-Auguste Renoir.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 -- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel said today he expected that resumption of oil drilling in the leak-afflicted Santa Barbara channel would be possible this week under tightened Federal regulations.

ALBANY, March 26 -- A bill to establish a program to teach the general practice of medicine as a specialty in all state-operated medical schools has been signed by Governor Rockefeller, his office announced today.

A slate of incumbent union officers, under attack because of four indictments and a dispute with the State Insurance Department, has won an over-whelminig victory in an election conducted by the American Arbitration Association.
The Port of New York Authority has asked the Federal Maritime Commission to reject an appeal for a public hearing on its plans to build a $60.5-million passenger-ship terminal on the Hudson River.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Federal Communications Commission told two of New York's major television stations today that they must run more antismoking messages during prime time.
While the city sleeps, Wall Street and the financial district rest, fitfully, with one eye shut and one eye wide open.

TOKYO, March 26 -- Former Premier Nobusuke Kishi said in an interview here today that American bases on Okinawa should be nonnuclear but that the United States should continue to enjoy free use of these bases for combat operations outside Japan proper. Mr. Kishi is the elder brother of Premier Eisaku Sato and a major figure in the ruling Liberal-Democratic party.
LONDON, March 26 (AP) -- Thieves broke into the Sir John Soane Museum and stole a Watteau painting valued at $350,000 to $500,000, the police reported today.

Maria Callas will sing with the Dallas Civic Opera in two performances of Verdi's Requiem on Nov. 26 and 29. The performances will be Miss Callas's only American appearance in the 1969-70 season.

MIAMI, March 26 -- Dave Hill, a 31-year-old professional from Evergreen, Colo., was suspended from the golf tour today and Lee Trevino, the United States Open champion, went home after having decided that an injured thumb was too painful to permit him to play in the $200,000 National Airlines open that starts here tomorrow.

Image advertising, that increasingly popular form of communication through which giant corporations seek to spread warmth in the marketplace, results from company or agency laziness, according to Fred C. Foy, chairman of the Koppers Company.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- The Rev. Paul D. Lindstrom, naional chairman of the Remember the Pueblo Committee, said today that the United States had paid a ransom to North Korea for the release of the Pueblo's crew.
MARTINEZ, Calif., March 26 -- The Republicans for the first time in 15 years have a clear-cut majority in the upper house of California's Legislature.
SHORTLY after Dr. Buris Boshell of Birmingham, Ala., had graduated from Harvard Medical School, a patient gave him a boxer.
NEWARK, March 26 -- Robert B. Meyner, the New Jersey Democrat who served two terms as Governor from 1954 to 1962, announced here today that he was a candidate for his party's nomination for Governor.

" THE women are married, their children are grown, they have money and enjoy living. It doesn't matter where they live, Sioux City, Iowa, or Houston, Texas. They're well-traveled and they know beautiful clothes."

In the ever-escalating advertising air war for the flying dollar, United is answering the barrage of Americanism from American and the planned flak of happiness from Trans World Airlines by adding Stage 3 to its "Fly the Friendly Skies" campaign.
PHILADELPHIA, March 26 -- The Boston Celtics, the defending champions of the National Basketball Association, were alive and playing well tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- A leading House Republican vigorously opposed today a reported plan under which South Africa would sell half her newly mined gold to the free gold market and the rest to monetary authorities.

The Crane Company, a leading manufacturer of valves, pumps and plumbing equipment, announced yesterday that its directors had authorized an exchange offer for the common stock of the CF Steel Corporation.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 26 -- The Pathet Lao has begun to circulate its own currency, bearing illustrations of Pathet Lao soldiers and patriotic inscriptions, diplomatic sources said here today.

The City Planning Commission yesterday approved a long-pending project of the Lindsay administration -- an urban renewal plan for about 1,080 acres of the generally undeveloped Annadale-Huguenot area of Staten Island.

CARMEN MURPHY's last business trip to New York coincided with St. Patrick's Day, and, naturally, she wore green. "I'm sort of black Irish," she said with a big smile, that deepened the dimples in her cheeks.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Except for the slower pace of inventory accumulation, the economy appears to have been expanding even more rapidly in the first quarter of this year than it did in the final quarter of 1968, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Rates on nine-month and one-year Treasury bills declined in todays' $1.5-billion auction from last month's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
MOSCOW, March 26 -- Mikhail A. Suslov, the Politburo's leading ideologist, said yesterday that the "cult of Stalin" set back the activity of the Comintern in its final years.
EVERYBODY knows that what really counts in Wall Street is the earnings-per-share a corporation is able to report.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 26 -- Representatives of 44,000 pilots in 54 countries adopted a resolution today intended to deter hijacking on the world's airlines. The resolution threatens boycotts and global strikes.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Ronald L. Ziegler, the Presidential press secretary, said today that active discussions were under way in the Nixon Administration on proposals to raise Social Security benefits.

ALBANY, March 26 -- The Legislature will be asked to consider a series of new revisions to the controversial Taylor Law changes they passed under severe pressure from the Republican leadership earlier in the session.

The aluminum division of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation said yesterday that it would raise prices about 4 per cent on its fabricated aluminum mill products, effective April 1. Should Olin's move take hold in the industry, it would constitute the second increase for aluminum mill products in less than three months.

The American Stock Exchange broke out of its mixed pattern yesterday and registered a modest advance.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen said today that former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey should give President Nixon more than 100 days to attack national problems. He said that Democratic Administrations had not been able to solve them in five years.

BALTIMORE, March 26 -- The New York Knickerbockers have no doubt who will be in the starting line-up for the Baltimore Bullets tomorrow night when the teams open a four-of-seven-game playoff series at the Civic Center.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The sudden dismissal of a top medical consultant for the Head Start program "looks fishy to me," the chairman of the House Committee on Education and Labor declared today.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- Except for two goals by Jean Ratelle, the New York Rangers drifted through a 6-4 loss to the Chicago Black Hawks tonight as Bobby Hull produced his 56th goal of the season, adding to his National Hockey League record, and Ken Wharram contributed three goals.

CARTERET, N. J., March 26 -- On Sunday, March 2, Mrs. Steve Bodak was helping to arrange a parish auction at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church when she was called to the telephone. It was an officer at Fort Bliss, Tex., with the news that her son Private Dennis Bodak, 22 years old, was dead of meningitis.

The New York Times announced yesterday plans for a computerized service that will for the first time permit outsiders, as well as company employes, to have access to materials in the newspaper's information files.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 (AP) -- The Peruvian freighter Yavari sank tonight in rough weather 950 miles southwest of San Francisco.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, March 26 (AP) -- North and South Korean forces clashed in the demilitarized zone today for the first time in six days, and both sides exchanged charges at an Armistice Commission meeting here. No casualties were reported.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 26 (UPI) -- A judge's decision to let a teen-age law-breaker choose between five years in prison and 20 lashes with a belt is being investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

As if threatened cuts in state aid to hospitals did not pose a serious enough danger to New York City's public health, a further threat is raised by two bills now pending in the Legislature. These bills, backed by the Rockefeller administration, would cut state aid to municipal health programs. They would also, in effect, grant the State Health Commissioner a veto over any new city programs.

ALBANY, March 26 -- The Senate passed a bill today that would allow greater flexibility in police assignments in New York City. In the Assembly, the Speaker -- stung by reports that he was holding the bill back to bargain for Democratic votes on the budget -- ordered the measure out of committee.

State Senator Harrison J. Goldin, Democrat-Liberal of the Bronx, yesterday announced his candidacy for City Controller. He offered to bring "imagination and energy" to a job that he said served "too often as a convenient dumping ground."

The Federal Communications Commission has asked the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to give educational television stations 48 hours notice before pre-empting airtime for commercial programing.

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that its member organizations had reported a decline of $190-million in stock margin debt during February. The month-end total was $5.68-billion, the lowest since August, 1967.

ROME, March 26 -- Pope Paul VI announced today the establishment of a special $1-million fund to aid development in Latin America and said he hoped his action would encourage others to make greater sacrifices for social progress in underdeveloped areas.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 26 -- The new military regime in Pakistan promised today to make way for a constitutional government chosen on the basis of universal suffrage. But it set no deadline for its own departure.

ROME, March 26 -- The Center-left coalition Government of Premier Mariano Humor won a vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies today over the resignation last week of his Minister of Education and the minor Cabinet reshuffle it brought about.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The opposition to the Administration's antimissile defense took a new tack today by seeking to demonstrate that the United States had so strong an "overkill" capacity that it need not fear the build-up in Soviet missile strength.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Gen. David M. Shoup, former Marine Corps commandant, says "an aggressive military" encouraged the Johnson Administration to wage war in Vietnam in 1964 and abandon long-standing opposition to involvement in an Asian land conflict.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- It is expected here that Mr. Hickel will permit the group headed by the Phillips Petroleum Company to resume offshore oil drilling. The PPhillips lease is on the southeast edge of the newly designated Santa Barbara Ecological Preserve.
