The nation's 14 largest housing producers have criticized local governments and some community-action groups for "impeding progress" toward the construction of sufficient housing for the nation's low-income and moderate-income families.
LISBON, March 26 -- Premier Marcello Caetano shuffled his Cabineet tonight with the apparent aim of providing new solutions to Portugal's economic problems.

NEW ORLEANS, March 26 -- The National Federation of Priests' Councils proposed here today that all 154 dioceses and archdioceses of the Roman Catholic Church in this country prepare an "open accounting" of their financial assets.

The fight between Chris-Craft Industries, Inc., and the Piper Aircraft Corporation continued yesterday as Chris-Craft challenged Piper's announcement earlier this week that the aircraft company had acquired two concerns for 469,200 shares of Piper common stock.
Harlem Hospital's medical board, though reiterating that it could not operate with a curtailed budget, agreed yesterday to hold off on its threat to close the municipal institution.

NASHVILLE, March 26 (UPI) -- In a ruling that a high legal source said could "fit the James Earl Ray case like a glove," the Tennessee Supreme Court held today that a convicted criminal could not invalidate a prison sentence by asserting that he had pleaded guilty because of faulty advice from his lawyer.

College "stage" bands, which carry on the tradition of the big professional jazz bands that all but disappeared 20 years ago, flourish mainly in the Midwest and Southwest. At least, bands from these regions tend to dominate the two major college jazz festivals held each year at the University of Notre Dame and in St. Louis.

Paul Zukofsky, the 25-year-old ivolinist who has been playing a sries of 20th-century music recitals at Town Hall this season, gave the third and last of them last night. Despite his great talent and an avalanche of journalistic attention this month in major publications, the event attracted only a very small audience.

Governor Rockefeller's recommendation that responsibility for most moving traffic infractions be taken out of the courts and transferred to the Motor Vehicle Department merits acceptance by the Legislature. The bill's passage would be a boon not only to motorists but also to the courts, now clogged with more than three million traffic cases a year.

BERNARDO BRAMSON was a chubby boy when Lee Corso spotted him kicking a soccer ball on the University of Maryland practice fields in the spring of 1964. Corso, an assistant football coach, was aware of what Pete Golak was then doing Cornell -- side-saddle kicking a football for many points.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- The United States should put an end to "self-defeating restrictions" on American business ventures abroad, a former Commerce Department official said today.

One of the most popular catch phrases used by many investment advisers in discussing the merits of buying convertible bonds -- securities that can be exchanged within a stated period at a fixed price for stock, generally of the same company -- is that the investor can "have his cake and eat it, too."
The diversion to Cuba of a Delta Air Lines jet brought the number of American airline hijacks thus far this year to fourteen, one more than in all of last year.

The nation's toy industry, which has built up a $3-billion annual volume, depends on imaginative innovation. The leading manufacturers in the industry are constantly looking for new ideas, and those that have come up with something appealing to children, young and old, manage to stay in front.

TAMPA, Fla., March 26 -- Most of spring training is devoted to general conditioning and "finding out," the endless process of evaluating players and making decisions about their deployment. Then the manager's focus starts to shift, gradually, but definitely, to "preparation" -- actually getting his team ready for the first game that will count in the standing.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Walter Reed Army Hospital said today that there had been no "appreciable improvement" in the condition of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower and that his failure to respond to treatment must be considered an unfavorable sign.

The Savings Banks Association of New York State announced yesterday the beginning of a new program, designed to assure that no credit worthy individual would be denied mortgage money in the current tight credit market.
ANGUILLA, March 26 -- Perhaps the most nonchalant man on the island of Anguilla these days is the man most under attack.

Mayor Lindsay made an urgent appeal last night to the State Legislature not to adopt a 1969-70 budget until "every effort" has been made to relieve our cities from the "crippling effects" of projected budget cuts.

The Board of Education voted last night to give a "strong reprimand" to the chairman of the governing board of Harlem's Intermediate School 201 complex for his part in barring teachers from Public School 39 last November.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The nation's television and radio broadcasters ended their annual convention this afternoon with a determined campaign to persuade Congress to curb some policies of the Federal Communications Commission and to express apprehension over political intrusion into news and entertainment programing.

THE Hungarian-Soviet war drama, "The Red and the White," which began a regular run here yesterday (it had a single showing at last year's New York Film Festival), is stark and memorable proof of the callous bestiality of war and the towering talent of Miklos Jancso, its Hungarian writer-director.

The USM Corporation, a Boston-based manufacturer of heavy machinery, reported yesterday that net income for fiscal 1969 rose 24 per cent to $16,735,000, or $3.46 a share, from $12,947,000, or $2.78 a share, in fiscal 1968. Revenue was up 23 per cent to a record $356,872,000, from $289,259,000.
WASHINGTON March 26 -Television:

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Two high officials strongly indicated today that the Nixon Administration would recommend extension of the present law permitting interest rate ceilings to be imposed on savings deposits in banks and thrift institutions.
Volume trading of live beef cattle futures soared to a record level yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as prices declined.
The dilemma of Harlem Hospital is another incident reflecting the distorted value system in America.
NORTHPORT, L. I., March 27 -- Five persons were killed today when their car and a bus collided head-on.
Events in Pakistan provide a classic example of the inability of a military regime to transform itself into a democracy.
Goodbody Co., the brokerage firm, reported yesterday that two of its customers had lost a large number of stock certificates in major industrial corporations, utilities and banks.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- President Nixon appointed today an advisory commission to develop a plan for the eventual elimination of the draft and the creation of an all-volunteer armed force. It is to report in November.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission certified today that the Cuban Government was liable for $108,957,062 because of losses suffered by North American Sugar Industries, Inc.

About 500 students at Queens College staged a sit-in yesterday in the dean's office to support their demands for the reinstatement of three students suspended for taking part in campus demonstrations.

BOSTON, March 27 -- Twenty-three Negro scholars, artists and performers gathered today around a green-felt-covered table in the elegance of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel and founded the Black Academy of Arts and Letters.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the city had asked the Federal Government for $750,000 for a development planning study of the "corridor" through which the route of the proposed Lower Manhattan Expressway would pass.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- President Nixon moved today to pull together the regional operations of five Federal agencies and to eliminate "general inefficiencies across the country" in the administration of important social programs.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 -- To avoid increased Governmental regulation, bankers should mount an extensive public relations campaign to educate consumers about installment credit, Rudolph A. Peterson, president of the Bank of America, said today.

The Roman Catholic Church's film-reviewing body, the Office Catholique International du Cinema, has withdrawn the award it gave at the Venice Film Festival last September to the Italian drama "Teorema."

LONDON, March 27 -- By special request of the Covent Garden management, critics were asked not to review the new ballet for Dame Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev, "Pelleas et Melisande," until after its first public showing tonight.

There is one way -- and possibly only one -- for the United States to settle its dispute with Peru so that the rest of Latin America will not accuse us, rightly or wrongly, of imperialism: Ask the Organization of American States to adjudicate our quarrel.

BOSTON, March 27 -- The line that brought the Rangers into the National Hockey League playoffs -- Jean Ratelle, Rod Gilbert and Vic Hadfield -- spent most of tonight getting off the ice after being tossed down and the Rangers' hope of clinching third place in the East Division must wait for the weekend, if it is to come.

Lana Turner stars, in gowns by Luis Estevez, with George Hamilton, outfitted by all the best tailors in London, Paris and Beverly Hills. Maurice Jarre, the two-time Academy Award winner, is composing the music.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Assistant Attorney General Richard W. McLaren disclosed today that he is about ready to bring an antitrust suit that will challenge the legality of a form of patent licensing -- the assignment grant-back.
CARSON CITY, Nev., March 27 (AP) -- A Federal judge said today that he would grant a stay of execution for Lester Morford if an appeal was filed before 4 P.M. tomorrow.
An organization of 2,600 city policemen yesterday charged the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, of which they are members, with mismanagement of its legal assistance plan.
DETROIT, March 27 -- The General Motors Corporation has recalled none of the school buses and only a fraction of the six million vehicles that, it said recently, have potential safety defects.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that his running mate for City Council President would be Sanford D. Garelik, Chief Inspector of the Police Department.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27 -- The United States today deplored Israel's "flagrant violation" of the Middle East cease-fire through air strikes against Jordan at a moment of "hopeful developments" in diplomatic efforts for a peace settlement.

Fifty handicapped persons, some in wheelchairs, demonstrated in front of Governor Rockefeller's office here yesterday for $2.5-million in extra state funds to maintain training and education programs for the disabled.

TRENTON, March 27 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today that New Jersey was being given "leading consideration" by the Federal Government for the nation's first high-speed ground transportation test center.

Eustace Seligman's March 26 letter urging the United States and Russia to "impose" a Middle East peace, recommends nothing less than a return to all of the conditions that led to the Six-Day War: guarantees by the major powers that cannot be kept, a U.N. peace-keeping force that cannot keep peace and a refusal by the Arab states to recognize Israel's right to exist.

LONDON, March 27 -- The British Petroleum Company, one of the giants of the international oil business, reported today a sharp increase in 1968 net income to a record 101.2-million ($242.9-million) from an abnormally depressed 64.2-million ($154.1-million) in the preceding year.

ROME, March 27 (AP) -- The 49-year-old monsignor who left the household of Pope Paul VI and then disclosed plans to marry says he decided before he met his fiancee that he could no longer remain a priest.
PARIS, March 27 -- Continental monetary authorities have taken exception to American goals to create a relatively large amount of a new international reserve asset in the first year of activation.
FORT LEWIS, Wash., March 27 (Reuters) -- Four California soldiers were convicted today of mutiny for a sitdown Oct. 14 at the Presidio stockade in San Francisco.
The Whitmore case, already the subject of three books and soon to be a motion picture, was back in a courtroom yesterday, nearly five years after it all began.

Never reluctant to defend the indefensible, Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, the Republican leader of the Senate, has now come to the aid of businessmen who practice racial discrimination. Senator Dirksen told Clifford Alexander, chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, that "we are getting over our ears in this field."

Postmaster General Winton M. Blount agreed yesterday to delay construction of a $21.7million post office in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan to allow Congress time to provide relocation assistance for about 300 people.

Interest rates throughout most of the money and capital markets continued to decline yesterday, spurred by hope of peace abroad and stable prices at home. Corporate bond prices rose, with the newly offered Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Company issue that originally yielded 8.42 per cent, highest in a century, climbing sharply.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

WASHINGTON -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada told President Nixon here the other day that the Canadian Government would decide within a week or so whether Canada will remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and this simple declaration of doubt from our closest ally dramatized just how fragile our alliances are.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- George Newcombe, who'll be 90 years old in August, looked at the Victorian furniture his daughters gave the Smithsonian Institution, and shook his head.

ROME, March 27 -- Six leading American Protestants who are to confer with Pope Paul VI tomorrow on ecumenical matters do not plan to discuss with him the question of diplomatic relations between the United States and the Vatican.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 27 -- In highly competitive races that drained the emotions of everyone except the swimmers, Mark Spitz of Indiana beat Hans Fassnacht of Long Beach State twice today and made swimming history.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Nixon Administration has agreed to Government ownership of the financially ailing D. C. Transit System, Inc., Washington's privately owned bus company, if necessary to prevent a breakdown o fpublic transportation in the capital.

MANILA, March 27 (AP) -- The United States Ambassador, G. Mennen Williams, delivered a note today apologizing to the Philippine Health Secretary, Amadeo Cruz, because guards barred him from Clark Air Force base at which he had been invited to speak.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI) -- A former Agriculture Department official urged Congress today to open the public purse as wide as necessary to eliminate hunger and malnutrition among the nation's 10 million underfed.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 28 -- The number of Americans killed in action last week, the fourth week of the current enemy offensive, declined by about a quarter, military spokesmen announced yesterday.
RENO, Nev., March 27 (UPI) -- Jackie Jensen, former major league baseball player and college football all-American, was in serious condition today following a heart attack.
Democratic leaders on Manhattan's West Side yesterday turned over to a representative panel of citizens the final decision on who the new Civil Court Judge for the district should be.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Association of American Railroads reported freight traffic in the week ended March 22 totaled an estimated 14.9 billion ton-miles, 3.5 above the corresponding week of last year. This was the largest ton-mileage reported so far this year.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of John A. Hannah, president of Michigan State University, as administrator of the Agency for International Development, the foreign aid agency.
The Song Cycle Series at Hunter College, one of the season's most distinguished additions to the musical life of New York, ended last night with a recital by Betty Allen in the Hunter Playhouse.

ALBANY, March 27 -- The leaders of the Legislature's Republican majorities reported general agreement today on a reshuffled, slightly trimmed version of Governor Rocke feller's $6.4-billion budget, but a band of holdouts in the Assembly was still standing in the way of passage.

ATLANTA, March 27 (AP) -- Trailing by as many as 13 points in the second quarter, the Atlanta Hawks rallied to take a 3-point half-time lead tonight and went on to beat the San Diego Rockets, 107-98, in the Western Division opener of their National Basketball Association playoff series.
Whatever maladies Arthur Ashe has been saddled with in recent months has obviously not affected his thirst for the professional tennis dollar.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 27 -- With or without all their heavy-hitting regulars, the Yankees continue to win.

The American premieres of Jean Anouilh's two short plays, "Episode in the Life of an Author" and "The Orchestra," both to be staged by Jose Quintero, will take place Sept. 16 at Buffalo's Studio Arena Theater.

LONDON, March 27 -- An unusual mutual fund, investing only in gold bullion, is being promoted by a Canadian-backed mutual fund group operating out of Munich, West Germany. The first public offering of the so-called Midas Gold Fund is set for May 1.

Hamershlag, Borg Co., a brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it had admitted three new general partners. They are Pierre J. LeLandais, director of investment banking and corporate finance; Karl W. Schlubach, research, and Joseph J. Mazzella, member of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. LeLandais also will be president of Hamershlag, Borg Co., Inc., a subsidiary formed recently to conduct an underwriting business.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 27 -- The whitewash brushes were out in Pakistan's largest city today.
LIMA, Peru, March 27 -- The Roman Catholic Archibishopric of Lima announced last night that one of its auxiliary bishops was secretly married in Buenos Aires last month.

The Society of Urban Physicians, which urged its members yesterday to refuse to submit plans for budgetary cuts in municipal hospitals here, is a new organization founded by and for physicians in city hospitals.

MADRID, March 27 -- Wearing two pairs of wool socks, a heavy sweater, a brown duffel coat belonging to her 12-year-old son and carrying a sleeping bag, the Duchess of Medina-Sidonia surrendered to the authorities today to begin a year's sentence in Madrid's provincial prison.

JERSEY CITY, March 27 -- On the theory that a parent's palm applied smartly to an unruly child's bottom is more effective than the courts in curbing juvenile delinquency, some mothers here are cooperating with the police in what has become known as the "Moms Squad."
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 27 -- The United States sent its second Mariner television scout on an accurate course toward Mars today to help determine whether the planet could support life.

The executive board of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union ordered its 30,000-member District 65 affiliate yesterday to pay $66,000 in delinquent per capita dues or face a possible lawsuit.

FINLEYVILLE, Pa., March 27 (AP) -- Three United States Senators, wearing miner's hats and chewing plugs of tobacco, went deep into one of the country's largest coal mines today to study the conditions in which miners work.

Edward A. Merkle told shareholders of the Madison Fund, Inc., yesterday that a decision not to sell several large, profitable holdings late last year had helped cause so far in 1969 "one of the worst performances I can remember in my 12 years as president."
DETROIT, March 27 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs clinched a Stanley Cup playoff berth tonight, defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 4-2, in a National Hockey League contest.

JERSEY CITY, March 27 -- The bodies of two expectant mothers and their four children were found early today among the debris of a three-story frame tenement destroyed by fire. Firemen said the blaze had trapped the two women and the children on the top floor of the building.

BONN, March 27 -- The West German Defense Ministry was stirred today by disclosures that a number of senior staff officers of the federal armed forces would stand as candidates of the right-wing extremist National Democratic party in the parliamentary election Sept. 28.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- An unmanned Soviet spacecraft bound for Mars is believed to have failed shortly after blastoff early today at the central Asian space launching station.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The House voted today to authorize $76-million additional to support increased aircraft operations in Vietnam and provide for repairs and modifications of aircraft being used there.
CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N. J., March 27 -- The father of seven children was sentenced today to die in the electric chair the week of May 18 for the slaying of an elderly Tuckahoe, N. J., couple.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Navy paid three times more to get cannon parts on a rush basis than it was already paying another supplier and still got them late, according to Representative Fred B. Rooney, Democrat of Pennsylvania.
ROME, March 27 -- Pope Paul VI promised today that the Roman Catholic Church would favor continuation of research on nonbelief begun here this week by theologians and sociologists.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27 -- Following are excerpts from the debate on the Middle East today in the Security Council:
The highest-ranking doctors in the 20 municipal hospitals agreed yesterday to disregard orders that they participate in the trimming of city hospital budgets.

NEWMONT MINING has dropped a controversial method of reporting profits that masked setbacks, but it has managed to keep a string of rising earnings intact by a move that has once again brought murmurs of dissent.
The City Center for Music and Drama is making plans to have four new theaters in an elaborate $150-million redevelopment project being worked out for the site of the old Madison Square Garden.

ANGUILLA, March 27 -- Ronald Webster, the leader of the Anguillan independence movement, got a hero's welcome from a small group of his followers today. He returned to this tiny island from a visit to the United Nations, where he said he had gone "to seek justice."
MONTREAL, March 27 -- Canada's first airport for jumbo jets and supersonic planes will be built 25 miles north of Montreal near Ste. Scholastique.

The Justice Department's antitrust division has asked Northwest Industries, Inc., to delay its tender offer for the B. F. Goodrich Company because the proposed move "raises very serious and substantial questions under Section 7 of the Clayton Act."

About 35 men and women sat in at the City Council chamber last night after a hearing by a special Council committee considering legislation to place rent controls on the 400,000 uncontrolled apartments here.

Following, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News, are excerpts from the opening statement by Secretary of State William P. Rogers to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee yesterday, and from his testimony under questioning by Senators J. W. Fulbright, committee chairman; John J. Sparkman, Frank Church, Jacob K. Javits and Clifford P. Case.

FISHERMEN living in Manhattan and surrounding areas often have difficulty finding choice spots in which to pursue their pleasure, and two booklets published by Outdoor Publications, Box 350, Ithaca, N. Y., are designed to solve this problem.

The Southern Railway announced yesterday the election of Ralph F. Leach to the board. Mr. Leach, vice chairman of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, succeeds Harllee Branch Jr., who retired at his own request for personal reasons.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- An official Peruvian commission has valued the expropriated properties of the International Petroleum Company at $71,015,314, a Peruvian Embassy statement said today.
Martin S. Ackerman, who earlier this month resigned as president of the Curtis Publishing Company, submitted his resignation yesterday as a director of that concern.

MIAMI, March 27 -- Dewitt Weaver Jr., a 29-year-old Atlanta golf professional who slams his drives and fairway woods a long way, led the first round of the $200,000 National Airlines open today with a 66, a record for the Country Club of Miami course.

Rey de la Torre's Town Hall recital last night took several steps beyond the classic guitar's standard repertory, and included the first performance of Carlos Chavez's "Three Pieces for Guitar" as well as relatively recent pieces such as Frank Martin's Quatre Pieces Breves" and Julian Orbon's Preludio y Danza.

The Government ordered an increase yesterday in copper setasides from 16 per cent currently to 19 per cent, effective in May. The setaside is the amount that domestic producers must allot to defense industries.
BANGKOK -- The process of American military disengagement from Southeast Asia may take fully as long as the process of American military engagement. An example why is Thailand.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- At least by protocol, Secretary of State William P. Rogers is the No. 1 man in the Nixon Cabinet, yet he waited to be the last to expose his views to public scrutiny and challenge. In waiting, he simply tolerated the whispered questions here about whether he really would become No. 1 in influence and importance.
PRAGUE, March 27 -- The Czechoslovak Central Committee opened the pages of its weekly Politika today to a dismissed Slovak party official for an attack on pro-Moscow conservatives.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Justice Department is looking into the possibility of using the antitrust laws to drive organized crime out of legitimate business. Attorney General John N. Mitchell disclosed today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- The Cincinnati Red Stockings of 1869 formed baseball's first professional team and that makes this a centennial year. As part of the elaborate promotional campaign plans have been drawn up for various polls including one that will produce baseball's "all-time team," the very best at each position.

BALTIMORE, March 27 -- The New York Knickerbockers functioned with concentration, cooperation and driving desire tonight to defeat the Baltimore Bullets, 113-101, in the opening game of their National Basketball Association Eastern Division semi-final round playoff before a disillusioned crowd of 11,941 at the Civic Center.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers assured Congress today that the United States would not increase its existing defense commitments to Spain in negotiating an extension of American military base rights in that country.

The site of the Sherman Square Hotel on Broadway between 70th and 71st Streets, which is being replaced by a 41-story apartment house, has been purchased by the Investors Funding Corporation, which leased it back to the seller, Hyman R. Shapiro, builder of the apartment house.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange moved up again yesterday in moderate trading.

A taxpayers' suit has been filed to force the Lindsay administration to return $23-million in real estate taxes it collected in the last year, which helped keep its current $6.2-billion budget in balance.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI) -- Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird and Representative L. Mendel Rivers, Democrat of South Carolina, clashed today over the defense budget.
The Columbia Broadcasting System plans to allow television critics to publish reviews of programs in advance of their presentation on the screen rather than after the shows have gone off the air.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., March 27 (UPI) -- The historic Mission Inn, where President Nixon was married and where four other American Presidents were guests, has closed because of financial troubles.

The Metropolitan Opera's new production of Verdi's "Il Trovatore," lavishly ugly though it is, has at least one good thing about it: There are plenty of flat surfaces to reflect vocal sound toward the audience.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- The Soviet Union has apparently lifted in recent days its curtailment of criticism of the Nixon Administration as a result of the President's decision to go ahead with a limited antimissile program.

Brazilian-born Juarez De Lima, the fifth-ranking middle-weight in the World Boxing Association ratings, will seek to enhance his title contender's status when he meets Pedro Miranda of San Juan, P. R., tonight in a 10-round fight at the Felt Forum.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The United States suffered the largest export-import deficit on record in February, but a major explanation appeared to be a dock strike, the Commerce Department reported today.

ALBANY, March 27 -- The Democratic minority in the Senate tried and failed today to dislodge three bills from committees for consideration on the floor. Among them was a proposed constitutional amendment that would lower the state's voting age from 21 to 18 years.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States could abandon President Nixon's proposed antiballistic missile system if the Soviet Union indicated, during arms limitation talks, that it would discard its system.

Pierre Duval, a French-Canadian tenor who sang with the New York City Opera four seasons ago, turned up with the company again last night in its fourth performance of "Rigoletto" for the season at the State Theater.
BUFFALO, March 27 (AP) -- The state lifted its moratorium today on $1.8-million worth of State University construction projects in the Buffalo area.

Orlando Cepeda's two-run homer, his second since joining the Braves last week, and two-hit pitching by Cecil Upshaw and Gary Neibauer, a rookie, lifted Atlanta to a 7-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles yesterday.
VIENNA, March 27 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger of West Germany arrived today for a deliberately low-key three-day visit in this capital of neutral Austria.

Writers and editors were advised yesterday to use "the full richness and inventiveness and daring of the American idiom," in the portrayal of current events, but not to exploit bold language solely to create a sense of shock.

In unveiling his plan for a modified ABM missile defense system, President Nixon was at pains to stress his desire to avoid provoking the Russians. He went out of his way to absolve Moscow of any offensive threat. Soviet political and military leaders, the President declared, "have always thought in defensive terms" and their "emphasis is on defense."
LAST fall, Hans Thorner, the head of Magic Mountain, watched a $220,000 snow-making system installed at his Vermont area with misgivings.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 27 -- Phil Rudolph nodded respectfully as he received last minute instructions today at Tinker Field.

NEWARK, March 27 (AP) -- The State Public Utility Commission today found the Rockland Electric Company's 9.2 per cent rate of return more than it was entitled to and ordered the utility to defend its position at a public hearing.
PARIS, March 27 -- North Vietnam and the Vietcong today denounced allied overtures for secret peace talks as deceitful maneuvers, but refrained from outright rejection.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The controversial "city hall" amendment to the antipoverty law of 1967 has had little effect on the operation of local antipoverty agencies, according to a study released today by the Office of Economic Opportunity.

LOOK around you. Consider the wreckage. There are mentholated cigars, hospitals closing, rallies for decency, Buster Mathis, snow in Queens, chocolate matzos, "Che!," Rod McKuen, knees, and the Kuomintang's 10th-national congress to discuss plans for retaking the Chinese mainland. Things always go wrong.
The possibility of a strike at Aqueduct was averted when a tentative contract agreement was reached yesterday by the New York Racing Association and the Independent Association, of Mutuel Employees.

Mutch Haberman Joyce, Inc., has created radio and TV spots for the Abortion Reform Association and is sending them to stations in the state today with the hope they will run them as public service messages.
" THOSE of us who are responsible for the health of the community can no longer sit back and see our patients get second - class treatment."
LONDON, March 27 -- Periodically, the Royal Shakespeare company drops a lightweight commercial comedy into its Aldwych Theater repertory.
